DOC.HEAD: Homeless Union Seizes Homes in Philadelphia
DOC.TEXT: A national union of the homeless said Monday it had seized at least seven vacant, government-owned houses as part of a national protest against housing policies. The National Union of the Homeless, which claims 18,000 homeless and formerly homeless members in 16 cities, said it took five houses in Philadelphia and one each in Alexandria, Va. and Detroit. Police prevented a move to take a house in New York City. The Philadelphia-based union said it also planned takeovers in Minneapolis, Chicago and Washington, D.C. Coordinators of those groups either didn't have information on the activities, or couldn't be contacted Monday night because of disconnected telephones. Anna Kontradas, a senior adviser to Housing and Urban Development secretary Jack Kemp, didn't address the union's actions directly, but said in a statement that HUD's ``immediate goal is to help provide both housing and supportive services to those who are homeless today.'' ``We feel like it's insane to have boarded-up houses when so many people are homeless,'' said Ronald Darnaby of the Philadelphia union, which took over five homes. In New York, about 30 members of the Tent City chapter of the union were thwarted by police in their attempt to take a house, said union member Renaldo Casanova. He said two groups members were arrested. Casanova, 43, defended the group's actions. ``I think it is against the law to let people live in the streets,'' he said. In northern Virginia and in Detroit, groups reportedly occupied a vacant house. No further details were available. A member of the Tucson Union of Homeless in Arizona said his group plans to set up a homeless camp next week in front of a federal building located downtown. The union wants a number of changes in national policies, including HUD allocation of 50,000 homes it owns to the homeless. ``We are sick and tired of empty promises,'' union President Leona Smith said. ``The government is more committed to bailing out mismanaged savings and loans banks than to saving and restoring the lives of people who are homeless, chronically unemployed and who are being pressed into a permanent underclass status,'' she said. The organization also wants half of all community development block grant money earmarked for remodeling or new construction of low-income housing and for more rent subsidies. The coordinator for the homeless for HUD's regional office in Philadelphia, Pat Mulligan, said his agency considered the seizures illegal trespassing, but said officials had not decided how to respond. City officials sent in building inspectors, but no police officers. Police Lt. Ed Kachigian said the city had referred the seizures to HUD and would not act against the homeless unless HUD requested police assistance. Darnaby said the coalition checked with HUD's inventory to identify houses for sale, then discussed the proposed seizures with community leaders and neighborhood clergy. The two-story houses would house two families each. None of the houses had utilities, Darnaby said. Inside one of the houses on Monday morning, protesters and homeless people wearing coats huddled around kerosene heaters and sipped hot drinks while about 20 other members picketed the sidewalks outside. ``We'll stay as long as it takes,'' said Charles Thompson. Across the street at Chew Transmission Center, an employee who would only identify himself as Ed said he had considered buying the house from HUD, and said the coalition should not be allowed to seize the house. `I think they should have to pay for it,'' he said. City Housing Commissioner Ed Schwartz said his department would not try to force the squatters out. Schwartz said he was willing to act as a mediator between Dignity Shelter, which is part of the union, and HUD, a role he played two years ago when the group seized several houses. HUD later sold those houses to Dignity Shelter. Mulligan said the federal agency gives priority to shelter groups when selling houses and offers the groups leases for $1 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Quiet Town Becomes a Front Line in the War on Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: More than a thousand miles from the Mexican border is perhaps the nation's unlikeliest drug battlefield, a small city in a farming valley that is being compared to Miami and New York. Drug dealers riding a sort of underground railroad to wealth have turned Yakima County into the heroin and cocaine trafficking capital of the Pacific Northwest. Traveling on long-established migrant farmworker routes from deep inside Mexico, they have brought death and disrepute. The sound of an AK-47 assault rifle shatters the evening calm one night. On another, a man's arm is chopped off with a machete, apparently the fallout from a soured drug deal. U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents arrest entire families, and police use spotlights to illuminate known drug houses. Once notable mostly for growing many of the nation's apples, Yakima County has become a front line in the nation's war on drugs. ``There is a war between the people of this city and the drug cartels,'' says county commissioner Graham Tollefson. ``This is not a war we are capable of winning ourselves.'' William Bennett, the federal drug czar, visited the city of 50,000 people last October and was astonished, said his spokesman, David Robb. ``Secretary Bennett came away with the feeling that for a community its size, there was clearly something wrong there,'' Robb said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``It definitely jumps off the map.'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., hoping to use Bennett's reaction to gain more DEA agents and federal resources, asked that Yakima County be designated a ``high-intensity drug trafficking area.'' Bennett instead selected New York City, Miami, Los Angeles, Houston and the southwest border region. But in a letter to Adams, his office acknowledged the Yakima area's problem and promised more help. Yakima County has become a warehouse and wholesale distribution point for drugs eventually consumed in other communities, said Robert Dreisbach, head of the DEA's office here. When the DEA opened its full-time office in 1986, agents were amazed by what they found, Dresibach said. ``I never saw anything like it,'' he said. But perhaps they should not have been surprised. While Yakima County is one of the world's premier food producers, supplying the nation with asparagus, apples, mint, pears, fruit juice and hops for beer, the metropolitan area ranked fifth from the bottom in per capita income in 1988 in a U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics study. The county's 186,000 residents easily have the state's highest metropolitan unemployment rate, 14 percent in January. Education levels are low and good-paying jobs are scarce, making drug-dealing an attractive option for those seeking to avoid the fields or the Fruit Row warehouses. The minority population also is high compared to the rest of the state. Law officers say the county's 17 percent Hispanic population provides a perfect cover for drug-dealers from Mexico to move freely in and out of the area. The problem has spread to other counties in central Washington as well. Franklin County, with just 35,000 residents, has the highest per capita felony caseload in the state, and a $350,000 court budget deficit. The county seat of Pasco was the site of a mass murder in 1988 in which five men were shot to death in an auto body shop. The presumed motive was drugs. The presumed killers escaped to Mexico. The city of Wenatchee, 100 miles north, has shown signs of sprouting as a drug trafficking center. Along with the drugs come violence and an overloaded criminal justice system described as near collapse. Drug arrests in Yakima jumped from under 300 in 1984 to more than 700 in 1988. The new county jail is already 30 percent over capacity, holding more than 400 prisoners a day. Law officers time their arrests to days when there is available jail space, Dreisbach said. Prosecutors are bogged down with caseloads triple those in nearby cities. ``We can't even put people in jail,'' said police officer Maria Schade, who for two years has been pursuing street-level dealers in the city's central business district. ``It's got to be a felony or a warrant.'' More troubling, violent crime has become almost commonplace. There were 23 murders in the county last year, following a record 28 the year before. As recently as 1984, only nine murders were recorded. Not coincidentally, requests from county residents for gun permits jumped from 411 in 1986 to 2,256 in 1989, Sheriff Doug Blair said. Police Chief Pleas Green says nearly all the murders are drug-related and believes it's only a matter of time before one of his officers is killed. ``We have stepped up training in officer survival techniques,'' he said. An example of the scope of the area's drug trade was last August's DEA raid that broke up two long-time drug-dealing families in the Yakima Valley and produced 18 arrests in Yakima, Tacoma, Seattle and Portland, Ore. For 15 years, the multi-generation drug families had provided up to 200 kilograms of cocaine a month to the Seattle and Portland areas, Dreisbach said. The operation was not that sophisticated, but provided another example of the drug pipeline police have come to know and fear. ``They get into a car and drive it south,'' Dreisbach said. ``They put drugs in the car and drive it north.''

DOC.HEAD: Violent Youth Gangs Plague Rural South Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Like many residents, auto parts dealer Jose Chavez has developed a fear of teen-agers in his crime-plagued colonia near the South Texas border. His advice for visitors: ``If you stop there at nighttime and you see a bunch of kids, you better not stop.'' They might be Tri-City Bombers, a youth gang claiming Lopezville as its territory. Other gangs roam many of Hidalgo County's rural colonias, the scores of impoverished subdivisions where migrant farm workers live along unpaved streets without adequate water, sewers or drainage. In this farming region separated from the rest of the country by huge ranches, people wonder how they ended up with a social problem considered symptomatic of big-city angst and alienation. How did they get an ``asphalt jungle'' in a place where the streets aren't even paved? Officials say the Lower Rio Grande Valley's gangs remain relatively unsophisticated. Yet, just as in Los Angeles, Chicago and other cities, they steal, fight and attack enemies' windows with rocks and bullets. Sometimes, they kill. In January, a gunfight between what police said were rival gang members left two young men dead in the town of San Juan. It is the despair of poverty, some say, that leads to gang membership, along with a high school dropout rate that hovers around 50 percent. ``Kids are real bored, man,'' said Gabriel Benavides, a 17-year-old still in school who has been named by the Hildago County Sheriff's Department as a Tri-City Bombers leader. The gang, which claims about 200 members, is named for the cities of Pharr, San Juan and Alamo, which share a school district. The spray-painted ``TCB'' initials show up everywhere in Lopezville. ``It's like having an outside family. We're all brothers,'' Benavides said, putting his fist on his heart with the index and pinky fingers extended _ the TCB salute. They don't like to fight, he said, but cautioned: ``I have a tendency to cause pain. If you give me trouble, I have a tendency to cause pain. If you don't mess with me, I won't give you pain.'' TCB member Jorge Alberto Cantu, 20, remains in jail without bond, accused in the shooting deaths of two males who authorities said belonged to a gang called the Spoilers. TCB members confrnted a group of Spoilers outside a San Juan video arcade the night of Jan. 5, said Police Chief Rene Lizcano. Parents of the victims, 14-year-old Guadalupe Gonzalez Jr. and his 21-year-old cousin, Miguel Ojeda, said neither belonged to a gang. ``He was going to get married a week later,'' Oralia Ojeda said of her son. Chavez gave up on keeping glass in the windows at his small store, Joe's Auto Parts. Gang members would throw rocks through them in revenge every time he painted over the graffiti they sprayed on his storefront, he said. Now, the windows are covered with heavy sheets of plywood. One night, a brick sailed through the front window of Chavez's house and hit his wife in the head, he said. Another day, someone fired shots into the cab of his truck. ``A lot of these people, they don't say nothing because they're afraid these kids will come and do something at their house at night while they're asleep,'' Chavez said. Two years ago, five area gang members were convicted of beating a 27-year-old man to death with a baseball bat outside a convenience store. They left his 33-year-old brother with permanent brain damage, said Chief Deputy Bob Davis of the sheriff's department. ``Apparently, it wasn't over anything,'' Davis said. ``These guys were on their turf.'' Davis estimates about 25 gangs operate in the county's rural areas, covered by only seven patrol cars. Gang members smashed the windows out of four patrol cars in a melee last Halloween. Some residents say the gangs have been around for nearly a decade but drew authorities' attention only after the cars were attacked. The developments worry J. Michael Olivero, a criminal justice professor at the University of Texas-Pan American in Edinburg. Olivero, who studied gangs in the Chicago area, believes the South Texas groups could become sophisticated crime rings involved in extortion, drug trafficking and other crimes typical of urban gangs. ``They found a kid with an Uzi,'' Olivero said. ``The things aren't cheap.'' Graffiti representing California and Illinois gangs has started appearing on area walls, which Olivero said could result from children of migrant farm families traveling to other states. Community leaders have been meeting recently to address the gang problem, and say parks and jobs would help kids stay out of trouble. School officials, meanwhile, have promised a late afternoon bus route to give students in outlying areas a chance to participate in extracurricular activities. Chris Willingham, head counselor at the local high school, said the transient lives of migrant farm workers keep many children off-balance at school. Many arrive late in the year and leave early, she said. ``We're going to have to address the educational needs of these kids,'' Olivero said, ``and we're going to have to get them water and get them roads and things like that to facilitate a sense of pride. Kids who are integrated with family, church and school don't join gangs.'' But while Lizcano, the San Juan police chief, acknowledges the county has a problem, he rejects the theory that gangs are fostered by poverty and hopelessness. ``I grew up in a colonia myself,'' he said, ``and I'm a chief of police.''

DOC.HEAD: Fiery Debate Sparked by Chicago Mayor's Plan for Third Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Windows of bungalows lining the streets of the city's industrial Southeast Side are starting to sport new signs _ an airplane stamped with a red circle and a slash. The message: No airport. Mayor Richard M. Daley's plan to build a third metropolitan airport near the Indiana line has sparked heated debate among politicians in two states and across the neighborhoods that would be bulldozed and replaced with runways. Daley announced the $4.9 billion project two weeks ago, saying it represents jobs and an investment that would help revitalize the area, site of shuttered steel mills and toxic dumps. But Indiana officials are fighting for a share of any new airport that might be built to alleviate congestion at Chicago's O'Hare International, the world's busiest. A bi-state committee already had been considering four possible sites, none in Chicago. And even in Hegewisch, a mixed industrial and residential neighborhood Daley's Lake Calumet Airport would displace, there is no consensus. ``Why should we have to leave? Why should somebody tell us where to live?'' homeowner Janet Chibicki said last week. But contractor James Amendola, a resident for 26 years, says there are any number of reasons to bulldoze Hegewisch for an airport. ``I think it'd be really good for the area considering we got dumps on one side killing us. The water's contaminated. What have we got left? All's we got left is people got pride,'' he said. On one street, a block of white frame houses dead-ends with a view of a flaming smokestack at the LTV Steel yard. At the William W. Powers State Fish and Wildlife Area, picnic tables overlook oil tanks on the opposite shore of Wolf Lake. Under the mayor's proposal, 5,510 to 9,360 homes would be replaced by runways in Chicago's Hegewisch and South Deering neighborhoods and in suburban Burnham and Calumet City. ``It took everything we have to get this house, now they're going to take it away from us,'' said Mrs. Chibicki. She and her husband, Gary, saved 10 years before buying it for $64,000 in 1988, and she does not think they'll get a fair price for it. ``I don't think anybody, even the powerful mayor of the city of Chicago, has the right to literally destroy neighborhoods, when you have options 20 miles south or east of us,'' said Calumet City Mayor Robert Stefaniak. No option has won federal support and even if Lake Calumet Airport is built, it would not open for about 20 years. The airport would cover 9,400 acres, compared with O'Hare's 7,700 acres. The city intends to pay for it with bonds, federal grants and either a $2.25 tax on travelers at O'Hare and Midway Airport on the Southwest Side, or state and local taxes. The city estimates the airport would create more than 200,000 permanent jobs and each year would inject $13.7 billion into the regional economy. The city has pledged to reimburse homeowners at fair-market value and to pay moving expenses and a relocation allowance, said Marj Halperin, Daley's deputy press secretary. Daley's announcement also spawned a political fight, because it pre-empts the Illinois-Indiana committee that already had chosen four finalist airport sites, two in Indiana and two south of Chicago. Sen. Dan Coats, R-Ind., has enlisted the aid of fellow Republicans, including Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, to fight Daley's plan. ``The mayor's plan is clearly unfair to Indiana, which has played by the rules from the beginning in the selection process for that new airport,'' Coats said. He is trying to block $5.2 million the city requested from the Federal Aviation Administration to produce a master plan for the airport. Rep. Pete Visclosky, D-Ind., has accused U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, former chairman of the Regional Transportation Authority of Northern Illinois, of favoring the city. ``All I've agreed to do is not eliminate any choices,'' Skinner said last week after meeting with Coats and Dole.

DOC.HEAD: California Issuing Formal Quake Advisories in Public Safety Experiment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
Eds: Lucile is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: While jittery Southern Californians sweated out earthquake aftershocks last week, officials took another step in a pioneering effort to issue warnings when they believe stronger jolts might be on the way. ``We're trying to save lives and property with whatever knowledge the scientists can derive from their instruments,'' said Michael Guerin, spokesman for California's Office of Emergency Services. Researchers are still a long way from being able to predict the exact time and place of earthquakes. But they are learning to use statistics on historical quakes to estimate the odds that one jolt might be followed soon by a larger one. There is about a 5 percent chance a moderate quake in California will be followed within three days by an equal or bigger jolt, according to research by U.S. Geological Survey seismologists Paul Reasenberg and Lucile Jones. So, four hours after a moderate quake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale shook Southern California on Wednesday, the Office of Emergency Services issued a formal earthquake advisory to four counties and the news media. It said scientists believed an equally powerful or stronger quake could happen within three days. The advisory _ officials avoided calling it a warning or prediction _ expired Saturday without a bigger quake, although dozens of smaller aftershocks rattled the region, including one that measured 3.4 on the Richter scale Sunday. It was only the fifth time since 1985 the state issued such an advisory. The other advisories, which also expired without a strong quake, were issued in June 1984 after three magnitude-4 quakes in San Diego, in July 1986 after a 6.1 quake in the eastern Sierra Nevada, and in June 1988 and August 1989 following 5.0 and 5.2 temblors on the San Andreas Fault south of San Francisco Bay. The section of the San Andreas involved in the 1988 and 1989 advisories finally ruptured on Oct. 17, 1989, in the 7.1-magnitude earthquake that killed 67 people in the San Francisco Bay region. Officials have said the advisories raised the level of public preparedness for that disaster. Because of differing scientific opinions and a desire to avoid public panic, the latest advisory was even more vaguely worded than previous ones, Guerin said. It neither cited a percentage likelihood for a larger quake, nor said how large that quake might be. ``Right now in this branch of science, vague is state-of-the-art,'' Guerin said. Al Langworthy, a San Bernardino County emergency planner, said the advisory didn't alter local precautions undertaken after the main quake. But Lt. Gary Schoeller of the Los Angeles County sheriff's Emergency Operations Bureau said quake advisories can spur authorities and citizens to take precautions. Examples include ``taking fire trucks outside fire stations (which might collapse and crush them), and alerting our people there may be a need to call them to duty,'' Schoeller said. Guerin said the state hopes citizens heed advisories by avoiding hazardous old buildings during high-risk periods, moving home furnishings that might topple, making sure a wrench is available to shut off gas lines, knowing the whereabouts of relatives, and stockpiling food, water, flashlights, radios and batteries. But the higher the potential for disaster, the greater the caution by officials. A magnitude-6.2 quake near the California-Mexico border on Nov. 23, 1987, spurred an all-night vigil by scientists and officials as aftershocks migrated toward the San Andreas Fault. They debated whether to issue an advisory saying the quake might be a foreshock to the long-feared 8.3-magnitude ``big one'' the government has said might kill 14,000 people. No advisory was issued and the ``big one'' didn't happen, but the 6.2 quake was followed 12 hours later by a magnitude-6.6 jolt on another nearby fault. Ninety-four people were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Soviets in Egypt Downed 21 Israeli Planes in 1970
DOC.TEXT: Soviet gunners disguised as Egyptian soldiers shot down 21 Israeli fighter jets in the summer of 1970 during Egyptian-Israeli combat near the Suez Canal, a Soviet newspaper reports. The Soviets openly assisted the Egyptian army until a 1971 break in Soviet-Egyptian relations, but neither country had formally revealed that the Soviets engaged in direct combat with Israeli warplanes. The Sovietskaya Rossiya newspaper quoted a retired Soviet colonel, Konstantin Popov, as saying divisions of Soviet anti-aircraft gunners were involved in the combat, bringing down Israeli Mirage and Phantom fighters. It said Popov commanded one of the divisions near Suez and recalled the fights with Israeli planes in detail in a full-page article. The officially Soviet press, which has been reporting on previously censored chapters of the Soviet military's past, carried a similar revelation last year about the combat role of Soviet ``advisers'' in the Vietnam War. Popov described how Soviet soldiers in civilian dress were smuggled on a merchant ship from the Black Sea into the Mediterranean, past corrupt Turkish guards, and then transported to Egypt. On June 30, 1970, a Soviet division brought down its first Phantom, Popov was quoted as saying. On July 18, eight Soviet troops were killed when they were hit by Israeli planes. ``In all, during the military activity of the Soviet pilots and gunners, 21 Israeli planes were brought down,'' Sovietskaya Rossiya said. Popov credited the Soviet gunners with stopping Israeli air attacks on Egypt. They ``forced the Israelis to understand that Soviet gunners would not allow them to act freely in the skies over Egypt and heighten aggression,'' the article said. Popov was unimpressed, however, by the reward he said the government of Egypt gave the Soviet troops on their departure: some hastily stamped aluminum medals.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Takes a Bow, but New Civilian Leaders Expect Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Augusto Pinochet is taking his final bows, declaring democracy restored after a coup and more than 16 years in power, but the civilians who will follow him say the job has just begun. Pinochet says he is leaving a thriving, orderly nation to President-elect Patricio Aylwin, who takes office March 11. ``We promised to restore democracy and we have done it,'' Pinochet said recently on a farewell tour of this narrow, 3,000-mile-long nation on South America's west coast. ``We gave it the indispensable stability required for living in peace, freedom and solidarity.'' His critics don't see it that way. ``The transition to democracy will be very, very hard, but the alternative to tackling the difficulties is remaining under a dictatorship,'' said Jorge Arrate, head of the Socialist Party. His party is prominent in Aylwin's center-left coalition. Arrate and others in the alliance say they are inheriting a powder keg of social problems long ignored or suppressed by Pinochet's military government. They say the new administration will be hard-pressed by the need for more social services, wage demands from labor and the desire for justice in cases of human rights abuses. Pinochet, 74, insists on retaining command of the 60,000-man army for up to eight more years, as permitted by the 1980 constitution his government wrote. He also hints at an eventual return to power and has not ruled out running in the 1994 election. At public gatherings in the waning days of his presidency, supporters can be heard shouting ``You'll be back soon!'' or ``Until 1994!'' The general held a referendum in 1988, trying to get approval for an eight-year extension of his presidency, but the voters said no. That forced him to call an election, and Aylwin, a 71-year-old centrist Christian Democrat, got 55 percent of the vote. Small but enthusiastic crowds have turned out for Pinochet's farewell tour, which uses the slogan ``Mission accomplished.'' Pinochet proudly tells them that Chile enjoys one of Latin America's healthiest economies, one of its lowest inflation rates _ about 20 percent a year _ and a gross national product that has grown steadily for six years. He says the political and social disorder that was rampant when he overthrew the elected government of President Salvador Allende, an avowed Marxist, in September 1973 has been replaced by an orderly society. The 1980 constitution provides an institutional bulwark against chaos or a Communist threat, according to Pinochet. Critics, however, consider the claims unfounded and the tour a disgrace. ``This idea that we have to express our gratitude, it's absurd,'' Arrate said. ``He's the only Chilean president ever to stage a farewell carnival.'' Arrate said Pinochet's claim to have laid the institutional groundwork for democracy was contradicted by last-minute laws that cut Aylwin's authority and gave armed forces unprecedented autonomy, among other changes. The new government plans to modify many of the laws, but ``the problem is you lose time in undoing those things,'' said Ricardo Ffrench-Davis, an economist with Aylwin's Christian Democratic Party. He said Pinochet's pride in the economic growth of the last six years ``is arbitrary, like so many arbitrary things that have occurred under this government.'' Pinochet also must take responsibility for ``the worst recession in Latin America'' in the early 1980s, when production in Chile fell by more than 13 percent and unemployment soared to 20 percent or more, Ffrench-Davis said. Improvement since then has represented recovery, with very little growth, the economist said, and poor people have not had a proper share in it. ``If you take the top 20 percent of the population and the bottom 20 percent, the gap has been growing all these years,'' he said. Ffrench-Davis said there is a desperate need for better public education and health services, but he and other economists in Aylwin's camp praise the existing free-market, export-oriented economic program and do not plan major changes. To distribute Chile's wealth, ``the economy must grow, and for the economy to grow, you must have stability,'' he said. Most unions were suppressed under Pinochet and Aylwin also expects a chorus of demands for higher wages, but Arrate said workers and the poor must not expect too much. ``We can't correct from one day to the next all the inequities that have accumulated during 16 years,'' he said. ``All we can do is give signs that the government has changed its tendency.'' Democracy is expected to bring a cry for justice in hundreds of pending cases of alleged human rights violations by security forces. At least 700 people disappeared after the coup and thousands were jailed and tortured. Demands by rights groups for swift and severe punishment probably will not be met. Aylwin has stressed the need for national reconciliation and said justice must be tempered by a spirit of pardon.

DOC.HEAD: University President Believed Among Americans Dead
DOC.TEXT: A former president of Brandeis Univesity and his wife are suspected to be among the Americans killed in last week's fire at a luxury hotel, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said Sunday. The spokeswoman said the bodies of Marver Bernstein and his wife were believed to be in the Cairo morgue but she could not confirm the deaths until a medical report was received. So far, she said, they are listed as unaccounted for. Dr. Kamal el-Saadani of Cairo's central morgue said Friday that a man with a similar name was among the dead and that the body of an unidentified woman was thought to be that of his wife. If confirmed, the deaths would bring to four the number of Americans killed in the hotel fire Thursday at the Heliopolis Sheraton, in which 17 people died. According to The Washington Post, Bernstein, 71, was dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University before serving as president of Brandeis in Waltham, Mass., from 1972 to 1983. He then joined the faculty of the Georgetown School of Foreign Service, where he taught both politics and philosophy and coordinated the school's American courses program. After his retirement from Georgetown last year, he remained as a lecturer. Bernstein, born in Mankato, Minn., and Sheva Rosenthal, a native of St. Paul, Minn., married in 1943, the paper said. Also Sunday, police said all Cairo hotels will be checked for adequate firefighting equipment. Maj. Gen. Fahr el-Din Khaled, head of the tourist police, said a police committee would check all hotels whether or not they have canvas tents similar to the one at the Sheraton where the fire started. ``This committee will prepare a comprehensive report which will be presented to the tourism minister to take suitable procedures so that such accidents do not happen in Egypt again,'' Khaled said, according to the official Middle East News Agency. Sheraton officials have insisted that a fire alarm was sounded when the fire spread from its garden tent restaurant to the hotel building itself early Thursday. They said hotel workers tried to put out the blaze with extinguishers, but strong winds caused it to spread so quickly it became uncontrollable. Survivors said there was no fire alarm or sprinkler system. Egyptian officials have said the canvas tents popular at most luxury hotels in Egypt are illegal because they are fire hazards. But spokesmen for four major hotels in Cairo contacted by The Associated Press said their tents had adequate safety precautions and there was no plan to dismantle them. It was not immediately clear if officials would ban the tents, which usually house restaurants or nightclubs. Tourism is one of Egypt's main sources of foreign currency. In 1989, 2.4 million tourists visited Egypt, bringing $2.3 billion into the country, according to official figures.

DOC.HEAD: Educators, Politicians on the `Restructuring' Bandwagon
DOC.TEXT: The huge blue-and-white banner behind the president of the National Education Association declared: ``No More Reports, No More Speeches. We Want Action.'' That backdrop signaled the group's intention to press for innovations it says are needed in the nation's schools. ``Over the past five years, we at NEA have launched program after program at the cutting edge of the movement to restructure America's schools,'' said Keith Geiger, NEA president. ``We have helped launch educational improvement projects at the school, district and state level in almost every one of our states _ more than 600 projects and programs.'' Geiger's speech, delivered at the National Press Club, was hardly unusual for a labor leader trying to boost the standing of his membership. But it also illustrated the eagerness with which the NEA _ along with hundreds of other education leaders and politicians _ has endorsed the notion of ``restructuring'' the nation's schools. The idea has gained attention and momentum as President Bush and the nation's governors set and promote education goals. Geiger's speech was timed to coincide with the winter meeting of the National Governors Association this past week. The session focused on completing six national goals and agreeing on the restructuring needed to achieve them. ``These goals are ambitious, yet they can and must be achieved,'' said the NGA document. ``However, they cannot be achieved by our education system as it is presently constituted. Substantial, even radical changes will have to be made.'' The NGA defined restructuring as changing what is taught and how it is taught, to get away from an emphasis on low-level basics and instead make sure that students are involved in challenging learning activities. The American Association of School Administrators said restructuring might include changes in the curriculum; variations in federal-state-local relationships; reform in the way teachers are prepared and paid; dealing more effectively with at-risk students, or simply fostering changes in the way people think. Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington told reporters at the NGA meeting, ``All governors made a commitment to lead restructuring efforts in their states.'' For example, Maine Gov. John McKernan Jr. pointed to a rural middle school which has been divided into teams of teachers and students who spend two years together. The teams have their own budgets and the flexibility to set their own schedules and goals within broad school guidelines. Officials said discipline problems are down and student involvement in learning is up. ``It takes educators a while to learn that they can go beyond existing boundaries,'' said McKernan. ``The cumulative effect of many regulations built up over the years has been to create an ingrained way of thinking and operating.'' Gov. Steve Cowper of Alaska told how students from Eskimo villages are invited to study at an open-enrollment high school in Sitka. The curriculum focuses on Pacific basin trade opportunities and includes instruction in Chinese, Japanese and Russian. South Carolina Gov. Carroll Campbell said 328 companies in his state have been encouraged to open classrooms at plant sites. He said workers can take remedial education courses or upgrade their skills. The program uses federal-state job training funds, he said. Other examples given were of Vermont Gov. Madeleine Kunin's focus on services to at-risk 3- and 4-year-olds to ensure they enter school prepared for learning, and Connecticut Gov. William O'Neill's investment of state aid to cities and towns and a boost of teachers' salaries to the second highest in the nation. Students at the Lassiter Middle School in Louisville, Ky., who turn in unsatisfactory work do not get a failing grade. Instead, the teachers work with them until the students' work is up to standard. ``The goals of these projects are almost identical to the national goals,'' said Geiger. To share information on the projects, the NEA created a network called the National Center for Innovation in Education. Geiger said the center has the capacity to involve all of NEA's 2 million members, ``working in schools in every community in America.'' Two years ago, the American Federation of Teachers began a Center for Restructuring to serve as a clearinghouse and to develop a network among school districts and local unions. One of the AFT projects is a joint venture with Apple Computer to create a multimedia resource that teachers can use to learn about projects in other areas. ``Restructured schools need not start from scratch, and they need not operate by trial and error,'' said an AFT brochure.

DOC.HEAD: Moffett Starts Long Road Back From Political Graveyard
LaserPhoto HF1
DOC.TEXT: From a small, ground floor office in a Republican stronghold, one of the leaders of the post-Watergate Democratic surge is plotting his congressional comeback after eight years in political exile. Toby Moffett came to Washington in 1974 as one of the ``Watergate babies,'' reform-minded Democrats bent on cleaning up the tarnished image of American politics. Twice a loser in bids for statewide office in Connecticut, Moffett has decided the House is what he enjoys after all. ``I think it's an important time to go back to Washington,'' he said. Moffett gave up his House seat in 1982 to wage an unsuccessful challenge to then-GOP Sen. Lowell Weicker. After another disappointing showing in 1986 when he failed to get on the Democratic primary ballot for governor, Moffett spent three unsatisfying years as a television anchor. ``I was really looking to do something more challenging,'' Moffett said. ``It's really a process of trying to understand what you do best and what you enjoy doing best.'' The 45-year-old father of five recently moved to Newton in Connecticut's fifth district to run for a seat being vacated by U.S. Rep. John Rowland, a Republican candidate for governor. ``Let's be honest,'' Moffett said. ``Congressional seats don't open up very often and this seat opened up in an area that I feel very comfortable with.'' And as he plots his comeback, Moffett is tailoring his statements and positions to an audience of rock-ribbed Republicans and blue-collar Democrats. In January, he proposed allowing the president to order the assassination of foreign leaders who commit criminal acts and threaten U.S. interests. He says he could accept a ``fair'' version of a capital gains tax cut and even says there may be enough room in the federal budget to pass a tax break for the middle class. His comments on federal programs do nothing to support the label of big-spending liberal that one GOP opponent has tried to attach to Moffett. ``We're not going to have for the foreseeable future a lot of money to play with to do great new things,'' Moffett said. ``We have to focus.'' Moffett brings to the race the 90 percent name recognition of his four terms in Congress and three years as a television anchor in Hartford. In Washington, he has the backing of some of his former colleagues, including House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt and other leaders who have promised him first crack at prestigious committee assignments. But Moffett would be the first to admit that his political comeback is anything but a foregone conclusion. He faces a Democratic opponent, Shelton Mayor Michael Pacowta, who commands strong support in the party apparatus. Five Republicans are vying for the nomination including one candidate, James McLaughlin, who recently referred to Moffett as a ``free-wheeling, nutty, cocky big-spending liberal of the 1970s.'' And Moffett will be running with the ``carpetbagger'' label in the state's most conservative district at a time when Rowland, highly popular locally, may be the top Republican on the statewide ballot. And although Moffett was successful as a congressional candidate, he is 0 for 2 in his most recent political battles. ``Clearly three strikes and you're out in this business. It's a lot like baseball. And he's got two strikes,'' said Dick Foley, head of the Connecticut Republican Party. ``He's out of step with Connecticut and out of step with America and that means you're way out of step with the fifth district.'' Moffett came to Congress at age 29 with a background of grassroots, citizen advocacy and motto of ``making old laws work.'' In 1979, he became the youngest subcommittee chairman in House history by taking over an energy and environment panel. Moffett investigated top Reagan administration officials James Watt, the Interior secretary, and Anne Gorsuch Burford, head of the Environmental Protection Agency; worked on acid rain legislation and new formulas for Medicaid reimbursements, and improved evacuation plans for nuclear plants. Political scientist William Schneider, who has written extensively on the class of '74, disagrees with those who say Moffett won't survive in his new, more conservative district. ``The class of '74 Democrats were unique in that they learned how to survive in Republican districts,'' Schneider said. The group included onetime presidential candidates Gary Hart, Michael Dukakis and Jerry Brown, all politicians who, in various offices, were able to set themselves apart from traditional, big-spending Democrats, Schneider said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Voter Apathy on Congressional Pay Raises
DOC.TEXT: The House of Representatives' legislative agenda is so light you could hear a bill drop. But you don't hear second thoughts about the record pay raise the lawmakers gave themselves last fall. The plan to boost House salaries by one-third by 1991 was so sensitive that only extraordinary cooperation by House Republicans and Democrats and President Bush made passage possible. The two parties even agreed to punish their own candidates if they raise the issue in this year's House elections. Now, eight months before election day, the deal is holding. House salaries have quietly risen from $89,500 to $96,600. The foremost question in the Capitol is whether the Senate, which took a similar ``cost of living'' raise this year, will join the House's decision to take a hefty 25 percent pay installment next January. If senators look toward the House to judge the political winds, they'll find comforting, balmy breezes. Both Democratic and Republican leadership offices say constituent mail on the issue has slowed to a trickle. So far, no one has introduced legislation to repeal the House raise. Last fall, 174 members of the 435-member House voted against it. But even in that group, the pay plan may be settling in comfortably. Roll Call, Capitol Hill's local newspaper, found 65 of those who voted against the pay raise now say they'll keep the dough. Only 15 said they would give it all back to the Treasury. The bulk of the others either were undecided or didn't respond. Rep. Dick Armey, R-Texas, voted against the pay raise. But having lost that battle, he has no doubt he should keep the money. ``He's obviously doing a better job than 99 percent of the guys up here,'' says his spokesman, Ed Gillespie. ``He votes against a lot of federal programs as well, but once they are funded he wants to make sure his constituents get a fair share. It doesn't make sense to do a better job than your colleagues and get paid less, and his constituents would agree.'' Some who voted against the raise decline to return the money to the Treasury but instead promise to turn the money over to charity. They can score political points both for turning down the raise and as philanthropists. For example, Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., is turning down this year's pay raise as he did the previous boost. He's putting the money into a scholarship fund he set up in his congressional district to provide stipends to deserving students. The pay raise was such a big issue with the public in early 1989 that it helped topple former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas. Is it possible that voters have slipped into apathy? Marshall Taylor of the National Taxpayers' Union says the public memory isn't as short as the politicians might like and his group doesn't consider nex January's pay hike ``a fait accompli.'' ``It's kind of seething below the surface with voters,'' he said. ``This ticks a lot of people off,'' he said, and should be a campaign issue even if the two parties try to avoid it. People who vote against the pay and then keep the money are another issue. It's ``kind of hypocritical,'' Taylor said. ``What are you telling the voters ... `I went on record, but, hey, I'll take more?''' While slumbering now, the pay issue is almost certain to heat up as the year goes on. The Senate, unless it takes action, faces the uncomfortable prospect of being paid less than the House. And several senators including Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., are pushing to ban senators from paid speechmaking, as the House will do next year. Such a ban on outside earnings would further increase pressure for a salary hike. The Senate is so politically fearful but so loath to fall behind the House that there's already talk of a pay raise bill in a lame-duck session after the November election. The permutations which arise with the pay raise issue can be baffling. In Roll Call's House survey, several respondents said they would keep the 25 percent pay raise in 1991 only if they were re-elected. So if they lose, they'll give it back?

DOC.HEAD: Bush Polishes Up His One-Liners
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, whose speeches are not renowned for their memorable prose, is trying out warmup material in the Johnny Carson style of news-oriented opening monologues. On his just-finished trip to California, the president unveiled some topical one-liners that registered stronger on the laugh meter than the ripple of twittering one expects at such political functions. Bush got things off to a rolling start at a New York fundraiser for congressional candidate Susan Molinari when he mentioned the headline-grabber of the day. ``Here I am in the middle of the battle right here in New York, where one of the great contests of 1990 will take place. A lot at stake _ there's been a lot of money spent on both sides, a lot of press attention.'' Bush paused. ``But I'm not here to talk about the Trumps.'' The next day, prolonged chuckling swept a ballroom breakfast of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in Los Angeles when Bush said: ``Being president does have its advantages ... I have a TV set there in the White House with five screens, one big one in the middle, four small ones around it, all of them on at once. Now I don't have to miss the nightly news while I watch `Wheel of Fortune.''' He told the TV industry audience he had six education goals for the country to achieve by the year 2000. ``And this morning I want to add a seventh goal _ by the year 2000, all Americans must be able to set the clocks on their VCRs.'' Bush couldn't resist a couple of jabs at his old nemesis, Daniel Ortega, the leftist president of Nicaragua who was voted out of office Feb. 25 in an upset by the U.S.-backed candidate, Violeta Chamorro. He said Molinari's father, Rep. Guy Molinari, was one of his oldest allies, even when no one gave Bush much of a chance to win the presidency. Back then, ``the pollsters had it figured out about the way they figured out Nicaragua,'' he said. At a San Francisco fundraiser for Sen. Pete Wilson, Bush predicted Wilson would be California's next governor. But, he warned, ``Just don't use the same pollster Ortega did.'' Other snippets from the presidential joke file during his California trip: ``Something that really impresses me about California is the West Coast's will to survive even triumph in adversity. New ways to cope spring up, no matter what kind of disaster strikes. Somebody told me there's even a new support group in Malibu _ called Parents Without Perrier.'' Georgia Frontiere, owner of the Los Angeles Rams football team, ``has built one of the toughest teams in pro football. Who says there's no role for women in combat?''

DOC.HEAD: Librarians Say the Government Hinders Access to its Own Words
DOC.TEXT: Librarians are asking Congress to guarantee public access to information generated by the nation's largest compiler of facts _ the government itself. The American Library Association says the Bush administration so far hasn't lived up to a promise to reverse Reagan administration policies which curtailed how much information the government gathers and restricted its distribution. Specifically, the 50,000-member association is concerned that making information available through electronic means, and not on paper, could wind up limiting access or costing the user for what he now gets free. And the librarians worry about the practice of letting private enterprise assume the responsibility of disseminating government information in hopes of turning a profit. ``A system of information `haves' and `have-nots' could be created: big business customers who can afford to buy, while students, individuals, libraries and others cannot,'' ALA President Patricia Wilson Berger testified last month before the Senate Government Affairs Committee. The committee is considering legislation re-examining the government's information distribution policies. The association fears that the proposed bill could require libraries to pay for information they now get free from the government. It would permit agencies to require libraries to share distribution costs of electronically relayed information. ``The taxpayer already has paid to gather and generate and maintain this information, and shouldn't be asked to pay again to get access to it,'' said Eileen Cooke, the ALA's Washington representative. Ms. Berger said she welcomes new technologies which could enhance access to information, but added, ``they are equally capable of erecting artificial barriers to citizens' rights to know.'' She said the problem arises when libraries lack equipment, software, indexes, finding aids, trained staff and expertise in the use of data bases. ``Since the earliest days of the republic,'' Ms. Berger testified, ``the federal government has provided ways to inform the public of its activities and to collect information essential to its operations. Today it is the largest collector and publisher of information in the United States.'' But Reagan administration guidelines adopted in 1985 encouraged the distribution of government information through private enterprise. The guidelines also pared the government's publication lists. ``Thousands of publications were scrapped, data collection programs were scaled back, libraries of many federal agencies were turned over to private management companies and access to the documents of regulatory agencies was made far more difficult,'' the ALA said. ``Under the Bush administration, the OMB has promised to revise these information policies,'' the association said. ``So far, however, no concrete action has resulted.'' A law passed in 1858 requires the government to make its publications available to 1,346 ``depository libraries'' around the country. In addition, 51 regional depositories are required to get and keep every publication issued by the Government Printing Office. Last year, the GPO distributed 27 million copies of 68,000 different publications to the depository libraries. As an example of the problem, the ALA cites an electronic data base operated by the Agriculture Department to furnish commodity, statistical, economic and other agricultural reports. Until 1985, the department released the information through a University of Nebraska computer system. Then, under new OMB guidelines, the government signed an exclusive contract giving the information to Martin Marietta Data Systems, which sells access to it. According to the ALA, information once distributed free or at nominal costs through the University of Nebraska to depository libraries now costs $45 an hour from Martin Marietta or as much as $96 an hour from clients which get the information from Martin Marietta and redistribute it.

DOC.HEAD: Faded Elegance, Proletarian Shabbiness Mingle in Cafe Life
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A passing generation still talks about the golden times in Prague when headwaiters shaved twice a day, coffee houses resounded with freewheeling debate and the pastries were more delectable than those in Vienna. If you want glimpses of what once was along with the proletarian overlay of recent decades _ and an absence of the West's trendiness _ come some evening to the Cafe Europa. A trio of elderly men plays Hapsburg Empire melodies while a pair of prostitutes eye new arrivals, homosexuals in leather jackets embrace and a scruffy man hops through the room on one leg, clutching his crutches. Paintings of semi-nude goddesses, florid mirrors and cut crystal chandeliers _ hallmarks of the art nouveau style _ adorn the premises. This popular haunt, located in the Grand Hotel Europa, dates back to the turn-of-the-century, when the Czechs were part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the coffee houses of Vienna, Prague and Budapest centers of social and political life. Their heyday continued for 30 years of independence, known nostalgically as the ``Golden Republic'', which many Czechs today hope will serve as a model for the future. ``Prague's coffee houses! Their pale remnants can no longer evoke the cafe life between the two World Wars,'' wrote Czech poet Jaroslav Seifert of this era. ``In the coffee houses we discussed, planned and engaged in passionate polemics, and I never had the feeling of time being wasted.'' There were cafes, wrote the 1984 Nobel Prize winner, frequented by artists; others by high society ``where the headwaiters had themselves shaved twice a day,'' and places which attracted students because they carried current newspapers from all over Europe. These vanished with the advent of Communism rule in 1948. But students and dissidents, like the country's new president Vaclav Havel and author Ludvik Vaculik, continued to gather although talk was more circumspect _ and hushed. In ``A Cup of Coffee with my Interrogator,'' Vaculik wrote that it was suspected some tables in every cafe were bugged by the authorities. ``Do you really think that without coffee houses there would have been no culture? '' Vaculik asks a friend in the book. ``No, of course culture wasn't created there but it was an environment that encouraged it,'' the friend replies. These days cafe talk is once again openly freewheeling and while the snooping devices may have been dismantled, the places themselves have yet to slough off the outer shabbiness and a roughness of manner to which Communist societies everywhere seem prone. The Cafe Slavia, one of the last of the great old coffee houses, still attracts artists from the nearby opera and theater, but filthy rags and cigarette butts lie unswept by slouching waiters. The future of Prague's coffee houses, like many institutions in the dramatically changing society, seems to hang in the balance. Will the country's leaders and leading actresses once again be mercilessly dissected over coffee and cake? Will the onetime sense of stylishness return with an improving economy? Will the coffee houses succumb to upmarket chic, catering more to tourists than local characters? Meanwhile at the Cafe Europa, matrons sip coffee topped with whipped cream for 10 crowns (25 cents) and earnest young men down good Czech white wine for 18 crowns a glass. The three gray-haired, bespectacled men could stand a neater fit to their suits and better tuning of their instruments. During a break, a West German businessman buys the trio beers and in a booming voice offers a lecture about all the changes they are to expect when capitalistic ways take hold. They nod politely, go back to violin, viola and piano and after their Strauss and Lehar staples, venture into Broadway tunes and ``As Time Goes By.''

DOC.HEAD: Contras Say They Are Taking Steps Toward Demobilization
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 5th pvs, `A coalition...' to UPDATE with Ortega response; pickup 6th pvs, `The archbishop...'
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan rebels said Sunday they have taken steps toward demobilization and that President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro should replace the Sandinista army with a civilian police force. The U.S.-supported Contra rebels said in a statement that they are in contact with leaders of the United National Opposition coalition, which upset the leftist Sandinistas in Nicaragua's Feb. 25 elections. ``The resistance is conscious that there will be an authentic democratization process in Nicaragua,'' the statement said. ``For that reason, it is willing to change its role of insurgent army to one of civic and political positions.'' ``We have begun to take the necessary steps to demobilize our combatants in search for mechanisms and guarantees appropriate to the current situation in Nicaragua,'' it said. In Managua, Sandinista President Daniel Ortega said he would need more information about which elements in the Contras made the statement but believed ``it would be good news for all the people of Nicaragua.'' ``We need to wait for more information because the communique from Honduras has no signature,'' Ortega told The Associated Press as he was leaving church Sunday night. A commission sent by the incoming government of Nicaragua was to meet with rebel leaders in Tegucigalpa this week to discuss their return home. The archbishop of Managua, Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, said Sunday he would send two representatives to Honduras to sound out the plans of the Contra rebels. ``I'm sending them to make a sounding before I say a word. I want to know what the situation is,'' the cardinal told reporters after saying Mass in his Las Sierritas parish. He said his representatives would go Tuesday or Wednesday. ``I believe that once there is democratization, the armed resistance has no reason for being,'' he said. The rebels said they also had begun to renew contact with the International Support and Verification Commission on guarantees for the safety of those returning to Nicaragua. The commission was created under an Aug. 7, 1989, agreement among five Central American presidents to disband the Contras. The statement, which offered strong support for Mrs. Chamorro, also said her government should replace the Sandinista army with a civilian police force. It did not say when that should happen. The statement from the Nicaraguan Resistance, titled ``Position of the Resistance on the Triumph of Democracy in Nicaragua,'' said the speed of demobilization of the Contras and their families would depend on the guarantees and logistics. About 10,000 rebels and their families have been in camps on the Honduran side of the border since the United States halted military aid in February 1988. The Honduran government has said another 30,000 Nicaraguans sought shelter the past 10 years in border provinces. The rebels said they have ordered ``an absolute halt in hostilities'' and asked the coalition and the verification commission ``to apply a special policy of persuasion'' to the 4,000 rebels estimated to have gone into Nicaragua since September. The rebel statement followed three days of talks between rebel military leaders and Harry Shlaudeman, President Bush's special envoy.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Gretchen Polhemus, Miss USA 1989, has some advice for her newly crowned successor: Get a lawyer. Polhemus said in an interview published Sunday she was required to work 12-hour days during her reign, hadn't received all her prizes and was denied permission to visit her sick grandmother. Miss Polhemus told The Wichita Eagle she considered quitting at one point. The new Miss USA, Carole Gist, 20, of Detroit, was crowned Friday at the pageant finals in Wichita. ``I told her to get an attorney. There's a lot of things in that contract that are unclear,'' Miss Polhemus said. Pageant spokeswoman Sara Meza said pageant officials renegotiated Miss Polhemus' contract to give her more days off after she complained. Ms. Meza said the $1,300 in wardrobe expense money, $3,000 worth of airline tickets and some camera equipment will be delivered in two weeks. She said Miss Polhemus would have gotten the prizes even without the new agreement. Miss Polhemus also said she wasn't allowed to visit her sick grandmother in Arlington, Texas, as preparations were under way for this year's pageant. The grandmother has suffered three strokes, she said. ``I just wanted to tell her I love her,'' Miss Polhemus said. Miss Meza said she didn't realize the grandmother was that sick.

Folk singer Tracy Chapman shuns the fame she quickly found after her 1988 debut album soared to the top of the charts and won her three Grammy awards, including best new artist. ``I guess if there were some way to choose what I wanted or didn't want from what my success has brought me, I would choose not to have the celebrity,'' Chapman said in an interview in the March 12 issue of Time. ``I don't think I'm very good at it.'' Chapman's first album, ``Tracy Chapman,'' hit No. 1 on the Billboard pop charts and sold 10 million copies. Her second album, ``Crossroads,'' has sold 4 million copies since its release five months ago. The albums mix songs protesting poverty and racism with love songs. Chapman, who begins an American tour in May, said she is hurt by criticism of her music by other blacks. ``There are people who have gone so far as to say that I'm not black or not part of the black musical tradition,'' she said. ``I think the reason I don't get played on black radio stations is because I don't fit into their present format. And they're not willing to make a space for me. ``I'm upset by what has been said because it doesn't speak well of black people,'' Chapman said. ``You know, it basically says black people don't respond in a cerebral manner to music, and that's just not true.''

Sammy Davis Jr., fighting cancer and unable to travel to St. Louis for the annual charity telethon that bears his name, called from a hospital to rally fund-raisers. Davis, who has been hospitalized at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center battling a recurrence of throat cancer, promised on Sunday to be back in St. Louis in 1991 to again host the Sammy Davis Jr. Variety Club Telethon. ``You're always there for me and next year I will be in St. Louis with you. Let's do it for the kids,'' Davis said. The telethon, in its seventh year, raises money for more than 150 children's organizations in the St. Louis area. Last year it raised $2.6 million, said Davis' spokeswoman, Susan Reynolds. ``The organizers of the telethon said that after the phone call their operators were just flooded with calls,'' the spokeswoman added. The show, featuring such celebrities as Angie Dickinson, John Forsythe, Lou Rawls and Perry Como, was on the air in the St. Louis area throughout the day. Davis hopes to leave Cedars-Sinai Medical Center soon, although no release date has been set. ``The doctors are encouraged by the progress they are seeing and he continues to get stronger every day,'' Ms. Reynolds said. ``He's been going down the corridors, talking to patients.''

Joan Kroc, owner of the hamburger chain with the golden arches, has sold her four-bedroom, seven-bath home here for $2.25 million. Ms. Kroc, who owns the McDonald's restaurant chain, has built a mansion at nearby Fairbanks Ranch. Her home here was on the market for more than a year before it sold to Mason and Laurel Pinnick. The 6,500-square foot home, which sits on nearly a half-acre, was built in 1981 by actress Raquel Welch's former husband, Jim Welch.

You don't have to be Irish to make the list the top 100 Irish-Americans in Irish America magazine. But it helps. Mayor David Dinkins, who is black, made the list in the magazine's March issue. Dinkins, who took office in January, was named for his work on behalf of illegal Irish immigrants in the city. ``We believe it is important to recognize the work of those who contribute to Irish issues, even those who are not Irish,'' magazine editor Sean O'Murchu said. Others on the list include the late Presidet Kennedy, Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, CBS News President David Burke and talk-show hosts Phil Donahue and Regis Philbin. Filmmaker Michael Moore, authors Tom Clancy, Mary Higgins Clark and speechwriter Peggy Noonan were among those named. Actors on the list included Mel Gibson, Mickey Rourke, Alec Baldwin, Tom Berenger, Matt Dillon, Brian Dennehy and Meg Ryan. And among the politicians listed were Mayors Richard Daley of Chicago and Raymond Flynn of Boston, Speaker of the House Thomas Foley and Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., and Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Calls US China Policy a `Disappointment'
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's China policy is a disappointment because it has failed to nudge Beijing's leaders toward political reform, Vice President Dan Quayle says. Quayle, appearing Sunday on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said he supported ``dialogue and engagement'' between the United States and China, but he conceded the administration's policy has failed to bring about the desired results. Asked if the policy had been a failure, Quayle responded: ``I will not say it's been a failure. It's been a disappointment. It's been a disappointment that China continues to be a holdout of political reform. ``China and the leadership in China refuses to recognize reality, and that's freedom and democracy eventually.'' President Bush came under heavy fire from Congress after revelations that Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, and Lawrence Eagleburger, the deputy secretary of state, traveled to Beijing for meetings shortly after the Chinese cracked down on pro-democracy student activists at Tiananmen Square in early June. Some members of Congress have complained that Bush moved too quickly to establish smooth relations with China, which has done little to loosen restrictions on dissent since the summer. Bush vetoed legislation that would have barred the United States from sending Chinese students back to their country when their visas expire, and the Senate upheld the veto after assurances that an executive order would accomplish the same result. Quayle defended the U.S. policy, saying the administration was not going to ``stick our head in the sand and ... say that China isn't important.'' At the same time, he said some U.S. sanctions on China remain in place. On other issues, Quayle refused to make a firm commitment on what kind of financial package the United States might be willing to offer Nicaragua's newly elected government. ``We will meet the demands of whatever is necessary,'' he said. A group of Nicaraguans representing President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is expected to be in Washington and New York this week asking for $300 million in aid. Quayle also praised Daniel Ortega, Nicaragua's ousted Sandinista leader, as being ``very conciliatory'' after Ortega promised earlier on the same program to turn over Nicaragua's government on April 25 and to respect its constitution. ``I thought it was on target, and perhaps it appears that we do have a new Daniel Ortega that is truly committed to democracy,'' said Quayle. Chamorro defeated Ortega on Feb. 25. Both Chamorro and Ortega have called for the demobilization of the Contra rebels, many of whom remain at camps in Honduras. The Contras have said they would remain intact until after Chamorro's inauguration in April. Quayle said the key to demobilizing the 12,000 Contras is a peaceful transition. While some Contras already have laid down their weapons and returned to Nicaragua, they have done so on a voluntary basis, he said. ``When democracy is there, and it appears that it's going to be, and when the Contras feel secure, they will demobilize,'' he said. ``That's part of the peace plan.''

DOC.HEAD: Tax Ban Plan Stirs Townspeople in Maine Community
LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.TEXT: Town meetings usually come and go without much of a stir in this quiet coastal community. But a plan to abolish local taxes promises to breathe new life into Yankee democracy this year. ``A lot of people are going who wouldn't normally be there,'' said Mark Gross, one of 1,200 residents in the blueberry-canning community. The proposal to scrap property taxes in 1991 and replace them with voluntary contributions and user fees ``has got a lot of people around town a little nervous,'' said Gross, who calls the plan ``a lot of crazy ideas.'' But to Royce Perkins, who is leading the tax-freedom charge from his hand-built log home deep in the woods, scuttling taxes seems as natural as lighting a fire in a wood-burning stove or skinning a weasel. Perkins, 53, a father of five whose 150 acres roll over scenic woodlands along a jagged coastal peninsula, envisions a system in which non-compulsory payments and pay-as-you-go fees finance only those services that people really want and really need. ``One of the great joys of life is to own your own home outright and clear. But when you have taxes against your home, it's like a constant mortgage,'' he said. Property taxation is like ``holding a sword over the land.'' A wildlife biologist and salmon fisherman in Alaska for about 20 years, Perkins returned with his family to his native environs several years ago. Also a former teacher, he educates his children at home. He runs the local landfill and also operates an earth-moving business. His proposal is on the agenda for Tuesday's town meeting because 35 people _ five more than the minimum needed _ signed a petition. The man who oversees Penobscot's $1.2 million budget, selectmen's board Chairman Jim Henry, said he's never heard of such an extreme plan. He said he'll definitely be among those taking a stand against it Tuesday. ``It's too idealistic,'' said Henry. Still, even Henry allows that ``I love the notion'' of having no taxes, and he believes the debate among taxpayers is unquestionably healthy. ``Now people know what services the town provides, what they would lose and what they would have to pay for, whereas before, they paid their taxes and didn't ask questions,'' said Henry. Of the total budget, $1 million goes to the schools, and the rest is divided among services that include road maintenance, a volunteer fire department, landfill, general government expenses and street lights. Perkins sees the string of street lights in the center of Penobscot _ a New England tableau of handsome clapboard homes, church, school and town hall overlooking the bay and river by the same name _ as an example of a municipal service that only the ``handful'' of its users should pay for. As for the big-ticket question of education, Perkins says the state should ultimately pick up the entire tab and issue vouchers so that families can send their children to the schools of their choice. His neighbors remain skeptical. ``A lot of people, if they don't have to pay, they're not going to pay,'' said Gross. ``Are you going to put tolls on our town roads and a toll booth at the town dump?'' asked Kenneth Reynolds, a fish dealer. One of the biggest fears is the prospect of being hit with huge school bills if parents of students are forced to support the schools alone. ``In my occupation I couldn't pay to educate my children _ and many others couldn't,'' said Rev. James Robertson of the South Penobscot Baptist Church. Perkins said he has received letters of support from people in other states, but he acknowledged that support among townspeople appears light at best. But win or lose, he said he is gratified his one-man tax revolt has at least spurred civic activism. ``I've had several say, `I haven't been to a town meeting in 20 years, but I'm going this time,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Closings Law Has Not Created Trauma Business Predicted, Supporters Say
DOC.TEXT: A year-old law requiring 60 days' notice for plant closings and major layoffs is not causing the trauma for business that opponents predicted, according to economists and the law's supporters. But others say its impact on workers is marginal and that struggling companies find compliance difficult and confusing. The measure was passed by Congress in 1988 amid complaints that it was an anti-competitive threat to industry. Then-President Reagan, who allowed it to become law without his signature, called it a ``ticking time bomb'' for companies. ``I don't see any devastating effects on businesses,'' said Gov. Michael Dukakis, the Massachusetts Democrat who pressed the issue during his failed presidential campaign. Dukakis said the advance notice lets state economic development officials try to find new buyers to keep troubled companies in business. Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust Co. of Chicago, said, ``The legislation was not as onerous as had been feared'' and has not harmed the nation's economy. Greg LeRoy of the Midwest Center for Labor Research, a Chicago-based consulting group that studies plant closings, noted there is no move to repeal or change the law. ``They've got no horror stories they can trot out to Congress that would compel anyone to change it. Now maybe we can lay all the malarkey to rest and move on to the more substantive issues, like severance pay, health care and retraining workers,'' LeRoy said. But Renee Reymond, the National Association of Manufacturers' chief lobbyist against the measure, said the law ``has been as complicated and confusing and difficult as we expected.'' The law requires 60 days' advance notice of plant closings by employers with at least 100 fulltime workers if the shutdown will cost 50 or more employees their jobs. Advance notice of a layoff is required if the number of affected workers totals either 500 people or 33 percent of the company's employees, whichever is lower. ``You can't always give notice. It's very hard to predict when things are going to come up. Companies who are struggling to survive don't know what their situation is going to be down the road,'' Ms. Reymond said. ``This law has not been the saving grace for American workers,'' she said. Even supporters acknowledge that although the law provides two months' paid notice, it can't provide long-term help to workers in areas where there are no other jobs available. When a Florsheim shoe factory in Hermann, Mo., closed last year, there was no other major employer in the town of 2,700 able to give the 250 displaced workers a job. The closing was announced before the Feb. 4 effective date of the law, but the company chose to provide advance notice anyway, said Joan Saurez, who heads the Southwest region for the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers' Union. Patricia Gentry, who worked at the Hermann plant for 16 years, said the advance notice ``gives you a chance to prepare yourself, so you can think straight, figure out what to do.'' She found out through employment counseling that she could get government help to return to school, and she now is working toward an accounting degree. Federal figures showed that before the law took effect, 64 percent of the nearly 2 million workers idled annually received no notice, and of those who did, white-collar workers received 14 days' warning and blue-collar workers got seven days' warning. The government has not yet studied the law's effect because states, not the federal government, keep track of the notices. In the past year in one of the largest industrial states, Ohio officials received 160 notices affecting about 23,000 workers. Of those notices, about two-thirds were plant shutdowns and the rest were layoffs. Officials speculate that many of those notices came from small firms that did not have to comply. ``Companies feel an obligation to provide the notice, even if they don't have to,'' said Reuven Carlyle, a spokesman for Ohio Gov. Richard F. Celeste, a Democrat. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton, a Democrat, said the law has created ``a subtle pressure on businesses to help in the transition ... Once you announce it, you don't have time to just cut and run. It's been a net plus.'' Still, others said neither workers or businesses have been affected a great deal. ``We had one side saying they're going to save the world with this and on the other, that it would destroy us. I think it's turned out no one was right,'' said Illinois Gov. James Thompson, a Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Siberian Baritone Makes Stirring Debut
DOC.TEXT: Out of the remote reaches of Siberia, a young singer has leapt onto the international music scene _ a baritone of such promise that at age 27 he seems on the verge of becoming a superstar. His name is Dmitri Hvorostovksy, and at his U.S. debut recital Sunday night, he showed that much of the excitement is justified. Hre is a voice of splendor, supple and powerful at the same time, tinged with a dark, mellow beauty over virtually the entire baritone range. His only discernible weakness is in the very highest register, around G, where he sounds less secure. He also has phenomonenal breath control, giving him the ability to sing long phrases without gulping for air. For his program, Hvorostovksy chose all Russian songs, half Tchaikovsky and half Rachmaninov. No doubt he felt most at home in this repertoire; still, more variety would have been welcome _ too many of the songs were slow, mournful lamentations over hopeless love or worldly misfortune. But there were striking moments and some first-rate interpretations: Tchaikovsky's familiar ``None but the lonely heart,'' was nicely restrained; the same composer's ``Don Juan's Serenade'' had a streak of cruelty as well as bravado. And Rachmaninov's ``Christ is risen!'' seemed deeply felt in its cry of anguish. The real revelation came at the end, when Hvorostovksy performed three operatic arias as encores: one from Rachmaninov's ``Aleppo,'' and one each from Verdi's ``Un ballo in maschera'' and ``Don Carlo.'' Here, the young Siberian's voice rang out with a thrilling, hall-filling grandeur that prompted wild cheering from the capacity audience at Alice Tully Hall. Hvorostovsky, who grew up and studied in the city of Krasnoyarsk, first came to international attention last June when he won the Young Singer of the World competition in Cardiff, Wales. Tapes of the BBC telecast of his performance there have circulated widely _ winning him admiration for both his voice and his matinee idol looks. Before returning to Europe, Hvorostovsky will repeat Sunday's program in Washington on March 10. He has signed a recording contract with Philips and is rapidly getting booked up by orchestras and opera companies. One hopes he won't take things too fast _ 27 is still very young, and his voice surely cannot have reached its full development.
