Most denials occur because analysts rule applicants are economic, rather than political, refugees. The State Department cautioned it is too early to be assured that democracy will stick in Nicaragua, but a spokesman said policy toward asylum will clearly be reviewed. Nat Kingsley of the State Department's Human Rights Bureau emphasized that under U.S. law, each application is treated individually, whether it comes from England or Albania. ``Obviously the conditions within a country play a role, but it is the individual's relations in that country that are the deciding factor,'' he said. Teams of State Department analysts are constantly revising evaluations of many factors in each country, including its human rights record. ``For Nicaragua, it's pretty early to tell how it will affect asylum,'' Kingsley said, noting that the constitutional transition is not scheduled to occur until April 25. Last year Poland and Hungary were in effect dropped from the list of nations that violated human rights _ making political asylum almost impossible. ``A few years ago Solidarity people from Poland were granted asylum almost automatically,'' Austin said. ``Now they're running the government and we no longer accept applications.'' In the week since U.S.-backed Violetta Chamorro beat the Sandinistas' Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua's presidential election, Miami immigration officials noted the decrease in the asylum requests. Dozens of Nicaraguan exiles have either dropped their petitions to stay or have stopped fighting deportation.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Lords Call State of Alert, Renewed Attacks Feared
DOC.TEXT: A week before elections, Colombia's cocaine barons have declared a ``state of alert'' in a message that suggests they intend to end a 6-week-old cease-fire in their war against the government. The announcement Sunday by the Extraditables, the name adopted by the Medellin drug cartel, came a day after President Virgilio Barco announced he will keep extraditing suspected drug traffickers instead of trying them in Colombia as they have requested. The traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire Jan. 17 in an effort to persuade Barco to end extraditions of drug suspects to the United States. The government has not extradited any drug trafficking suspects since Jan 21 and currently holds sixteen. In the previous five months of the drug war, it sent 14 suspects to be tried in the United States. Resumption of the drug lords' assassinations and bombings, which had killed more than 200 people since the war began in August, could disrupt balloting on Sunday for mayors, city councilmen, state assemblies and a new congress. Campaigning already has been plagued by almost daily attacks by leftist guerrillas. The traffickers did not say what they meant by a state of alert, but there was little doubt it was a message that more bloodshed may lie ahead. The traffickers' announcement was published Sunday by the Bogota daily El Tiempo and broadcast by the radio network Caracol. Barco has rejected all appeals by the traffickers that they be given guarantees they would be safe from extradition if they were to surrender. He reiterated his position Saturday night upon return from a state visit to Argentina and Uruguay. In its fight against the drug cartels, which began after the August assassination of a leading presidential candidate, the government has wielded extraditions as its chief weapon. It has also tracked down and killed a top Medellin figure, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, raided drug labs and seized cocaine, weapons and $38 million in cash, gold and platinum hidden at traffickers' ranches. In their announcement Sunday, the traffickers denied any role in the recent murders of members of Colombia's leftist party, the Patriotic Union. Diego Montana, president of the Patriotic Union, has blamed the army and the secret police for killing many of the 72 party members slain this year. In the Caribbean coastal city of Barranquilla, the headquarters of many drug traffickers, election officials said Saturday night that they had discovered that 34,000 voters were paid money for their votes. Some candidates have said traffickers are financing some campaigns, but no names have been mentioned and no one has been arrested. On Sunday, leftist rebels ambushed an army patrol, killing 12 soldiers, the 7th Brigade said in a statement. The ambush by the rebel Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces took place near the town of San Jose de Ocune, about 250 miles east of Bogota, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: Versace Soars to New Hemline Heights
By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: If Gianni Versace was daring last season when he hiked his hemlines 10 inches above the knee, this time he's darn right fresh with skirts so tiny they no longer cover anything. The peek-a-boo effect of the new fall-winter collection presented in Rome on Sunday was no accident. The flamboyant designer, favorite son of the showbiz crowd, presented them in a variety of styles from derriere hugging jersey dresses and skirts, to elaborately embroidered silk cocktail gowns. Also super short was the 1990's Versace version of the loose trapeze dress first launched in the 1960's. Gianni was a bad boy when it came to his evening wear too, slitting the side of a floor length gown straight up the leg. The same gown has a plunging backline which joins the slit at the waist in a single snap. What happens if the snap were to pop is anybody's guess. Apart from a few raised eyebrows, mainly from the staid Milanese crowd on the first day of the four day ready-to-wear collections, the general consensus was that whatever Gianni does he does so well he can get away with it. One of the things Versace does best is jeweled embroidery, which this season he uses heavily to divert attention from the many bare spots in his collection. Thus a tiny A-line silk dress, which is really no more than a slip, becomes a sumptuous cocktail gown when Versace stiches a myriad of shimmering crystals and pearls in the form of a heart down the back or across the front. Bustier tops made up entirely of encrusted jewels give substance to the micro skirt below, while simple silk stretch pants turn into sophisticated evening wear when decorated with paisely or floral prints shaped entirely out of rich sequins. Plumage on hemlines and waistlines are another filler in the collection. To further make up for the skimpy styles underneath, the Versace jacket is loose and full with wide sleeve and generous shawl collar, in bright shades of blue, green, yellow and red. Speaking of red, Versace uses cardinal red heavily in his new winter fashion, throwing down the gauntlet to fellow Italian designer Valentino, who up to now had the monopoly on the rich and elegant shade. The four-day Italian ready to wear shows got off to a fresh start Sunday morning with the Emporio Armani (a Giorgio Armani label aimed at the younger set) fall-winter 1990-1991 collection full of fun ideas for the chilly months ahead. According to Armani, heavy knit sweaters will be worn over jackets next winter, boots will reach the thigh to protect legs bared by melon shaped mini skirts and bermuda shorts, and jump suits will be knitted and worn with a scarf tied around the waist for extra coziness. During the trend-setting Milanese fashion week such top Italian names as Krizia, Ferre, Fendi, Missoni Gennyi and Byblos will present their new winter wears. Most of the shows take place in the fashion pavillion of the modern trade fair on the outskirts of Milan. However some of the big names in Italian style prefer to show in more exclusive surroundings. The five Roman Fendi sisters have rented an elegant palazzo for their much awaited fur show Tuesday night, while Armani, the ``numero uno'' of Italian ready to wear, will close the shows Wednesday night with his label collection presented in the theater of his downtown Milan headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: New Storm Moves into Rockies; Dry Weather Over Much of U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A snow storm was expected to move into the Rockies today, and dry weather was to prevail across much of the nation. Light rain that fell on parts of the central Plains on Sunday was to taper off today, as temperatures cooled in the 40s. Flurries were expected today over the Great Lakes and Upper Ohio Valley in a pattern similar to Sunday, when light snow also fell in northern New England. In most of the the Great Lakes and New England Sunday temperatures dipped to below freezing all day and were expected to stay there today. In the Plains as far north as Nebraska and Iowa on Sunday, temperatures climbed into the 60s and afternoon highs in the 70s warmed Florida, southern Georgia and most of Texas. The Southwest basked in the lower 80s Sunday. A new storm was to spread snow across the Sierra Nevada and upper Rockies into Colorado today and Tuesday. The storm also was to bring rain to western Oregon and northern California, where snow fell in the region's highlands on Sunday. In California, more than a half inch of rain fell Sunday in Marysville and more than a third of an inch fell at Shelter Cove. Skies were fair Sunday from the northern Plains to the southern Atlantic. The nation's high for Sunday was 83 degrees at Buckeye and Gila Bend in Arizona, and Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Government Will Slash Spending, Raise Income, Economy Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: In its latest drastic attempt to end hyperinflation, the government says it will fire and retire civil servants, radically trim bureaucracy and raise taxes and duties on farm products. Economy Minister Antonio Ernan Gonzalez announced the new package in a nationally televised speech Sunday night. He called for public ``support, tolerance and comprehension to prevent bankruptcy from dragging us into anarchy and social chaos.'' Banks and exchange houses were to remain closed today to allow implementation of measures aimed at stabilizing the country's financial system. The government of President Carlos Menem, who took office in July, has been beset by recession, inflation that soared more than 8,100 percent over the last 12 months, the plunging value of the national currency, rising interest rates, labor strife and record unemployment. The package Gonzalez announced was approved during marathon weekend Cabinet sessions. He said the government plans to trim $2 billion from expenses through the retirement and dismissal of government workers and elimination of state bureaucracy. Effective immediately, Gonzalez said, all state workers who have reached retirement age but continue to work will be retired while those who are within two years of retirement will be laid off and paid their salaries until they reach retirement. Vacancies will not be filled. The minister did not say how many state workers would be affected. State employees now total 2.5 million in a total national labor force of 12.5 million. In addition, the minister said, all 56 government secretariats will be eliminated and sub-secretariats will be cut from the current total of 112 to 32, with their duties being taken over by the ministries from which they now depend. Speaking to reporters after the speech, Gonzalez described the elimination of secretariats and sub-secretariats as the ``most drastic'' of the new measures and denied that the retirements constituted ``massive dissmissals.'' The minister also announced intervention in the management of the National Development Bank and the closure, effective today, of the National Mortgage Bank, used principally to finance building of low-income housing. The banks lose tens of millions of dollars a year through bad loans, poor collections and the political decision to finance provincial budgets at the expense of the national government. Steps also will be taken to solve the problems of a few private banks that encounter chronic difficulties, Gonzalez said, without specifying what would be entailed. Other steps included suspension for 60 days of payments to holders of state contracts and continuation of an earlier measure suspending state subsidies for industrial promotion. Gonzalez said the state will raise an additional $600 million in income through a 1.5 percent increase in the tax on capital goods and an average 5 percent boost in duties on agricultural exports. Guillermo Alchouron, president of the Argentine Rural Society, which represents the country's leading producers of beef for export, said the minister's description of the crisis ``was realistic and impressive'' and recommended postponement of sectoral complaints ``no matter how just and reasonable they may be.'' The printing of money to finance the state deficit has been prohibited, Gonzalez said. The minister also announced that all state employees will be paid a minumum monthly salary of $90, beginning April l. Many state employees now earn far less than that amount. The largest teachers' union announced last week it would strike today, the first day of the 1990 school year, if the government did not grant a basic wage of $66 a month. Gonzalez made no mention of expected increases in public utility rates. Fuel prices, however, rose by 124.5 percent on Sunday, following a Saturday night announcement by Energy Secretary Julio Cesar Araoz. Menem has raised public service rates drastically during his eight months in office, and pledged to open up Argentina's state dominated economy by selling public companies, deregulating monopolies, lowering tariff barriers, raising taxes and cutting subsidies.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Steady
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies in European trading this morning but gained against the British pound. Gold prices were steady. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 149.95 yen, up 0.20 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar eased to 149.25 yen. In recent days, the dollar has been at its highest level since closing at 151.30 yen on June 15. It has gained 5.43 yen since Feb. 19. ``The dollar's strength remains unchanged,'' said Norio Takeda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. ``But it doesn't seem like it will rise sharply at this time.'' Dealers said the Bank of Japan sold large amounts of dollars in support of the yen, but the amount was not known. The central bank does not comment on its exchange market activities. Other morning dollar rates compared with late Friday: _ 1.7035 West German marks, down from 1.7200 _ 1.5015 Swiss francs, down from 1.5130 _ 5.7540 French francs, down from 5.8065 _ 1.9275 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9365 _ 1,256.50 Italian lire, down from 1,268.00 _ 1.1915 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1939 The British pound was quoted at $1.6420, down from $1.6515 late Friday. The pound, under pressure from disappointing trade figures and the government's declining position in opinion polls, has retreated steadily from its recent peak of $1.7145 on Feb. 22. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $403.00 per troy ounce this morning, compared to $403.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $403.00, up from $402.50 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $403.44 per troy ounce, up 70 cents from Saturday. Silver was quoted in London at bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, up from Friday's 5.12.

DOC.HEAD: 4,000 Re-enact Civil-Rights `Bloody Sunday,' March to Montgomery
LaserPhoto MY2
DOC.TEXT: Civil-rights leaders assessed their movement's progress as about 4,000 people re-enacted the historic voting-rights march to Montgomery and ``Bloody Sunday'' confrontation with police on a bridge 25 years ago. ``Lord knows we're not where we ought to be, but thank God we're not where we used to be,'' Hosea Williams said Sunday as he crossed Edmund Pettus bridge. ``We've come a long way. But Lord knows we've got a much further way to go,'' Williams said. From that bridge, named for a confederate general, Williams on March 7, 1965, first saw the state and local police who ordered the marchers to disperse, then used billy clubs and tear gas to chase them back across the bridge. The day went down in civil-rights annals as Bloody Sunday. About 300 people marched to a point four miles beyond the bridge and returned to Selma on Sunday night before resuming the 50-mile trek this morning. Marchers plan to cover the distance in several daily segments, arriving in Montgomery March 10 for a rally at the Alabama Capitol. After the 1965 clash and the death a few days later of James Reeb, a white Unitarian minister from Boston who was hit in the head while on a Selma street, President Johnson made passage of the Voting Rights Act a priority. The Selma-to-Montgomery march took place two weeks later. Killed after that march was Viola Liuzzo, a white homemaker from Detroit shot by night-riding Ku Klux Klansmen while she drove demonstrators back to Selma. On Sunday, as marchers reached the midpoint of the bridge, smoke was released simulating tear gas. Marchers retreated, some falling to the ground. Jesse Jackson and Coretta Scott King, widow of slain civil-rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., were among participants Sunday. Also marching were Albert Turner, F.D. Reese and U.S. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., who were among those attacked on Bloody Sunday. ``We shed a little blood here that made a difference. People are now registering to vote,'' Lewis said. Jackson told about 600 people at the First Baptist Church that King did not die and Nelson Mandela did not languish in a South African prison for 27 years for blacks not to exercise their right to vote. He said 35 percent of all eligible black voters are unregistered. ``You cannot walk around here with these unused blessings,'' Jackson said. ``God has given us all these votes. When you drop them they become snakes and go to Washington and bite us.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Hopeful Editorial Not Government Statement
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper said today that a weekend editorial interpreted as a hopeful sign for the release of Western hostages in Lebanon was the personal opinion of the writer and not a government statement. The statement came amid reports from Damascus, Syria, that a senior Iranian envoy met with Syria's foreign minister and discussed efforts to free the hostages. Syria is the power broker in neighboring Lebanon by virtue of its 40,000 troops there. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted the English daily Kayhan International as saying Western media distorted its editorial by reading it as an official hint of contacts between and Iran and Washington over the hostages, who are believed held by pro-Iranian factions. In the Saturday editorial, also excerpted by IRNA, the paper suggested U.S.-Iranian ties might be improved in the ``post-hostage era'' if Washington agrees to release three American Moslems imprisoned in the United States in exchange for two Americans in Iranian jails. But today the government-run paper distanced itself from the statement, said IRNA, monitored in Nicosia. ``Neither the writer of that column nor the author of this present one is a government spokesman or employee,'' IRNA quoted Kayhan as saying. ``No officials of any sort were consulted before putting pen to paper.'' ``What was and is now being expressed are privately held views,'' Kayhan said. Western media reports took the editorial as another in a series of signs from Tehran in recent weeks that a new effort was under way to free the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon. They include eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Most are believed held by Shiite Moslem factions loyal to Iran. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The editorial followed a spate of statements from Iranian newspapers saying the hostages should be released because they are fueling propaganda against Iran. A Syrian source, who refused to be identified further, said a meeting Sunday between Mahmoud Hashemi of Iran and Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria ``appears to be to coordinate efforts between the governments of Syria and Iran to gain the release of all the hostages.'' The source said Hashemi, the brother of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, had arrived from Beirut, where he met with senior Shiite Moslem figures on the hostage issue. Another source said: ``This appears to be a serious effort, the first in some time, to end the hostage ordeal. ... But I don't think we'll see anyone out tomorrow.'' The Iranian paper on Saturday had suggested that two Americans, David Erwin Rabham and Jon Pattis, could be released if Washington freed Dhoruba-al-Mujahid, Elmer ``Geronimo'' Pratt and Khalifa Hammas Abdul Khalis, who it identified as ``political prisoners'' in the United States. Pattis, a 53-year-old engineer, was arrested in June 1986 for allegedly passing Iranian military secrets to the CIA for use by Iraqi bombers in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Businessman Rabham has been in jail for almost 10 years. He was arrested after a phone conversation with former President Jimmy Carter when Iranian militants stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 and held 52 Americans hostage. Of the three Americans mentioned, Khalis was the leader of a Hanafi Moslem group that took over three Washington buildings in 1977, holding several hundred people hostage for several days before surrendering. One person was killed by gunfire from the group. Pratt, the one-time ``defense minister'' of the Black Panthers, is serving a life sentence for a 1972 murder conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Isolate Uzbek City Hit By Rioting, Activist Says
DOC.TEXT: Rioting prompted security forces to seal off a city in Uzbekistan, where about 30 demonstrators were killed when soldiers fired on them, an activist said. Officials reported only the death of one soldier. Yadigar Abidov, spokesman for the Uzbekistan grassroots organization Berlik, said Sunday that soldiers would let no one leave or enter Parkent, about 30 miles from Tashkent, the capital of the republic considered the cultural and geographic heart of traditionally Moslem Central Asia. There were conflicting reports over what sparked the violence. Abidov said the city was blocked off after a regional Communist Party leader was stoned to death Saturday by the protesters, who demanded their own candidate in a local election Sunday. Officials denied it. A newspaper said the clashes broke out after residents demanded the government move out several hundred Meskhetian Turks who had fled ethnic violence in the nearby Uzbek region of Bukinsky. Grigory Kuplin, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry in Moscow, said at least one soldier died in a clash between demonstrators and Interior Ministry troops Saturday. He said he had no information on other dead or wounded and knew nothing of a curfew in Parkent, a city of 200,000. The Uzbekistan Interior Ministry and other official sources contacted in Tashkent refused all comment on the violence. One national newspaper printed a small report Sunday on unrest, but other official media, including the official Tass news agency, provided no information. The republic of Uzbekistan has been the most recent area of the Soviet Union to erupt in violence as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev loosens decades of tight Kremlin control. Twenty-two people were killed in rioting in Dushanbe, the capital of the neighboring Tadzhikistan republic, last month. Tensions persist in the Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, where hundreds have been killed in the past two years. In addition to ethnic tensions, residents of Uzbekistan are frustrated by low wages in the cotton-growing republic, ecological devastation, and poor housing exacerbated by large families. The Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper reported Sunday that the Parkent violence occurred during a meeting of residents demanding the evacuation of Meskhetian Turks. The Turks were forcibly resettled in Uzbekistan from the Caucasus republic of Georgia by Josef Stalin. In June, they were targeted in ethnic violence in the Fergava Valley of eastern Uzbekistan that left about 100 people dead. Abidov said the violence broke out when a crowd of Parkent residents gathered in front of local Communist Party headquarters Saturday to demand registration of their candidate in runoff elections to the Uzbekistan parliament. Uzbekistan held elections of its parliament Feb. 18 and runoffs were held Sunday. Abidov said Parkent residents were angry that Ismail Salimov, a regional Communist Party first secretary, had refused to allow any other candidates on the ballot. At one point, soldiers gave demonstrators three minutes to disperse and when the crowd refused the troops opened fire, Abidov said. In the ensuing pandemonium, some protesters grabbed stones and began to pelt Salimov and another party official who died as a result of their wounds, the activist claimed. His account could not be confirmed. Kuplin said he had no such information, and an official with the local Election Commission in Parkent, who refused to give his name, said Salimov was alive and voted Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Wins, But Many Candidates Headed For Runoffs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with dozens of runoffs expected, including for Politburo member. Pickup 16th graf `In the Slavic...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,6
DOC.TEXT: Communist reformer Boris N. Yeltsin easily won his contest but dozens of other local and regional races were headed for runoffs after old guard Communists in the Slavic heartland faced their first challenges at the polls, early returns indicated today. Sunday's balloting _ the first contested local elections for the Russian, Ukranian and Byelorussian republics, was seen as a key test of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to transform Soviet politics. While the vote was only partially democratic, pro-democracy candidates were expected to unseat many long-entrenched Communists. In the Baltic republic of Lithuania, pro-independence activists said results in runoff elections Sunday assured them of the quorum they need to covene the republic's parliament, where activists are expected to push for creating a mechanism to secede from the Soviet Union. Nearly 150 million voters were registered to choose among more than 11,000 candidates for 1,800 seats in the legislatures of Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia. Thousands of seats in local governing councils were contested. Official results were not expected to be announced until Tuesday, election officials said, but preliminary results showed that runoff elections will have to be held in dozens of districts where none of the candidates won a majority of the votes. The balloting is expected in two weeks. Yeltsin easily won a Russian parliamentary seat with 72 percent of the vote in his home district in the Ural Mountain city of Sverdlovsk, Anatoly Moisyev, a member of the republic's election commission, said today. Yeltsin hopes to be elected president of the Russian republic by legislators. That post is currently held by Politburo member Vitaly Vorotnikov, who also won a seat Sunday with a majority of 71.3 percent. The Russian presidency traditionally merits a seat on the nation's ruling Politburo, and Yeltsin could possibly return to the ruling body from which he was ousted by Gorbachev in February 1988 for criticizing the pace of reform. In the Ukrainian capital of Kiev, preliminary results showed that Communist Party First Secretary Vladimir A. Ivashko, a member of the Politburo seen as a Gorbachev protege, failed to win a majority over 11 opponents and will have to stand again in a runoff election. Although Communist leaders have at Gorbachev's urging endorsed a multiparty system, non-Communist parties are not yet permitted. ``Opposition'' candidates ran Sunday as members of grass-roots citizens' groups or as reformist Communists. ``Our elections involve a new type of people, people who have been given new impetus from perestroika,'' a relaxed, confident Gorbachev said after voting. ``The essence of it is that it is a people's referendum on perestroika.'' ``Perestroika'' is Gorbachev's name for his program of restructuring Soviet politics and the economy so the system is more democratic and the bureaucracy that has strangled the economy is dismantled. In the Slavic republics, reforms _ where they have managed to get started _ have proceeded more slowly and quietly than in other areas. There have been neither the concerted drives of the Baltic republics nor the violence of the Caucasus and Central Asia. In the Ukraine's Donetsk coal basin, however, miners went on strike Friday demanding resignation of the local Communist Party leadership and complaining that promises made after coal strikes in the region last summer were not implemented quickly enough. Gorbachev has pressed the Communist Party to relinquish its monopoly on power and pushed for a new, more powerful presidency. Hundreds of thousands of people have turned out for pro-democracy rallies. Responding to reporters' questions after he voted in Lenin Hills, the Soviet leader said it was not particularly important whether the victors in Sunday's elections were Communists. The 20-million member party is trying to get much closer to the people, ``and so the question of proportions is not crucial,'' he said. ``It is important that people are there who support perestroika and are prepared to move this process ahead. Communist or non-party members, all will be good enough.'' Voters in the Ukraine selected a 450-member Supreme Soviet legislature, Byelorussia chose a 310-member legislature and Russia elected a 1,068-member congress that will choose a legislature and leadership from among its members. The balloting in the Slavic republics follows local elections in Lithuania swept by candidates endorsed by the pro-independence Sajudis movement, and several other republics. Voters in 28 Lithuanian districts cast ballots in runoff elections Sunday. Runoffs in the remaining 17 districts not settled in the Feb. 24 election will be held later in the week, the official Tass news agency said. On Sunday, at least nine deputies to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet were elected, eight of them supported by the pro-independence movement Sajudis, said Longinas Vasiliauskas, a Sajudis spokesman. Two-thirds of the 140-member parliament must have been elected before a session can be called. Observers have speculated that Sajudis wants a quick parliament session so Lithuania can vote to secede from the Soviet Union before Gorbachev gains his expected broad new powers, which include the right to suspend republic parliaments and send in troops. The Soviet Congress meets in one week to consider Gorbachev's proposal. Vasiliauskas said the Lithuanian parliament would not vote to leave the Soviet Union immediately but wants to create the mechanism for secession because ``We don't know what Gorbachev will do after he's elected president.''

DOC.HEAD: Minor Quake Shakes Eastern Idaho; No Damage Reported
DOC.TEXT: A minor earthquake measuring 3.9 on the Richter scale shook eastern Idaho but caused no damage, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey said early today. The temblor, at 11:51 p.m. MST Sunday, was felt by residents of the Jackson, Wyo. area near the Idaho line, according to Pat Jorgenson, spokeswoman for the USGS in Menlo Park, Calif. The epicenter of the quake was about 30 miles southwest of Jackson, Jorgenson said. The last recorded quake in eastern Idaho was in the early 1980s, she added. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale is considered capable of causing slight damage in the local area; a quake of 4 can cause moderate damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Transplant Recipient's Condition Upgraded
DOC.TEXT: The 12-year-old girl who is the world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant remained in fair condition early today at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Stormie Jones' condition had been upgraded from serious to fair on Sunday. Stormie, of White Settlement, Texas, is recovering from her second liver transplant, which was performed Feb. 20. Stormie received a new heart and liver at Children's on Feb. 14, 1984, to control a condition in which her cholesterol level was 10 times higher than normal. Doctors decided to implant a new liver after Stormie's first transplanted liver was damaged by hepatitis caused by an unknown virus. Her donor heart was not affected by the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Calls Some Rock Music Satanic
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John O'Connor said some kinds of rock music help trap teen-agers into devil worship, and he disclosed that two exorcisms have been performed in the New York area within the past year. ``Diabolically instigated violence is on the rise,'' O'Connor said in his sermon Sunday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Divorce and abortion are two examples, he told parishioners. O'Connor said heavy-metal rock music in particular ``can help trap people, especially teen-agers,'' into devil worship. He singled out the song ``Suicide Solution'' by Ozzy Osbourne as an example. The parents of a teen-ager who killed himself while listening to the song sued Osbourne in 1986. The lawsuit later was dismissed. ``I think the industry had better police itself,'' O'Connor told reporters after the sermon. He avoided calling for music censorship. O'Connor described how young devil-worshippers gather in cemeteries for ``disgraceful'' satanic ceremonies. Such a ceremony could end in suicide, he said. He said the Roman Catholic archdiocese's vicar general, Monsignor Patrick Sheridan, approved the use of exorcism, a ritual to cast out an evil spirit, in two recent cases of demonic possession. ``As far as we know they have been successful,'' the cardinal said. Possession ``seems to be very rare ... Psychological, medical and other causes of what appears to be possession must be ruled out,'' O'Connor said. He said the novel ``The Exorcist'' is a ``gruesomely authentic'' portrayal of demonic possession.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Visits Independence War Memorial
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela laid a wreath today at a memorial to those who sacrificed their lives in the independence war that transformed white-ruled Rhodesia into black-governed Zimbabwe. Mandela, 71, said Zimbabwe's victory was an inspiration to the people of South Africa, where some 5 million whites wield political and economic power over a voteless black majority of 28 million. Mandela began his fourth week of freedom from South African jails at the North Korean-built Hero's Acre shrine _ a monument to the blacks' wartime victory. ``Today I have seen something altogether new,'' he later told South African trade unionists and exiles at the University of Zimbabwe in Harare, referring to the country's multiracial society. ``And this has convinced me that we are on the threshhold of something altogether new in our country.'' ``Nothing can ever stop an idea whose time has come,'' he added, ``and the time of the idea of liberation, freedom and peace has come in our country.'' Mandela, now vice president of the African National Congress, was freed Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the Pretoria government. President Robert Mugabe, who led the Zimbabwean guerrillas in the seven-year conflict, declared today Mandela Day, a public holiday. But many Zimbabweans flocked to work anyway, unaware they'd been given a day off. At a state banquet Sunday night, Mugabe spoke of ``discordant voices'' being heard in the face of efforts towards peace talks between the anti-apartheid groups and the white-led government. This was a clear reference to the Pan-Africanist Congress, the ANC's main rival which opposes contacts with Pretoria and pledges to escalate an armed struggle. The ANC, the PAC and the South African Communist Party were all legitimized by President F. W. de Klerk last month as a prelude to Mandela's release. The ANC, which embraces the Communist Party, has agreed to talks expected to begin in Cape Town mid-March. But the PAC, which Mugabe once favored over the ANC, refuses to engage in any discussions. Mugabe noted that his own country's independence came as a result of direct talks between guerrilla leaders and the government under British chairmanship in 1979. This was after Mugabe himself was detained by Ian D. Smith's Rhodesian regime for 10 yeers. Mandela is due to leave Harare Tuesday for Dar es Salaam, the capital of Tanzania where most ANC exiles live, before traveling to Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Sends Troops Into Homeland After Rioting Follows Coup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd pvs, `Foreign Minister...' to UPDATE with three killed, dozens injured. Pick up 3rd pv, `Botha said...'
DOC.TEXT: South Africa sent troops into the Ciskei homeland today to suppress riots by mobs that burned factories and looted shops after the territory's authoritarian president was ousted in a military coup. Foreign Minister Pik Botha said his government intervened at the request of Brig. Gen. Oupa Gqozo of the Ciskei army, who seized power in a military coup Sunday in the nominally independent homeland. Doctors at Cecilia Makilwane Hospital said three people had been stabbed to death and dozens of others injured in the rioting. Botha said South Africa intervened after mobs threatened to attack government buildings in the Ciskei capital of Bisho. He gave no details and did not say whether South African forces were involved in fighting with rioters. There was no immediate word from Gqozo's junta on the developments. Botha had said earlier that South Africa would not ``entertain any request'' to intervene. He did not say if South Africa would recognize the new government in Ciskei. More than 50 factories, many of them owned by Israeli and Taiwanese firms, were set ablaze today as major rioting and looting flared for a second day in Mdantsane, a sprawling township and industrial area in eastern Ciskei near the South African city of East London, officials said. Mobs attacked and burned businesses and shops in Fort Jackson, Dimbasa and Zwelitsa, they said. Gqozo said Sunday after the coup that the ultimate aim of the new government of Ciskei was to reincorporate it into South Africa. ``We are looking for a new future,'' he told a news conference. Gqozo was flanked at the conference by officials of the African National Congress, the main South African black anti-government group, and its allied Mass Democratic Movement. He said the coup was aimed at ending widespread violence, detentions of citizens, corruption and deteriorating education and health services. Human rights monitoring groups say at least 700 people have been detained in the homeland this year, and about 200 were still in detention Sunday. Gqozo said all security forces, including police and prison service officers, supported the new Council of State. But order was not being kept today as hundreds of looters, many of them drunk, broke into shops, removed the contents and then set buildings ablaze with firebombs, officials said. ``All the shops and factories were burning ... Everybody was looting and there was complete chaos,'' said an employee at a local hotel. Some onlookers attempted to stop the looting, but the local police made little effort to intervene, eyewitnesses said, adding that some shots were fired, apparently by security forces, but there were no reports of injuries. Residents said the factories were a symbol of the oppressive rule of the old government and people were burning them because of poor wages and bad working conditions. The previous government attracted major foreign investment with subsidies and by providing workers for wages of $50 or less a month. But many of the people who looted shops were simply taking advantage of the lawlessness, others said. Botha said South African forces would protect all threatened property. At least two supermarkets and dozens of shops and houses were burned and looters used wheelbarrows to haul away stoves, refrigerators and other goods taken from shops, officials said. ``Everybody in Mdantsane has TVs now,'' said one man watching the looting. Ciskei, a 3,600-square-mile territory of about 1 million people, is not recognized as sovereign by any country other than South Africa. South Africa has made it and three other homelands independent as part of efforts to create separate homelands for blacks, but no other nations recognize them as independent. Residents in the homelands lose South African citizenship, but the Pretoria government pumps millions of dollars into the homelands to keep them afloat. No casualties were reported in Sunday's overthrow of President Lennox Sebe in which troops seized control of the capital, Bisho. Sebe was in Hong Kong on a trade mission. Jubilant soldiers and civilians danced, sang and embraced in the streets of Bisho to celebrate the coup. Gqozo said Sunday that he and three other officers had formed an executive committee for a Council of State to run the government. The coup leaders arrested Lt. Gen. Kwame Sebe, the president's son and commander of the defense force's special services; Brig. A. Sixishe, chief of the defense force; and Brig. Solly Swelindaba, chief of the army. President Sebe, 63, led the territory to independent status in 1981, although a commission had found the majority of residents opposed losing their South African citizenship. The other members of the Council of State were identified as Col. O.M. Guzana; Cmdt. S.S. Pita; and Maj. P. Hauser, who is white. There are often white officers in the homeland security forces, either seconded South African officials, former mercenaries or immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Defends Summit Results, Says Didn't Cave in To Bush
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told critics in Parliament today that his summit with President Bush had ``very good results'' in reducing economic friction and was not a case of one-sided yielding to U.S. pressure on trade issues. ``The United States is willing to have a dialogue with us. Do you really believe dialogue is bad?'' Kaifu asked Japan Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi, who delivered a lengthy criticism of his party's policies. ``To avoid going backward, we must continue cooperating,'' Kaifu said. ``I would like to ask for the help and understanding of the whole nation in doing so.'' While ruling Liberal Democratic Party officials saw the summit in Palm Springs, Calif. as contributing to relations with the United States, leaders of the Socialist Party, the largest opposition group, accused Kaifu of weakness. ``What promises did you make to President Bush in the United States?'' Doi asked after charging that Kaifu's trip, on a week's notice, lacked ``adequate preparation or consultations.'' On Sunday, Socialist Party Secretary General Tsuruo Yamaguchi charged that Kaifu had unilaterally yielded to Bush's demands for economic reform in Japan aimed at slimming this nation's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Kaifu denied he had merely yielded to U.S. pressure. He said a decline in the trade imbalance from a peak of $59.8 billion in 1987 to $49 billion last year was the result of both countries' efforts. He also defended Bush's pledges to cut the $155 billion U.S. federal budget deficit. ``The United States is committed to resolve its problems, and we must also follow through with our reforms and continue our cooperative dialogue with them,'' said Kaifu, who returned late Sunday from the weekend summit. He faced skepticism, however, over his ability to follow through on promises to Bush that he will reform Japan's distribution system and land use policies, improve living standards and tighten enforcement of anti-monopoly laws. In talks called the ``Structural Impediments Initiative,'' U.S. officials have said these reforms are needed to eliminate what they call informal trade barriers. The nation's largest newspaper, the Yomiuri Shimbun, said Bush's requests to Kaifu would ``severely test Kaifu's leadership ability.'' Another major paper, the Asahi, said the challenge would test the entire Japanese leadership. ``The Japan-U.S. Structural Impediments Initiative will end in empty talk unless Japanese companies' overly strong competitiveness and the nature of Japan's closed economy are subjected to close scrutiny,'' the Asahi said in an editorial. In Palm Springs, Bush also said he wanted to help cut the trade imbalance by reducing the U.S. federal budget deficit, improving education and worker training, increasing savings and investment, and encouraging long-term management strategies aimed at boosting industrial productivity. Japan is under pressure to show it will implement promised reforms before early April, when trade negotiators are to issue an interim report on the structural trade talks. Japanese officials expressed concern Kaifu will have problems gathering support for reforms soon enough to satisfy the United States. Kaifu lacks political clout within his own party and faces an upper house of Parliament dominated by the Socialist-led opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Ambush Paramilitary Troops
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants ambushed a government patrol in the heart of Srinagar while curfew was lifted briefly today, and one civilian was killed when the troops returned fire, a senior officer said. The militants claimed they killed 12 members of the Border Security Force, but a senior officer of the paramilitary force said only two of his men were wounded and none were killed. The officer said the ambush in Srinagar was one of the boldest and best organized ever carried out in the Kashmir city, center of the pro-independence movement by Moslems who want to secede from predominantly Hindu India. The officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the attackers fired Soviet-designed AK-47 rifles from three directions, using at least 100 rounds of ammunition. The attack occurred on the main shopping street in the heart of Srinagar. The curfew, which had been in effect since Friday morning, was lifted for the first time for a few hours early today to enable thousands of stranded villagers to return home. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front claimed responsibility for the attack, saying it was to avenge the killing of 49 Moslem demonstrators by army and paramilitary troops last Thursday. ``We have killed 12 Indian soldiers. We carried out the operation this morning to take revenge for the deaths of our Moslem brothers who were killed by the army,'' a telephone caller told a local journalist. The Border Security Force officer said one civilian was killed and a suspected militant was seriously wounded when the ambushed troops returned fire. About 150,000 people _ many of whom had participated in a massive anti-India demonstration on Thursday _ were stranded by the curfew, the intelligence officers said on condition of anonymity. An estimated one million people streamed through Srinagar Thursday to demand Kashmir's independence from predominantly Hindu India. It was the largest pro-independence demonstration ever staged in the Kashmir Valley. The government said its troops opened fire in self-defense. Witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity said some of the marchers had tried to grab the weapons of soldiers and paramilitary police. The killings by government troops prompted rebukes from neighboring Pakistan, an Islamic nation, and appeals for restraint from the U.S. State Department. Gov. Jagmohan, a federally appointed Hindu who is the top administrator of Jammu-Kashmir state, met army and security officials during the weekend and was to receive a delegation of federal officials from New Delhi today, sources said. Jagmohan, who uses only one name, said in an interview Sunday the government was prepared to call new state elections within six months. But this seemed unlikely to appease the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front and other militant groups who say they will be satisfied by nothing less than independence. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. The southern Jammu region of the state is mostly Hindu, while the Kashmir region that includes Srinagar is predominantly Moslem. Spurred in part by the Hindu ruler of the old princely state of Kashmir, the valley acceded to India rather than join Pakistan. The two countries went to war in 1949 and 1965 over Kashmir, but the region still remains divided by a cease-fire line separating Indian and Pakistani troops. Kashmiri secessionists initially sought to join Pakistan, but in the past year the militants have been pressing for full independence. Jammu-Kashmir's population of 6 million is 64 percent Moslem and 32 percent Hindu with small minorities of Buddhists, Sikhs and Christians. Nationwide, Hindus account for 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems comprise 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Western Pakistan, Killing 5
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6 on the Richter scale jolted western Pakistan early today, collapsing several mud-dried homes and killing five people, the state-run news agency said. Associated Press of Pakistan said the epicenter of the quake was located about 60 miles east of the Iranian border in Pakistan's Baluchistan province. Rescue teams unearthed five bodies in the hardest hit villages, about 90 miles southwest of the provincial capital of Quetta, APP reported. The earthquake was the second in less than a week. No damage or injuries were reported in last week's tremor, according to APP.

DOC.HEAD: Lenin Statue Removed After Weekend Of Work
DOC.TEXT: To the cheers of hundreds of onlookers, workers succeeded in lifting Bucharest's imposing statue of Lenin from its foundation today after a weekend of intensive demolition work. ``He was built to last a thousand years, but luckily he couldn't withstand us,'' said Duri Gomfedele, a member of the crew that finally brought down the 25-foot, seven-ton bronze statue. Workers labored all day Saturday and Sunday with jackhammers and blowtorches to bring down the statue, located in front of the Stalinist-style state publishing house in the recently renamed Free Press Square. This morning, the statue was lifted from its marble base, placed on a flatbed truck and driven away to a storeroom in Fondul Plastic, the city's plastic art foundation, workers said. ``I can't believe it's finally happened,'' said Mihai Radulescu. ``I've been here every day since Saturday, waiting to see Lenin go. This morning I didn't go to work.'' Demolition crews had been slowed by the thick bronze rods implanting the statue deep in its foundation. A small wrecking ball that slammed against Lenin's arm Saturday failed to do more than shake the statue slightly. ``To our surprise, there was a bronze plate ... protecting the concrete foundation that also went up through his legs,'' said Gomfedele. ``It was much more difficult than we expected.'' The ruling Provisional Council of National Unity, acting as a mini-parliament until national elections scheduled for May 20, decided on Friday to remove the 30-year-old image of Lenin. The statue had become a symbol of the 45 years of Communist rule that ended in December with the ouster of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu by a popular revolt. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas day after a summary trial. The demolition provided weekend entertainment for hundreds of Bucharest residents who monitored the job and joked about the statue's resilience. Authorities said Saturday they had not decided what to do with the statue, which depicts Lenin holding his cap and the lapel of his overcoat. From where he stood, he stared down a broad avenue towards Bucharest's Arch of Triumph. The now empty pink marble base is covered with anti-Communist graffitti and blue writing that reads, ``Down with the Statue.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister in Moscow for Kremlin Talks
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow arrived today in Moscow for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expected to focus on prospects for future trade and security after the March 18 East German elections. The Tass news agency said Modrow was met at the airport by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Deputy Foreign Minister Anatoly Adamishin. Before Modrow's departure from East Berlin, the East German news agency ADN suggested Gorbachev was concerned about Moscow's future military and economic ties with a unified Germany. East Germany has been the Soviets' chief trading partner and firmest defense ally. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised Gorbachev during a meeting in Moscow Feb. 10 that the Soviet Union wouldn't lose vital supplies as East Germany moves towards unification. The Kremlin is at odds with West Germany and its allies over Western demands that a single Germany should remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev is insisting on neutrality for a unified Germany. Another key topic likely to be on the agenda will be Kohl's refusal to give Poland a binding promise that a united Germany would respect Poland's current frontier with East Germany. Poland gained territory from Germany after World War II, but also lost large regions to the Soviet Union. Poland has requested the two Germanys to begin work on a treaty that would guarantee the Oder and Neisse rivers as the permanent border between Germany and Poland. Modrow supports Poland on the issue. The East German Foreign Ministry has declared that all neighboring countries should be represented at an international summit, where the two Germanys will plot the course for unification with the World War II victors: Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. East Germans go to the polls March 18. The Communists, running under the new party name Party for Democratic Socialism, are a distant third in the campaign for 400 parliamentary seats to be distributed by East Germany's first competitive election in its 40-year history. The Communists are intent on preventing what they see as 40 years of accomplishments in East Germany from being wiped out in a hasty merger with their Western neighbor.

DOC.HEAD: `The Last Metro' Wins Best Film of Decade Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with best of decade awards; Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Depardieu was...'
DOC.TEXT: Francois Truffaut's 1981 film ``The Last Metro'' was named France's best movie of the 1980s today by the 2,500 film professionals who also pick winners of the annual Cesar awards, the French Oscars. In ceremonies Sunday, ``Too Beautiful for You,'' the story of a salesman who drops his beautiful wife for a passionate affair with his dumpy secretary, won five Cesars, including best film, best director and best screenplay. ``The Last Metro'' starred Gerard Depardieu and Catherine Deneuve as an actor and a theater owner. It takes place in World War II during the German occupation of Paris, when a strict curfew made it essential to catch the last subway train home. Depardieu was chosen best actor of the decade. The award for best actress went to Isabelle Adjani for her performances in such films as ``Camille Claudel.'' The 1980s ``Super Cesars'' were announced in a statement the day after Sunday's awards, at which actor Kirk Douglas was master of ceremonies. Bertrand Blier won best director for ``Too Beautiful for You,'' and Carole Bouquet, who played the wife, was named best actress. Among those she edged out was Josiane Balasko, who put on weight to play the fat and apparently ordinary temporary secretary who wins the heart of the car salesman, played by Depardieu. Depardieu was nominated for best actor, but the award went to Philippe Noiret for his portrayal of a French army officer in the aftermath of World War I in ``Life and Nothing Else.'' The fifth award for ``Too Beautiful For You'' went to Claudine Merlin for best editing. Best foreign film was ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' by the British director Stephen Frears, an adaptation of the 18th century French epistolary novel, ``Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' by Choderos de Laclos. A French-made film adapted from the same novel, ``Valmont,'' won the award for best costumes. Its director, Milos Forman, was nominated for best director. Before the ceremonies, Culture Minister Jack Lang made Douglas an officer in France's Legion d'Honneur.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal by Cleveland Company Rejected in Case Steeming from Hostage Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, in a case stemming from the 1981 settlement of the Iran hostage crisis, today rejected an appeal by a Cleveland, Ohio, company seeking to avoid paying $3.6 million to Iran. The court, without comment, let stand what was described as a first-of-its-kind ruling that American courts have authority to enforce such payments. The agreement between the United States and Iran that freed 52 American hostages in 1981 included release by the U.S. government of billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets. The settlement also set up a process permitting those with claims against Iran to take them to an international tribunal. The Supreme Court previously upheld the power of former President Carter to approve the settlement. At issue in the appeal acted on today was whether U.S. courts can force American companies to pay claims the international tribunal has awarded to Iran. Gould Inc., a high technology firm, was ordered by the international tribunal to pay $3.6 million and return military radio equipment to Iran. Iranian officials asked U.S. District Judge Richard A. Gadbois Jr. in California to enforce the tribunal's decision. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last year that U.S. courts have such power, although the appeals court said the authority does not derive directly from the 1981 settlement. The appeals court said the settlement was designed to secure payment of claims against Iran and provided ``no specific vehicle for the enforcement of awards in favor of Iran.'' Instead, the appeals court relied on a 1958 United Nations pact called the New York Convention. It provides for enforcement of international arbitration awards. ``Party-states to the convention agree to recognize arbitral awards as binding and enforce them in accordance with their own rules of procedure,'' the appeals court said, noting that the United States signed the pact in 1970. The $3.6 million payment order against Gould qualifies as such an arbitral award, the appeals court said as it sent the case back to Gadbois for further review. Gould acquired Hoffman Export Corp. in 1978. The Hoffman company sold electronic military equipment to Iran when it was a U.S. ally ruled by Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. The case is Gould Inc. vs. Iran, 89-1103.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal From Western Pilots in Suit Against Delta
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear an appeal by 661 pilots who say their seniority rights were violated after Delta Air Lines acquired Western Air Lines. The court, without comment, let die the pilots' lawsuit against Delta and the Air Line Pilots Association. The pilots, most of whom had worked for Western and now are employed by Delta, said Delta reneged on a promise to arbitrate labor disputes arising from the 1986 merger of the two airlines. The former Western pilots also accused the Air Line Pilots Association of failing to represent them adequately. They said Delta used illegal coercion to enforce new seniority rankings, threatening to lay off more than 300 pilots if the rankings were rejected. As a result, the pilots said they occupy just 95 of the top 600 positions instead of the 189 they are entitled to by seniority. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year upheld a California judge's dismissal of their lawsuit. ``The integration of a seniority list involves much more than listing pilots according to the date that each began work,'' the appeals court said. ``It encompasses such variables as the pilot's rank and the kind of aircraft with which a pilot has had experience.'' The appeals court said the post-merger agreement between Delta and the pilots union was acceptable to most of the union members, although it was opposed by most of the former Western pilots. ``Only the collective bargaining representatives _ or the carrier _ may submit a dispute over the integration of seniority lists to arbitration,'' the appeals court said. That rule is designed to allow a union ``to focus on the needs of its whole membership without undue fear of lawsuits from individual members,'' the 9th Circuit court added. The case is Herring vs. Delta Air Lines, 89-1119.

DOC.HEAD: College Basketball Star Dies After Collapsing During Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, bgng, `The 6-foot-7 ..., to UPDATE with reax from high school coach; SUBS last 2 grafs, `Gathers had ....', with 8 grafs to UPDATE with reax, Gathers lowering dosage of medicine. A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA6,13,14, AB1; LaserColor LA12
DOC.TEXT: Hank Gathers, one of college basketball's premier players, collapsed and died after sinking a slam dunk during a game. He was 23. The cause of the Loyola Marymount University star's death Sunday night was not immediately known, but he had fainted during a game in December because of an irregular heartbeat and had been taking medication for the condition, doctors said. An autopsy was planned but not before Tuesday, said an official in the Los Angeles County coroner's office who refused to identify himself. The 6-foot-7, 210-pound senior center from Philadelphia was expected to be a first-round choice in this year's National Basketball Association draft. He was known for his intensity and his will to win. ``If there can be any good in this, at least he died doing the thing he loved best,'' said his high school coach, Rich Yankowitz. Yankowitz, who coaches at Dobbins Technical High School, said he talked with Gathers three weeks ago, and the player said he felt good and looked forward to the rest of the season. ``He was pleased with the way everything was going. He seemed real happy, again focused properly on what was important to him. Everything was fine,'' Yankowitz said. Gathers averaged 28.8 points and 11.2 rebounds a game this year. During his junior year, he averaged 32.7 points and 13.7 rebounds, and his 1,015 points last season ranked him 11th on the all-time single-season scoring list. Gathers had dunked the ball during the first half of a West Coast Conference tournament game against Portland and headed upcourt with a big smile. Seconds later, without warning, he crumpled to the court. He tried to rise but got only to his knees before collapsing again. He appeared to suffer convulsions for a few seconds while his mother and aunt raced to his side. Their cries could be heard throughout Gersten Pavillion as the crowd of about 3,000 sat in stunned silence. Efforts to resuscitate Gathers on the court, in an ambulance and at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital failed. He was pronounced dead less than two hours after he collapsed. ``I thought the chances (to save him) were good,'' cardiologist Dr. Mason Weiss said. ``We were unable to generate any activity.'' The game and tournament were canceled and Loyola, which was leading Portland 25-13, was declared the league champion by virtue of its 13-1 record in conference games. The team planned to meet today to decide whether to accept a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. ``Words are hard right now,'' Loyola coach Paul Westhead said in a statement. ``This is the hardest thing I've experienced ... to be so close to a player and see him fall and for it to be over. I feel a deep hurt for his family.'' Gathers had collapsed Dec. 9 because of what doctors suspected was an accelerated heartbeat. He was hospitalized several days for tests, returned after missing two games and began taking medication to regulate his heartbeat, doctors said. Yankowitz said he had spoken to Gathers' doctors and college coach and had been told that he would be fine. ``That's what makes it so alarming; he was playing with the doctor's blessing,'' he said. Jerome ``Pooh'' Richardson of the NBA's Minnesota Timberwolves said Gathers recently told him that doctors had allowed him to lower his dosage of medication because it was making him drowsy. ``He said he felt great. He was in good spirits,'' said Richardson, who played against Gathers in high school. He said Gathers had planned to watch the Timberwolves play the Los Angeles Lakers after Loyola's game Sunday. After Gathers' death, ``This game means absolutely nothing,'' Richardson said. Two of Gathers' closest friends from Philadelphia, La Salle University players Lionel Simmons and Doug Overton, began sobbing when they learned of the death during a game Sunday night in Albany, N.Y. ``We're going back to the hotel and we're going to talk about it,'' La Salle coach Speedy Morris said later. ``They're having a cry right now. Their feelings and emotions are pouring out. It's very difficult to talk to them right now.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Challenges Sections of ``Born on Fourth of July'' Movie
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Robert Dornan is challenging the accuracy of ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' saying the hit movie could mislead viewers about the record of author Ron Kovic, who may be his election opponent. The Republican congressman said he was attacking the movie because it could leave people in his district with the impression that all of the events actually happened to Kovic, whose wounds in Vietnam left him paralyzed from the waist down. The movie recounts Kovic's transformation from patriotic Marine to war opponent. ``The movie is in effect his political resume. And Kovic has engaged in resume padding,'' Dornan said recently. Sid Galanty, Kovic's media representative, dismissed Dornan's remarks. ``It's an entertainment vehicle, not a documentary,'' said Gallanty, who did not dispute the discrepancies brought out by Dornan. ``People who want a strictly factual account should read the book.'' Kovic, 43, whose autobiography was made into the Tom Cruise film directed by Oliver Stone, has been wooed by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Kovic has not said if he will run against Dornan, but said his ``time of dedicated service to my country has come again.'' In February, Dornan sent out 20,000 fund-raising letters that called Kovic the favorite of the ``ultra-liberal ... Hollywood left.'' Among the inaccuracies cited by Dornan and backed by others were: _Kovic is shown accidentally killing a fellow Marine during combat, then later going to the dead Marine's parents to tell them of the incident. Marine Lt. Col. Fred Peck, responding to media inquiries, said Kovic's commanding officer concluded that Kovic did not shoot the Marine. Kovic told KNBC-TV that the scene of the visit to the man's family did not actually happen, but was a recurring nightmare that he had. _Kovic is shown being attacked with other students by nightstick-wielding riot police in 1970 at Syracuse University after a speech by the late activist Abbie Hoffman. New York state Sen. Nancy Hoffman and Washington attorney David Ifshin, who both participated in the protest, say Abbie Hoffman was never on the campus. ``The movie is totally inconsistent with the facts,'' said Ms. Hoffman, adding that police ``displayed remarkable restraint.'' _Kovic also is shown being spat on and roughed up by security guards at the 1972 GOP national convention in Miami. But former CBS correspondent Roger Mudd, who was near the scene of the alleged action, doesn't remember it that way. Mudd also denies Kovic's account in his autobiography that Mudd interviewed the activist during the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Leaders Insist PLO Be Involved in Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian leaders from the occupied territories demanded today that the PLO be involved in proposed Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a move Israel has consistently opposed. The statement, signed by more than 30 prominent Palestinians from the occupied lands, was released as Israeli leaders were deadlocked over accepting U.S.-backed compromises aimed at getting preliminary peace talks under way. The hardened stance by the Palestinian leaders lessens the chances of Israel accepting the compromises, which were aimed partly at avoiding even the appearance of PLO involvement. Israel's right-wing Likud bloc, headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, has resisted proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III to include residents of Arab east Jerusalem and two Palestinians deported by Israel among the negotiators. Party hard-liners fear such a move would allow indirect participation by the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. The statement by 34 Palestinian leaders from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip was circulated in Jerusalem and the West Bank. It called for ``the immediate opening, without pre-conditions, of a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue'' and chided the Israeli government for ``placing obstacles in the way of any effort to move the peace process forward.'' But it also repeated the Palestinian demand that the PLO represent them in the talks. ``The PLO alone has the right both to form and to announce any Palestinian delegation to the peace dialogue,'' the statement said. ``No Palestinian from the Israeli-occupied territories will participate in any delegation that is not formed or announced by the PLO.'' The U.S. compromises for getting talks started reportedly specify that Egypt will announce the makeup of the Palestinian delegation. Asked about the statement, Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner reiterated the government's position on the PLO, saying that, ``anything that is connected to the PLO is disqualified by us. We won't agree to the PLO participating in any way, directly or indirectly, in the talks.'' Palestinian leaders, meanwhile, said they were not concerned their statement might deepen the rift between the Likud bloc and its partner in the coaltion Cabinet, the left-leaning Labor Party, which supports the U.S.-backed compromises. ``We do not care about the dispute between Labor and Likud,'' said Jamil Tarifi, a pro-PLO lawyer from the West Bank town of Ramallah who signed the statement. Another signer, Saeeb Erakat, a political science professor from the West Bank city of Jericho, said the statement was issued because ``there are a lot of rumors and confusion created by Israel insisting Israel will have a say in the delegation.'' ``We are not a herd of sheep. We have a leadership. Israel knows it, but pretends it doesn't know,''he said. The statement also called for ``an open agenda'' for the talks and said they should lead eventually to an international peace conference. Israel has repeatedly said it wants the agenda focused on Israel's call for elections in the territories. The elections plan, put forward in May 1989, would select Palestinians to hold talks with Israel on limited autonomy for the territories. The statement called for continued pressure on Israel to accept PLO participation in negotiations, including continuation of the nearly 27-month uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied lands. In the uprising, which began in December 1987, at least 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians and 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Volcanic Ash Slows Some Dog Sled Teams
DOC.TEXT: The leader in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race hit the highest point in the 1,160-mile competition today on the third day of the wilderness trek, but others were slowed by volcanic ash. Four-time champion Rick Swenson reached a 3,500-foot pass in the towering Alaska Range after holding back Sunday at Skwentna during the warmest part of the day while others went ahead, sparing his dogs and waiting for the trail to freeze. Temperatures have risen into the 30s. Three-time winner Susan Butcher of Manley continued to move up the pack, having hit 11th place after starting the race in Anchorage as No. 68 of 70 mushers. A quarter-inch of gritty volcanic ash from Sunday's eruption of Redoubt Volcano was reported on the trail at Finger Lake, slowing the sleds, said race spokeswoman Theresa Daily. The race across Alaska from Anchorage to Nome, on the Bering Sea coast, has been run since 1973. It was founded to commemorate the delivery by sled dog relay team of diphtheria serum to Nome in 1925. The serum staved off an epidemic.

DOC.HEAD: University President And Wife Among Americans Dead In Hotel Fire
DOC.TEXT: Medical records confirmed today that a former president of Brandeis Univesity and his wife were among four Americans killed in last week's fire at a luxury hotel, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said. Also today, a tourism official said the fire safety procedures of all Cairo hotels will be reviewed. Seventeen people were killed in the hotel fire early Thursday at the Heliopolis Sheraton, which started in a garden tent restaurant. Among the victims were Prof. Marver Bernstein, 71, a former president of Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. and his wife, Sheva Rosenthal. Spokeswoman Marcelle Wahba of the U.S. Embassy said the couple's dental and medical documents arrived today, providing positive identification. Bernstein was dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University before becoming president of Brandeis in 1972. In 1983 he joined Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, where he taught both politics and philosophy and coordinated the school's American courses program. He retired last year but remained as a lecturer. Bernstein was born in Mankato, Minn.. He married Rosenthal, a native of St. Paul, Minn., in 1943, the Washington Post said. Also today, officials said security systems at Cairo's hotels and firefighting equipment would be reviewed. Hamdy el-Shamy of the Tourism Ministry said there would be ``coordination to organize regular checks.'' He said most of Egypt's luxury hotels had tents similar to the one that caught fire at the Sheraton and that they were legal. Officials have charged that the Sheraton set up the tent illegally. Survivors of the Sheraton fire have said there was no sprinkler system or fire alarm, but Sheraton officials have insisted an alarm was sounded when the fire spread from the tent restaurant to the hotel. Scores of brightly colored canvas tents decorate many of the country's major hotels to create a Middle Eastern flavor in nightclubs and restaurants. They are popular with Egyptians and foreigners. About 2.4 million tourists visited Egypt in 1989, bringing in $2.4 billion in revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules on Questioning of Criminal Defendants in Michigan Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS lead to specify that court's ruling concerned right to legal help; Inserts graf 5, The court, with background.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that even when police question criminal defendants in violation of their right to legal help, the responses may be used to contradict trial testimony by the defendants. By a 5-4 vote in a Michigan case, the court said the Constitution does not bar use of such statements when they are used by prosecutors to rebut a defendant's testimony and impeach the accused person's credibility. ``The prosecution must not be allowed to build its case against a criminal defendant with evidence acquired in contravention of constitutional guarantees,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. ``But use of statements so obtained for impeachment purposes is a different matter,'' he said. ``If a defendant exercises his right to testify on his own behalf, he assumes a reciprocal obligation to speak truthfully and accurately.'' The court previously has ruled that statements obtained by police in violation of a defendant's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination may be used to challenge the defendant's trial testimony. Today, the court extended those rulings to allow use of statements obtained in violation of a defendant's Sixth Amendment right to legal representation. The court ordered further lower court hearings that could lead to reinstatment of Tyris Lemont Harvey's criminal sexual conduct conviction and 6-to-10-year prison sentence. Harvey was accused of sexually assaulting a woman on June 11, 1986. Two months after his arrest and after he was assigned a court-appointed lawyer, Harvey was questioned unlawfully by police. The police told Harvey he did not need to speak to his lawyer first because the attorney ``was going to get a copy of the statement anyway.'' The statement was used at the trial when prosecutors cross-examined Harvey to challenge his testimony on the witness stand. Harvey testified the woman agreed to remove her clothes voluntarily and said the two did not engage in sexual intercourse. The woman said she was forced to engage in sexual acts. Harvey's conviction was overturned by a Michigan appeals court which ordered a new trial. The state court said any statements to police as the result of an unlawful interrogation may not be used for any purpose at the trial. Rehnquist said the Sixth Amendment to the Constitution, guaranteeing legal representation to defendants, does not prohibit use of Harvey's statement to police as long as it was made voluntarily. ``We have never prevented (all) use by the prosecution of relevant voluntary statements by a defendant,'' Rehnquist said. ``The search for truth in a criminal case outweighs the speculative possibility that exclusion of evidence might deter future violations of rules'' by the police. Rehnquist was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice John Paul Stevens, in a dissenting opinion, said, ``The tragedy of today's decision is not merely its denigration of the constitutional right at stake. It also undermines the principle that those who are entrusted with the power of government have the same duty to respect and obey the law as the ordinary citizen.'' He was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun. The case is Michigan vs. Harvey, 88-512.

DOC.HEAD: Six Die in Two Alabama House Fires
DOC.TEXT: Two house fires in Alabama killed six people early today, including three children whose father suffered burns while trying to reach them in their burning Albertville home. The others were a woman and two men who died of asphyxiation after fire broke out in their home at Dothan. Authorities in Albertville, about 60 miles northeast of Birmingham, identified the victims as Brandy Leigh Michael, 12, Terry Lynn Michael, 8, and Jeremy Daniel Michael, 4. Albertville Fire Marshal Guy Campbell said the father, Larry Daniel Michael, 31, escaped through a window and was burned when he went back into the home trying to save the children. He was taken to University Hospital in Birmingham for treatment of second- and third-degree burns. Campbell said the cause of the blaze, which was reported at 1:52 a.m., was not immediately determined. The fire in Dothan, which occurred at about 3 a.m., was blamed on either cigarette smoking or an electric heater. The three victims were identified as Mildred B. Cook, 70; Johnny Lee Ward, 68, and Ward's son, Irvin Price, 51. Dothan is in southeast Alabama, 105 miles from Montgomery.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Protest Human Rights Violations
DOC.TEXT: At least 500 lawyers walked off their jobs and sat on the lawns in front of the Supreme Court building Monday to protest what they called human rights violations by the government. The hour-long demonstration, organized by the Nepal Bar Association, brought work in the court to a standstill, court officials said.
