Bystanders and visitors to the court were held back from the site of the demonstration by riot police. Lawyers say 59 of their colleagues were arrested in the government's crackdown on a movement for greater democracy. Several have been released and one alleged police tortured those detained. ``For five days I had to sleep on damp floors, with only rotten food to eat. Even drinking water was not available,'' said Asik Ram Karki. He said some of those arrested were beaten on the soles of their feet. A nationwide movement was launched Feb. 18 by the Nepali Congress Party and the Communist Party of Nepal demanding the restoration of multiparty democracy and an end to a 1961 royal decree banning all political parties. According to the government, 12 people have been killed in demonstrations and police firing since then, but activists say the toll is double that figure. Nepal's 2-year-old experiment with Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, father of the present monarch, King Birendra, dissovled the government of the Nepali Congrees Party, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. The government accuses the multiparty advocates of trying to impose their version of democracy on a nation that they say already has a working deomcracy. Power in Nepal is shared between the king and the non-partisan Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly. One-fifth of the Panchayat's 140 members are nominated by the king; the rest are elected. The government of King Birendra says the campaign to lift the ban on political parties runs counter to a 1980 referendum which narrowly voted for retaining the Panchayat's system of non-partisan membership.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Conviction of Death-Row Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today used the case of a South Carolina death row inmate to limit the ability of criminal defendants to challenge their convictions in federal court. The court, in a 5-4 decision, upheld the conviction of Horace Butler, sentenced to die for the 1980 murder of Pamela Lane. The court refused to apply retroactively a 1988 ruling that bars police from questioning a suspect about any crime once the suspect has invoked his right to have a lawyer present. The body of Ms. Lane, an 18-year-old clerk at a convenience store near Charleston, was discovered near a bridge July 17, 1980. Butler was arrested six weeks later on assault and battery charges unrelated to the woman's death. He obtained a lawyer's representation after refusing to talk to police without an attorney present. Sometime later, police questioned him about Ms. Lane's death and Butler confessed he shot her. Butler asked a federal judge to throw out his conviction on grounds that, under the Supreme Court's 1988 ruling, his rights were violated by unlawful police questionning. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said it was too late for the 1988 ruling to be of any help to Butler. He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. In a dissenting opinion, Justice William J. Brennan said the decision _ by refusing to apply new court rulings to previous criminal cases _ ``strips state prisoners of virtually any meaningful federal review of the constitutionality of their incarceration.'' He was joined in dissent by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. The case is Butler vs. McKellar, 88-6677.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Unhappy With Progress in U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Top U.S. trade negotiators told Congress today that they have been disappointed with the lack of progress so far in efforts to reduce Japanese barriers to American imports. But the negotiators held out hope that the weekend summit between President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu may re-energize the stalled talks. Two senators warned of growing congressional unhappiness with the seemingly intractable $49 billion trade deficit America is running with the Japanese. They raised the possibility of legislation that would force the administration to retaliate against Japanese products sold in this country. Deputy U.S. Trade Representative S. Linn Williams told a Senate trade subcommittee that in the three rounds of talks held so far little progress has been made. He said the Japanese negotiators have raised a number of reasons for being unable to make the reforms sought by the American side. ``We are not satisfied with the progress of the talks,'' Williams said. ``The basic question is whether the Japanese side sees (the negotiations) as damage-control and a public relations exercise or as a substantive effort. On that, the jury is still out.'' Williams appeared with officials from State, Treasury, Commerce and the Council of Economic Advisers to give a progress report on the so-called structural impediments initiative, which aims at eliminating economic shortcomings in both countries viewed as culprits in the massive trade imbalance. On the Japanese side, negotiators are focusing on various exclusionary business practices that keep out foreign competition. The American issues include a low savings rate and high federal budget deficit, which increases the need for foreign capital to finance the U.S. savings shortfall. The negotiators, who face a deadline of April for an interim report and July for a final report, have achieved no breakthroughs so far. Trade held center stage at a two-day summit between Bush and Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., over the weekend. The administration officials today said they were encouraged by the pledges both leaders made after the discussions concerning the need to make progress. However, Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the trade subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee, said that Kaifu's promises of reforms made to Bush were not enough. ``Every U.S. president since Nixon has gotten promises of a more open market from Japan. Most of those promises have been empty,'' he said. Baucus and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., both said that Congress' patience was growing short and if the talks failed it was likely that Japan would face legislation requiring mandatory legislation. ``The next few months are going to be telling months for Japan and for the Bush administration,'' Danforth said.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Goes on Trial in Iran-Contra Case
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs seven selected for jury pool; picks up 2nd graf, Richard Beckler...; deletes last 4 grafs to shorten
DOC.TEXT: Seven women were sent into a pool of potential jurors today for the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter, including a lawyer who worked in George Bush's presidential campaign. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene disqualified one of eight prospective jurors as the jury selection process got under way for the trial of the former national security adviser. One of those questioned by Greene and lawyers for both sides was a real estate lawyer who worked in Bush's campaign on a team that did background reviews of potential vice presidential candidates. The woman said one of Poindexter's defense lawyers, Joseph Small, had babysat for her when she was a child. ``Just because counsel babysat for her doesn't cast any doubt on her,'' said Greene, who sent her into the pool. Richard Beckler, one of Poindexter's lawyers, started off the questioning by asking the first prospective juror what she thought of Reagan. The young woman, an unemployed delivery driver for an auto parts firm, wasn't given a chance to answer. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb objected to Beckler's question, without giving a reason, and U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene sustained the objection. A pool of 206 potential jurors was set up for the Poindexter trial and 50 of them were in the U.S. courthouse for the first day of questioning. Seventy-six of the 206 prospective jurors said in questionnaires filled out last week that they had seen, read or listened to portions of Poindexter's immunized testimony to Congress in 1987, according to Greene. Poindexter is accused of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements for allegedly covering up Oliver North's secret Contra resupply network and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Theformer president gave videotaped testimony last month in the case and Poindexter's lawyers are expected to replay it in court. Reagan said he instructed his staff that all efforts to assist the Nicaraguan Contras ``should be done within the law.'' Reagan said he didn't think Poindexter had made any false statements to Congress and that ``I'm in complete support'' of letters by Poindexter which form the basis of one of the obstruction charges against him concerning the Contras. Poindexter is the highest-ranking Reagan administration official to go on trial in the scandal. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene is presiding in the Poindexter case and a jury of 12 people will be selected from a pool of residents from the District of Columbia. Directing the prosecution is Chicago trial lawyer and former U.S. attorney Dan Webb, while Poindexter is being defended by longtime Washington D.C. attorney Richard Beckler. The Iran-Contra affair began unfolding in October 1986, when an ammunition-laden C-123 that was part of North's operation was shot down inside Nicaragua. North later testified under a grant of immunity that he began shredding documents after the cargo plane was shot down. The next month there were news reports from Beirut of U.S. arms sales to Iran. North later testified that then-CIA Director William Casey advised him to destroy evidence relating to the initiative. The Contra and Iran parts were linked on Nov. 25, 1986, when then-Attorney General Edwin Meese III announced that Iran arms sale money had been diverted to the Contras. The indictment against Poindexter deals with his alleged assertions to Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, that he didn't find out that Hawk missiles had been shipped to Iran in November 1985 until two months after the delivery. Poindexter ha said his recollection of the Hawk shipment was ``very, very fuzzy'' in November 1986 and that while he may have made incorrect statements, he did not lie to Congress. National Security Council computer messages support North's testimony last year that he kept Poindexter advised of the November 1985 shipment both before and immediately after it occurred, but Poindexter said he forgot. ``My best recollection is ... that I did not remember anything about, or know anything about the Hawks until January '86,'' Poindexter told congressional investigators in immunized testimony in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Andy Rooney's Return Boosts ``60 Minutes'' Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Viewer curiosity over Andy Rooney's return to ``60 Minutes'' after a shortened suspension helped the CBS show trounce its competition in preliminary ratings, a CBS research official said Monday. With Rooney back at work, commenting on his suspension, Sunday's ``60 Minutes'' got a 36 per cent share of the audience and a 22.7 rating in the A.C. Nielsen Co. overnight audience estimates. Those estimates are from 23 cities that collectively represent 45.3 per cent of the nation's TV households. The show's share usually averages 32 or 33 percent in overnight ratings. ABC's ``Life Goes On'' averaged a 15 per cent audience share and a 9.6 rating. NBC's Walt Disney movie series was third, averaging a 14 per cent audience share and an 8.5 rating. National ratings are due Tuesday. Athough still top-rated, ``60 Minutes'' had begun falling in the ratings since Rooney's three-month suspension, on Feb. 8. On Feb. 25, the show slipped to 18th place in the weekly Nielsens. But research analysts at all three networks said that primarily was due to ABC's competition that night, a rerun of the one-hour premiere of its hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' series. The ABC special, in the time slot normally held by ``Life Goes On,'' beat ``60 Minutes'' in the ratings. Rooney was suspended without pay after a homosexual-oriented magazine quoted him as making disparaging racial remarks. Rooney denied the remarks attributed to him. He had drawn fire earlier from gay-rights groups for a December special on CBS in which he cited ``homosexual unions'' as among the causes of premature deaths. On Thursday, CBS News president David Burke, who never specifically said why he suspended Rooney, ordered an early lifting of the suspension, allowing the 71-year-old commentator to return to work. ``Obviously, the return of Andy Rooney had a lot of people tuning in,'' said CBS research vice president Michael Eisenberg. ``People were curious about the whole matter, and we probably picked up people who don't normally watch `60 Minutes.''' Sunday's ``60 Minutes'' averaged a 33 per cent share of the audience in New York, and a 39 per cent share in Los Angeles. Those cities are the nation's first and second largest TV markets in size of audience. In San Francisco, which has a large homosexual population, the program averaged a 41 per cent share of the audience, according to Eisenberg.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Wounds 10 Others With Birdshot After Basketball Snub
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager snubbed by youths playing basketball at a schoolyard returned with a shotgun and sprayed the group with two blasts of birdshot, wounding 10, police said Monday. The group, which included two junior-varsity players from Edison High School, was playing Sunday outside an elementary school when a stranger asked to play but was told he couldn't, witnesses told police. The teen-ager left, but soon returned, riding in the passenger seat of a small van. The van slowed as it passed within 20 feet of the court and the teen-ager fired a shotgun twice into the group, the witnesses said. Police were looking for the youth but had little to go on, said spokesman David Rivero. ``It's shocking,'' said Dorothy Jackson, grandmother of one of the wounded players. ``Where can these boys go now if they want to stay out of trouble? They can't even go to the school.'' None of the injuries were serious. All 10 were released after hospital treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leader Defends Stamp Rates
DOC.TEXT: The head of the union representing mail carriers came to the defense of higher postage rates Monday, a day before the Postal Service was expected to announce plans to raise the price of a stamp. ``A stamp today, in terms of real dollars, is cheaper than it was in 1971,'' said Vincent R. Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers. The U.S. Postal Service has scheduled a Tuesday news conference, at which it is expected to announce plans for a rate increase affecting all classes of mail. The new rates would take effect sometime in 1991, probably including a 30-cent price for first-class stamps. Currently, the first-class rate is a quarter. It cost 8 cents to mail a first-class letter when the current postal service was set up in 1971. Adjusting for inflation since then, the cost should of a stamp now should be just what it is, 25 cents, Sombrotto said. But, he added, in 1971 the postal service received several million dollars in tax subsidies that have been eliminated. If that value were included, stamps should be selling for 33 cents today, Sombrotto said. Sombrotto said he anticipated that a planned rate increase will renew discussions of turning the postal service over to private business, or allowing private companies to compete in mail delivery. ``It would be an absolute disaster'' if that were to happen, he said. The postal system is designed to provide service to everyone in the country at the same price, he said, contending that private companies could choose to serve only profitable urban areas, leaving the costly rural deliveries to the postal service. That would mean either higher costs for rural residents or taxpayer subsidies, Sombrotto said.

DOC.HEAD: Spelunker Rescued After Falling 30 Feet in Caving Accident
DOC.TEXT: A man was rescued from a cramped, wet cave Monday 16 hours after he fell 30 feet from a ledge and suffered lacerations and broken ribs. More than 75 rescuers worked through the night to extricate Aaron Howell, 20, from the cave on private property about five miles west of Bloomington. Howell, of Franklin, and two friends entered the cave Sunday morning. He slipped off the ledge about three hours later. Jeff Schepper, one of Howell's spelunking partners, said Howell fell about 30 feet and was unconscious for about 10 minutes. Schepper went for help but it took him about two hours to find his way out of the cave. Paramedics and cave rescue workers found Howell conscious and coherent about 1,300 feet inside the cave Sunday night but had to use hand chisels and mallets to clear a path to him at the base of the ledge. ``It was all hand labor; they didn't take any specialized tools in,'' said Capt. Paul Spicer with the Van Buren Township Fire Department. ``It's very low,'' Paquette said. ``It's rocky. We have deep pools of water. There's a lot of obstacles they have to get through,'' said Don Paquette of Bloomington Grotto, a cave exploration group. Paramedic Jeff Rogers, who spent about six hours with Howell in the cave, said Howell was uncomfortable but in good spirits throughout the rescue. The temperature in the cave was estimated at about 53 degrees. Howell was finally removed from the cave about dawn Monday. He was listed as stable at Bloomington Hospital with multiple lacerations and rib fractures. Hospital spokeswoman Beth Maxwell said he also suffered hypothermia and dehydration.

DOC.HEAD: City Tossed by History Still Retains Charm
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: On a hill overlooking the center of Vilnius, three tall, white crosses stand in simple defiance to history. Hidden by locals to prevent destruction by the Soviets in the late 1940s, the stone crosses were brought out again last year and given their former place of prominence. The crosses are emblematic of the city of about 400,000 people that is surrounded by low wooded bluffs and bisected by the green-gray ribbon of the Nera River: Vilnius has learned to survive foreign conquest and re-emerge with its essential character intact. Today, as electric trolleys whoosh along its stone-paved streets past colorful kiosks and centuries-old churches, Vilnius presents an attractive face in contrast to the gray monotony of other Soviet cities. As the capital of Lithuania, the Baltic republic incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940 and now struggling to restore its sovereignty, Vilnius finds itself at the center of a peaceful rebellion against Soviet control. The Lithuanian Communist Party officially broke ranks with Moscow in December and multiparty elections on Feb. 24 brought to office what will be the Soviet Union's first non-Communist-dominated parliament. Its first duty will be to lead Lithuania back to full independence. Despite the momentous changes, the city seems curiously calm and rancorless, as though it would not be wise to get too excited just yet. On the spring-like day last month when the voting took place, townspeople lounged in Lenin Square, reading books or chatting with their grandchildren. At the center of the park stands the 30-foot-tall statue of Lenin, but his oratorical posture seemed out of place with the relaxed mood around him. If Lithuania follows the rest of Eastern Europe, the Lenin statue may not be standing much longer and the Communist Party will find itself on the sidelines. ``The situation is not yet ripe for the Communists to leave, but in the long run, yes, they will go,'' said Kastas Kumstys, a student sharing a park bench with his girlfriend. They had voted earlier in the day for a professor from the Sajudis independence movement, but Kumstys said he had no illusions the situation would quickly improve. ``My parents had Stalinism and now we have a time of everything overturning,'' he said. ``I don't think it will be better soon.'' What most people talk about is not the elections, but the terrible state of the shops. On otherwise elegant Gedimino Street, where a huge placard proclaims ``A Lithuania without sovereignty is a Lithuania without a future,'' scores of Saturday shoppers lined up for small green oranges being unloaded from moldy boxes marked ``Cuba.'' Elsewhere in the market, barriers kept people back while workers filled a stand with grapefruit. When the barriers were removed, shoppers raced to the stand, elbowing aside each other as they greedily grabbed for the citrus. At a music store up the street, the only records being offered for sale were Comecon music: LPs from Czechoslovakia, Cuba, Bulgaria and the Soviet Union. ``The kind of music I like, they don't have here,'' said a 20-year-old disgruntled shopper walking out the door. The young man spoke in Russian-accented Polish, one of the three languages of Vilnius. Lithuanian is spoken most, followed by Russian. But many residents are ethnically Polish and retain the language that dominated the city _ then known as Wilno _ when it was part of Poland from 1920 to 1939. Poland and Lithuania were united from 1386 to 1795 and its upper classes remained Polish into modern times. Marshal Jozef Pilsudski so loved his home town that he conquered it for newly restored Poland in one of the small wars that followed the collapse of the Russian empire in World War I. The nascent state of Lithuania was forced to set up its capital in Kaunas, 60 miles away, a fact Lithuanians have neither forgotten nor forgiven. After Poland fell in the early days of World War II and the Soviets annexed Lithuania, Vilnius was made capital of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic _ one of the 15 republics making up the U.S.S.R. A year later, the Nazis swept in. During a brutal occupation, they killed nearly all of the city's Jews. The partisan Polish Home Army drove out the Germans in 1944, but then came Soviet commissars who arrested the Poles in turn. After the war, Vilnius' damaged old town was lovingly repaired, including the 400-year-old Vilnius University, where the Polish faculty was deported to Poland and replaced by Russian professors. At Ostra Brama (The Pointed Gate), in the last remaining segment of the old city wall, Polish pilgrims come again to pray before the painting of Our Lady of Ostra Brama, which used to rank with Our Lady of Czestochowa as the most revered of Polish icons. A synagogue also remains and bakeries still sell round rings very much like bagels in addition to brick-like loaves of black bread, a local specialty. The mixture of cultures is what gives Vilnius its special charm, says a Lithuanian-speaking resident of Russian, Polish and Jewish descent who asked that her name not be used. ``Vilnius was always so,'' she said. ``It has always been a crossing of nations. There were four nations living here: Poles, Lithuanians, Russians and Jews. They lived here peacefully. ... Because of this Vilnius has this open, tolerant character.''

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica Wants Fugitive Rancher to Return, Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica's ambassador called on fugitive rancher John Hull on Monday to return to Costa Rica to face trial on charges ranging from aiding the Nicaraguan Contra rebels to alleged involvement in a terrorist bombing. Ambassador Danilio Hernandez stood up in the middle of a news confernece called by friends of Hull to declare: ``He should be tried by the courts of Costa Rica, not by the press or by his friends.'' ``Mr. Hull is a (naturalized) Costa Rican citizen and therefore he is subject to Costa Rican law,'' Hernandez said. ``He has been accused; the investigation has been carried out.'' Hull, 70, had been scheduled to appear at the news conference to discuss plans to sue people he contends fabricated the evidence on which the Costa Rican charges are based. Associates said Hull was seriously ill and recovering from recent heart surgery in Indiana, his home state. Gus Breene, who identified himself as a former test pilot who has investigated charges against Hull, said the suit would seek several million dollars in damages and would be filed within the next few weeks in a federal court. He would not name either the likely defendants or Hull's lawyers. Hernandez said a request for Hull's extradition to Costa Rica is moving through that nation's legal system, but indicated it might be months before it is ready to be filed. The ambassador denied accusations Hull has made that he was denied medical attention for more than 50 hours after his arrest. ``That is not true,'' Hernandez said. Hull, in comments read by Breene, denied the charges against him and contended they were based on perjured statements. Breene said Hull has told him he intends to return to Costa Rica and face the charges ``as soon as his health is repaired.'' Among other charges, Costa Rica wants Hull to stand trial for allegedly planning the bombing of a news conference being held in a house in La Penca, Costa Rica, on May 31, 1984, by Eden Pastora, a Contra commander who had defected from the Sandinista cause. An Amercan reporter, two Costa Rican journalists and a a Nicaraguan rebel were killed. Pastora and about a dozen other people were injured. ``We're going to prove all of this is made up,'' said Hull's 18-year-old son, John Jr.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Delays Race Slaying Trial To Find Missing Witness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with judge reversing order and agreeing to delay. Picks up 7th graf, `A second ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge today reluctantly agreed to a month's delay in the trial of four young white men accused of killing a black teen-ager. The prosecution had sought the delay to find a missing witness. Judge Thaddeus Owens had first ruled that jury selection should begin today as scheduled. ``If you can't move the case, that's your problem,'' he told the prosecution. But he changed his mind less than an hour later after prosecutors insisted they were not ready to proceed. ``I have no choice,'' Owens conceded. ``The law is clear on that.'' He set a new trial date of April 2, a date which he said was ``written in stone.'' Prosecutors announced last week that an important witness was missing and said that if he were not found by today they would seek an adjournment. The four defendants are among seven young white men who are charged in the slaying of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, who was surrounded and killed Aug. 23 after he ventured into the predominantly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to look at a used car. Zistrict Attorney Charles J. Hynes had said the disappearance of John S. Vento would not ruin the rosecution's case. ``Obviously, you want as many building blocks as possible, but without him we'll be able to proceed to trial,'' he said earlier. Privately, though, prosecutors said the setback was a severe blow, and defense lawyers _ who had pressed for an immediate start of the trial _ maintained the disappearance would seriously affect the prosecution's case. A second blow to the case came when it was revealed several days ago that another key prosecution witness, Gina Feliciano, a woman who has been under police protection since the attack, has entered a drug rehabilitation center. The judge was expected to empanel two juries to simp,waneously hear testimony against two sets of defendants. Lawyers on both sides said Vento, 21, has admitted participating in the attack and maintains he saw a gun passEdXto the man accused of fatally shooting Hawkins in the chest. Vento was given a deal to testify; if he fails to surrender in the next few weeks, Hynes said he will void the plea bargain and charge Vento with murder. Authorities have described the killing as a racial attack sparked by a dispute between one of the defendants and accused ringleader, Keith Mondello, 20, and Miss Feliciano, a former girlfriend. As word spread through the mainly white neighborhood on the evening of the slaying that Miss Feliciano had invited black and Hispanic friends to her 18th bcrshday party, Mondello allegedly recruited several friends to take on what they saw as intruders. Police said the whites mistook Hawkins and his three pals, all black, for Miss Feliciano's guests and set upon them. As the gang of up to 30 whites surrounded the young blacks, Joseph Fama, 19, allegedly opened fire with a pistol. Hawkins collapsed on the sidewalk and died as members of the mob fled. Fama and five others have been charged with murder; a seventh defendant, Steven Curreri, 19, was charged with assault. The remaining three defEnants will be tried later. Miss Feliciano is considered a key witness by prosecutors who planned to call her to the stand to establish a motive for the attack and to identify gang members.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitution Charge Against Slaying Suspect Dismissed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0563 to fix cycle designation
DOC.TEXT: A judge Monday dismissed a misdemeanor prostitution charge against a man accused of killing 11 women. Arthur J. Shawcross was to be tried on a charge of patronizing a prostitute. But the prosecution did not want to proceed with the case because of the possibility that Barbara Mae Dodson, a key witness, would invoke the Fifth Amendment and refuse to testify about her alleged prostitution activities. The Monroe County district attorney's office also was concerned about generating publicity before Shawcross' murder trial, Abate said. Jeffrey Abate, an assistant district attorney, had asked that the prostitution trial be postponed until after the murder trial, but City Court Judge John Manning Regan had denied the request. Shawcross' attorney, David Murante, opposed the dismissal of the charge, saying the trial would have been an opportunity to test Dodson's testimony. Dodson gave police a statement on Jan. 3 detailing two alleged encounters she had with Shawcross. Shawcross was arrested the next day on the prostitution charge, and subsequent questioning led to his being charged in the slayings, which occurred during the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman Atwater Collapses During Speech; Hospitalized
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf, Atwater, just ... to UPDATE with spokeswoman doubting dieting a factor; CORRECTS 10th graf, Presidential spokesman ... to CORRECT `White House' to `hospital'
DOC.TEXT: Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, fainted while speaking at a fund-raising breakfast today and was rushed to a local hospital, a spokeswoman said. Atwater recovered immediately after he collapsed at the podium, said Leslie Goodman, RNC communications director. Atwater, just back from the West Coast where he accompanied President Bush to several GOP fund-raisers, recently has been on a special liquid diet. Ms. Goodman said, however, that Atwater was not now on a diet and she did not believe it was a factor in his collapse. Atwater is a frequent jogger. One aide said Atwater had been using a diet food sold in powder form in grocery and drug stores and designed to be mixed with milk. The aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said however that Atwater had lost little weight on the diet because he frequently supplemented its milkshake-like regimen with regular high-calorie foods. Ms. Goodman said Atwater was not a strict adherent of any diet. She said that he had encouraged ``everyone who wanted to'' at the RNC to go on a voluntary diet. ``It was Lee's suggestion that we be lean and mean for the 1990s, and that the only thing we were going to lose this year was weight.'' Atwater told a reporter last week that he was no longer using a liquid diet supplement, and recentlty had gained several pounds. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that Atwater told the White House that he expected to be released soon from the hospital. On the issue of a liquid diet, Fitzwater said: ``How can he be on a diet? He only weighs 25 pounds.'' Ms. Goodman said that Atwater, 39, had not been ill and that his collapse was a ``total surprise.'' He was being kept at George Washington Hospital for tests. Atwater was attending a fund-raising breakfast for Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel. ``He was in the middle of a speech,'' Ms. Goodman said. She said that a doctor at the event ``immediately attended to him'' and that an ambulance was quickly summoned. ``He is up and about at the hospital, but he is going to remain there to undergo a series of tests,'' she said. ``We don't have any more information. He's coherent. He knows what's going on,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolians Express Resentment of Decades of Soviet Domination
DOC.TEXT: Mongolians are showing resentment of the generations of domination by Moscow that began when their country followed the Soviet Union to communism in the early 1920s. Growing anti-Soviet feeling is expressed in many ways, from heated exchanges between Mongolian journalists and Soviet diplomats to a hissed ``Russkie!'' when a Mongolian driver mistook an American for a Russian. Soviet influence has been strong since the founding of the Mongolian People's Republic. When its two neighbors, China and the Soviet Union, parted over ideology in the 1950s, Mongolia sided with Moscow. A foreign reporter who had spent five years in the Soviet Union described Ulan Bator, Mongolia's capital, as ``a typical Russian town.'' The Mongolian language is written in Cyrillic, the same script as Russian. Nearly all educated Mongolians speak Russian and almost all intellectuals studied in the Soviet Union, which has put a great deal of money into the vast pastoral nation of only 2 million people. Ulan Bator's debt to Moscow has been estimated by Western economists at the equivlalent of nearly $6 billion. In recent years, Mongolians have begun emerging from the Soviet shadow. Nationalism, which sometimes takes the form of anti-Sovietism, is growingre usually averages 32 percent or 33 percent in overnight ratings. DOC.HEAD: 309-Year-old Plantation Damaged During Hugo Reopens
DOC.TEXT: A 309-year-old plantation has reopened to tourists five months after Hurricane Hugo left $1.3 million in damage to the grounds and buildings. Hundreds of tourists and picnickers took advantage of Boone Hall Plantation's free admission Sunday to visit the attraction in this Charleston suburb. The plantation reopened Thursday to paying customers, but the fee was waived Sunday to thank those who helped in the rebuilding. ``We've done remarkably well to be this close to normal,'' office manager Jean West said. ``People have been wonderful about helping out. That's just one of the reasons for having a day like today _ to say thank you to the people who have been so kind.'' The plantation, a frequent filming site for Civil War movies, suffered an estimated $1.3 million in damage in the Sept. 21 hurricane. Nearly every building lost its roof, and all 300 acres of the plantation's timber and 80 percent of its commercial pecan grove were destroyed. In addition, its commercial cattle operation was halted because of the many downed fences on the estate. Plantation director William H. McRae said the commercial operations will not be resumed. Since Boone Hall was a ``working plantation'' before the storm, the closing of the pecan and cattle ventures will result in long-term income loss, but McRae said he hopes to find new revenue sources. The plantation was built in 1681 by Maj. John Boone, who was granted the land from the Lords Proprietors of England. The privately owned property has been open to the public since 1956 and receives more than 100,000 visitors a year.

DOC.HEAD: Once Docile Black Homelands Turn Rebellious
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the white government established black homelands in the 1960s, it saw them as the perfection of segregation and the ultimate answer to South Africa's racial conflict. Now those homelands, long ignored and usually docile, are turning on their creators. Some are becoming a force in the struggle against apartheid, South Africa's official policy of segregation by race. Military leaders who seized power Sunday in the Ciskei homeland left no doubt of their loyalties: They were flanked at their first news conference by officials of the African National Congress, the main black group fighting white domination. The coup ousted President Lennox Sebe, 63, one of several authoritarian leaders of homelands who have worked closely with South African security forces and suppressed anti-apartheid activists. Homeland leaders of Sebe's generation face increasing pressure from restless young activists who see the homelands as an attempt to restrict blacks to the most isolated and underdeveloped parts of the country. South Africa spends hundreds of millions of dollars annually to support the homelands, which have little industry or arable land. Brig. Gen. Oupa Gqozo, 37, who led the Ciskei coup, said he wants the homeland to relinquish its nominal independence and return to South Africa. ``The homelands are falling apart, unable to contain the accelerating rate of political change,'' the anti-apartheid newspaper Weekly Mail said in an editorial. ``Rising expectations for reincorporation in South Africa and long-running resentment against poverty have led to strikes, demonstrations and political violence.'' South Africa has 10 black homelands and has declared four of them independent since 1976, including Siskei. Their independence is not recognized abroad. About half of South Africa's 28 million blacks live in the homelands, which are scattered across the eastern half of the country and were established when Hendrik Verwoerd led South Africa as prime minister in the 1960s. Verwoerd sought to make all blacks citizens of the homelands, giving them local autonomy and leaving whites in control of the national economy and government. The rule of older, conservative, tribal chiefs in the homelands began to falter in 1987 when Gen. Bantu Holomisa, then 32, seized power in Transkei. Holomisa made overtures to anti-apartheid groups and favors a referendum on whether Transkei should relinquish independence and return to South Africa. He recently helped organize a huge rally for Walter Sisulu and other leaders of the African National Congress, which rejects the homelands and praised Holomisa as an anti-apartheid ally. Leaders of the Lebowa and KwaNgane homelands also have expressed support for the ANC. Since Holomisa began making changes in Transkei, rebellion has increased in other homelands. Among recent developments: _ Dissident army officers in Bophuthatswana held President Lucas Mangope hostage in February 1988 until the South African military intervened and restored him to power. In the past month, unrest has has cost six lives and injured dozens of people. Mangope rejects calls to return the territory to South Africa, and declared: ``We will be an independent state 100 years from now.'' _ Hudson Ntsanwisi, chief minister of Gazankulu, was not seen in public for several days during recent violence in which at least 10 people were killed. Students, workers and bureaucrats have conducted strikes or demonstrations in recent weeks. _ Civil servants have been striking in Venda and at least 18 people were reported killed, several in confrontations with authorities. _ In KwaZulu, supporters of Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the chief minister, are involved in a 4-year-old power struggle with anti-apartheid groups aligned with the ANC. Buthelezi sees the homelands as a step on the path to black majority rule. He opposes apartheid, but parts with the ANC over its support for guerrilla warfare, sanctions, boycotts and other confrontational measures. South Africa sent security forces into Ciskei to stop looting, but did not indicate Monday that it planned to restore Sebe, who was accused of widespread corruption. The South Africans have not tried to intervene on behalf of other homeland leaders threatened by unrest. President F.W. de Klerk has not renounced any aspect of the homeland system or taken a position on returning the areas to South Africa. He has said, however, that the homelands will be welcome to take part in negotiations on a new South African Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds IRS Ruling Denying Tax Exempt Status to All-White School
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Tax Court has upheld an IRS order denying a tax exemption to a South Carolina private school on grounds it discriminates against blacks. ``The absence of either a single black student in the school or a plausible explanation of inability to attract black students permits an inference of discrimination, particularly in view of ... (the school's) history,'' the court held. The decision, made public Monday, means that contributions to Calhoun Academy in St. Matthews, S.C., are not deductible. Chief Judge Arthur L. Nims III held that although Calhoun had adopted a racially non-discriminatory policy, the school had failed to operate under that policy. ``We cannot conclude that non-discrimination in ... operations is more likely than discrimination,'' Nims wrote for the court. Calhoun, organized as a not-for-profit corporation Dec. 30, 1969, offers classes for grades kindergarten through 12. The school has never had a black pupil or teacher. Two black parents requested and were given application forms for enrollment in 1984-85, but a black teacher has never applied for employment. Since 1982, at least one pupil of Oriental background has been enrolled in Calhoun. The only non-white teacher, a Japanese-American, was hired in 1983, court records showed. The school amended its charter in 1985 and began advertising that it did not discriminate. It applied to the Internal Revenue Service for a tax exemption in 1986. The IRS denied the exemption, citing the fact that Calhoun was formed at a time of enforced desegregation in area public schools, its total lack of black pupils despite blacks being a majority in Calhoun County and its failure to announce a policy of non-discrimination until 1985. At a later meeting, the IRS suggested that Calhoun improve its contacts with the black community and offer reduced tuition for black pupils. A director of the school rejected the reduced-tuition suggestion, saying it would result in unequal treatment on the basis of race. In siding with the IRS, the Tax Court cited a 1983 case in which the Supreme Court had stripped a tax exemption from Bob Jones University after finding that it discriminated on the basis of race. The Supreme Court held that racially discriminatory schools violate fundamental public policy and cannot be viewed as conferring a benefit on the public. ``From the record before us,'' Nims wrote, ``it appears that white students and their parents gravitate to petitioner (Calhoun) at least in part because of a historical absence of black students: Petitioner admits that the local public schools are superior in material respects, yet considerably less expensive. ``Petitioner's survival would thus depend to some extent on perpetuating its history,'' the court ruled, adding that such discrimination would clearly preclude a federal tax exemption.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Waves Caution Flag at Proposal to Expand Health Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis W. Sullivan said Monday that a $66 billion plan to expand federal health care benefits could backfire like last year's failed Medicare catastrophic coverage program. ``Good intentions can have unintended consequences, particularly if they carry a high price tag,'' Sullivan told the House Select Committee on Aging. His comments were directed at recommendations last week by the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, known as the Pepper Commission in honor of its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. The commission _ made up of 12 members of Congress and three White House appointees _ recommended a broad expansion of benefits to the uninsured and those who need long-term care at home or in nursing homes. The plan would cost the federal government $66 billion and private businesses $20 billion in increased contributions to employee health plans. The commission did not specify how the government would pay for the new benefits. Sullivan called the commission's recommendations ``one contribution to the public debate over desirable health policy goals'' but said the administration was awaiting reports from several other panels that also are looking at health issues. Sullivan said he hoped the administration would have its own recommendations by this fall. ``I want to be sure that as I go forward with recommendations to the president that they are recommendations that will stand the test of time,'' Sullivan said. ``We do not want another catastrophic outcome on our hands, and my concern is that the $66 billion price tag on the Pepper Commission's proposal could result in just that,'' he said. Congress last year repealed the Medicare catastrophic program, which offered expanded health benefits to 33 million elderly and disabled individuals, after some older Americans complained that the benefits were too expensive and in many cases duplicated their private insurance coverage. Noting that the Pepper Commission's recommendations on long-term care were adopted on a divided vote, Sullivan said ``there clearly is not yet a strong concensus for those programs.'' He also expressed concern about the added costs to business under Pepper Commission plan, saying the new requirements ``could have very adverse effects on businesses as well as their employees as well as on national competitiveness.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than 360 Lebanese Detained in Europe with Forged Visas
DOC.TEXT: More than 360 Lebanese fleeing their war-battered country have been detained at Rome and Brussels airports with forged visas to the Netherlands, aviation officials in Beirut said Monday. More than 300 were being held at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci Airport and 60 at Brussels' Zaventem Airport after a Dutch immigration officer ruled their visas fake, preventing them from continuing to Amsterdam, the officials said. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the detainees were mostly young men and their families who have lost hope that Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war will end. The latest round broke out Jan. 30, with more than 750 people killed and thousands wounded in the fight between renegade army Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia under Samir Geagea for control of the Christian enclave. Those held in Rome traveled during February from various Middle Eastern points, including Beirut, the Syrian capital of Damascus and the Cypriot town of Larnaca, the officials said. The Brussels detainees were stopped by police when they arrived on a Middle East Airlines jetliner on Feb. 28 with fake visas to the Netherlands, the Lebanese aviation officials said. Italian and Belgian authorities have reached no final verdict on what to do with the detainees. A Belgian magistrate ruled he airline should cover the expenses of the group in Brussels, according to the officials. In Italy, the case prompted the authorities to impose a fine of about $1,100 on any carrier for every passenger brought in with a forged visa. The decision has not retroactive, the officials said. They said Belgium warned the airline in January for carrying 32 passengers bound for Stockholm, Sweden, via Belgium because they asked for political asylum when they arrived in Brussels. Their passports and visas were found to be fake and they remain under arrest in Brussels, the officials added. Lebanese police have said racketeers have been tricking thousands of desperate Lebanese into buying false visas at up to $1,200 per visa. They said these rackets operated in Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors, as well as east Lebanon's Bekaa valley and the main Palestinian base at the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp in the southern port of Sidon.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
DEATH PENALTY
The court overturned a key portion of North Carolina's death penalty law in a decision that might invalidate the sentences of the state's 85 death row inmates. By a 6-3 vote, the justices set aside a North Carolina murderer's death sentence, reaffirming a decision that makes it easier for capital case jurors to consider all ``mitigating evidence.'' The court also gave state prosecutors greater leeway in what they tell juries choosing life or death for convicted murderers, voting 5-4 in a separate case to uphold a California man's death sentence. And in a third death-penalty ruling, the justices split 5-4 in ruling that an Oklahoma murderer is procedurally barred from contending that a jury wrongly was told to ignore ``sympathy'' before it sentenced him to death. The cases are McKoy vs. North Carolina, 88-5909; Boyde vs. California, 88-6613; and Saffle vs. Parks, 88-1264.
CHALLENGES
The court used the case of a South Carolina death row inmate to limit the ability of criminal defendants to challenge their convictions in federal court. The court, in a 5-4 decision, upheld the conviction of Horace Butler, sentenced to die for the 1980 murder of Pamela Lane. The court refused to apply retroactively a 1988 ruling that bars police from questioning a suspect about any crime once the suspect has invoked his right to have a lawyer present. The case is Butler vs. McKellar, 88-6677.
QUESTIONING
The court ruled that even when police question criminal defendants in violation of their right to legal help, the responses may be used to contradict trial testimony by the defendants. By a 5-4 vote in a Michigan case, the court said the Constitution does not bar the use of such statements when they are used by prosecutors to rebut a defendant's testimony and impeach the accused person's credibility. The case is Michigan vs. Harvey, 88-512.
IRAN CLAIMS The court, ruling in a case stemming from the 1981 settlement of the Iran hostage crisis, rejected an appeal by a Cleveland, Ohio, company seeking to avoid paying $3.6 million to Iran. The court, without comment, let stand what was described as a first-of-its-kind ruling that American courts have authority to enforce such payments. The case is Gould Inc. vs. Iran, 89-1103.
MIND-ALTERING DRUGS
The court agreed to decide whether Louisiana officials wrongly are giving a convicted murderer mind-altering drugs just so he can be executed for his crime. The justices said they will study the case of Louisiana death row inmate Michael Owen Perry, convicted of killing his parents and three other relatives. The case is Perry vs. Louisiana, 89-5120.
PILOTS
The court refused to hear an appeal by 661 pilots who say their seniority rights were violated after Delta Air Lines acquired Western Air Lines. The court, without comment, let die the pilots' lawsuit against Delta and the Air Line Pilots Association. The case is Herring vs. Delta Air Lines, 89-1119.
KISMET
The court refused to alter the fate of a 14-year-old copyright dispute over songs from the play ``Kismet.'' The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that awarded about $1.2 million to the writers and copyright holders of the play from MGM Inc. The case is MGM vs. Frank Music Corp., 89-1269.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Demands Settlement of Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict
With AM-Soviet-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature Monday directed two feuding Caucasus republics to start negotiations toward settling the ethnic conflict that has killed hundreds of people in two years of unrest. The Supreme Soviet returned to the emotional theme that has added a constant undercurrent of tension to its deliberations on a day during which a lack of a quorum frustrated efforts to take up a law on property ownership, one of the key aspects of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reforms. If approved, the law on property would break Soviet socialist tenets by allowing private individuals to own means of production and hire workers. A final draft presented Monday also dropped a preamble that declared socialist property ``the foundation of the social-economic system of the Soviet Union.'' Instead of using the long-hated term of ``private property,'' the measure instead calls it the ``property of citizens.'' Legislators approved a directive written on the dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan by its Presidium, or executive body, on a vote of 298-20 with 45 abstentions after a debate punctuated by pleas for reason and angry shouting by Armenian deputies. Supporters and opponents of the directive agreed it would not solve the key problems of the region, but they differed on whether it was a step forward. ``Every passionate speech is one more letter in a death sentence for a living person,'' said deputy Nikolai Medvedev of Lithuania, speaking in support of the directive. Armenian deputy Lyudmilla Arytyunyan told reporters all 14 Armenians present voted against it. Armenians say Azerbaijan has lost the moral right to rule the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh territory, and demand that it be taken from Azerbaijan and placed under national jurisdiction, she said. Control of predominantly Armenian Nagorno-Karabakh is at the center of the dispute between the two republics, but the directive said nothing about Nagorno-Karabakh. Asked about Medvedev's plea, she said: ``I would like to ask, `Is it better to live on your knees or die standing up?''' It gave the Interior Ministry, which controls the police, the KGB and the two governments, two months to report back on who was responsible for ethnic attacks on Armenians in Baku, Azerbaijan, in mid-January that killed scores of people and led the Kremlin to send in soldiers. An angry Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, who presided over the session, told legislators it was a ``shame'' to show on the daily delayed TV broadcast that they could not muster a quorum to debate the property law. Some of the missing lawmakers were occupied by Sunday's election to local and republic governing councils in Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia, he said. Two-thirds of the 542 members of both houses of the Supreme Soviet, or 361 members, must be present to pass legislation. On Monday morning, 346 were present, and that swelled to 364 when Lukyanov brought the 34-article bill up for an item-by-item vote. But then only 352 deputies voted on the first item, and Lukyanov gave up further consideration of the bill until Tuesday. It was brought to the Supreme Soviet two weeks ago, just after the Communist Party declared that individuals should be allowed to own factories and other means of production. Legislators found it too vague and sent it back for more committee work. The new draft strengthens provisions allowing individuals to hire others, long prohibited by Soviet socialism as exploitation, as long as they are provided adequate wages and benefits. Yuri Kalmykov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet committee on legislation, told legislators the committees rejected a specific mention of private property in the law because Soviets cannot agree on what it means.

DOC.HEAD: White House Doesn't Expect Imminent Release of Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Monday that there are no grounds for expecting the imminent release of American hostages in Lebanon, though ``there is a lot happening'' in behind-the-scenes efforts. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said many people _ excluding U.S. government officials _ are involved in discussions around the world on behalf of the hostages. The intermediaries include businessmen, diplomats of other countries, representatives of the hostage families and their employers and people who have contacts in Iran and Lebanon, he said. Often, they represent themselves as representing the United States, ``but that is not the case,'' Fitzwater said. ``Many of them have had contacts with the U.S. government,'' he said. ``They have told us what they are doing, they have asked us for advice. ``When all this comes out later, I don't want it said they were working for the U.S. government. ... They've gotten advice and comments and so forth, so there is a lot happening. ``I don't want to be discouraging,'' he said. ``I want to be encouraging. We want as many people to be helping on this as possible.'' However, Fitzwater emphasized that the United States ``will make no concessions in return for the hostages' release.'' ``We cannot say that there is any movement,'' he said. ``We know of no imminent release.'' Fitzwater underscored that the United States is ready to talk directly with Iran about the hostages ``whenever Iran is ready to do so.'' So far, he said, Iran has not shown any interest. Iran is believed to exert considerable influence over Hezbollah, an umbrella group of Shiites believed to hold some of the Americans in Lebanon. Fitzwater said that no U.S. government officials were speaking with Iran about the hostages. Asked what the administration said to intermediaries who want to work on the hostages' behalf, Fitzwater said: ``We give them our policy and we say, `No deals. If you can be helpful, fine, but keep in mind, this is our policy _ no deal.''' Fitzwater told reporters that if the United States becomes involved in talks about the hostages: ``We'll try to keep you informed of talks. I suspect they would be public, but you never know.'' Eighteen Westerners are being held in Lebanon. They include eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Most are believed held by Shiite Moslem factions loyal to Iran. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Speculation about their release has been fueled by a spate of stories about contacts in the Middle East about the hostages. For example, a Syrian source said Mahmoud Hashemi, a senior Iranian envoy, met Sunday in Damascus with Farouk al-Sharaa, Syria's foreign minister, ``to coordinate efforts between the governments of Syria and Iran to gain the release of all the hostages.'' The source said Hashemi, the brother of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, had arrived from Beirut, where he met with senior Shiite Moslem figures on the hostage issue. Another source said: ``This appears to be a serious effort, the first in some time, to end the hostage ordeal. ... But I don't think we'll see anyone out tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Witness, Defense Attorney Clash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony. Picks up 2nd graf, `Any captain...'.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecution witness against Joseph Hazelwood clashed angrily today with a defense attorney who suggested the witness had been coached to give opinions damaging to the skipper of the Exxon Valdez. William Milwee Jr., an expert in salvaging grounded vessels, shouted, ``They didn't tell me to say anything,'' as attorney Michael Chalos attacked his testimony. Milwee has said that Hazelwood was reckless in his maneuvering of the grounded tanker after it rammed a jagged reef. He has said Hazelwood risked capsizing the ship by trying to run it off the reef. Chalos produced a letter from prosecutors to Milwee which suggested facts supporting those opinions. The letter was dated before Milwee wrote his report in the case, but Milwee said he formed his opinion independently. The interrogation came as the prosecution prepared to close its case against Hazelwood. Defense lawyers were marshalling expert witnesses to show the nation's worst oil spill was an accident, not a crime. ``Any captain that was ever involved in a grounding or a collision could be in the defendant's chair if a maritime accident were a crime,'' said defense attorney Michael Chalos. Chalos, who said Hazelwood was feeling better after a bout with the flu, said the defense planned to call about 10 witnesses. The prosecution was expected to rest today or Tuesday. Defense witnesses will range from experts in matters of the sea to ``fact witnesses'' who saw Hazelwood on the day his ship grounded. They will seek to show that his actions do not support felony and misdemeanor charges. ``These are not criminal acts,'' the lawyer said in an interview Sunday. ``This is a maritime accident.'' Chalos said an expert in computer simulations will show jurors conclusively that the Exxon Valdez voyage would have ended safely if crew members followed the skipper's orders for navigating through a narrow passage into Prince William Sound. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was absent from the ship's bridge when the 987-foot tanker went aground on jagged Bligh Reef last March 24. The prosecution claims he was reckless and has charged him with a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could receive up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The three issues which the prosecution has raised and which the defense must address are Hazelwood's alleged intoxication, his departure from the bridge 10 minutes before the accident and his alleged recklessness in trying to move the tanker off the reef after the grounding. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound, killing thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife and coating hundreds of miles of rocky shore with black goo. Chalos sees the alcohol issue as ``the keystone'' of the prosecution's case and suggests there is no conclusive proof Hazelwood was intoxicated. ``If they can't prove intoxication, it's a very flimsy case,'' he said. An expert in alcohol toxicology was expected to be the prosecution's climactic final witness, and the defense will answer with its own expert, interpreting Hazelwood's blood alcohol reading of .061 in a test 10{ hours after the grounding. Does this indicate alcohol consumed hours before the ship sailed or possible drinking after the ship grounded? No one has said, and not a single witness has described Hazelwood as appearing drunk. The charge of recklessness hinges on Hazelwood's actions after the grounding. Prosecution witnesses have accused Hazelwood of recklessly risking his ship and the lives of crew members by trying to run the tanker off the reef. The defense insists he never tried to get off the reef and said Exxon's salvage master will support that point in testimony. But even if Hazelwood did try to move the tanker, the defense says, it would never have budged. ``The prosecution's own experts have said conclusively that it couldn't move,'' said defense attorney Thomas Russo. To find Hazelwood guilty of recklnessness, Russo said, the jury must believe there was a substantial risk the skipper ignored. ``There was no risk because it couldn't move,'' Russo said. ``If you can't commit the crime, there is no crime.'' Of course, only one witness can say exactly what the captain had in mind on the fateful night, and that is the captain. Will he testify? ``We haven't decided that yet,'' said Russo, ``and we won't decide it until the very end.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korea to Buy Soviet Enriched Uranium
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday approved a plan that would allow the state-owned Korea Electric Power Corp. to import enriched uranium from the Soviet Union for nuclear power plants, an official said. The decision cleared the way for South Korea and the Soviet Union, which have no diplomatic relations, to begin cooperation in nuclear power. The power company will import 40 tons of uranium each year for 10 years. Other details of the agreement have not been worked out yet, but one power company official, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said the price of the Soviet uranium would be set at between $600 and $700 per ton, almost half of what the company is paying now. In return, South Korea will make nearly 30 percent of its payments to the Soviet Union in electronic consumer goods such as televisions and computers. South Korea buys most of its uranium ore from Australia and Canada and has it enriched in the United States and France. South Korea pays $1,060 per ton for the enriched uranium, officials said. South Korea has nine nuclear power plants in operation and two under construction. It plans to build three more by 1998. South Korea is the world's 10th largest producer of nuclear energy and generates nearly 50 percent of its electricity in nuclear power plants. Despite a lack of diplomatic relations, the Soviet Union and South Korea have expanded economic and cultural ties recently. Trade between the nations totaled $700 million in 1989 and is expected to rise to $1 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Most people won't recognize her name, but Helen Stearns collaborated on several songs with her brother-in-law. The brother-in-law was Hoagy Carmichael, who composed such legendary songs as ``Star Dust,'' ``Lazybones,'' and ``Georgia On My Mind.'' He died in 1981. ``I loved to listen to him play,'' Stearns said. ``He'd be sitting there pecking around on the piano and he'd come up with a tune and say, `You're the writer. Give me some words.' So I did sometimes. We wrote a lot of songs together, mostly children's songs.'' ``April In My Heart'' was one of their best. ``I didn't think much about it at the time, but I still get small royalty checks for it from time to time,'' she said. Stearns, 82, was back in Carmichael's native state over the weekend in conjunction with a retrospective concert by the Indiana Symphony Orchestra. ``You know, there's something about Hoosiers that is wholesome,'' she said. ``No matter where they go or what they do, they carry it with them. That's what I remember about Hoagy. He was always wholesome in that odd Hoosier way. ``That, I guess, and his music were what I liked most about him.'' Stearns was one of the ``Barclay Girls'' who modeled for artist McLelland Barclay in the 1930s, wrote screenplays that included the hit 1937 movie ``I Met Him In Paris,'' and later worked as a newspaper editor in California and Maine, and as a writer, editor and publisher of children's books.

Jiang Xi Reng, best known for his portrayal of the lord chamberlain in the 1986 film ``The Last Emperor,'' is helping to organize a theater exchange program that was delayed by China's political crackdown. The exchange between the Children's Theatre Company and the Children's Art Theatre of Shanghai had been announced last spring. Jiang, a 30-year veteran of the Children's Art Theatre of Shanghai, will play the wizard Gandalf in the Children's Theatre Company's staging of ``The Hobbit.'' The production, directed by CTC artistic director Jon Cranney, goes into rehearsal Tuesday for an April 20 opening. In May 1991, Cranney and a team of designers stage the Theater Company's version of ``The 500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins'' in Shanghai. The Children's Art Theatre is the oldest children's theater company in China. It was established in 1947 by Madame Soong Ching Ling, wife of Sun Yat-sen, founder of modern China The exchange is an outgrowth of meetings that took place a year ago between Cranney and Jin An Ge, his counterpart with the Shanghai company. Plans were shelved, however, after the June massacre in Beijing against advocates of democracy, and the two artistic directors did not meet again until February. Plans for a joint production to tour China and Japan are incomplete. Because relations between the U.S. and Chinese governments remain strained, neither company has sought government assistance.

The first black Miss USA says she's not a ``stereotypical all-American winner,'' and being raised by a single parent on tough streets is a handicap that can be overcome. ``I had not the happiest of upbringings, but you don't have to become a statistic just because you grew up in a broken home,'' 20-year-old Carole Gist told reporters Monday. Miss Gist, of Detroit, dreams of setting up a fine arts institute for underprivileged children who, she says, are too often taught to think ``the only way you can get ahead now is in sports.'' She was chosen Friday from among 51 women competing for $200,000 in cash and prizes and the chance to represent the United States in the 38th annual Miss Universe pageant in Hollywood on April 15. A junior in management and marketing at the Northwood Institute, she said being black helped her ``stand out over all the blond, blue-eyed women there.'' But she said it was likely she was much different in other ways, too. Raised by her mother, she moved often and sometimes lived in rough neighborhoods. ``My home was broken into a lot,'' she said. ``When I was 5, I remember seeing a burglar in my home and I was frightened to death.''

Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, remained in fair condition Monday two weeks after her second liver transplant. Doctors said the 12-year-old girl's condition was upgraded from serious to fair Sunday at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Stormie, of White Settlement, Texas, received a new heart and liver at Children's on Feb. 14, 1984, to control a condition in which her cholesterol level was 10 times higher than normal. Doctors decided to implant a new liver Feb. 20 after Stormie's first transplanted liver was damaged by hepatitis caused by an unknown virus. Her donor heart was not affected by the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Requests Ruling on Arab Citizenship
With AM-Israel-Peace Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The religious affairs minister said Monday he had asked for a ruling on whether the government could revoke the citizenship of Arabs who petitioned the Soviet Union to halt the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel. About 4,000 Israeli Arabs have signed a petition sponsored by the pro-PLO Sons of the Villages saying the current wave of immigration is ``at the expense of the Palestinian people.'' Thousands of immigrants are arriving in Israel each month because of the Soviet Union's more liberal emigration policies. Zevulun Hammer, religious affairs minister and head of the National Religious Party, told army radio such protests were ``a blow to the heart of Israel,'' which was founded as a homeland for Jews. He said he sent a letter Sunday asking the attorney general to decide whether citizenship could be withheld from anyone ``who acts against the right of Jews to return to the Land of Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Defends Linking War Reparations with Treaty Guarantee
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Monday defended his demand that a guarantee of Poland's border be linked to Warsaw's renunciation of war reparations, saying Poland has been demanding compensation for forced laborers used in the Third Reich. In East Berlin, meanwhile, Communists and opposition parties agreed to submit a broad social charter to lawmakers in both Germanys designed to protect East Germans against social hardships once the countries merge under a capitalist system. The charter, adopted at weekly negotiations between the Communists and 15 opposition groups, demands that the right to work and the right to accommodation be enshrined in the constitution of a united Germany. It also calls for guarantees of democratic and humane working conditions, education and health services for all, protection of pensions, equality of the sexes, and social integration for the disabled. Kohl's refusal to give Poland guarantees about its border has led to a widening split with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and the two met privately Monday to discuss the issue. Results of the meeting were not made public. Genscher has been saying that West Germany must make clear to its neighbors that a unified Germany would not be a threat. ``This not only concerns Poland's trust, but that of all Europeans,'' he told the ZDF television network. Kohl has said he has no designs on land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's defeat _ about a third of modern-day Poland. But he has insisted that only the government of a united Germany could have final say on the matter. Kohl faces West German elections in December and is apparently concerned about losing the conservative vote. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has called on both Germanys to begin negotiations on a treaty that would recognize the Oder and Neisse rivers, which currently form the border, as the permanent boundary between Poland and Germany. On Friday, Kohl said such a treaty would have to be tied to Poland's 1953 renunciation of war reparations and of its pledge last year to protect the ethnic rights of its German minority. Kohl's demands produced astonishment in Warsaw and harsh criticism from politicians at home. The chancellor, trying to justify his demands, said Monday that since 1987, Poland has been raising the topic of compensation for Poles sent to Nazi labor camps during World War II. Kohl also said he would oppose signing a peace treaty as a means of settling the border issue. No World War II peace treaty was ever signed. In East Berlin, opposition minister Gerhard Poppe said the new social charter, once adopted by the East German parliament, should serve as the basis for East Germany's negotiations with its capitalist neighbor on economic, monetary and social union. He said the charter also would be presented to the West German Bundestag for discussion. According to the charter, unification should be based on ``reforming of both German social security systems, to perfect the positive points of both.'' Single parents, large families, pensioners and the disabled should receive special advantages, the document said. Delegates also urged guarantees to protect East Germans' personal property and savings. The proposed social charter comes less than two weeks before East Germany's March 18 elections for a new parliament. East Germans traditionally have viewed their social security network as the paramount achievement of more than 40 years of Communist rule, and they are nervous about what might happen to them under a capitalist system. Once efficient Western methods are introduced to East Germany's state-controlled industry, for example, the now-negligible unemployment rate in the country's 9 million-member work force could jump to as much as 15 percent. Rent prices also are likely to surge. East Germans in general know little about West Germany's social security network, viewed as one of Western Europe's most generous. The conservative Alliance for Germany, backed by Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, appealed to voters not to fear the switch to capitalism. East Germany's Christian Democratic Union chairman Lothar de Maiziere said difficulties in the transition were a direct result of years of Communist mismanagement. He pledged that the abolition of rent and food price subsidies would be compensated by an increase in personal income. Meanwhile, hundreds of disabled demonstrated in Leipzig Monday for the conversion of a Communist government hostel into a center for the handicapped, the East German news agency ADN reported. The agency said the demonstrators, many in wheelchairs, protested inadequate accommodation by waving banners that read ``Integration instead of isolation, rights not charity!'' The hostel is the only building in the city built with provisions for the disabled, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Apologizes For Police Detention of Young Black in Fatal Shooting
DOC.TEXT: The mayor said Monday he plans to apologize to the family of a young black man who was questioned in a manslaughter investigation that has prompted comparisons to Boston's infamous Stuart case. A white man has since been arrested. Although Mayor Mark Johnston said he would write a letter of apology, he insisted that police in this southern Maine town did nothing wrong and were not motivated by racism when they detained 19-year-old Jonathan Johnson as he returned home from school Wednesday. ``They did exactly what they were supposed to do _ look for a man fitting that description,'' Johnston said. It would be no different, he said, ``if it had been a large fat man with a balding head.'' An NAACP leader agreed that authorities had acted properly. ``When I first heard about this, the first thing that came to mind was the Stuart case,'' said Neville Knowles, president of the Maine chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``But after sitting down and talking with the chief and the deputy chief, it's my feeling that race didn't have anything to do with the actions of the Saco Police Department.'' In the Boston slaying of Carol Stuart, black men were randomly questioned by police on the basis of a false report by the woman's husband, who eventually was implicated in the killing and jumped to his death off a bridge. Johnson was questioned about the shooting death of 21-year-old Joseph Low after two of the white victim's roommates said a black youth had fired the fatal shot. A third roommate, who is white, was later arrested and charged with manslaughter. Detective Sgt. Michael Harriman said Johnson was detained for about an hour and 45 minutes before being questioned for about five minutes. He was then released. In the interim, police were interviewing two of Low's roommates, Lisa Catroppo, 17, and Simon Langdon, 20, Harriman said. ``As we continued the interview we came to realize that the story about the black man was bogus,'' the detective said. The two roommates later admitted they had fabricated the story and that no black man was involved, according to Harriman. Low's other roommate, 20-year-old Dana G. Harris, was later arrested on a charge of manslaughter and was being held in lieu of $25,000 cash bail, authorities said. Harriman said no charges have been filed against Catroppo and Langdon in connection with their initial report to police. He said the state attorney general's office was considering filing charges, but Assistant Attorney General Pamela Ames said no criminal prosecution was contemplated. Harriman said Johnson's mother had spoken to police when they arrived at the apartment to question her son and was ``very understanding'' about the situation. ``She could understand that her son happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time,'' Harriman said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Helps Single People From Farms Finds Mates, Fellowship
DOC.TEXT: Farmers often choose agriculture because it offers independence and wide open spaces. But singles isolated on the high plains and wind-swept prairies have found life on the land is lonely without love. ``What surprises me is the number of people in the 30s, 40s and 50s who've never been married,'' said Marcy Gahm, president of Singles in Agriculture. ``A lot stay on the farm with their parents, and when mom and dad die, suddenly they're really alone.'' Gahm said about 700 singles from around the country belong to the organization, which she founded four years ago. They meet regularly to share stories about their common bond. Many live and work on farms, especially in the Midwest; others who now live in town trace their roots to agriculture. They gathered here in the heart of the Cornbelt from Thursday through Sunday for the organization's fourth national convention. ``I started dating late in life and I live in an isolated area, so there is no way to meet people,'' said farmer and winemaker Jerome Hoelscher, 53, of Garden City, Texas. ``I was really uncomfortable when I attended the first meeting, but now I feel so at ease with all these people, it's hard to believe,'' said Hoelscher, who raises cotton, wheat and sorghum on his 1,700-acre farm in west Texas. Members pay $20 to join and $15 to $30 for a listing in the group's directory _ either by name or by confidential code. They meet at various places throughout the year _ camping in Arkansas, square-dancing in Ohio, boating on the Mississippi River. Some make no bones about it _ they want to get married.
