Others just enjoy being with people who understand them. ``I'm not interested in getting married, but I do like that macho, outdoor-type man _ strong, healthy and down-to-earth.'' said Nell Youngblood, a 62-year-old widow from Tulsa, Okla. Hoelscher said women with agricultural backgrounds understand the oddities of farm life _ things that might put off a woman from the city. ``The first thing they wouldn't understand is that you can't go a short distance to the shopping center or supermarket,'' he said. ``They'd miss being surrounded by a lot of other people.'' Farmers also have to work long hours, including Saturdays and Sundays sometimes. And, he said, farm wives often share the chores. ``She might wind up doing work with her hands that's not so attractive, getting dusty and cold,'' said Hoelscher. ``It's not a sheltered life like the city.'' It is a life that appeals to Debby Loveless of Mechanicsburg, Ohio, a 36-year-old divorced mother of two. ``I'd like to live on the farm again, but I'm very particular about men,'' she said. ``I haven't met anybody I want to spend the rest of my life with.''

DOC.HEAD: Artists AIDS Fund Raiser Comes to Washington
DOC.TEXT: The Artists Against AIDS fund-raising effort came to Washington on Monday, le by Elizabeth Taylor and artist Rubert Rauschenberg. The campaign is hoping to raise $1 million in Washington. Earlier efforts in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco have brought in $5 million so far, Miss Taylor said. ``The world is looking to the United States both to find a medical solution ... and to find a compassionate and caring response to those who are already afflicted,'' she said. ``Artists have to be the conscience of the country,'' said Rauschenberg, who announced the donation of a painting to help raise money. Rauschenberg has already donated art work worth $500,000, said Patricia M. Kluge, a leader in the local effort. Special stage performances, a public art exhibition and a gala fund-raiser are among the Washington events scheduled. Half of the money raised will go to the national research effort and the rest to local organizations dealing with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome victims in the Washington area, said Miss Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Court Overturns Key Portion of North Carolina Death Penalty Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 4 grafs new to update with N.C. atty gen's remarks; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Essentially.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today overturned a key portion of North Carolina's death penalty law in a decision that will invalidate the sentences of most of the state's death row inmates. By a 6-3 vote, the justices set aside a North Carolina murderer's death sentence, reaffirming a decision that makes it easier for capital case jurors to consider all ``mitigating evidence.'' ``The decision does not mean that any death row inmates will go free, but it does mean that as many as 70 convicted murderers must have new sentencing hearings,'' said North Carolina Attorney General Lacy Thornburg. ``It means in each case that another jury will be required to again decide the appropriate punishment.'' It was not immediately clear why the decision would not affect all 85 of the state's death row inmates. ``Essentially, the system that was condemned is the system we've been using since 1977 for sentencing people to death,'' said Raleigh lawyer Malcolm R. Hunter Jr., who represented the death row inmate involved in today's decision. ``It could have a very broad impact,'' Hunter said. The court also gave state prosecutors greater leeway in what they tell juries choosing life or death for convicted murderers, voting 5-4 in a separate case to uphold a California man's death sentence. And in a third death-penalty ruling, the justices split 5-4 in ruling that an Oklahoma murderer is procedurally barred from contending that a jury wrongly was told to ignore ``sympathy'' before it sentenced him to death. The court's decision in the North Carolina case probably will not affect any death row inmate outside the state, and the two other rulings are not likely to affect many of the some 2,200 death row inmates across the nation. In other action, the court: _ Ruled that even when police question criminal defendants in violation of their right to legal help, the responses may be used to contradict trial testimony by the defendants. By a 5-4 vote in a Michigan case, the court said the Constitution does not bar the use of such statements when they are used by prosecutors to rebut a defendant's testimony and impeach the accused person's credibility. _ Ruling in a case stemming from the 1981 settlement of the Iran hostage crisis, rejected an appeal by a Cleveland, Ohio, company seeking to avoid paying $3.6 million to Iran. The court, without comment, let stand what was described as a first-of-its-kind ruling that American courts have authority to enforce such payments. _ Agreed to decide whether Louisiana officials wrongly are giving a convicted murderer mind-altering drugs just so he can be executed for his crime. The justices said they will study the case of Louisiana death row inmate Michael Owen Perry, convicted of killing his parents and three other relatives. The court's decision in the California death penalty case is a defeat for Richard Boyde, who was convicted and sentenced to die for the Jan. 15, 1981, murder of Dick Gibson, a Riverside, Calif., convenience store clerk. Police said Boyde, then 24, was accompanied by his 19-year-old nephew, Carl Ellison, when abducting Gibson during a robbery that netted $33 in cash. Gibson was taken to a nearby orange grove and shot. Ellison also was convicted, and was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. Boyde had been convicted of robbing the same convenience store five years earlier, and had been implicated in at least four other convenience store robberies. The jury that sentenced Boyde was read a list of specific mitigating factors it could consider in choosing his punishment. Jurors also were told they could consider ``any other circumstance which extenuates the gravity of the crime even though it is not a legal excuse for the crime.'' Boyde's lawyers argued that the instruction prevented jurors from considering factors regarding his background and character that might have been found to be mitigating even if they did not lessen the gravity of the crime itself. The jury also was told it was required to impose a death sentence if it found that aggravating factors outweighed mitigating factors. Boyde's lawyers said the mandatory language prevented sentencing jurors from considering his case a whole. The California Supreme Court decided by a 4-3 vote in 1988 that Boyde had not been harmed by the challenged instructions. Neither instruction is still used in California, however. In upholding the state court ruling today, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote, ``There is not a reasonable likelihood that the jurors in (Boyde's) case understood the challenged instructions to preclude considerations of relevant mitigating evidence.'' Rehnquist was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens dissented. In the North Carolina case, the court set aside the death sentence of Dock McKoy Jr., convicted of the Dec. 22, 1984, shooting death of Anson County Deputy Sheriff William Kress Horne. Prosecutors said Horne was one of several deputies who responded to reports that McKoy was drunkenly shooting off his shotgun at his home near Wadesboro, N.C. Relying on its 1988 ruling in a Maryland case the high court said the jury that sentenced McKoy wrongly was limited in its consideration of mitigating factors because jurors were told they had to agree unanimously on the existence of each mitigating factor. ``North Carolina's unanimity requirement violates the Constitution,'' Marshall wrote for the court. He was joined by Brennan, White, Blackmun and Stevens. Kennedy wrote a separate opinion joining in the result. Rehnquist, Scalia and O'Connor dissented. In the Oklahoma case, the court never reached the merits of death row inmate Robyn Leroy Parks' challenge on an ``anti-sympathy'' instruction his sentencing jury received. Instead, Kennedy wrote for the court that Parks was procedurally barred from raising that argument after having exhausted his direct appeals in state courts. Kennedy was joined by Rehnquist, White, O'Connor and Scalia. Parks was convicted of the 1977 killin of Abdullah Ibrahim, a gas station attendant in Oklahoma City. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, by a 6-4 vote in 1988, threw out Parks' death sentence after it upheld his murder conviction. The appeals court said the instruction given to his sentencing jury undermined its consideration of ``mitigating evidence'' _ factors pointing to life in prison rather than death as the appropriate punishment. The presiding judge had told jurors, ``You must avoid any influence of sympathy, sentiment, passion, prejudice or other arbitrary factor when imposing sentence.'' The justices in 1987 upheld a California murderer's death sentence even though jurors in that case were told they should not be swayed by ``mere sympathy.'' The court said in the 1987 ruling that reasonable jurors would understand that instruction ``as a directive to ignore only the sort of sympathy that would be totally divorced from the (mitigating) evidence.'' Today, the court never answered whether the instruction given to the jury in Parks' case is constitutional. ``The relief Parks seeks would necessitate the creation of a new rule,'' Kennedy said, and such a decision generally cannot be made in a case that is not on direct appeal. The cases are Boyde vs. California, 88-6613, McKoy vs. North Carolina, 88-5909, and Saffle vs. Parks, 88-1264.

DOC.HEAD: Roe Messner Files For Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: A developer who has blamed much of his financial trouble on $15 million owed him by Jim Bakker's bankrupt PTL ministry filed personal and corporate bankruptcy reorganization petitions Monday. Both Chapter 11 petitions say Roe Messner of suburban Andover intends to propose a plan to reorganize his debts and continue in business. The Chapter 11 provision of federal bankruptcy law allows a debtor to forestall payments to creditors while coming up with a plan to pay them. Messner and his wife, Ruth Ann, and their companies, Commercial Builders of Kansas Inc., Messner Enterprises, Cloudridge Apartments and Meadows Plaza Shopping Center, were included in the filings. A list of assets was not included. Unsecured debt amounts listed in the personal petition include $750 million for a disputed court judgement in Greensboro, N.C., against Messner, Bakker and others; $8.7 million to a California bank; $5 million to a South Carolina savings and loan; nearly $4 million to a Wichita bank; $1.3 million to a Wichita savings and loan; and nearly $350,000 to the Internal Revenue Service. The Commercial Builders' petition listed debts totaling more than $2 million owed to 20 companies.

DOC.HEAD: World Conference Calls For Urgent Action Against Illiteracy
DOC.TEXT: Delegates opened an international conference on education Monday urging action to fight illiteracy and saying that the world can not develop with almost 1 billion people unable to read. ``How can we hope to advance on the road to freedom and democracy as long as one in three adults in the world remain illiterate?'' said Frederico Mayor, head of the U.N. Scientific, Educational and Cultural Organization. Mayor said that almost 100 million children in developing countries have no access to basic education, and in some impoverished nations 75 percent of the women are illiterate. But he said illiteracy also affects wealthy nations. ``Evidence ... suggests that between 10 and 20 percent of the population of so-called advanced societies lack essential basic skills of reading, writing, numeracy and problem solving,'' he said. Mayor was among the more than 1,200 government and non-government representatives from 155 countries at the World Conference On Education For All, the largest meeting ever held on education. It was largely sponsored by the United Nations. His call to fight illiteracy was echoed in speeches by Thailand's Princess Sirindhorn and Bangladesh's President Hussain Muhamad Ershad. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez De Cuellar sent a message to the conference saying that he expected the meeting to ``spur efforts towards drastically reducing illiteracy by the year 2000.'' The United Nations has declared 1990 International Literacy Year. The conference was held in Jomtien, a beach resort about 68 miles southwest of Bangkok. The U.S. delegation was headed by Thomas H. Kean, the president of Drew University and former governor of New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Espionage Probe Part of FBI Harassment Pattern
DOC.TEXT: The FBI's suspension of a Cuban-born agent in connection with a reported spy probe is part of a pattern of harassment against Hispanic agents, the man's lawyer charged Monday. Hispanic agents won a discrimination lawsuit against the bureau two years ago. Special Agent Fernando E. Mata, a 15-year veteran stationed in Miami who in 1983 received the Justice Department's top award for his counterespionage, has been placed on administrative leave and his security clearance has been revoked, said Antonio Silva, who represents Mata in the bias case. ``The case against Mr. Mata is a house of cards,'' Silva said. ``There is no substance whatsoever to the allegations. It is nothing more than reprisals and retaliation against him.'' The investigation involves Mata's alleged contacts with Cuban intelligence agents, The New York Times reported Monday, but Silva said that under a federal court order he could not confirm that. He did say that the FBI's case apparently relies on the disputed results of lie detector tests. In Washington, the FBI issued a statement saying it would be inappropriate to comment on the case. Mata's home telephone number is not listed. Silva, an El Paso, Texas, attorney who handled the 1988 discrimination case tried in that city, said the FBI initially looked into accusations against Mata in 1987 but dropped that investigation. Then, in August 1988, Mata testified in support of the lawsuit brought by 311 Hispanic FBI agents who charged they were discriminated against in hiring, promoting and disciplining. Silva said the old investigation suddenly resurfaced. ``The timing on this is just outrageous,'' Silva said. ``It had lain fallow for one year, and was resurrected two weeks after his testimony.'' The attorney said in the eyes of some superiors, Mata had violated what agents call the First Commandment _ ``don't embarrass the FBI.'' There has been a series of retaliatory charges against agents who testified in the lawsuit, he said, including three in San Antonio, one in Philadelphia, and one in Los Angeles. Silva also said there have been ``almost daily'' informal reports of other kinds of harassment. Some of the cases have involved accusations as serious as tipping off underworld figures or stealing confiscated money, Silva said. ``The difference in Mr. Mata's case is that it's coming from the upper levels of the FBI,'' Silva said. In November 1988, three months after appearing in court, Mata filed an affidavit with the court complaining he had been put under administrative inquiry for supposed security lapses during his trial testimony. Silva, and Mata's other attorney in the case, Hugo Rodriguez, also were investigated by the FBI _ a probe ordered halted by U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton, who presided over the bias case. In his trial testimony, Mata, 48, who has a law degree, said he was told he could not be a legal adviser for the bureau in Washington because of his dark skin and accent. He also said he was ostracized by his colleagues in Miami because he participated in a fund-raiser for the lawsuit. Bunton found the FBI had discriminated, and in May stripped FBI supervisors of the power to overrule decisions by the bureau's career promotion board. His order also set up a panel of three outside attorneys to decide if up to 200 Hispanic agents should be promoted to make up for past job discrimination. FBI Director William Sessions decided not to appeal the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope Wins Big at Charity Raffle
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope was unable to attend a charity event whose host was Jimmy Stewart, so he bought five raffle tickets at $1,000 apiece to help out. He pulled the grand prize, including a luxury car. ``Isn't that amazing? I never win a thing,'' Hope said from his desert home Monday, a day after learning he had won a $50,000 BMW, a set of luggage and a trip to Germany. Hope was performing Friday night in Port Arthur, Texas, and couldn't appear at the Beverly Hilton Hotel's ``An Evening of Elegance.'' He bought five of the 100 tickets sold for the benefit for abused and neglected children. It would seem the globe-trotting entertainer wouldn't need luggage or a free trip to Munich. He's made dozens of overseas trips to entertain U.S. troops over Christmas, including visits to Germany. ``You think you're kidding, don't you? I can use the luggage,'' Hope said. Asked what he would do with the car, Hope said: ``I don't know.'' ``I bought in at the last minute. I was late getting into it so I bought five $1,000 tickets,'' Hope said. When Stewart picked Hope's name, he said, ``You're not going to believe this. It's Bob Hope.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Officials See Little Gain in Japanese Talks So Far
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Monday the Japanese ``risk having our market closed or at least gravely limited'' if they fail to open trade barriers to American exports. Two key senators made similar comments, suggesting a protectionist trade war, as Bush administration negotiators admitted making ``little progress'' so far in cracking Japanese trade bars. The negotiators said that it is too soon to predict whether President Bush's weekend summit with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will produce results but that the Japanese now ``must move rapidly to provide solutions.'' Hills, answering questions after a speech, said, ``There's no question that Japan has gained its economic well-being from worldwide trade and worldwide investment.'' ``And if it fails to open its markets to the same extent to our entrepreneurs as our markets are open to Japanese entrepreneurs they risk having our market closed or at least be gravely limited, and therein risk killing the goose that laid their golden egg as well as ours.'' The senators, meanwhile, said there could be a trade war if Tokyo does not bow to U.S. demands in the ``structural impediments talks'' before the next economic summit in July in Houston. ``Anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States is rising fast,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. ``Japan has a choice. It can either follow the lead of the rest of the world and open its markets or it can keep its markets closed and have the rest of the world follows its lead.'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said the Bush administration ``has done nothing yet to warrant congratulations'' on getting Japan to open its markets, adding Congress will not accept a ``public relations job which attempts to buy us off.'' ``If we didn't go far enough in 1988, believe we can go farther,'' Danforth said, referring to the Trade Act two years ago calling for retaliatory steps if Japan does not lower is barriers to imports from abroad. Under Secretary of State Richard McCormack said U.S. negotiators avoided pressuring Japan in the first three rounds of talks in order to prevent the issues from becoming ``political footballs'' in Japan's parliamentary election last month. ``But at the next session (April 2 and 3 in Washington) the Japanese side must move rapidly to provide solutions to the problems we have been discussing for six months,'' he said. The negotiators, however, said there is no assurance that will happen, despite the mutual pledges by Bush and Kaifu at their hastily arranged meeting last weekend in Palm Springs, Calif., to redouble efforts on both sides. ``The basic question is whether the Japanese side sees this as a damage control exercise _ public relations _ or whether they see it as one requiring substantive effort,'' said Deputy U.S. Trade Representative S. Linn Williams. ``On that point, the jury is out,'' Williams told the Senate Finance subcommittee on trade, chaired by Baucus. ``Proof is in the results. It's too early for us to pass judgment.'' J. Michael Farren, the Commerce Department's under secretary for trade, said the U.S. trade deficit with Japan has improved by only $7.3 billion, less than 15 percent, since 1987 despite a 45 percent devaluation of the dollar against the yen. At the same time, he said, the U.S. deficit with West Germany has declined by half and with Korea, Taiwan and other East Asian countries it is down by 29 percent. While Kaifu last weekend promised Bush more action, during the election campaign last month he ruled out repealing a retail store law that keeps some U.S. companies out of Tokyo, Farren said. He also complained that Japan's trade minister has rejected revising anti-monopoly laws that allow ``collusion among Japanese firms'' to effectively bar U.S. steel companies access. ``Even more fundamentally,'' Farren said, ``there is an all-but-explicit underlying assumption that the Japanese surplus must be maintained ... as a hedge against anticipated oil prices increases. ``Which means,'' he said, ``that American workers will continue paying the insurance premium with the price being American jobs and a diminishing U.S. standard of living.'' John Taylor, a member of Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged the ``faster and further progress we seek has not materialized.'' But, he said it ``would be premature to pass judgement'' before the April round is concluded and a final report is completed in July.

DOC.HEAD: Three Officers Shot, One Reported Killed
DOC.TEXT: Three plainclothes members of a drug-fighting task force were gunned down Monday afternoon, killing one of the officers, authorities said. The shootings occurred at about 3:30 p.m. on Manhattan's East Side, according to police. The officers were in plainclothes, members of a Drug Enforcement Administration task force, which includes city, state and federal officers. Albert Scardino, spokesman for Mayor David Dinkins, said one of the three had died. Charles DeGaetano, a spokesman for the Emergency Medical Service, said one officer was in critical condition, apparently shot in the head, and the others were stable. All were taken to Bellevue Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term Interest Rates Highest Since September
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level since last fall. The Treasury Department sold $8 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.85 percent, up from 7.72 percent last week. Another $8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.79 percent, up from 7.70 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.88 percent on Sept. 5, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent on Oct. 2. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.12 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,801.60 and 8.22 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,606.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.14 percent last week, down from 8.19 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Humanities Endowment Head Nominated for Another Term
DOC.TEXT: Lynne Cheney, head of the National Endowment for the Humanities since 1986, will be nominated for another four-year term, the White House announced Monday. Ms. Cheney is the wife of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Her nomination must be confirmed by the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Chopper Crashes into Sugarcane Field During Test Flight
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Coast Guard helicopter carrying two crewmen crashed in a sugarcane field Monday during a test flight, but nobody was injured, authorities said. Police said the French-built HH-65 Dolphin helicopter narrowly missed roadside electrical wires before crash-landing seven miles southwest of Ramey Air Station on Puerto Rico's western coast. Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Alan Burd said the pilot and mechanic, the only two on board, escaped unhurt. The pilot was identified only as Lt. J. Durfey; the mechanic's identity was not divulged. Burd said the helicopter was on a ``routine test flight after an inspection'' and that cause of the crash was not known.

DOC.HEAD: Assessment Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Flue-cured tobacco farmers and buyers each will be assessed one cent per pound for the 1990 crop, the Agriculture Department said Monday. The total of two cents per pound will be assessed, down slightly from last year's total of 2.24 cents. The No-Net-Cost Tobacco Program Act of 1982 requires that the program operate at no net costs to taxpayers. Officials said they consulted with the Flue-cured Tobacco Cooperative Stabilization Corp., the producer-owned association that handles the support program, before determining the 1990 assessment.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adopts Law Restoring Turkish Names
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Monday adopted a law restoring names the 1.5 million ethnic Turks and other native Bulgarian Moslems had to forsake under a forced assimilation campaign launched by the old Communist leadership. Under the new law, all Bulgarian citizens can choose their own names without restriction. Some ethnic Turks are still unhappy with the law, which includes a clause that requires name changes to be approved by a court. About 3,000 Moslems held a protest vigil outside the cordoned-off parliament building Monday, saying they would not leave until they saw the law in writing. They were informed of the law's passage by Medyud Doganov, a Turkish leader, and two legislators. Also Monday, 30,000 miners and other workers were on strike in several regions, according to the opposition newspaper Demokratsiya. Workers at 26 mines went on strike last week, alleging the government has not kept its promise to increase their pay and improve working conditions. Ethnic Turks and other Moslems were forced to take Bulgarian names in an often-violent assimilation campaign authored by Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, who was deposed in November. Most of Bulgaria's 9 million people belong to the Bulgarian Orthodox Church. The name law became the centerpiece of the parliamentary session after other reform items were shelved, partly because they had not been discussed with the opposition. Talks between the Communist government and opposition were suspended three weeks ago over disagreement over political and economic reform. Communists in Bulgaria, unlike those in other Soviet bloc countries, have retained much of their clout in national politics. On Sunday, Moslem and opposition leaders appealed for people to stay away from Sofia, fearing clashes between Moslems and Bulgarian nationalists, some of whom oppose any concession to Turkish or other minority groups. The assimilation campaign was marked by protests and violence. In the past two years, authorities violently suppressed ethnic Turkish unrest over the policy that denied them religious and other minority rights. Amnesty International said 100 people died. Last year, about 320,000 ethnic Turks emigrated to Turkey after Zhivkov granted them passports. Turkey had to close its borders to stem the influx it said it could no longer handle. Since then, more than 150,000 Turks, facing poor housing and a lack of jobs in Turkey, have returned to Bulgaria, only to find their jobs forfeited and their homes occupied. The new Communist government led by moderate of Andrei Lukanov has so far failed to complete an emergency economic program badly needed to revamp the wobbly economy or to implement promised political reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Sees $8 Billion Cut in Defense Budget
DOC.TEXT: A senior member of the House Armed Services Committee predicted Monday that Congress will try to slash more than $8 billion from President Bush's $292 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991. Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, who also serves on the House Budget Committee, questioned Army officials on what impact a significant reduction in the president's spending blueprint for the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1 would have on their service. ``I don't like to play a `what if' game,'' Leath said. ``If we hold the cut to $8 billion, some (members of Armed Services) would feel some kind of victory.'' Leath suggested that if such a cut were made, the Army might be faced with a reduction of $3 billion to $4 billion from the proposed total. ``It would be devastating if we took that kind of cut,'' said the Army chief of staff, Gen. Carl E. Vuono, who predicted that personnel and readiness expenditures would bear the brunt of the cuts. Reducing the size of the forces _ not spending on major weapons programs _ would result in the quick savings many members of Congress expect from the defense budget with the Soviet threat to the West diminishing but the deficit increasing. ``You would be back to fracturing the force and I don't use that term lightly,'' Vuono told the House Armed Services Committee. But Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services panel, said the $8 billion is ``not far off of what's being kicked around.'' The committee chairman suggested that Vuono and Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone start planning on restructuring the force to reflect the expected congressional cuts. The fiscal 1990 defense budget calls for an increase from this year's $286.8 billion in outlays to $292 billion _ a 2 percent reduction after adjusting for anticipated inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Cost of Luxurious Living up 6.4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: New Yorkers hungering for a taste of the good life had to shell out 6.4 percent more dough last year than in 1988, in part because of a 28 percent jump in the price of caviar, according to a survey released Monday. The annual survey, commissioned by Moet & Chandon champagne, tracked the cost of a dozen luxury items and services in New York City, and found they went up in price last year faster than the 4.6 percent rate of the government's Consumer Price Index. There were a few relative bargains for the well-to-do, though: the price of a man's Rolex watch remained the same as it was in 1988 _ $11,700 _ and a pound of imported chocolate truffles was still $36. The fee for a wash, cut and blow dry at a leading Manhattan hair salon actually decreased, from $70 to $65. But Dom Petroff Russian caviar rose 27.7 percent to $60 for 30 grams, up from $47. The next biggest rise was one day of maid service, up 13.6 percent to $100, from $88. Among the other items measured were a ticket to the Broadway show ``Cats'' (up 10 percent to $55), a bottle of Hennessy X.O cognac (up 10 percent to $87), a round-trip ticket between New York and Paris on the Concorde (up 8.9 percent to $5,308), and a Rolls-Royce Corniche III convertible (up 5 percent to $215,800).

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: For 31 years, Felix Itz has been driving to work as Runnels County surveyor, taking field notes and searching courthouse records. He got the job at age 69. About 170 people gathered at the American Legion Hall for Itz's 100th birthday party Sunday. Asked to describe his lifestyle, Itz, a man of few words, said: ``I'm just piddling around.'' He also was reluctant to give away secrets on longevity. ``I haven't passed on yet,'' he told the Houston Chronicle. The secret could be in his genes. His father lived to be 88 and his mother to 92. Both his maternal grandparents made it into their 90s. Itz plans to remain on the job until his current four-year term expires on Dec. 31. ``Grandma always complained that he worked too hard,'' granddaughter Nancy Simpson said. Itz's wife of 67 years, Zelma, died in 1981. His son, Milford, 73, and 87-year-old baby sister, Cora Lehne, are both retired. Itz has been hospitalized just once: to have gallstones removed in 1985. After two weeks, he was back on the job. He actually retired once, from the state highway department in 1958, but soon tired of idleness. He ran for the county surveyor's job at the age of 69 and has held it since, without opposition.

One woman ate a dozen cockroaches. Two others covered themselves with syrup, coconut, almonds and chocolate to look like Almond Joy candy bars. With $10,000 on offer, no stunt was too bizarre. Radio station KKBQ offered the prize to whoever could carry out the most outrageous stunt. And a dozen contestants were willing. One woman shaved her shoulder-length hair and let people sign their names on her head, and a man shaved his underarm hair, topped it with shaving cream and ate the mixture. Two women showed their love of hot dogs by sitting in a small pool filled with wieners and spraying ketchup and mustard over each other. But the grand prize went to 19-year-old Colin Thiele, who covered his body with honey and chicken feathers, jumped into a pool of pig poop and bobbed for apples and carrots. ``I faxed the idea to the radio station and I didn't ever think it would get this far. And yes I would do it again,'' said Thiele. ``For $10,000, it's hard to turn down.''
DOC.HEAD: A longer version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three sisters on the same team can be confusing enough, but it's beyond confusion when they're identical triplets. ``It's really funny,'' said Bonnie Collins, who's on the same track team as her sisters, Betty and Bobbie. ``People will look at us and say, `Look here, they all have ...''' ``` ... the same faces,''' chimed in Bobbie and Betty. The sisters look so much alike it's tough even for family members to tell them apart. ``We probably don't sit still long enough,'' Bobbie said. Being good sisters is what makes them strong, Betty said. ``I think God put us here as triplets to be stronger than if we were born a year apart instead of only five minutes. I think he had a plan for us.'' Bonnie agreed and said that being triplets also is a case of strength in numbers. ``With 10 older brothers and sisters, it would've been hard for one girl to be the only youngest,'' she said. The triplets are Iresse Collins' 11th, 12th and 13th children, and although they are 21 years old, their mother still calls them her babies. ``We've been through the same stages of life together _ acting stupid, puberty, college and boyfriends. And we're still friends,'' Bonnie said. ``That's what's best. Being best friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Turned Back to Norfolk Because of Bomb Threat
DOC.TEXT: An USAir DC-9 returned to the airport shortly after takeoff Monday because of a bomb threat, an airline official said. Flight 195, carrying 14 passengers and a crew of five, was turned around because of remarks by two people who approached the gate as the plane was preparing to take off, said Susan Young, a spokeswoman for USAir in Arlington. They demanded that the plane be brought back so they could board, Ms. Young said. When the couple was told that was impossible, ``they made remarks to the effect that `you'll bring it back,' and some comments about a bomb in their luggage,'' Ms. Young said. By then, the plane had taken off. USAir officials in Norfolk recalled the plane, which landed without incident around 2:45 p.m. The plane was taken to a remote part of the field, and one piece of luggage was taken off, said Wayne Shank, the airport's deputy executive director. The passengers also were taken off, he said. The two people who made the comment were turned over to authorities, Ms. Young said. ``Any type of joking about any type of bomb on board is a federal offense and taken very seriously,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Recalling Microwave Soup
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. has voluntarily recalled 24,000 packages of its Microwave Chunky Beef Soup because the soup was not heat-processed and could contain harmful organisms, the Agriculture Department said Monday. ``Although no illnesses have been reported, we strongly urge consumers to avoid opening or tasting the product,'' said Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. The microwave soup was made in the company's Maxton, N.C., facility and distributed to retail stores in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Wisconsin. Some of the 24,000 packages also were distributed to the military, but the amount was not determined, said Jim Greene, a spokesman for Crawford. The soup was packaged in paper cartons, each containing one 9{-ounce microwavable plastic bowl with a ``metallized sealed lid,'' the announcement said. The suspected product is identified by a three-line code stamped on the side panel of the package. Only packages with the code ``Dec90, Est4R, CO9J'' are being recalled. The problem was reported to USDA after company officials discovered that one day's production was not sterile and ``could allow the growth of organisms that cause illness, if those organisms were present,'' the agency said. Greene said there was a ``high probability'' the suspected product contains organisms that can cause botulism, a deadly form of food poisoning. None has been found in the product at this time, however, he said. Consumers with questions about the recall may call the toll-free USDA hotline at 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST, Monday through Friday. In the Washington metropolitan area, the number if 447-3333.

DOC.HEAD: Power Plant Worker Accused of Spiking Cooler With Radioactive Water
DOC.TEXT: A nuclear power plant worker was charged Monday with spiking a lunchroom cooler with radioactive water that eight men drank before the contamination was discovered. The eight who drank the contaminated water last month at the Point Lepreau plant have a slightly higher chance of getting cancer, officials said, but are in no immediate health danger. Daniel George Maston, 33, assistant operator at the plant bordering Saint John, was arrested Sunday in the incident, which at least one power plant worker said appeared to be a practical joke gone awry. Royal Canadian Mounted Police released few details of the investigation that led to Maston's arrest. During a court appearance Monday, Maston was charged with causing a noxious substance to be administered with intent to endanger lives or cause bodily harm. The charge carries a maximum penalty of 14 years in prison. The contamination was discovered Feb. 22 during routine urine checks of plant employees. Police officials said the day before, a glass of slightly radioactive heavy water was dumped into a 5.2-gallon cooler that provides water to a dispenser that mixes it into fruit juice. Heavy water is used to cool the power plant's reactor. It is not radioactive itself but the water is exposed to radioactivity from the plant's uranium fuel rods. Maston did not speak during his 10-minute appearance. Provincial court Judge Bill McCarroll ordered him held until he finds a lawyer and enters a plea Wednesday. The courtroom was crowded with other workers from the nuclear power plant, but only one, Trent Lamb, spoke with reporters. He described Maston as a ``quiet guy'' and said many Lepreau employees believe the water contamination was not malicious but a bad practical joke. Lamb was not among the eight who drank the tainted drink. Maston does not work in the control room of the power plant, officials said. He has been an employee of Lepreau for several years. Colin Nichols, president of the union that represents more than half the workers at Point Lepreau, refused to discuss Maston or the charge against him. But Nichols said the arrest has eased tensions. ``People are feeling a little more comfortable,'' said Nichols, head of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 2309. ``But there are still a whole lot of questions we all want answered about why someone would do this.'' The workers who drank the spiked juice, none of whom have been identified publicly, met Monday afternoon with a doctor who advises the Atomic Energy Control Board, which regulates the Canadian nuclear industry. The doctor was brought in to answer the workers' questions about their exposure, officials said. One worker was exposed to almost four times what is considered the annual safe limit of radiation, officials said. The others received lesser exposures. The annual limit of radiation for workers in the nuclear industry is set at 50 millisieverts. The average person is exposed to about three millisieverts a year, from the sun's rays and uranium on Earth. Under federal regulations, none of the eight will be allowed to work in areas of the generating station where they would be exposed to radiation for one year. ``Before, most people were very proud to say the worked at Lepreau but right now ... people are pointing fingers, making jokes about glowing in the dark,'' Nichols said. ``Our production record is world-class and all that goes out the window with this black mark.''

DOC.HEAD: Both Sides Look to Governor In Hawaii Labor Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Workers picketed 11 major hotels Monday as both sides awaited word on whether Gov. John Waihee would intervene in a 2-day-old strike. The walkout by 7,500 employees began early Saturday after negotiators for Local 5 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union rejected management's final offer. Economists have said the strike could badly damage the Hawaiian economy if it is lengthy and if news reports give potential visitors the impression that the state's tourist industry is paralyzed. The strike affects about one-fourth of the 37,000 hotel rooms in Waikiki, the state's prime tourist destination, and one-seventh of the 70,000 hotel rooms in the state, according to the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. The union has filed two unfair labor practice charges against the hotels, including one accusing management of refusing to bargain in good faith. ``Their charges are totally groundless,'' said William Crawford, executive director of the Council of Hawaii Hotels. ``We bargained in good faith all the way through.'' Management and union officials were waiting for a decision by Waihee, who was being briefed by his staff after returning from the mainland during the weekend. Waihee helped the two sides work out an agreement during 1987 contract talks. Hotels have continued to operate during the strike, using management to fill in at unionized jobs. Some hotel services have been curtailed. Crawford sharply criticized union leader Tony Rutledge, who encouraged union workers to exercise civil disobedience by engaging in sit-ins at the affected hotels, even if it meant getting arrested. No one has been arrested so far. ``I think that's very irresponsible of the union, making them criminals,'' Crawford said. ``That cannot have a productive effect on negotiations.'' Rutledge has been meeting with his staff to plan strategy to bring national attention to the dispute. ``We don't plan to lose,'' he said. ``If they (the employers) knew what I know and what we plan to do ... they would settle.'' Rutldge plans to extend the strike to non-union hotels owned by the same companies as the affected hotels. If the strike continues to next week, the international union will begin informational pickets on the mainland, he said. Hotel workers who do not receive tips now earn an average of $9.22 an hour, while tipped workers earn an average of $4.87 an hour. The union turned down a four-year contract that includes what management calculates as a wage-and-benefit package of 7 percent annually, but which the union calculates at 4 percent a year.

DOC.HEAD: Bikers Will Lead Funeral Procession of Jimmy Carter's Sister
LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: Gloria Carter Spann, the last surviving sibling of former President Carter, died Monday of the type of cancer that killed three other family members. She was 63. Mrs. Spann had been diagnosed in December as having pancreatic cancer, which killed her father, James Earl Carter; her sister, Ruth Carter Stapleton; and her other brother, Billy Carter. Her mother, Lillian Carter, had breast cancer that had spread to other organs, including her pancreas, when she died in 1983. Mrs. Spann, who lived on a farm southwest of Plains, died at Sumter Regional Hospital at about 1 a.m. She was with the former president and his wife, Rosalynn, several close friends and her husband, Walter Spann. Mrs. Spann, an avid motorcyclist, will be buried Tuesday at a graveside service at Lebanon Cemetery in Plains following a funeral procession led by fellow motorcyclists. All but Mrs. Stapleton are buried in the cemetery. Billy Carter's widow, Sybil, said the family is bewildered by the disease and hopes that scientists can learn more about it. ``It's very sad for all of us,'' she said. ``It's just something we don't understand. Our family is grieved and saddened.'' Carrie Harmon, a spokeswoman at the Carter Presidential Center in Atlanta, said the former president was issuing no statement about his sister's death. Carter will depart as scheduled on a Middle East trip later this week. As residents of her small farming community mourned Mrs. Spann's death, a group of about 10 fellow bikers, some in jeans and leather jackets, consoled her husband at the family farm. The Spanns were described by friends as private people who shunned the publicity that Carter's presidency brought to the south Georgia town of 600. A 6-foot wire fence protects the Spann's white frame house from unwanted guests. A sign posted at one of the gates says, ``Motorcycles Only.'' Spann, wearing a leather vest, dark glasses and with long, flowing gray hair, said his wife had requested the motorcycle procession. He and the other bikers gathered in the yard declined to be interviewed. A red Harley-Davidson motorcycle was parked nearby. Some of the bikers had beards, while some wore jackets and shirts with Harley-Davidson logos. A burly biker wearing a military-style beret stood a few feet from a reporter with his arms crossed over his chest, as if to protect Spann from unwelcome guests. In downtown Plains, tourists visited a Jimmy Carter museum in the railroad depot Monday and Mrs. Spann's cousin, Hugh Carter, chatted with visitors in his antique shop. ``She was a fun person, outgoing, smart and beautiful,'' he recalled. ``She had lots of friends. The mood everywhere is very sad.'' ``Everybody is concerned. We're going to miss her,'' said Walter Dozier, a neighbor. Mrs. Spann belonged to the Georgia Motorcycle Rights organization and was named Most Outstanding Female Motorcyclist in the nation in 1978. Just after her cancer was diagnosed, she said through a spokeswoman that she and her husband planned to ride their motorcycles to Florida for the weekend. She and her husband traveled widely by motorcycle and at one time she received an award for having biked 100,000 miles. Mrs. Spann was co-author of the book ``Letters from Home'' in the early 1970s, based on letters written by her mother while she served with the Peace Corps in India. Besides her brother and husband, Mrs. Spann is survived by a son, William C. Spann.

DOC.HEAD: Too Late to Appeal Using New Constitutional Rulings, Court Says
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court slammed shut the federal courthouse door Monday to fresh appeals by many convicted criminals, including death row inmates. In two 5-4 rulings, the court generally barred defendants from using new constitutional rulings to attack state court convictions after exhausting initial rounds of appeals. The justices upheld a South Carolina death row prisoner's conviction and reinstated the death sentence of a convicted Oklahoma murderer. The court's four dissenters and the American Civil Liberties Union denounced the rulings. The ACLU, in a statement signed by three officials, said the court has ``sent a clear signal that it will turn away and allow people to be executed in plain violation of the Bill of Rights.'' In the South Carolina case, the court upheld the conviction of Horace Butler, sentenced to die for the 1980 murder of Pamela Lane, a clerk at a Charleston-area convenience store. The court refused to apply retroactively to Butler's case a 1988 ruling that limits police questioning. The 1988 decision said police may not question a suspect about a crime _ the one for which he was arrested or any other _ once he asks for a lawyer. The 1988 ruling was foreshadowed by a 1981 decision banning a second round of police questions about the crime for which a suspect was arrested. Butler was in jail on a relatively minor charge and had obtained a lawyer's representation after refusing to talk to police. Police later questioned him about an unrelated murder, and Butler confessed. Butler asked a federal judge to throw out his murder conviction on grounds that, under the Supreme Court's 1988 ruling, his rights were violated by unlawful police interrogation. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said it was too late for the 1988 ruling to be of any help to Butler. Prisoners cannot rely on new high court rulings to overturn their convictions as long as the state appeals courts that upheld the convictions reasonably interpreted then-current constitutional rulings, Rehnquist said. He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. In a dissenting opinion, Justice William J. Brennan said the decision ``strips state prisoners of virtually any meaningful federal review of the constitutionality of their incarceration.'' ``After today, despite constitutional defects in the state processes leading to their conviction or sentencing, state prisoners will languish in jail _ and others like Butler will die _ because state courts were reasonable, even though wrong,'' Brennan said. He said that with Monday's ruling ``the court has finally succeeded in its thinly veiled crusade to eviscerate'' federal laws aimed at protecting criminal defendants' rights. Brennan was joined by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. In the Oklahoma case, the same five majority justices ruled that Robyn Leroy Parks is barred from contending that a jury wrongly was told to ignore ``sympathy'' before it sentenced him to death. But Kennedy wrote that Parks was barred from raising that argument after exhausting his direct appeals in state courts. Parks was convicted of the 1977 killing of Abdullah Ibrahim, a gas station attendant in Oklahoma City. At Parks' sentencing trial, the judge told jurors, ``You must avoid any influence of sympathy, sentiment, passion, prejudice or other arbitrary factor when imposing sentence.'' The justices overturned a ruling by the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that said the judge's instruction undermined the jury's consideration of ``mitigating evidence.'' The appeals court had said Parks should be resentenced.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Austerity Measures Provoke Strikes
DOC.TEXT: Employees occupied the national mortgage bank Monday, protesting the decision to close it in an austerity plan that includes mass layoffs to combat inflation averaging 80 percent a month. Teachers boycotted classes, disrupting the start of a new school year after the summer recess, and professors at the 27 national universities also were on strike. All seek higher pay. Court clerks, who have shut the federal court system twice in two weeks, planned to begin another pay strike Tuesday and doctors at municipal hospitals said they would walk out Wednesday. Banks and foreign exchange houses were closed Monday while the Economy Ministry put the finishing touches on measures to prop the austral currency, which has lost 99 percent of its value the past year. ``They are committing an error'' in shutting the bank that finances low-income housing, Juan Zanola, director of the powerful Bankworkers Association, said about the decision to close the mortgage bank. When banks reopen, the 150,000-member union may strike the other four national banks, including the Central Bank, as it did two weeks ago when the government announced a bank restructuring plan Zanola said. Real wages have shrunk up to one-half because of inflation, which was 79 percent in January and probably equal that in February. A recession has stalled business activity and forced one of every five adults out of a job or into part-time work. The austral has lost so much of its value that prices and wages are quoted increasingly in dollars. Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez said on national television Sunday night the government, which has played a central role in Argentina's economy for decades, is ``on the verge of bankruptcy.'' Public employees beyond retirement age will be dropped from payrolls, he said, and those within two years of retirement will be suspended with pay. Overtime will be curbed and vacancies will not be filled. Gonzalez estimated those measures, along with suspension of federal subsidies and deferral of payments to state contractors, would save $2 billion a year. He did not say how many public employees would be laid off or retired, but newspapers speculated tens of thousands might have to go. About one-fourth of Argentina's 12.5 million workers are employed by the government. The General Labor Confederation, with 3 million members Argentina's largest labor organization, said it was studying the government measures. It has criticized earlier versions and has not ruled out a general strike. Restructuring of the national banks is aimed at reducing losses that contribute to a deficit this year of about $70 billion, or 12-15 percent of gross national product. Because of poor lending and collection practices, the mortgage bank has run up a deficit of $1 billion with the Central Bank. Until now, the Central Bank simply printed money to cover such losses. A report last month in the newspaper Pagina 12, citing bank data, said the National Development Bank was owed $1.9 billion by its 60 largest debtors, including the state telephone, electric, coal, railroad and gas companies. Closing the mortgage bank and laying off public employees are seen as a test of the government's resolve to address the deficit without printing money. In past months, the government has announced plans to retire or transfer hundreds of employees of the state railroad, mortgage bank and Congress. It backed off in each case because of union opposition.

DOC.HEAD: PTA Blames Some School Problems on Parents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comments. Picks up 5th graf pvs `The most ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that parents must ``spark the flame of curiosity'' in their children but that the national Parent Teacher Association may have to supply the matches. The president's comments to about 250 PTA leaders at the White House came hours after the organization released a poll that found that fewer than half of those surveyed had visited their children's schools to participate in a back-to-school night or attend parent-organization meetings during the fall of 1989. Bush criticized parents for ``thinking of education as a service we can hand over to the school boards, much the same way we expect our cities to provide electricity or water.'' ``Education is not a utility. Education is a national mission that must include parents,'' he said, noting that a school program ``won't kiss away the pain from an injured knee'' or ``calm the fears of a child about to get a first shot'' or ``instill a lifelong love of learning.'' ``But parents can spark the flame of curiosity by reading to their children, every night,'' Bush said, adding that the 6.6 million-member PTA can provide the needed leadership. ``There is no organization in America that can reach as many schools and as many parents as you can _ not the state governments, not even the federal government,'' he said. Bush was accompanied by his wife, Barbara, who has made literacy one of her priorities. ``Many parents are doing only half their job when it comes to getting a good education for their children,'' national PTA President Ann Lynch said in releasing the poll. ``Too many (parents) sit at home and complain about the schools without ever setting foot through the doors to find out how they can help.'' The most common reasons for visiting schools included attending a scheduled parent-teacher conference, which 71 percent had attended, or class or school program, which 64 percent had attended. The survey, commissioned by Newsweek magazine for the national PTA and Chrysler's Dodge Division, was based on a national sample of parents in 538 households with children enrolled in kindergarten through 12th grade. Ninety percent of the children are in public school with 10 percent in either private or parochial schools. While school involvement was often low, the survey found most parents said they were very active in their children's education at home. Two of every three, 69 percent, said they discussed school topics with their children nearly every school day. More than half, 58 percent, helped with homework at least two to three times a week, and 52 percent read to or with their children at least once a week. More than half, 57 percent, said their own role was ``extremely influential'' in their children's learning. However, slightly more than half, 53 percent, of the parents surveyed were not involved in any kind of parent group. Many of those parents cited lack of time or work commitments as a deterrent to participation. ``We're all busy with work and family commitments, but it's amazing how we can find the time for things that are really important to us,'' said Ms. Lynch. ``A few hours or less a month is all it takes to keep in touch and help at the school.'' Among parents who are involved in parent groups, a large majority are more likely to help with fund raising, 80 percent, and extracurricular events, 72 percent, than to volunteer in classrooms, 52 percent, or participate in curriculum or policy-making, 33 percent. ``Parents tend to get involved in fund raising because it's easy and makes them feel as though they are doing something for their child's school,'' said Ms. Lynch, noting that parents also must work for better school funding and participate in school decision-making. The survey was conducted by ICR Survey Research Group in Media, Pa. between Dec. 29 and Jan. 7. The margin of error is plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Tibet Bans Tourists Until Mid-March
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Tibet have barred tourists until mid-March, when several dates important to Tibetans seeking independence from China will have passed, a Western tourist said Monday. The tourist, speaking on condition of anonymity, said tour agents at Chengdu in the southwest, the air gateway to Lhasa, had told travelers none would be allowed until March 15. She said the few tourists already in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, would be allowed to remain until the end of their planned stays. Lhasa has been under martial law since last year. Lhasa is in the midst of Moinlam Qenmo, an important 10-day prayer festival. Chinese authorities have called for increased vigilance and said that, if ``separatist elements dare to stir up trouble again, we will resolutely strike a heavy blow.'' Pro-independence Tibetans have fought security forces on March 5 in each of the past two years. Sixteen people were killed and more than 100 injured in three days of confrontation in 1989. China expelled all foreign tourists from Lhasa and imposed martial law in the city March 8 of last year. In 1988, 24 Tibetans died in anti-Chinese rioting, Western travelers reported. An unsuccessful uprising March 10, 1959, led to the exile of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader. Four times since September 1987, Tibetan demonstrations for independence have become battles in which Chinese police and soldiers opened fire on the crowds. China occupied Tibet in 1950 and claims it has been part of Chinese territory for seven centuries.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Moves Tracey Ullman to New Night, Puts Reporters on Hold
DOC.TEXT: In a mid-season schedule shift, the Fox television network said Monday it would air two new series, is moving ``The Tracy Ullman Show'' to Saturdays and is taking ``The Reporters'' series off until fall. Fox also cancelled the low-rated ``It's Gary Shandling's Show,'' whose self-deprecating star last month said the show would stop production this spring. Also Monday, cable TV's Lifetime network said it had bought rights to rerun the Shandling and Ullman shows. Lifetime said it would start repeats of Ullman's series in September, and Shandling's in June next year. The new Fox series are ``The Outsiders,'' an hour-long drama series co-produced by Francis Ford Coppola, the Academy Award-winning director, and ``In Living Color,'' a half-hour sketch comedy series starring Kennan Ivory Wayans. The latter series will premiere April 21, preceding Ullman's show on Saturday nights. Ullman's half-hour comedy series, which had been shown on Sundays, will shift to Saturdays starting April 7. ``The Outsiders,'' about growing up in the 1960s, will start in its regular Sunday time period on April 1, after a 90-minute premiere on March 25. Fox's ``The Reporters'' is a Saturday newsmagazine series with five reporters. It will begin a production hiatus on March 31, Fox said. Its executive producer, Gerald Stone, said in a statement the show has been on the air 20 months without a break, and ``we look forward to the chance to regroup and fine-tune ourselves, as well as get stories in the can for the fall.''

DOC.HEAD: White Surges as Richards Stumbles on Drug Question
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Unless Ms. ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with news conference; picks up 13th graf, `White, governor ...'
DOC.TEXT: With the gubernatorial primaries a week away, former Gov. Mark White is the sudden Democratic front-runner and state Treasurer Ann Richards is struggling after refusing to say if she ever misused drugs. On the Republican side, three contenders are trying to keep multimillionaire oilman Clayton Williams from winning the nomination outright without a runoff. After pumping more than $4 million of his own into a slick television ad campaign, the colorful Williams stood at 45 percent in a Dallas Morning News-Houston Chronicle poll published Feb. 25. If he wins 50 percent in the March 13 balloting, he avoids a runoff election for the GOP nomination to succeed retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements. Among the Democrats, Ms. Richards had been front-runner since entering the race in June, until White pulled ahead in the Feb. 25 poll, which showed him with 34 percent to Ms. Richards' 31 percent. State Attorney General Jim Mattox was third at 17 percent. Ms. Richards, who rose to national attention after her keynote speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention _ where she said George Bush was born with ``a silver foot in his mouth'' _ insists her refusal to disclose whether she's ever used an illegal drug isn't a problem. ``I have been tested by fire, and the fire has lost,'' said Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic. ``I feel truthfully that it has energized a great number of people who feel it is important to do and say what I am saying, and that is: If you need help, get help.'' But her opponents and others watching the race disagreed. ``Voters are more tolerant of that than lack of candor,'' George Christian, an Austin political consultant and former press secretary to President Johnson, said of drug use. The question arose in two debates that were televised statewide. White and Mattox said they had never used illegal drugs. Ms. Richards didn't answer the question directly. ``My addiction was alcohol,'' she said, adding: ``I have revealed more about my personal life, including my alcoholism and my recovery, for 10 years, than any person who has ever run for governor. ``By continuing to raise these questions I think that we are sending a very sad message to a lot of people who see that if they seek treatment they will forever bear the stigma of their addiction.'' The issue came up again at a news conference Monday. Ms. Richards again refused to say whether she had used illegal drugs, but did say she'd never knowingly commited a felony offense. Unless Ms. Richards answers the question, Republicans will make it an issue if she wins the nomination, her opponents said. ``It won't be pretty. It's a serious question,'' said White. Ms. Richards attacked White and Mattox on Monday for making her refusal to answer the drug question a campaign issue. ``No one has ever raised this question while I have been managing all of the money of the state of Texas,'' she said. ``The only time this question was raised was when I got in the way of those boys who want to be governor.'' White, governor from 1983 to 1987, has risen steadily in the polls since entering the race in November as he and Mattox have dueled over the death penalty and taxes. Mattox, who as attorney general has attended most of the 33 Texas executions since they resumed in 1982, has emphasized his crime-fighting record. His television commercials show him walking in front of prison bars. White responded with a chilling commercial that showed him walking beside giant photos of felons who were put to death during his term. ``Only a governor can make executions happen. I did. And I will,'' White said. Mattox and Ms. Richards have even become issues in the Republican race. Struggling to cut into Williams' staggering lead, rival Kent Hance has aired an ad focusing on the oilman's contribution of $1,000 to Mattox. ``Do we know the real Clayton Williams yet?'' Hance's ad asks. Williams also gave $200 to Ms. Richards. Williams, who is making his first bid for public office, insists his donations were made while he was a businessman and before he considered entering politics. Hance, a former Democratic congressman who sponsored President Reagan's 1981 tax cut legislation, is rnning a distant second to Williams with about 22 percent support, according to recent polls. The two other major contenders have earned most of the endorsements from the state's major newspapers. But both _ Tom Luce of Dallas, lawyer for billionaire H. Ross Perot, and former secretary of state Jack Rains of Houston _ remain in single digits in the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Intelligence Chief: Unit Plotted Killings, Harassment of Tutu
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 12th `De Klerk, who' with Malan denial. Picks up 13th `The defense...'
DOC.TEXT: Members of a secret intelligence unit planted bombs, were suspects in political killings and plotted to harass Archbishop Desmond Tutu by sending him a baboon fetus, an intelligence official said Monday. Gen. Rudolph Badenhorst, head of the Military Intelligence branch of the Defense Force, was the first witness to testify before a judicial inquiry into allegations of military and police participation in death squads. Opposition leaders claim the squads may have been involved in about 60 unsolved murders of anti-government activists in the past decade. Badenhorst said the Civil Cooperation Bureau _ a unit so secret that President F.W. de Klerk says he was not told of its existence until recently _ had blown up a Pretoria store owned by an anti-apartheid activist, exploded a bomb at a community hall in a mixed-race township near Cape Town and planned to deliver a baboon fetus to Tutu, an anti-apartheid leader and winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize. Badenhorst gave no reason for the plan to send the fetus. He said the idea was called ``Operation Apie.'' The intelligence chief said an internal military investigation begun in November revealed that prominent anti-apartheid activists such as black mineworkers leader Cyril Ramaphosa, the Rev. Frank Chikane of the South African Council of Churches and Jay Naidoo, general secretary of the nation's largest trade union federation, were on a list to have their movements monitored. He maintained that he did not know the bureau existed before November and he didn't know the purpose of the surveillance. The secret unit reportedly consisted of cells of civilians, mostly former policemen, in undercover operations against government opponents. An attorney for the Civil Cooperation Bureau said its chief, Col. Joe Verster, had been detained Friday for questioning by police who are investigating the 1989 assassinations of David Webster, a Johannesburg anthropologist, and Anton Lubowski, the only white executive member of the South-West African People's Organization in Namibia. Badenhorst confirmed that three former policemen wanted in Lubowski's death were members of the Civil Cooperation Bureau. All three disappeared last month after police in Namibia issued warrants for their arrests. Badenhorst said the Civil Cooperation Bureau was not involved in Webster's slaying. He said that during questioning by military investigators, Verster had seemed surprised at some of the activities of bureau members, and was especially surprised by the hiring of an ex-policeman, Ferdie Barnard, after he had been released from prison. De Klerk, who became president in August, said Defense Minister Magnus Malan did not tell him of the Civil Cooperation Bureau until January. Badenhorst told the commission de Klerk had not sanctioned any of the unit's activities. Malan said Monday he did not know the bureau existed until November. The defense minister has said he never authorized killings or other illegal acts, but he has come under increasing pressure from opposition parties to resign. In another judicial inquiry ordered by de Klerk, Supreme Court Justice Richard Goldstone ruled that Clayton Sizwe Sithole, identified by friends as the former boyfriend of Nelson Mandela's youngest daughter, Zindziwe, committed suicide in police custody on Jan. 27. Sithole had been arrested with others in a murder investigation, and after police interrogation he was found hanging by his shoelaces and belt at the Johannesburg police headquarters. Goldstone said there were no recent injuries on his body other than those associated with hanging.

DOC.HEAD: 45 mph Gusts Slow Shuttle Work After `Secret' Mission Ends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with wind speed, move up reference to hydraulic leak; picks up 5th graf pvs, `He said preliminary ...' ADDS one graf at end with Discovery being towed to assembly building in Florida in preparation for next shuttle mission. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gusts whipping the Mojave Desert on Monday prevented NASA workers from preparing the space shuttle Atlantis for its return to Florida after a not-so-secret four-day mission in space. ``It's a good day to fly a kite,'' said Atlantis processing director Conrad Nagel, as gusts reached 45 mph. The wind also delayed efforts to investigate the apparent leaking of hydraulic fluid that developed before the shuttle landed at Edwards on Sunday, Nagel said. Atlantis and its five-man crew landed on a dry desert lakebed after an officially classified mission reportedly to launch a $500 million spy satellite. The shuttle was to be hoisted into position Monday inside a 100-foot-tall steel trusswork so workers could prepare it to be mounted atop a modified Boeing 747 jetliner for a piggyback flight to Florida. But Nagel said the work would have to wait until late Monday because of the wind. He said preliminary inspection revealed possible hydraulic fluid leaks in three parts of the shuttle, but added that they hadn't posed any danger in Sunday's landing and probably weren't a safety issue. The shuttle has three redundant hydraulic systems that operate shuttle steering during re-entry. Inspectors for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration also found 62 heat-shield tiles with ``dings,'' including one that probably will be replaced. But Nagel called the damage insignificant and said Atlantis was in excellent shape. Nagel said he had hoped Atlantis would be ready for the flight to Florida on Friday, but the wind-related delay meant the trip would be Saturday. Had the winds come earlier, they could have delayed Sunday's landing. The shuttle's launch last Wednesday from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida had been delayed five times by weather, a computer glitch and the sore throat of the commander, Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The next shuttle flight is scheduled for April 12 when Discovery is to begin a five-day mission to deploy the $1.55 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Discovery was towed Monday to the vehicle assembly building at Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NASA spokeswoman Pat Phillips said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: President Of Cyprus Lobbies Congress
DOC.TEXT: The president of Cyprus pressed congressional leaders Monday to help break deadlocked negotiations over his country's future. President George Vassiliou said that his discussions went ``very well. ... It was very productive, very useful.'' Vassiliou flew to Washington on a private visit after U.N.-sponsored talks on the future of Cyprus collapsed last week. U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called off the negotiations that included both Vassiliou and Rauf Denktash, the leader of Cyprus' Turkish community. The island nation in the Mediterranean has been divided since 1974 when the Turks invaded the island. Turkey maintains roughly 35,000 troops on the island although only 18 percent of the population lives in the Turkish section. The island's president met with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., as well as with House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., the panel's ranking minority member, and Sens. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., and Larry Pressler, R-S.D. Vassiliou was expected to see national security adviser Brent Scowcroft late Monday. Vassiliou said in a brief interview that he would like to see a ``more clear-cut policy on behalf of the administration and Congress to help bring an end forever ... to this problem that has been with us so long.'' Broomfield said Vassiliou had ``won a lot of support in Congress'' for his efforts, and the Michigan Republican criticized Denktash for not ``acting in good faith'' at the U.N. talks. He said he favored cutting military aid to Turkey until Ankara pressured Denktash to adopt a more conciliatory negotiating stance. While Broomfield doubted Congress would take such a drastic action, he said members would work with the Bush administration to see if it could be more forceful in prodding the parties toward reconciliation. Pressler predicted that Congress would take an initiative, perhaps in the form of a resolution, ``to try to get the talks with the Turks off dead center.'' The Bush administration has followed the lead of the U.N. secretary general in trying to bring about a peaceful resolution to the conflict on the island, a State Department official said. A spokesman for the Turkish-Cypriot office in Washington, was out of the office and unavailable for comment about the negotiations involving the island.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: I've Never Used Marijuana
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo said Monday he never tried marijuana because he was ``busy doing other things, like playing ball and studying.'' ``It was never part of my environment,'' said the 57-year-old New York Democrat during the taping of a weekly radio interview. But Cuomo, considered a potential 1992 presidential contender, said ``that doesn't mean anything. That doesn't make you good or bad.'' The governor's comment came during an interview for Albany radio station WAMC's weekly ``Capitol Connection'' when he was asked about some Massachusetts politicians who have recently admitted to having tried marijuana. ``People are free to confess if they feel they should. That's fine by me, if they wish to,'' said Cuomo. Nonetheless, Cuomo said ``politicians should discourage a practice of everybody stepping forward and confessing everything they ever did, because then you construct a new category. When does it end? Did you ever shout at your wife, et cetera, et cetera.''

DOC.HEAD: Storm Brings Snow And Wind To The West
DOC.TEXT: A storm packing gusty winds spread up to a foot of snow over sections of the West on Monday after coming ashore from the Pacific Ocean over the weekend. The snow was expected to move onto the Plains overnight. Winter storm watches were in effect through Tuesday for northeastern Colorado, the Nebraska Panhandle and southwestern and south-central South Dakota. By early Monday, up to 11 inches of snow covered the northern mountains of Utah, and more than a foot of snow had fallen across some higher mountains in Nevada. A high wind warning was posted for north-central and northeastern Arizona, where Show Low reported gusts to 70 mph late in the morning. Snow also spread across Montana, Wyoming, Colorado and New Mexico. In southwestern Wyoming, 5 to 8 inches of snow fell at Evanston and Kemmerer during the morning, and Lander got 4 inches of snow in about two hours. Ahead of the snow, light showers fell over the southern and central high Plains. Light showers also were scattered from northern Missouri and southern Iowa to the upper Ohio Valley. Snow fell across southern Lower Michigan during the night. Up to 4 inches were reported around Detroit. Afternoon temperatures were mostly in the 60s across the southern Atlantic Coast, the central Gulf Coast states, and from the southern Plains and lower Mississippi Valley to the lower Missouri Valley. Readings were in the 70s across southern Texas and the Florida Peninsula. Lows only in the teens and single digits were reported from the Dakotas to New England. Below-zero readings were reported in Michigan and northern Maine. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 12 below zero at Warroad, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers, Rebels Killed in Fighting; Judges Stage Protest Strike
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas ambushed a military patrol in an eastern jungle and 15 soldiers and seven rebels were killed in a dynamite blast and the ensuing battle, an army general said Monday. Colombia's judges and judicial employees, meanwhile, declared a one-day strike to protest the killing last week of a criminal court justice and her bodyguards, a spokeswoman for the judicial workers' union said. Leftist insurgents belonging to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia Sunday exploded more than 100 pounds of dynamite on a road as two army trucks carrying 40 soldiers drove by, Gen. Jaime Neira said in an interview broadcast by the Caracol radio network. The attack occurred near San Jose de Ocume, a town 257 miles east of the capital Bogota. The explosion destroyed one of the trucks and killed 13 soldiers. Two more died as they received medical treatment Monday, Neira said in a telephone interview from his office in Villavicencio, the eastern city where region's brigade is based. He said seven rebels were killed in fighting after the blast. The troops had been patroling as part of a government security plan to try to guarantee peaceful balloting in March 11 legislative and mayoral elections. Guerrilla groups have threatened to disrupt the elections. ``Despite the ambush, there will not be any problem with elections in the region,'' Neira said. Rebel groups, especially those belonging to the National Liberation Army, are trying to prevent voting in their areas of influence through a campaign of kidnappings, assassinations, ambushes and sabotage.
