The Liberation Army is holding five mayors, two congressmen, a city councilman and several political organizers. Most were kidnapped in the country's northeastern region, where support for the group is strongest. Police said that another leftist guerrilla group, the People's Liberation Army, was responsible for Thursday's killing of the criminal court judge but did not give further details. Judge Carmen Elisa Rosas and her three police bodyguards were shot to death near Puerto Hugria, a town 304 miles south of Bogota. A spokeswoman for the judicial employees' union, Yolanda Parra, said in a telephone interview that the country's 4,000 judges and 19,000 judicial workers stayed off the job Monday to protest what they consider a lack of security for judges. She said almost all courts were closed and that the union had called for assemblies in several cities so workers could vote on whether to extend the strike. Since 1981, 225 judges and judicial employees have been assassinated. Many of the killings have been carried out by drug traffickers trying to stop criminal cases against them. The judicial workers' union said recently that at least 1,300 judges are working under threat of death from drug traffickers and other criminals. The Medellin cocaine cartel declared what it called a ``state of alert'' Sunday, indicating it may soon renew its bloody war with the government after suspending attacks six weeks ago. The traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire Jan. 17 in an effort to persuade President Virgilio Barco to end extraditions of drug suspects to the United States. But Barco said on Saturday that he will not change the policy, which began after the August killing of a leading presidential candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Authors, Editors Accuse Random House
DOC.TEXT: About 350 authors, editors, literary agents and sympathizers staged a noisy sidewalk protest Monday to accuse Random House of destroying one of its key subsidiaries for financial reasons. ``The bottom line is not the last word,'' read one sign displayed outside the publishing giant's midtown headquarters, where a lunchtime crowd had to thread its way past police barricades. The protesters charged that Random House owner Samuel I. Newhouse had effectively killed the subsidiary, Pantheon Books, by forcing the resignation Wednesday of its longtime editorial director, Andre Schiffrin. Schiffrin reportedly had refused to cut his staff and the number of books he planned to publish. Five of Pantheon's six senior editors subsequently quit, saying Pantheon's established role as a publishing house for unconventional and otherwise little known writers was being ruined in the name of profits. Random House chairman Alberto Vitale said he was ``absolutely puzzled'' by the reaction to Schiffrin's resignation. He said Pantheon would have ceased to operate ``a long, long time ago'' without Random House's support. ``It's not Random House who is hurting anything,'' Vitale said in a telephone interview. ``Random House has kept Pantheon going all these years.'' He said the editors who have quit have ``in effect abandoned their authors. ... These people by leaving have hurt Pantheon.'' One of those editors, Tom Engelhardt, told reporters at the demonstration that while Pantheon had provided a forum for such writers since it was acquired by Random House in 1962, ``the real disaster for us is that the next generation of writers will be marginalized; they won't have that opportunity.'' Author Studs Terkel, clutching a plastic coffee cup in the near-freezing weather, was among a number of Pantheon-published writers who turned out for the demonstration. Author Kurt Vonnegut, although not a Pantheon client, said he was taking part out of sympathy for his colleagues. Vonnegut said he feared what was happening to Pantheon was ``of little general interest to the country,'' but said, ``I'm disturbed that a great American institution like this should be destroyed.'' In an unsigned statement handed out at the demonstration, the organizers said: ``Just as we have protested censorship _ however rationalized _ by dictators left and right, we protest censorship _ however rationalized _ by corporate fiat. ``At a moment in history when intellectual freedom is scoring stunning victories around the world, it is appalling that a unique center of American intellectual vitality should be so thoughtlessly,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Milan Prepares for a Short and Sporty Winter
DOC.TEXT: Italian designers are predicting a short winter for next year _ at least where hemlines are concerned. Not only is the average skirt a good three inches above the knee, but the fall-winter 1990-91 ready-to-wear collections being presented in Milan this week are full of bermudas and short shorts, items usually reserved for the warmer months. What was a daring step in the late 1980s, when for the first time in 20 years the ``moda Milanese'' hiked hemlines above the knee, has become a way of life for the fashionable woman in the new decade. Most fashion followers agree the latest Gianni Versace mini-skirt, which almost reaches the navel, is just too short, but at the same time Versace is the clearest statement that short hemlines are here to stay. Once women have agreed to bare their thighs it is easy to get them to wear shorts in the winter too. The new winter bermudas and shorts are loose and sporty, usually in corduroy or light wool jersey worn with dark or printed stockings and comfortable walking shoes. In general the latest ``moda Milanese'' is pert rather than sexy, with a heavy accent on sportswear. Gone are the tailored city suits and elegant coats of past seasons, to be replaced by sweatsuits, sport jackets, parkas, down and duffel coats and loads of knitwear from cozy cardigans, pullovers and sweaterdresses to the brand new all-knit jumpsuit. Colors range from the browns and reds of autumn leaves, to the icy beige, green and blue pastel shades of a winter landscape. Three of the designers who showed there new collections here Monday _ Krizia, Missoni and Byblos _ are longtime experts in the field of chic sportwear. Krizia proposes a soft and casual look. Shoulders are natural, hemlines brief and waistlines loose. Jackets tend to be oversized with huge shawl collars, rounded hemline and drawstring waist. In the coat department Krizia offers cozy bathrobe coats with silk cord monk belts. For mountain fun or cold city days Krizia offers a series of quilted items from long down coats and duffel coats to pert quilted mini-skirts. Every season Krizia picks specific motifs to adorn her pullovers and sweaters. For next winter she steals cherubs from a Renaissance painting and prints them on her soft cashmere pullovers and short sweater dresses. White horses and imperial eagles also adorn many of her outfits. To dress up her sporty look Mariuccia Mandelli, the woman behind the Krizia label, embroiders gold onto lapels, hemlines and cuffs. Since last winter, the Italian designers have caught on to the ecological movement, replacing their once sumptuous furs with exquisite lookalikes in teddy-bear plush. Thus the Krizia lady can flaunt her tiger, leopard or brightly dyed beaver knowing its all innocuous fluff. Missoni has been king of Italian knitwear ever since he presented his reversible knit and quilted jackets in Florence several decades ago. But his latest collection, entirely dedicated to the Soviet Union, is one of the best in seasons. Beautiful reversible coats and parkas are knitted in patterns of Russian folk art: the onion towers of Red Square, the quaint houses of a Russian village, the geometric designs of a carpet. These patterns are also used for the knitted jumpsuits and sweat pants, as well as for the silk evening outfits. Later in the day, Keith Varty for Byblos presented his version of the sporty 1990-91 winter woman. True to his British blood, he dresses her in the favorite items of his native countryside, riding jackets with velvet collars, riding breeches,and blouses complete with ascot tie. Lace embroidery adds a feminine touch to the austere look. For languid hours by the fire of your favorite ski lodge Varty offers heavy knit pullovers in ivory-white with large rose patterns, and cable-knit Irish sweaters. Speaking of skiing, Varty's new parka with string-tie and fur-trimmed hood in icy beige or blue are sure to be a hot item on the slopes from Aspen to St. Moritz.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Encourages Argentine President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Bush statement. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `His economy ...' ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday offered support for Argentine President Carlos Menem's austerity campaign and promised to look for ways to help the inflation-plagued Argentine economy recover. Menem's government announced a series of austerity measures Sunday to end the hyperinflation that has triggered labor strife, soaring interest rates, record unemployment and other problems. The White House said the Argentine president called Bush last Thursday to tell him in advance of the steps being taken to shore up the economy. Bush said in a statement Monday that Menem's actions ``indicate that he clearly is determined to bring about economic recovery in Argentina.'' ``The United States encourages him in this effort and in his support for democracy,'' Bush said. ``We realize, however, that this process is not easy and respect the efforts that President Menem is making. ``We will be studying closely the reforms he has announced, and will look for ways to continue helping the Argentine people to achieve economic recovery and prosperity,'' Bush said. Menem took office in July. His government has been beset by recession, a plunge in the value of the national currency and inflation exceeding 8,100 percent over the last 12 months. His economy minister, Antonio Ernan Gonzalez, said Sunday that the Menem government would seek to save $2 billion by cutting back on the state bureaucracy, in part through early retirements and layoffs. Gonzalez said the state also would raise an additional $600 million through a 1.5 percent increase in the tax on capital goods and an average 5 percent boost in duties on agricultural exports. Argentine banks and exchange houses were closed Monday to allow implementation of the measures aimed at stabilizing the country's finances. Vice President Dan Quayle, who leaves Friday on a week-long mission to South America, will meet with Menem and other officials during a March 13-14 stop in Argentina.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says DOE Committed to Building Collider As Envisioned
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department plans to build the supercollider as originally envisioned although it has not determined how high above $5.9 billion the cost may climb, Secretary James A. Watkins said Monday. Watkins said physics changes in the design could increase the cost by $1.2 billion, while changes in labor rates could add another $300 million. The cost of supercollider originally was estimated at $4.4 billion, then rose to $5.9 billion. The increase, coupled with the lack of a firm figure on the new estimate, could spell trouble in Congress as supporters seek their second year of construction funding for would be the world's largest scientific instrument. It is to be built south of Dallas. ``This creates some problems, yes it does. I wish they were able to give us a definite figure, but we have been through this many times on other projects,'' said Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on energy and water development. Asked if Congress could reverse last year's commitment to building the collider, Bevill appeared unsure of the project's fate. ``That's always possible,'' he said. ``No, I don't think that's going to happen. I don't know. I don't know. At this point I don't know.'' The collider would be a a 54-mile underground ring where subatomic particles are hurled against each other to test theories about the fundamental nature of matter. Rep. Silvio O. Conte, R-Mass., ranking Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, says the collider has no practical application. Watkins said two independent studies to determine the impact of design changes on the cost of building the particle accelerator likely would be finished in June, and that the new estimate would ``fall close to $7 to $8 billion.'' The Bush administration is seeking $318 million for the collider in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Bevill said having a final estimate before he seeks an appropriation from the full House could be critical. Watkins told the panel that too great an increase in the cost could imperil the administration's support for the project.

DOC.HEAD: Adventurers Begin Loading Soviet Ship for Trip Home From Antarctica
DOC.TEXT: Six mushers who spent seven months making the first dog sled trek to the South Pole in 78 years loaded their supplies aboard a Soviet ship Monday at the end of their adventure. Because of two-mile-thick ice surrounding Antarctica, the ship docked two miles from the Soviet science station in Mirnyy, where the International Trans-Antarctica Expedition ended its 3,741-mile trip across the frozen continent Saturday, said spokeswoman Jennifer Gasperini. The team used small boats to ferry sled dogs and supplies to the ship, she said. The team hopes to depart late Tuesday on a 12-day sail to New Zealand or Australia and a hectic series of homecoming celebrations that begins March 19 in Sydney, Australia, Gasperini said. An audience with French President Francois Mitterrand is set for March 21 and with President George Bush for March 27. Sunday was the first day off the trail in 220 days for the team, which by reaching the South Pole on Dec. 11 completed the first dog sled trek since Roald Amundsen arrived there on Dec. 14, 1911. Co-leader Will Steger of Minnesota made history four years ago when he led a similar assault on the North Pole. He said the sound of people's voices and the taste of cucumber were his biggest pleasures at the end of the trip. Geoff Somers of Britain relished a chair to sit on and a table to eat at, while Keizo Funatsu of Japan enjoyed the sight of birds flying and the feel of rock under his feet. Qin Dahe of China and Jean-Louis Etienne of France both appreciated having a warm, dry bed. ``You don't have to work so hard to go to sleep,'' Etienne said. For Soviet polar scientist Victor Boyarsky, to whom the research stations of Antarctica are a second home, there was someone special awaiting him in Mirnyy: his wife, Natasha. The six were besieged by television cameras even before they skied to the edge of the continent at sunset Saturday. A French film crew traveled at their side the last 90 miles. Their triumphant finale was followed by a rushed sauna, and the cameras followed them inside. A dog sled parked in a snow drift outside the Mirnyy mess hall, lit up by TV lights, provided a surreal backdrop for interviews that continued non-stop through the night. Boyarsky's reunion hug from his wife and Steger's first words were carried live to an estimated 150 million people in the Soviet Union. Funatsu, 33, who became an end-of-the-trail sensation when he spent Thursday night lost in a blizzard, sent assurances to his parents in Osaka via a morning news show. Between reporters hungry for news and Soviet scientists hungry for autographs, the mushers captured a brief three-hour nap Sunday morning, then got back to work. Qin, 43, a glaciologist, carefully refrigerated hundreds of snow samples for dispatch to laboratories in France, the United States and China. Somers, 40, a veteran guide for the British Antarctic Survey, unloaded sleds, many of which will be lent to polar museums in the United States and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Jury Selection Begins; Former GOP Campaign Aide in Pool
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead, SUBS 4th graf: ``U.S. District,'' to update with 21 sent into the jury pool; court over for the day; following should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one people, including a lawyer who worked for the Bush presidential campaign, were chosen prospective jurors Monday as the selection process began for the Iran-Contra trial of former National Security Adviser John Poindexter. Poindexter is charged with five felony counts _ one of conspiracy, two of obstructing Congress and two of making false statements to congressional committees _ in connection with accusations that he covered up Oliver North's secret Contra resupply network and lied about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. He is the highest-ranking Reagan administration official to go on trial in the Iran-Contra affair. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene disqualified one woman who expressed uncertainty when asked whether she could be fair and impartial. The judge also disqualified an equipment operator who said that ``when the whole thing was going down'' following public disclosure of the Iran-Contra affair ``all you heard was North and Poindexter.'' Seventeen of the first 21 in the pool were women. Two hundred six people have filled out questionnaires to be possible jurors for the trial, and 76 of them have said they had heard, watched or read portions of congressional testimony Poindexter gave in 1987 under a grant of immunity from prosecution based on what he said. The judge approved for the jury pool a real estate lawyer who worked in President Bush's campaign as part of a group doing background reviews of potential vice presidential candidates. Bush was President Reagan's vice president at the time. The woman also said one of Poindexter's defense lawyers, Joseph Small, had babysat for her when she was a child. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb questioned whether she should be in the jury pool since she knew one of the defense lawyers. ``Just because counsel babysat for her doesn't cast any doubt on her,'' said Greene. The woman also said a brother-in-law has worked for former Virginia Govs. Charles Robb and Gerald Baliles, both Democrats. Robb is now a U.S. senator. Also accepted for the jury pool: a clerical worker who said under questioning that she knew former Poindexter aide North ``was on trial'' in the past and that he had been fined and was performing community service. ``It was a big to-do in D.C.,'' said the woman. A jury of 12 people and six alternates will be selected from a pool of residents from the District of Columbia. Greene is expected to build a pool of several dozen prospective jurors from which to select a jury. Most of those questioned said they knew little about the Iran-Contra affair. A retired cook who said she had worked for seven lawers in the 1950s said she had heard nothing of Poindexter's or North's testimony to Congress. She said she was unaware of Reagan's videotaped testimony taken Feb. 16-17 and publicized extensively in the past week and a half. Poindexter's lawyers are expected to replay Reagan's videotaped testimony in court. Several people said they would give the same weight to Reagan's testimony that they would to anyone else who might testify in the case. Poindexter lawyer Richard Beckler started off the questioning by asking the first pospective juror what she thought of Reagan. The young woman, an unemployed delivery driver for an auto parts firm, wasn't given a chance to answer. Webb objected to Beckler's question, without giving a reason, and Greene sustained the objection. The others sent to the jury pool were a data processing employee who works two jobs, a nursing assistant and a janitor at a National Guard armory. Each of the charges against Poindexter carries a maximum five-year prison term and $250,000 fine on conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Troopers Fire on Rioters, Kill 2
DOC.TEXT: Security troopers fired into a rioting mob Monday at Bandipur, killing two people, a news agency reported, and Moslem militants ambushed a patrol during a curfew relaxation in Srinagar. Militants claimed they killed 12 members of the Border Security Force in the ambush, but an official spokesman in New Delhi said two soldiers were wounded and a civilian was killed when the troopers returned fire. At least 166 people have been killed since a crackdown began Jan. 20 on Moslem militants who seek to make Jammu-Kashmir state either independent or a part of neighboring Pakistan. United News of India reported the shooting in Bandipur. Three government officials visited Srinagar on Monday. A government spokesman in New Delhi, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said Cabinet Secretary V.C. Pande, Defense Secretary Naresh Chandra and Home Secretary Shiromani Sharma made ``an on-the-spot review of the situation.'' They reported to the Cabinet Committee on Political Affairs, which includes Prime Minister V.P. Singh, Home Minister Mufti Mohamed Sayeed and other top government ministers. The spokesman did not reveal details of the meeting, but said the three officials conferred with ranking civilian and military officers in Srinagar. Kashmir has been an issue between India, which is predominantly Hindu, and Pakistan, an officially Moslem nation, since they were formed in 1947 and gained independence from Britain. Srinagar and the surrounding Kashmir Valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir, while western Kashmir was attached to Pakistan. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since independence, two of them over Kashmir. A paramilitary officer said the ambush was among the boldest and best organized ever carried out in Srinagar, center of the Moslem separatist movement. He said the ambushers fired at least 100 rounds from three directions with automatic weapons at 7:30 a.m., on the main shopping street in central Srinagar. The officer spoke on condition of anonymity. Authorities lifted the curfew, which had been in effect since 4 a.m. Friday, from 5 a.m. to 8 a.m. so thousands of stranded villagers could return home. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front claimed responsibility for the attack, describing it as revenge for the killing of 49 Moslem demonstrators by army and paramilitary troopers last Thursday. ``We have killed 12 Indian soldiers,'' an anonymous telephone caller told a Srinagar journalist. ``We carried out the operation this morning to take revenge for the deaths of our Moslem brothers who were killed by the army.'' On Thursday, an estimated 1 million people marched through Srinagar in support of the secessionist movement. It was the largest pro-independence demonstration ever held in the Kashmir Valley. At least 49 people were reported killed when soldiers opened fire on groups of people returning home from the march. The government said they fired in self-defense. Witnesses said some demonstrators tried to grab the weapons of soldiers and police.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Calls for Investigation of Suspected Invasion Tunnels
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-led United Nations Command on Monday called for a joint investigation of an ``invasion tunnel'' allegedly dug by Communist North Korea across its border into South Korea. The United Nations Command, which polices the border zone formed by the 1953 Korean cease-fire, said in a letter to North Korea, ``We have evidence of another tunnel under the Demilitarized Zone, which is an extremely serious violation of the Armistice Agreement. U.S. Rear Adm. Larry G. Vogt said in the letter that, ``All the evidence gathered thus far by our multinational special investigation team indicates the tunnel began inside your side of the DMZ, and extends over a thousand meters (1,000 yards) into our portion of the DMZ. ``Such a tunnel could be used by military forces and represents a flagrant violation of the Armistice Agreement,'' he added. Vogt proposed that a joint observer team of the two sides meet Tuesday to investigate the tunnel. There was no immediate response from North Korea, which has denied digging the tunnel. The tunnel, discovered Saturday in the eastern sector of the 155 mile-long border, was the fourth tunnel discovered since 1974. Pyongyang has denied digging the other three tunnels. The latest tunnel discovered is two yards wide by two yards high and about 2,030 yards long. It crosses about 1,000 yards into the southern sector of the DMZ. The United Nations Command, formed during the three-year Korean War to help South Korea repel the North Korean invasion of 1950, said it would formally protest the existence of the tunnel. Earlier Monday, South Korea's Unification Board said in a statement that the tunnel ``is proof that North Korea has not given up its policy of communizing the South.'' The Defense Ministry said a South Korean searching party was moving cautiously through the tunnel after a land mine exploded Sunday, killing a patrol dog. South Korean officials said North Korea broadcasted messages through loudspeakers along the border saying ``Don't look for tunnels that do not exist,'' and ``Don't revive worn-out talk about underground tunnels.'' The United Nations Command said in a statement that it suspects that another 20 tunnels exist along the frontline.

DOC.HEAD: Izvestia Prints Draft of Gorbachev Proposal on Presidency
With AM-Soviet-Elections, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens saw an official draft of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a vastly more powerful presidency Monday, a week before the Congress of People's Deputies considers it. As printed in Izvestia, the government newspaper, the proposed constitutional amendments closely resemble the version leaked last Tuesday, when Gorbachev pushed the plan through the Supreme Soviet. The amendments now must be approved by the legislature's parent body, the 2,250-member Congress, which will hold a special session next Monday. According to the draft in Izvestia, the new president: _Must be at least 35 years old and not more than 65. _Will be elected for five years and cannot serve more than two terms. _Can veto laws passed by the Supreme Soviet. If the Supreme Soviet overrides his veto with a two-thirds vote, he can bring the measure before the full Congress of People's Deputies. _Is commander in chief of the armed forces. _Appoints the premier and other top government officers, subject to confirmation by the Congress of People's Deputies. _Can block decrees by the Council of Ministers. _Has the power to declare a general or partial mobilization, or ``declare a state of war in the event of an attack and promptly bring the question before the Supreme Soviet.'' _ Can declare, ``in the interest of the defense of the U.S.S.R. and security of its citizens, a state of martial law or emergency in specific places. ... He can, in these cases, introduce temporary presidential rule. _Issues decrees that ``have obligatory force in the entire territory of the country.'' _Is chosen in a nationwide general election. The jurist who presented the bill to the Supreme Soviet, however, said the first president would be elected by the Congress to a four-year term because organizing a general election would take too long. Gorbachev's proposal has inspired complaints from the opposition, who say the president will have dictatorial powers. Pro-independence groups in the Baltic republics and elsewhere fear Gorbachev will use the new powers to crush their movements and their plans for secession.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Ruling Will Invalidate Most N.C. Death Sentences
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 15th graf: ``The requirement,'' with explanation of why state believes not all prisoners affected
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court overturned a key portion of North Carolina's death penalty law Monday in a ruling that will invalidate the sentences of most of the 85 death row inmates in that state. By a 6-3 vote, the court set aside a murderer's death sentence because his sentencing jury was told not to consider any factor suggesting a lesser sentence unless all 12 jurors could agree on that factor. The decision probably will not affect any death row inmate outside North Carolina. ``The system that was condemned is the system we've been using since 1977 for sentencing people to death,'' said Raleigh lawyer Malcolm Hunter Jr., who successfully challenged the North Carolina law. He said Monday's ruling ``could have a very broad impact'' within the state. A spokesman for North Carolina Attorney General Lacy Thornburg said as many as 70 death row inmates now must receive new sentencing trials. In a separate decision, the court gave judges and prosecutors leeway in what they tell jurors choosing life or death for murderers, voting 5-4 to uphold a California man's death sentence. And in a third death-penalty ruling, the justices split 5-4 in ruling that an Oklahoma murderer is procedurally barred from contending that a jury wrongly was told to ignore ``sympathy'' before it sentenced him to death. The rulings in the California and Oklahoma cases are not likely to affect many of the some 2,200 death row inmates across the nation. In other matters Monday, the court: _Agreed to decide whether Louisiana officials are violating an insane death row inmate's rights by forcing him to take mind-altering drugs in an effort to make him sane enough so he be executed. _Cut back severely the right of criminal defendants to attack their prosecutions on constitutional grounds after an initial set of appeals in state courts. The 5-4 ruling upheld a South Carolina murderer's death sentence. _Ruled, by a 5-4 vote in a Michigan case, that even when police questioning violates a criminal defendant's right to legal help the responses may be used to contradict his trial testimony. In the North Carolina death penalty case, the court set aside the death sentence of Dock McKoy Jr., convicted of the 1984 shooting death of Anson County Deputy Sheriff William Kress Horne. Relying on their 1988 decision in a Maryland case, the justices said the jury that sentenced McKoy wrongly was limited in its consideration of ``mitigating evidence.'' Jurors were told they had to unanimously agree on the existence of each mitigating factor. The requirement of unanimity was laid down in 1985, and the attorney general's office believes Monday's ruling will affect only defendants sentecned after that said Jim Coman, senior deputy attorney general. ``But I'm sure all the attorneys for all the death row inmates will appeal.'' Writing for the court, Justice Thurgood Marshall said the unanimity requirement is unconstitutional. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Sandra Day O'Connor dissented. The court upheld the California death sentence of Richard Boyde, who was convicted of the 1981 murder of Dick Gibson, a Riverside convenience store clerk. Boyde's sentencing jury was read a list of specific mitigating factors it could consider in choosing his punishment. Jurors also were told they could consider ``any other circumstance which extenuates the gravity of the crime.'' California courts no longer use that instruction. Rehnquist, writing for the court, rejected arguments by Boyde's lawyers that the instruction prevented jurors from considering factors regarding his background and character that might be deemed mitigating even if they did not lessen the crime's gravity. Justices Marshall, William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens dissented. In the Oklahoma case, the court never reached the merits of death row inmate Robyn Leroy Parks' challenge of an ``anti-sympathy'' instruction his sentencing jury received. Instead, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the court that Parks was procedurally barred from raising that argument after having exhausted his direct appeals in state courts. Parks was convicted of the 1977 killing of Abdullah Ibrahim, a gas station attendant in Oklahoma City. The presiding judge told jurors, ``You must avoid any influence of sympathy, sentiment, passion, prejudice or other arbitrary factor when imposing sentence.'' The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the instruction undermined the jury's consideration of mitigating evidence but that ruling was overturned. Kennedy was joined by Rehnquist, White, O'Connor and Scalia.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Teenager Wins $20,000 Science Award
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 7:30 p.m. EST _ Time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old Chicago youth won a $20,000 college scholarship Monday night for a project on molecular genetics that he believes may advance understanding of the conversion of nitrogen from air into ammonia. Matthew Peter Headrick won first place in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the nation's oldest high school science competition. His selection was announced at an awards banquet attended by more than 500 leaders from science, government, education and business. Headrick is a senior at the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools High School and plans to study at Princeton or Stanford universities for a career in physics or biophysics. The next two top winners were David Ruchien Liu, 16, of Riverside, Calif., who entered a neuroscience project, and David Michael Shull, 17, of Tacoma, Wash., who developed a method of placing the genetic coding for production of a molecule into white blood cells. They each received $15,000 awards. The prestigious Westinghouse Science Talent Search, an annual competition established in 1942, started last September when 1,431 students entered from 36 states. The list was cut to 300 by a board of eight scientists from a variety of fields. Forty finalists received a five-day trip to Washington, where they underwent additional judging to determine their scientific creativity and potential. Of the 1,960 winners in the Search since its inception, five have gone on to win Nobel Prizes; two have won Field Medals for distinguished work in mathematics and eight have been awarded MacArthur Foundation Fellowships for research in the physical and life sciences. For his winning project, Headrick used molecular genetics techniques to isolate for the first time the gene that is necessary for nitrogen fixation in a fresh water blue-green alga. Nitrogen fixation, the conversion of molecular nitrogen from air into nitrogen-carrying chemical compounds that plants can use, is essential for the synthesis of amino acids and for all life. The alga in question converts the nitrogen to ammonia. Search officials said that Headrick ``believes his work will help toward a better understanding of the nitrogen fixation systems and the process of cellular differentiation.'' The fourth through 10th place winners and scholarship amounts were: _Soojin Ryu, 18, Bronx, N.Y., $10,000; _Joshua Fischman, 17, Bethesda, Md., $10,000; _Royce Yung-Tze Peng, 17, Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., $10,000; _Laura Andrea Ascenzi, 17, Sunnyside, N.Y., $7,500; _Andrew M. Lines, 17, Arlington, Va., $7,500; _Mina Kim Yu, 17, of Fairfax, Va., $7,500; _Bianca Denise Santomasso, 17, New York City, $7,500. Selected as first and second alternates were Jennifer Lynn Ryder, 17, Fresno, Calif. and Sean Eric McGuire, 18, San Antonio, Texas. The alternates and the 28 other national finalists were awarded $1,000 scholarships making the total value of the awards $140,000.

DOC.HEAD: President Defends Violence Used Against Protesters
DOC.TEXT: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny on Monday defended the violent suppression of student protests that have forced him to review economic austerity measures. The Ivorian leader, speaking at his first news conference since 1985, suggested multinational companies were trying to destabilize Africa to obtain the lowest possible price for its raw materials. Houphouet-Boigny, 84, denied protesters' claims that he had siphoned millions of dollars from state coffers. ``If you think I have that kind of money, do you think I would leave my people in that situation?'' he told a reporter who asked whether he would use his ``immense fortune'' to help Ivorians suffering the worst economic crisis in the country's history. Hundreds of government and other workers joined protesting students Friday in demonstrations in Abidjan and chanted: ``Houphouet: thief. Houphouet corrupt.'' Abidjan was calm Monday although dozens of armed soldiers were deployed and presidential guards in red berets blocked off the presidential office in the city center. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, has condemned ``severe beatings'' by soldiers and police who have fired tear gas and stun grenades to halt protests. Many demonstrations have been peaceful and some have been violent protests in which people have burned and stoned cars and ransacked several stores. ``If I have to choose between disorder and injustice I will choose injustice because there will be time to redress that,'' Houphouet-Boigny said. He noted that no one has been killed in the protests. The president repeated his opposition to protesters' demands for a multiparty democracy, saying parties in Africa tend to be drawn along tribal lines, promoting ethnic rivalry and endangering national unity. ``When everything has been debated, and we deliberate on everything, the decision always rests with one person: me,'' Houphouet-Boigny said. His critics say Houphouet-Boigny made a fortune from shares in companies that buy cocoa and coffee, the main Ivorian exports, when commodity prices were high in the 1960s and 1970s and farmers were poorly paid. Slumping prices of raw materials have caused Ivory Coast's economic crisis and led to protests, which began Feb. 19 with demands the president resign. He has ruled since the country became independent from France in 1960. Houphouet-Boigny confirmed Monday that his government will reduce other expenses of Ivorians to offset proposed pay cuts of between 15 percent and 40 percent for civil servants and increase a pay tax on private-sector workers from 1 percent to 11 percent. ``We are going to ask for sacrifices, but at the same time we are going to cut rents, water, electricity, clothing and food costs,'' he said. Houphouet-Boigny also appealed to developed nations to set ``a just price'' for Africa's raw materials. Cocoa and coffee prices have surged on exchanges in New York and London amid dealers' concerns that the protests could interfere with delivery of Ivory Coast's 800,000-ton crop. The Ivorian crop _ a third of world supplies _ has mostly been sold and awaits shipping at Abidjan docks. In October, Houphouet-Boigny was forced to halve prices paid to farmers for coffee and cocoa. He noted coffee producers in Ivory Coast now get 16 cents a pound, which produces 22 cups of coffee sold in moderate-priced European restaurants for up to $3.50 a cup. ``We are now back in a situation of forced labor, except the label has changed,'' he said. He accused multinational companies of ``being at the root of Africa's political problems.'' ``I have the feeling that someone is proceeding to destabilize'' African countries, he said.

DOC.HEAD: College Star Who Died Remembered as Inspiration on and off Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, ```We thought ...,' to CORRECT name to Fryer, sted Fry. A version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA20
DOC.TEXT: Hank Gathers, the college basketball star who collapsed in the heat of competition and died, was mourned Monday as an inspiration on and off the court by teammates and his coach, who said, ``Whatever we were, we were Hank's team.'' Gathers, 23, a fifth-year senior and center for the Loyola Marymount University Lions, crumpled Sunday night soon after sinking a thunderous slam dunk in the first half of a tournament game against the University of Portland (Ore.). ``We called him `Bank man' because we went to him for everything,'' said Coach Paul Westhead. ``We went to him for rebounds, we went to him for points, we went to him for life. ``He was a walking thunderbolt.'' Gathers, who was considered a certain pick in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft, was pronounced dead at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital. Autopsy results were unavailable Monday, but doctors said he'd been treated after a similar collapse in December for an irregular heart rhythm. Gathers, a 6-foot-7, 210-pound center from Philadelphia, became the second player in NCAA Division I history to lead the nation in scoring (32.7 average) and rebounding (13.7 average) last year. The feat was first accomplished by Wichita State's Xavier McDaniel five years ago. Gathers also was 11th on the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I single-season scoring list, with 1,015 points last season. After the first collapse, he missed two games, but began taking medication and was cleared to play again. Gathers persuaded doctors to cut back on his medication, and said he felt himself strengthening. Teammate Jeff Fryer said Monday that Gathers had done something unusual before the game that turned out to be his last. He ran on the track to warm up rather than jumping rope as usual. ``We thought he was crazy,'' Fryer said, adding, ``That was Hank.'' Just 6{ minutes into the West Coast Conference tournament game, Gathers slam-dunked for his eighth point, giving 22nd-ranked Loyola Marymount a 25-13 lead over Portland. He was heading back to his regular spot in the Lions' press when he dropped to the floor. Loyola doctors rushed onto the court. After a few moments, Gathers tried to get up, struggling to his knees. But then he began to suffer what appeared to be a seizure. His mother, Lucille, ran onto the court, followed by his aunt, Carole Livingston. Their screams and cries rang through Albert Gersten Pavilion as a stunned crowd of about 3,000 watched in silence. The tournament was canceled and Loyola Marymount, a Los Angeles school, was declared the league champion by virtue of its 13-1 regular-season record in conference games. Gathers' death prompted CBS to postpone a scheduled broadcast of ``Malcolm Takes a Shot,'' a drama for children about a high school basketball star stricken with an epileptic seizure in the final seconds of a game. Teammates and coach had trouble talking about Gathers at a news conference Monday. ``Hank represents the little kid in all of us because to Hank Gathers basketball was play, and we all want to play,'' Westhead said. ``Basketball was free play, and Hank Gathers was the best in playing freely.'' Longtime friend and teammate Bo Kimble came West with Gathers after graduating from Dobbins Tech in Philadelphia in 1985. The pair went to the University of Southern California for a year, then transferred to Loyola Marymount, where they were the main ingredients in college basketball's highest-scoring team the last three seasons. Trying to share his memories with reporters, Kimble was overcome by emotion and had to be helped from the podium. Later, he was able to summon a smile when asked about the team's berth in the NCAA tournament. ``Oh yes, definitely, I'm sure we're going to play. We can turn a negative thing into a positive thing,'' said Kimble, the nation's leading scorer, an honor earned by Gathers last season. ``We're going to be up for the challenge, we're going to dedicate this to Hank.''

DOC.HEAD: Widow of Allende Moves Back to Chile
DOC.TEXT: The widow of former President Salvador Allende returned for good to her homeland Monday and said she would attend the weekend ceremony in which Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who led the coup that toppled her husband's government, gives up power. ``I want to spend my last years here,'' Hortensia Bussi de Allende, 75, told reporters at Santiago's international airport. She arrived from Mexico, where she lived for more than a decade in exile. She was met by Socialist Party officials and by a daughter, Isabel, and granddaughter, Marcia. A small crowd cheered her arrival, which was virtually unpublicized. Mrs. Allende said she would attend Sunday's inaugural ceremony, in which Pinochet hands over the presidency to an elected successor, Patricio Aylwin, in the port city of Valparaiso. Asked if she planned to participate in the new government, she replied: ``No. I've always said we have to make way for the younger people.'' Aylwin, a Christian Democrat, is backed by a coalition of 17 centrist and leftist parties, including the Socialist Party that Allende once led. Mrs. Allende said she would lobby to have her husband's remains moved to ``a deserved spot in Santiago, where everyone can pay him homage, and to have a grand monument built.'' Allende died in the presidential palace while it was being bombarded by the military during a coup on Sept. 11, 1973. According to witnesses, he committed suicide with a machine gun when it became evident his leftist government was falling. He was buried in the unpretentious plot of a brother-in-law, in the coastal resort of Vina del Mar, near Valparaiso. The military kept the grave unmarked for many years. The military forced Mrs. Allende to leave the country within days of the coup. She first returned in late 1988 after Pinochet, campaigning for an eight-year extension of his rule, ordered an end to her exile and that of hundreds of other dissidents. Voters in an October 1988 referendum rejected the extension for Pinochet, forcing him to call elections.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Pay Interim Relief to Gas Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf with latest statistics show per capita income in India is $270 a year.
DOC.TEXT: The government said Monday it would pay interim compensation of $12 per month to each of 500,000 people living near the site of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster. ``The government has been deeply concerned about the continuing miseries of hundreds of thousands of people of Bhopal who were affected by this gas leak disaster,'' said Petroleum and Chemicals Minister M.S. Gurupadaswamy. ``The disbursement of final compensation may take considerable time and the victims, who have suffered for over five years, cannot be asked to wait any longer,'' he said. The leak of toxic gas from the pesticide plant operated by Union Carbide Corp. in December 1984 killed at least 3,598 people and injured another 20,000 in the world's worst industrial disaster. The announcement Monday said all the people living in the vicinity of the pesticide plant at the time of the leak, including minors, would be paid interim compensation, pending the outcome of legal battles with Union Carbide, a U.S.-based multinational. The payments would run for at least three years, it said, so that victims ``may continue to get regular assistance over a period of time and this may help them in meeting their medical expenses and earning of basic livelihood on a continuous basis.'' ``This decision, to cover all the residents, has been taken because we feel that all those people who were exposed to the gas have suffered, even though some of the health effects may show up (only) in the long run,'' Gurupadaswamy said. The payments, he said, will be adjusted against any final compensation arrived at. The government said in January it will challenge a $470 million settlement agreed to last year by Union Carbide and the previous government. Arguments in the case are continuing in the Supreme Court and it unlikely a quick decision will be reached. According to the 1989-90 Stateman's Yearbook, the average per capita income in India is $270 a year, citing the latest available figures from 1986.

DOC.HEAD: 1 Officer Killed 2 Injured, in Undercover Drug Buy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout officer dying, details of gunbattle, quotes, officer's name. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A state policeman was killed and two other members of a drug-fighting task force were gunned down Monday afternoon while trying buy cocaine in an undercover operation, authorities said. Police said the sellers tried to rob the officers, setting off a firefight. Two men were arrested, one of whom was wounded. Police sought a third man who may have been involved. The shootings took place about 3:30 p.m. in the Jacob Riis housing projects on the city's Lower East Side, when the officers arrived to meet people from whom they had agreed to buy nearly 4{ pounds of cocaine, said police Commissioner Lee Brown. According to Brown, an officer entered a building with one of the sellers and was confronted by another inside. They struggled, and as other officers came to help, the gunfight broke out. ``Our preliminary information is the perpetrators were going to rob the officers,'' Brown said. ``We don't know if they knew the undercover officers were police.'' No drugs were found, but the $42,000 the officers brought to make the purchase was recovered. State police Investigator Joseph T. Aversa, 31, was killed said Lt. Ronald Clark, a spokesman at state police headquarters in Albany. Aversa, shot in the left eye, died at Bellevue Hospital, and two New York City detectives who were shot in the leg were in stable condition there, officials said. The arrested man also was treated at Bellevue. The officers were members of a drug enforcement task force which includes city, state and federal officers. Deputy Inspector Mike Julian said the undercover officers arrived in what is called a ``flash car'' _ a black Pontiac Formula 350 with tinted windows _ to show drug dealers that they had the money. No drugs were found after the shooting, but the $42,000 the officers brought to make the purchase was recovered. Mayor David Dinkins went to the hospital. ``This is further evidence of the fact that our police officers, women and men, put their lives on the line for us everyday,'' he said. James Brown, a resident of the building, said that from his 14th-floor window he saw two men run from the building, then open fire on officers who tried to cut them off. ``It was really scary,'' said Brown, who estimated 15 shots were fired during the five-minute battle. ``It was chaotic. People were screaming. Civilians were running all over the place,'' said paramedic Lt. Carlos Ariza.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Calls for High-Level Warsaw Pact Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier on Monday invited his counterparts from other Warsaw Pact countries for a March 17 meeting on the unification of Germany. Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky said letters of invitation were sent Monday, and the meeting has the backing of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. ``We also know the response of the GDR to have this meeting in Prague is favorable,'' Jan Martinek, a foreign ministry official, told The Associated Press, using the acronymn for East Germany's formal name. Dienstbier welcomed the idea of a unified Germany, but reiterated Czechoslovakia supports Poland's demands to participate in reunification talks involving the German states and the Allied powers, which divided Germany after World War II. Poland insists on West German guarantees that the Polish-German border is inviolable _ a guarantee that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been reluctant to provide. ``Germans should realize they owe their unification also to Polish Solidarity and the democratization processes in Eastern Europe,'' Dienstbier said, noting that only three months ago the idea of uniting the Germanys was not expected in this century. ``We have bitter experience with events such as the Munich Pact, when borders of one country were determined by others,'' Dienstbier told the Czech parliament earlier Monday. He was referring to the 1938 Munich conference involving Germany, Britain, France and Italy. It gave Czechoslovakia's border region known as the Sudeten to the Nazis. Dienstbier also said that Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, will be the site of a planned April 9 meeting among the presidents of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, as well as their premiers and foreign ministers. Dobrovsky said the invitations are a ``practical implementation'' of a proposal made by Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel to his Hungarian and Polish counterparts. He said the foreign ministers of Yugoslavia, Italy and Austria also will be invited. He said the one-day meeting's main purpose would be ``brainstorming.'' ``There will be no creation of new blocs or structures. It should be a discussion about various issues related to these countries,'' Dobrovsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Group Signs Pact With Shopping Mall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 13th graf, `In an interview ...'
DOC.TEXT: A shopping mall pledged to hire more blacks and discontinue its practice of detaining black teen-agers under a 1960s trespass law in an agreement with the NAACP, officials said Monday. The civil rights group's national chairman, William F. Gibson of Greenville, said the pact with the 128-store Columbia Mall was the first of its kind, and encouraged other NAACP chapters ``to negotiate similar agreements.'' The Baltimore-based National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had planned to boycott the mall if no agreement was reached, Gibson said. George Forbes, an attorney for mall owner Jacobs, Visconi and Jacobs of Cleveland, said the agreement was reached in a ``spirit of cooperation'' but is not legally binding. ``The Columbia Mall does not, it has not and it will not discriminate as regards to race, creed or color,'' said Forbes, a longtime member of the NAACP. ``There seemed to be an indication that we have done that, and I consistently said that we have not, and anyone at the mall found to be involved with that would be immediately dismissed.'' The agreement, negotiated over the last month by NAACP and mall officials, calls for hiring and promoting more blacks by mall management and encouraging stores to do the same, and for using more black contractors and suppliers. However, the pact does not specify the number of jobs or work contracts the mall will give to blacks. The mall's owners also offered to sponsor a jobs fair, create an employment center, advertise in the black media, provide sensitivity training for employees, and work with the NAACP to closely monitor the mall's relationship with the black community. Informal studies show blacks comprise 30 percent to 40 percent of the mall's 150,000 weekly customers, Gibson said. About a month ago, the mall discontinued its practice of detaining black youths under a 1960s anti-trespassing law designed to maintain segregation, Jacobs said. Minority groups alleged last summer that about 50 black teen-agers had been detained by mall security officers under the trespass law. The youths were photographed, their names placed in security files, and many were told not to return for six months. In most cases, no criminal charges were ever filed. In December, two black teen-agers were shot inside the mall in the latest of four such incidents. In an interview afterwards, Richland County Sheriff Allen Sloan was quoted by a newspaper as saying the best way to reduce mall violence was to ``keep the niggers out.'' Sloan denied making the statement. Forbes said the mall owner is committed to minority hiring. He said one of the four administrators is black and that blacks comprised 35 percent of the security force. ``We think that is not only good sense, but it makes good business,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Observes 20th Anniversary Of Nuclear Treaty
DOC.TEXT: President Bush marked the 20th anniversary Monday of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty by calling on all holdout nations to sign the pact. He urged the 140 signatory nations and the rest of the world to work together ``even more dilligently to prevent nuclear proliferation, which possess one of the greatest risks to the survival of mankind.'' Among the nations that have not signed the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons are Israel, South Africa, Cuba, Pakistan, India, Argentina, Brazil and Chile. North Korea technically has signed up, but Bush administration officials say it has failed to accept international safeguards on its atomic energy program. Still, Bush called the treaty ``the most widely accepted arms control instrument in history.'' At a time of ``major progress in arms control,'' Bush urged ``all states that are not party to the (treaty) to join and thereby demonstrate their support for the goal of preventing nuclear proliferation.'' In addition to furthering arms control, the treaty has also fostered international cooperation on the peaceful uses of atomic energy under safeguards applied by the International Atomic Energy Agency, Bush said. The 140 signatory nations will convene a fourth review conference on the treaty later this year.

DOC.HEAD: China Agrees to Resume Fulbright Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 beginning `Chinese education' to UPDATE with program to resume next fall. Picks up 3rd, `China took...'
DOC.TEXT: China has agreed to resume participation in the Fulbright program but on a smaller scale than in recent years, the U.S. Embassy said Monday. Chinese education officials agreed to send 16 Chinese scholars and students to the United States next fall to do research, and accept 16 U.S. professors to teach, said embassy spokesman Sheridan W. Bell. He said the embassy was still waiting a letter from the Chinese government to formalize the agreement. China took part in the U.S. scholarly exchange program for a decade, with 24 scholars traveling in each direction in recent years. It abruptly canceled the 1989-90 academic year exchanges in August in anger over U.S. criticism of the army's killing of pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. Talks on resuming the exchanges began in December, after U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft mae a fence-mending visit to Beijing. The reduction in the number of scholars exchanges means fewer academic fields will be represented, Bell said, but he did not know which fields the Chinese had cut. Since June, Chinese authorities have stressed the need to learn from the West in technical areas, but have said fewer students in the social sciences will be sent abroad. Resumption of the Fulbrights does not indicate that a complete healing of U.S.-China relations, deeply shaken by the June killings, is likely in the near future. That will not be possible as long as the U.S. Embassy shelters two fugitive Chinese dissidents, Fang Lizhi and his wife, Li Shuxian. China has demanded the two surrender and face charges of counter-revolutionary crimes, and shows no sign of softening that stance. A range of people-to-people contacts are resuming slowly, however. Last week, four non-official U.S. delegations passed through Beijing _ one to join in climbing Mount Everest, and the others to hold talks on trade or political relations.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Man Who Allegedly Threatened Stephanie Zimbalist
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of sending threatening letters to ``Remington Steele'' star Stephanie Zimbalist was arrested in a hotel, the FBI said Monday. Michael Lawrence Shields, 43, of Plymouth, Mich., was arrested Friday at the Valley Hilton in the suburban Sherman Oaks area after allegedly sending 212 letters to the 33-year-old actress, most of them threatening, authorities said. FBI agents found Shields because his last letter to the actress said he would be coming to Southern California, giving his flight number and the name of the hotel, said FBI Agent Lawrence Lawler. Miss Zimbalist played sleuth Laura Holt on NBC's ``Remington Steele,'' which ran from 1982 through 1986. Her father is actor Efrem Zimbalist Jr., who played an inspector on the drama series ``The FBI.'' The arrest of Shields marked the latest in a series of cases in which fans are alleged to have threatened celebrities through the mail. In December, a shipping clerk accused of sending nearly 6,000 threatening letters to actor Michael J. Fox pleaded guilty to three felony counts and was sentenced to three years probation.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the key provisons of the compromise clean air bill being considered by the Senate.

_Local communities must attain federal air quality standards within five, 10 or 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area is allowed 20 years. _Areas must show annual progress, ozone reductions of 4 percent a year for the first six years and 3 percent annually thereafter. A waiver may be granted if the costs of the annual reductions exceed $5,000 per ton of ozone-forming pollutants. Reductions are to be attained through cuts in automobile emissions and smog-causing releases from industrial plants. Small business emitting less than 100 tons are exempt.

_Automakers must reduce tailpipe emissions of smog-causing pollutants with all cars covered by new emission controls by 1995. Hydrocarbons _ unburned fuel _ would have to be cut by 22 percent to 0.25 grams per mile and nitrogen oxides by 60 percent to 0.4 grams. A second round of tailpipe controls would go into effect in 2003 cutting emissions another 50 percent if 11 cities now with ``serious'' pollution problems fail to meet air quality standards. Cities with even more serious problems would have to use cleaner-burning fuels such as methanol or specially formulated gasoline.

_Utilities must reduce in two phases annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the year 2000 and cap emissions at 1980 levels at that time. First phase begins in 1995, but utilities using clean coal technology may delay initial compliance until 1997. Dirty plants, primarily in Midwest, also received extra pollution control allowances, which may be sold to recoup some of control costs. Western states also receive additional bonus allowances to provide cushion for growth. _Nitrogen oxide emissions by utilities must be reduced 4 million tons by year 2005.

_Industry must install by 1997 the ``best available technology'' to reduce releases of 191 toxic chemicals by up to 90 percent. _The National Academy of Sciences will recommend methods for assessing remaining health risks, especially from cancer. The Environmental Protection Agency must implement health-based standards to deal with those risks after study is completed.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Makes Emergency Landing in Norfolk After Bomb Threat
DOC.TEXT: A New York-bound USAir DC-9 made an emergency landing shortly after takeoff Monday when a couple who missed the flight allegedy warned there was a bomb on board in their luggage, the airline said. No explosive device was found on the plane, which was carrying 14 passengers and a crew of five, authorities said. Flight 195 was on the runway at Norfolk International Airport preparing for takeoff when a couple showed up at the boarding gate and demanded to board the plane, USAir spokeswoman Susan Young said in Arlington. When the couple was told the plane was preparing to take off and could not return, ``they made remarks to the effect that `You'll bring it back,' and some comments about a bomb in their luggage,'' Ms. Young said. The plane turned back and landed 20 minutes after takeoff. A search by the state police and FBI failed to turn up anything suspicious, and the flight arrived in New York three hours behind schedule. ``It's my understanding that one piece of baggage has been separated from the rest,'' said Wayne Shank, the airport's deputy executive director. Shanks said the plane was moved to a remote section of the field and the passengers taken off while the plane was searched. Ms. Young said the couple, who were not identified, were turned over to the police.

DOC.HEAD: Theologians Surprised by Exorcism Disclosure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Exorcism existed...worship,' to ADD that both experts surprised at O'Connor's statement. Pick up 11th graf, `In the gospels...'
DOC.TEXT: Theologians expressed surprise Monday about Cardinal John O'Connor's disclosure that the rare rite of exorcism has been performed twice in New York in a year. But other ceremonies dealing with evil spirits, including a baptismal prayer, are more common in the Roman Catholic Church. O'Connor mentioned the exorcisms during a sermon Sunday and to reporters afterward. He said heavy-metal music spiked with satanic lyrics created an atmosphere conducive to devil-worship and demonic possession. The cardinal said the exorcisms were approved by the archdiocese's vicar general and appeared to be successful, but gave no other details. He also said the novel, ``The Exorcist,'' is a ``gruesomely authentic'' portrayal of demonic possession. According to a story published Dec. 12 in the San Francisco Chronicle, Pope John Paul II recently increased the number of exorcists in Rome and in Turin, where there are a reported 40,000 devil worshipers. Last week, police in Indianapolis asked an unidentified priest to pray and sprinkle holy water in a house after they saw a radio, a vase and other objects inexplicably move. They had been called to investigate a possible burglary after the resident came home and found smashed dishes, windows, a lamp and eggs. A 14-year-old relative who had been staying there was believed to have been involved in devil worship, authorities said. The Rev. Simon Harak, a theology professor at Fairfield University in Connecticut, said that exorcism, recognized in the church's book of rituals, is performed for people under the highest form of attack by an evil spirit _ people ``who are no longer in charge of their own will.'' Exorcisms are confidential; no figures are kept on the number performed in the United States, said Bill Ryan, spokesman for the U.S. Catholic Conference in Washington, D.C. But channeling _ the phenomenon popularized by actress Shirley MacLaine of speaking through spirits _ has similarities to demonic possession. The spirits that emerge in channeling, however, are supposed to be good, not evil, according to the Rev. James T. Burtchaell, theology professor at Notre Dame University. Exorcism existed before the time of Christ, but is rare in modern times, and both Burtchaell and Harak said they were surprised there would have been two exorcisms in a year in New York. Harak noted the rite may gain prevalence in times or places of satanic worship. ``In the gospels, there's quite a bit of reference to Jesus not only healing people of diseases but freeing them from diabolical possession,'' said Burtchaell. ``Ever since then, there have been outbreaks of similar behavior,'' he said. ``It was found that when very holy priests were sent to pray for and about these very troubled people, there would be an increase in the behavior, then eventually a complete liberation from it.'' Exorcism is more common in countries where Christianity is not well established or where other influences, such as voodoo, come into play. Since the 1970's, exorcism has been performed only by a priest approved by a bishop, archbishop or cardinal. ``If you ask most bishops in the country, `Who is your exorcist?' they probably wouldn't have one. It's an ad hoc thing,'' said Burtchaell. ``Probably a number of bishops would be surprised to hear there were two in New York,'' one of the largest dioceses in the nation. Typically, he said, an exorcist must be a ``very self possessed, consistently holy man'' to survive the experience. ``It involves a great deal of self-abuse, bodies being flung around the room, excrement, assumed voices _ it's pretty vile stuff.'' ``The average Catholic would have no first-hand information to speak of,'' he said. ``The darn movie is going to be the image everybody has. But, I must say, events in the movie are very faithful to stories I've read'' about real exorcisms. A battery of medical and psychological tests is ordered before someone undergoes exorcism. ``If a person has Lupus, for instance, and periodically has seizures where they go out of control, that's a chemical imbalance,'' said Harak. But there also are informal rites to get rid of, or guard against, demons. Harak said a standard, prebaptismal ritual contains ``three scrutinies that are really rites of exorcism that have been kind of tamed in the church.'' ``It's not like, 'Oh, my goodness, William Peter Blatty's 'The Exorcist.' It's a recognition that there are good spirits, angels, and bad spirits, devils. And the evil spirit hates human nature,'' Harak said. The church also has a practice called deliverance for ridding ``infestations of evil spirit'' less serious than possession, said Harak. They are performed somewhere in this country every day, by laity as well as priests. ``Usually, the name of Jesus, holy water, holy oils, prayers of community are so powerful that these deliverances are not difficult. Many of us do them,'' he said. ``Say you've been fooling around with a Ouija board, or the more modern thing, Dungeons and Dragons. You chant incantations and stuff like that.'' Those practices could make you susceptible to evil spirits, he said, especially if you have a psychological or emotional problem. ``Evil spirits are like flies,'' said Harak. ``Our own personal hatreds or resentments, lack of self worth, faith or love, those are the garbage in us around which the flies tend to cluster.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Rejects U.S. Statements on East Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Likud ministers giving conditional approval to U.S. peace proposals; pickup 3rd pvs, `Israel captured...' DELETES final graf to CONFORM.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Peace, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders dismissed U.S. statements defining Jewish neighborhoods in annexed Arab east Jerusalem as settlements and said Monday that the Holy City ``will not be divided again.'' Later Monday, Cabinet ministers of the conservative Likud party gave conditional approval to U.S. proposals for peace talks with Palestinians. There was concern the new U.S. statements on Jerusalem would complicate efforts toward peace in the Middle East. Israel captured Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 war and has declared the unified city, home to 350,000 Jews and 130,000 Arabs, its capital. ``United Jerusalem, the capital of Israel, will not be divided again,'' Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said in Parliament. ``It will grow and will be enlarged under Israeli sovereignty. All the partners to the coalition accept this principle.'' Arens, of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's conservative Likud bloc, was supported by Vice Premier Shimon Peres of the center-left Labor Party, Likud's main political rival and coalition partner. ``Following the statements that were heard in recent days and linked Jerusalem with settlements, the vice premier ... stressed that he and his party are committed to the unity of Jerusalem, Israel's capital, and to Israeli sovereignty over the city,'' an announcement from Peres' office said. Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem scheduled a city council meeting for Tuesday morning to discuss the U.S. position, which also opposes housing construction for Soviet immigrants in east Jerusalem. ``Israel and the whole Jewish people are united regarding the necessity to maintain the unity of Jerusalem as Israel's capital, and opposition to immigrant absorption there cannot be imagined,'' he said in a statement. Most Western countries, including the United States, do not recognize the Israeli annexation and say the status of Jerusalem should be determined in negotiations. The United States says the city must stay united. The latest U.S. position, first expressed Saturday by President Bush, objects to Israeli housing projects in east Jerusalem, where an estimated 120,000 Jews now live. ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or in Jerusalem,'' Bush told a news conference on Saturday. ``I will conduct that policy as if it is firm, and I will be shaped in whatever decisions we make to see whether people comply with that policy.'' Shamir said Sunday: ``There are no settlements in Jerusalem. It is part of Israel and it will never be divided again.'' He said the the government would try to direct as many Soviet Jews as possible to Jerusalem. Previously, the United States publicly objected only to Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, calling them an obstacle to peace. About 75,000 Jews and 1.7 million Palestinians live in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Victories Reported by Yeltsin, Others Seeking Quick Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs with State Department comment after 7th pvs, `Activists said...' Picks up 8th pvs, `Defeat of...'
DOC.TEXT: Candidates who want faster reform won elections across the nation's Slavic heartland and Boris N. Yeltsin easily gained a legislative seat in the Russian republic, unofficial returns indicated Monday. Yeltsin has said he will seek the presidency of the republic, which traditionally means a place on the Communist Party's ruling Politburo. That could return the Communist maverick to the membership he lost in February 1988 for advocating speedier change. Leaders of popular movements in the Ukraine and Byelorussia, an outspoken television commentator in Leningrad and a defiant editor in Moscow also appeared to have won in Sunday's local and republic elections. ``We're so happy! Such success!'' said Irina Rozhenko of the Ukrainian pro-democracy movement Narodny Rukh. Byelorussia, the Ukraine and the vast Russian republic account for 80 percent of the Soviet Union and more than two-thirds of its 290 million people. Most of the 1,800 contests for seats in the legislatures of the three republics remained undecided, with no candidate getting the required majority. State TV said fewer than 15 percent were resolved in the Russian republic. Activists said strong showings in this round nearly guaranteed victories in runoff elections for candidates who want to step up the pace of reforms begun by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The runoffs are expected in two weeks. In Washington, State Department spokesman Margaret Tutweiler said Monday that, ``While, for the most part, these were not multiparty elections, there were, nonetheless, many hotly contested, competitive regional and local races, offering voters a clear choice of candidates and ideologies. ``This represents an important and, indeed, historic step forward in the process of democratization in the Soviet Union,'' she said. Defeat of old guard local Communist leaders probably would help Gorbachev's liberalization. He has railed against functionaries who hamper reform, and people hoping to exercise new economic freedoms have told of crippling obstacles erected by local party officials. Ukraine party chief Vladimir A. Ivashko, considered a moderate protege of Gorbachev, qualified for a runoff against an opponent backed by the Narodny Rukh pro-democracy group. Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, president of the Russian republic, defeated a lone opponent in the city of Krasnodar, winning 71.3 percent of the votes cast. Both are members of the Politburo. Preliminary figures showed Yeltsin, who has said he will challenge Vorotnikov for the republic presidency, got 72 percent of the vote in his district of Sverdlovsk in the Ural Mountains. He defeated 11 other candidates, said Anatoly Moiseyev of the Russian Federation Election Commission. Narodny Rukh members said the movement's leader, poet Ivan Drach, was elected in the first round along with several other prominent activists. Zyanon Paznyak, leader of the Byelorussian People's Front, got 59 percent of the vote in his Minsk district, said spokesman Victor Ivashkevich. He said activist candidates appeared to have carried cities but party ``apparatchiks,'' including Byelorussian party chief Yefrem Sokolov, won rural districts. In Leningrad, Bella Kurkova, controversial commentator of the television program ``Fifth Wheel,'' appeared to be the only first-round winner, said IMA Press, an official youth news agency. ``Fifth Wheel'' is a public affairs program that includes long segments about politics and such social problems as crime and poor living conditions. Despite Leningrad's reputation as a conservative bastion, pro-democracy candidates dominated the elections, said Yelena Velinskaya, editor of IMA Press. She said only two of about 150 candidates supported by the ultra-right nationalist group Pamyat survived the first round. Vladislav Starkov, editor of the country's most popular newspaper, Arguments and Facts, was reported the winner of a seat to the Russian republic's parliament. Starkov ignored a strong suggestion from Gorbachev that he quit last year after the paper, which has a circulation of 33 million, printed results of a poll implying human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov was more popular than Gorbachev. Unofficial reports said well-known dissident Sergei Kovalyov also won a seat in the Russian parliament. Nearly 150 million voters were registered to vote Sunday and more than 11,000 candidates vied for 1,800 seats in the three republic legislatures and thousands more places on local governing councils. Official results are expected Tuesday. Official reports said 86 percent of the candidates in the Russian elections and 80 percent in the Ukraine were members of the Communist Party. Gorbachev, who was not a candidate, described the elections as a battle between reformers and entrenched bureacrats, and added: ``I am convinced that perestroika will win.'' ``Our elections involve a new type of people, people who have been given new impetus from perestroika,'' his plan for restructuring the Soviet society and economy, he told reporters after voting. Political tension has increased in some regions as direct control from the Kremlin decreases. In recent weeks, Gorbachev has prodded the Communist Party into giving up its monopoly on power and pressed for a new, more powerful presidency. In Lithuania, candidates of the pro-independence Sajudis movement swept earlier legislative elections and won more seats in runoffs Sunday. Of the 25 candidates elected Sunday, 18 were from Sajudis, according to reports from activists and the official news agency Tass. Some activists in the Baltic republic want the legislature to vote on secession from the Soviet Union before Gorbachev gets his new powers, which would include the right to suspend the legislature of a republic and send in troops.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: Four Killed in Uzbekistan Unrest, Others Say 30
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official said Monday that four people were killed in ethnic rioting in an Uzbekistan city but activists said 30 people had died from violence sparked by an election dispute. Interior Ministry spokesman Dmitri Seleznev said in a telephone interview that about 5,000 people gathered Saturday in Parkent, a city 30 miles from the Uzbekistan capital Tashkent, to demand the removal of Meshketian Turkish refugees. The crowd attacked the district police headquarters and burned it down after authorities stopped them from attacking refugees' homes, he said. One soldier and three civilians were killed in the fighting, and 92 people were injured, including 60 police and Interior Ministry soldiers, he said. He said the Central Asian city was relatively quiet Monday. The late dictator Josef Stalin forced the Meshketian Turks to resettle in Uzbekistan from their native area in the republic of Georgia. Last June, about 100 people were killed in attacks on them in Uzbekistan's Fergana Valley. In a telephone interview Sunday, Yadigar Abidov of the Uzbekistan grass-roots political group Berlik claimed at least 30 people died after soldiers opened fire on a crowd of Parkent residents who were demanding registration of their candidate in a runoff elections for the Uzbekistan parliament. He said residents of the city of 200,000 were angry that Ismail Salimov, a regional Communist Party first secretary, had refused to allow any other candidates on the ballot. Abidov claimed that Salimov and another local party official were stoned to death by the crowd, but officials denied it. The republic of Uzbekistan has been the most recent area of the Soviet Union to erupt in violence as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev loosens decades of tight Kremlin control. Last month, 22 people were killed in rioting in Dushanbe, the capital of neighboring Tadzhikistan republic.
