DOC.TEXT: Southeast Asia's answers to the Champs Elysees and Fifth Avenue are Orchard Road in Singapore and Nathan Road in Hong Kong, both beacons to tourists and fashion-conscious shoppers in the exotic Orient. Here are two stories describing what has become some of the most expensive real estate in the world.

Orchard Road is the very symbol of Singapore, one of the world's smallest and most successful countries, a place where consumerism is indeed conspicuous. The official guide to this city-state says, ``Orchard Road is a testament to modern Singapore, with its pedestrian malls shaded by huge trees and enlivened by small gardens full of tropical blooms and lush greenery.'' This 239.5-square-mile country, with no natural resources except a strategic location and the skills of its 2.6 million people, enjoys the highest standard of living in Southeast Asia and the second-best in all Asia after Japan. With Hong Kong, it is arguably the most unabashed materialistic society in the region. Orchard Road recently was rated in a private survey by the New York real estate firm Huberth & Peters Inc. as the world's 10th-priciest street in terms of commercial space for rent. Conspicuous consumers abound, both the domestic and tourist variety. Status-conscious ``Chuppies,'' as Chinese Yuppies are known, sport Rolex watches, designer clothes, jade rings, Mercedes-Benz cars and a taste for the latest in food and fashion. Orchard Road is where they can shop till they drop, eat till they pop and then plop into the swimming pool at the Hilton, Dynasty, Mandarin or some other elegant hotel. Named for the nutmeg and tropical fruit plantations that lined it in colonial days, Orchard Road is centrally located and easily reached by Singapore's 2-year-old subway system. Thousands of domestic servants, most of them from the Philippines, throng the tree-lined street on Sundays, the usual day off for maids here. They catch up on gossip from home and take advantage of the three main features of Orchard Road: shopping, eating and people-watching. The survey by the New York real estate firm showed that one square foot of shop space along the 1{-mile thoroughfare costs an average of $175 a year. By comparison, the survey found that one square foot for a year costs $675 on The Ginza in Tokyo, the world's costliest shopping district. A check by The Associated Press found that the more desirable retail space on Orchard Road fetched more than $350 each year. Rent for shops in the popular but by no means top-of-the-line Lucky Plaza is now $368 per square foot a year, almost double that of last year. The multistory Lucky Plaza houses scores of shops selling electrical appliances, clothing, jewelry, watches, cameras, cosmetics, shoes, sporting goods, luggage, radios and hi-fi equipment, plus restaurants and bookstores. While the mostly locally owned retail outlets in Orchard Road pay the highest rents in Singapore, they also charge from 30 percent to 50 percent more for their merchandise than other shopping areas. Much of it consists of high-priced imports and for everyday necessities most Singaporeans eschew the glittering boulevard for more modest stores in Chinatown and elsewhere. The Huberth & Peters survey found one common denominator to the most expensive streets around the world was that they almost always contain designer names and upscale shops. The brands prominently displayed along Orchard Road include Cartier, Gucci, Christian Dior, Dunhill, Omega, Rolex. Boutiques and department stores offer the latest in high style and casual wear from the fashion centers of Europe and North America. Not all the fancy branded goods are what they seem, however. Many tourists are pestered by touts to buy ``genuine copy-watches'' from certain stores at a fraction of the price of the real thing. ``The selling of fakes is at the heart of the touting problem. Touts are there mainly to persuade people to buy fakes,'' says police Deputy Superintendent Ng Kee Hoe. In the eight months prior to Feb. 1, the police arrested 126 touts and seized 11,564 fake watches from 61 shops. First offenders can be fined up to $5,000 or jailed up to six months or both. Some touts appear to have their own turf and competition among them is as fierce as that between McDonald's and Burger King. One of the first McDonald's outlets in Singapore was in Liat Towers at 541 Orchard Road. It proved so popular that after the Burger King franchise holder bought the building, Big Mac lost the coveted location to the Whopper.

DOC.TEXT: In a city known worldwide as a shopper's paradise, no road is better traveled by the legions of bargain-hungry tourists than Nathan Road in the heart of Kowloon peninsula. Tourists pour out of the five-star hotels and economy guest houses that co-exist at the head of Nathan Road, making the retail space along that stretch among the most expensive on Earth to rent. Retailers along the street say that from 50 percent to 90 percent of their business comes from overseas visitors. ``Over the past years, the number of tourist arrivals have been increasing at a non-stop rate, so recently the rentals have kept going up,'' says Albert Chan, head of the retail department of Vigers Hong Kong Property Consultants. He estimated annual increases of about 30 percent in the past few years. Indeed, Nathan Road and Queens Road across the harbor on Hong Kong island were listed second in a recent survey of the world's most expensive commercial rental streets. According to the survey, conducted by a New York commercial real estate firm, space on Nathan Road rents for $575 a square foot a year. Only the Ginza in Tokyo is more expensive. The high rents apply to only the first half dozen or so blocks of Nathan Road, a four-lane street that begins at the stately Peninsula Hotel and runs past Kowloon Park before heading into the overcrowded, lower-rent districts to the north. The head of the street, near the British colony's famed Victoria Harbor, is a bazaar of swank boutiques selling the latest high-priced fashions and of bargain basements offering ``I Love Hong Kong'' T-shirts and silk ties for just over $1. Gaudy neon signs hang low over the sidewalk. There also are several dank and dark alleys leading off the road, home to venders selling cheap art, luggage and various types of pornography. Among the designer stores on the street are Charles Jourdan, Diane Freis, Alfred Dunhill and Benetton. Department store branches include Yue Hwa Chinese Products and Lane Crawford, the priciest in town. Nathan Road also has dozens of shops selling cameras, electronics, watches and jewelry, and haggling is often required to get the best price. For tourists who cannot afford name-brand watches, on many a corner are young men who whisper offers of counterfeits to passersby. Retailers typically rent out space on the ground floors of the luxury hotels and run-down commercial buildings that front the street. There are a few new structures along the road, including a mosque and a two-tiered retail center built in front of the park. Real estate professionals say that some retail space on Nathan Road can go for about $770 a square foot a year. The recent asking price for one of the street's rare vacancies was 10 percent higher. Nathan Road retailers interviewed by The Associated Press, however, indicated that rents can be much lower. Peter Lau, owner of Volvo Video and Camera Supplies, says he pays $446 a square foot to rent the store he has occupied for two months. Lau says his 1,000-square-foot shop, jammed with the latest electronics, must bring in nearly $9,000 a day to break even. He says he is making a profit. Retailers say the political turmoil in China hurt sales during much of last year, scaring tourists away and dampening the spending mood of local consumers. But the tourist business is recovering and Nathan Road still remains a Mecca for visitors in search of the legendary Hong Kong shopping experience. Several factors, including the colony's status as a duty-free port, traditionally have made local prices for many goods among the most competitive worldwide. Joan Lyon of London, Giordano shopping bag in hand, was in the latest wave of visitors to Nathan Road, which she described as a ``new Bond Street'' that was ``devoid of atmosphere.'' Bond Street is London's ritziest retail row. ``We are having a little bit of a spending spree,'' Mrs. Lyon said during a break from window-shopping. Prices generally are comparable to those in London, she said, but quickly added, ``I think there are bargains to be had here.''

DOC.TEXT: There comes across the American cultural landscape once in a while someone who enhances life on a grand scale. These are the builders of a Lincoln Center, a Kennedy Center, a Music Center of Los Angeles and more. They are many spirits and this is the story of one of them _ Alice Tully.

She is an American Muse, like her sisters in Greek mythology, a patron of the arts. Here in America, the Muse is not mythic. Here feminine largess has created museums, art galleries, ballets, orchestras and concert halls that enrich the nation's cultural life. In this tradition is Alice Tully. And she at 87, in all modesty, is hopeful there are more. There already are many. Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center is home to chamber music and to the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which she helped found. Today she is only an interested bystander, but her heart is in it everyday. Her cousin, Arthur Houghton Jr., one of the founders of Lincoln Center, suggested she pay most of the costs of a small concert hall to be built at the center. ``When he asked, I had the most wonderful feeling,'' she recalls. ``And I just knew this is for me. I said, `Oh, Arthur, I can't think of anything I'd rather do.' I was overjoyed. ``On very important occasions, that voice inside of me tells me things. And I heard inside of me, `Well, this is what you came to do.''' The honor role of American Muses is long. In New York, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney founded the Whitney Museum in 1930 to house American art. Lillie P. Bliss, Mary Sullivan and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller founded the Museum of Modern Art in 1929. Jane Wrightsman, Lila Acheson Wallace, Brooke Astor and Joan Payson have contributed hugely to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Blanchette Rockefeller gave one-third of her American art collection to the M.H. de Young Memorial Museum in San Francisco. Eleanor Belmont, by starting the Metropolitan Opera Guild, got that opera house through the Depression. Lucia Chase for years used her fortune to support the American Ballet Theater. Anne Bass, Nancy Zeckendorf and LuEsther Mertz donate to ballet. Martha Hyder of Fort Worth aids the Van Cliburn Competition. There are builders of concert halls. The Filene Center at Wolf Trap near Washington was built by Jouett Shouse with money from that department store fortune. Buffy Chandler donated and raised money for the 25-year-old Music Center of Los Angeles, for which Lillian Disney recently donated $50 million to build Walt Disney Hall. Louise Davies gave the San Francisco Symphony's hall. Frances Pew Hayes paid for the symphony's new hall in Naples, Fla. Patricia Corbett, with money from door chimes, is a music philanthropist in Cincinnati. The University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music has Corbett Auditorium and Patricia Corbett Theater and at the top of the Cincinnati Symphony's Music Hall is a ballroom named Corbett Tower. Miss Tully is the granddaughter of Amory Houghton Jr., the founder of Corning Glass. Her career was as a concert singer. ``My mother wasn't interested in the arts per se,'' she recalls. ``My parents never expected to have an artist in the family. But they were very kind when they realized that I just wanted to sing, and that was it, and that I was only too anxious to work. And so they let me do it. That was wonderful, that they let me go and live and study in Paris. At that time (1923) it was not the usual thing.'' She hasn't been a philanthropist all her life. ``I didn't have anything to give until after my mother died,'' she says. ``I always wished that I could because I was always so interested in that world.'' She knew how artists struggled. ``I had friends who were painters and sculptors and singers and composers. They all needed money.'' Miss Tully, by nature a person of dignity, reserve and gracious charm, was talked into allowing Alice Tully Hall to be named for her for by John D. Rockefeller III. ``I would have liked it better being anonymous. Absolutely. It took me six months to make up my mind to give my name to the hall because I knew what would happen. And it did.'' Within a week, she says, requests for donations poured in. ``Now it's worse than ever. When I came back on Monday, there was a stack of mail like that.'' She gestures high above a table. ``And I had taken out a stack like that when I went off on the weekend. I sit up late at night opening mail. ``In the arts, the need is greater than ever. Expenses go up so steadily. And of course that wonderful fantasy world of opera where we can lose ourselves is the most expensive of all. It is so wonderful and I have loved it since I was a child. I love all forms of art.'' Now she pours tea from violet-sprigged china in the living room of her Manhattan apartment, with its moss-green carpet and draperies and bleached-oak paneling. Flowering plants are placed on occasional tables and windowsills. Her two pet Maltese dogs, Sophie and Tati, scamper in to bark hello. That is present tense. Past tense she can remember the lunch when she first heard of the Lincoln Center project, a year before President Eisenhower turned the first spadeful of earth and gave the signal to start the steam shovels, June 1959. She was not just a philanthropist. Alice Tully Hall, which opens on the street, is tucked into a corner of the Juilliard School. Miss Tully objected when Juilliard wanted to make it part of the school. ``I had, above all, to stand my ground, which I did.'' It took her three years of insistence to get the wide space between the chamber hall rows. She has more letters over the last 20 years thanking her for the comfort than she has received about the fine acoustics. Arthur Houghton also suggested to Gian-Carlo Menotti that he call on his cousin when the composer was looking for money to start a summer music festival in Spoleto, Italy. Miss Tully has been a supporter ever since. In January, a benefit to repair hurricane damage at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., was held at Alice Tully Hall, with Miss Tully attending. Some have referred to Miss Tully as a grande dame of arts philanthropy. But that is not how she thinks of herself. ``I just do what I like to do, what I think I have to do and what it is my privilege to do.''

DOC.TEXT: It's a posse of volunteers ready to gallop off after horse thieves and it keeps a noose handy. The Wild West? No, upstate New York, circa 1990. Admittedly, the horse thief trackers of the Empire State haven't had much to do most of this century, but they stay organized, in case they're ever called on.

``The 167th annual meeting of the Schodack, Stuyvesant, Kinderhook and Chatham Society for the Detection of Horse Thieves is hereby called to order. Any old business?'' ``Not since that horse was stolen 73 years ago.'' ``New business?'' ``Not till the next horse is stolen.'' ``What's on the menu this year?'' ``Same as always. Minced-ham sandwiches, clam chowder and oyster stew.'' ``Meeting's adjourned. Let's put on the feed bags.'' That's as lively as it gets these days for the horse thief trackers of Columbia County, 30 miles south of Albany. The group has met on the first Saturday in February since 1824, when the most serious environmental emission was what landed on a dirt road. ``It's just a tradition,'' said the society's president, Lewis Leggett, 78, who can't remember when he joined the group. The last time anyone called on the society to track a stolen horse was in 1917, when Henry Ford was busy transforming the nation's stables into garages. For Woody Klose, president of the Red Hook Society for the Apprehension and Detention of Horse Thieves in neighboring Dutchess County, carrying on the group is more than tradition. ``It's got to be the greatest organization in the world,'' said Klose, a lawyer and county legislator. ``It meets just once a year and we haven't had a horse theft in years. Thieves are so terrified of us that they leave our horses alone.'' In Columbia County, a mule went on the hoof in the 1930s, but it came back by itself. One year someone stole the hobbyhorse off a villager's porch. Another year, a society member stole the group president's old gray horse as a joke. The prankster wasn't hanged or even horsewhipped. About 10 years ago, a couple of horses were stolen from a local breeding farm, but police didn't call on the volunteer posse. ``I think they figured the troopers could do a better job,'' said society secretary Ralph Duck. Yet the group still has nearly 200 members who gather once a year to meet with old friends they otherwise wouldn't see, said Duck, 79, who joined about 50 years ago. The group began when eastern New York was still on the frontier and horse thieves ran unbridled among the farming towns hugging the Hudson River. Horses were practically part of the family, doubling as transportation and as plow power. ``You could probably get away with stealing a man's wife easier than stealing a man's horse,'' Leggett said. ``If you lost your horse, you lost your heart.'' The society still has the noose used to hang horse thieves. But members don't know when _ if ever _ it was used. ``I've always had the feeling they didn't hang them around here like they did in the Wild West,'' Duck said. Similarly, the minutes of the Red Hook society are ``terrific about writing down who didn't show up at the meetings, but they don't say anything about catching horse thieves,'' Klose said. ``I can't find any report of a member ever having done anything,'' he said. A feeling of continuity keeps the 65 members of the Red Hook society, founded in 1796, crowding around the trough for their roast beef dinner on the first Tuesday of every October, Klose said. ``We still live in what we like to think of as a semi-rural area,'' he said. ``It makes you feel good because you can go back to minutes from seven or eight generations ago and find the same names of people attending our meetings today.'' Unable to afford full-time posses, farming villages formed societies _ like today's volunteer fire departments _ to trail horse thieves. Each year, societies elected a group of riders who would be called in when a horse was stolen. The Columbia County society paid its riders $2 a day while they were on the trail. Red Hook riders earned more money the farther they rode. They got a bonus if they trailed a horse thief out of Dutchess County and brought the bandit back home, Klose said. The societies also acted as insurers, paying farm families the money to replace stolen horses. As automobiles and tractors replaced horses in the early 1900s, most horse theft societies folded. On today's thoroughbred ranches, there are few worries about stolen horse flesh. It's tough to launder a stud horse, whose value depends on careful documentation of its parentage. ``If you wanted to take a stolen horse to Outer Mongolia, you could probably get away with it,'' said Mary Midkiff of the American Horse Council in Washington, D.C. While horses don't vanish from New York farms anymore, horse thief detectives haven't donned blinders when it comes to their science. Annual meetings feature experts discoursing on police trail dogs, the horse in folklore and archaeological evidence of eohippus, the prehistoric forerunner of today's horse. Even so, the posses of Columbia and Dutchess counties won't be saddling up anytime soon. ``With the state of modern law enforcement,'' Klose said. ``we don't take things into our own hands anymore.''

DOC.TEXT: Martin Mull, co-star of the new CBS sitcom ``His & Hers,'' is a laid-back comic performer who works hardest at something he's really serious about _ painting. ``Performing is my day job,'' he explains. ``I'm so serious about art I get crazy. I paint every day. I paint until I'm exhausted. I'll start painting and suddenly realize it's 2 o'clock in the morning.'' Although he has a master's degree in painting from the Rhode Island School of Design, Mull is known primarily for his acting and writing. In ``His & Hers,'' he co-stars with Stephanie Faracy. They play marriage counselors trying to make it work as partners at home and the office. ``We've done 13 episodes of `His & Hers' and not a word of it is mine,'' says Mull. ``It's just being an actor getting a job. I always wondered if I had diminished my acting by wearing too many hats. ``Television is really a writer's medium. A show will succeed or fail on the quality of the writing. I feel in many sitcoms the actors are interchangeable.'' One thing that makes Mull funny is that he doesn't look like a hip comedian. He looks more like an accountant. And in his passion for art, Mull's business-suit demeanor is in stark contrast to the artist stereotype. ``My life is my art. I was trained for it,'' he says. ``We're talking art. Slapping paint on canvas art. ``My work is in galleries in New York and Florida. The reason I don't have a gallery here is I don't want to be considered a celebrity painter, even though some are pretty good Sunday painters.'' As a performer, Mull first became known for his television role on ``Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman,'' then on ``Fernwood 2-Night'' and ``America 2-Night.'' His movies include ``Mr. Mom,'' ``My Bodyguard,'' ``F.M.,'' ``Take This Job and Shove It,'' ``Clue'' and ``Painted Lips,'' which he wrote. He's also done television movies, specials and record albums. His last series was ``Domestic Life,'' which lasted only six episodes on CBS in 1984 but was listed by Time magazine as one of the year's 10 best. He co-wrote, produced and acted in the TV comedy specials ``The History of White People in America'' and its movie spinoff, ``Portrait of a White Marriage.'' Mull was offered ``His & Hers'' while working on a movie in Utah called ``Ski Patrol.'' He says he and Ray Walston were the only actors over the age of 21 in the movie, which he adds disappeared from movie houses as fast as the melting snow. In ``His & Hers,'' Mull and Faracy are a husband-and-wife team of marriage counselors. It's his second marriage and he has a 15-year-old son, played by Blake Soper. The show also stars Richard Kline as his best friend, a divorce lawyer. ``I'm Freudian and she's Jungian, so we have a conflict of psychological styles,'' Mull says. ``Ostensibly, we're supposed to have separate practices, but we seem to share patients and crises. I guess `physician heal thyself' is the concept.'' Mull recently sold his homes in Montecito and Hollywood and bought a larger house in Brentwood. One reason he moved was to find a better area for him and his wife, Wendy, a musician and composer, to raise 4-year-old Maggie Rose. ``I've spent the last six months building a studio,'' he says. ``It's the first real studio I've had. I can write or paint. It's got 14-foot ceilings and special lighting. ``I've also switched from airbrush to oils. I'm back to basics. With an airbrush I always felt I was in medicine with that stainless-steel tool in my hand. ``It's hard to describe the kind of painting I do. You know how when you look at something you have a split second of perception. That split second is what I'm trying to capture.'' Mull says he gets his physical exercise by kicking a football around, a pasttime he hopes to turn into a movie called ``End Over End.'' ``I said on a radio show that something I'd always wanted to do was kick a field goal for the Cleveland Browns,'' says Mull, who grew up in northern Ohio. ``I got a call from the Browns inviting me to Cleveland. I suited up and kicked the ball, and I've been at it since. Now I can kick my age in yards, which is 46. ``It's gotten into my blood and I've written this script about an aging kicker. A producer has it and we're in the process of getting studio backing. I hope I can do it before I'm too old.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo. ColorFoto subscribers get 1 35mm slide.)
DOC.TEXT: John Steinbeck always turned down requests to adapt for the stage ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' his epic novel about Dust Bowl Okies and their migration to the Promised Land of California. He loved the film version, starring Henry Fonda, which was written by Nunnally Johnson and directed by John Ford, all three of them his good friends. But he didn't want to see the story as a play. ``I think John wondered if it would be visual in a theater,'' says Elaine Steinbeck, the writer's third wife and most ardent fan. After he died in 1968, she continued to reject proposals for a play, except for a local production at Actors Theater of Louisville in the early 1980s. ``But the minute Steppenwolf asked me, I said `yes,''' adds Steinbeck's widow, referring to the Chicago theater company that has made a name for itself all over the world with its highly kinetic, freewheeling productions. ``I knew their reputation and had seen `Orphans' in London and `Balm in Gilead' in New York. They were professional, imaginative, exciting and had sent their actors, directors and plays out into the theatrical mainstream. ``I also knew that the 50th anniversary of the publication of `The Grapes of Wrath' was going to come up last April _ the book was first published in April 1939 _ and I felt, `Wouldn't that be a wonderful time for somebody to do the play?''' The Steppenwolf version, adapted and directed by Frank Galati, opened in Chicago in September 1988 and was done later in La Jolla, Calif., and at the Royal National Theater in London. Now, it has made the trek to Broadway, where it has found a house at the Cort Theater. The book, the story of the Joad family and their journey westward during the Great Depression, is known everywhere. In the United States alone, in every one of those 50 years from 1939 to 1989, it has never sold fewer than 100,000 copies. It has been published in 40 languages. ``Whenever anybody would say, `What's your favorite novel?' John would say: `The one I've just finished.' But I think he had taste enough to know that `The Grapes of Wrath' was his big book,'' says Mrs. Steinbeck in a soft, Texas twang not erased by her more than 50 years in New York. Mrs. Steinbeck, one of Broadway's first female stage managers, worked on such shows as the original ``Oklahoma!'' and ``Othello'' with Paul Robeson. She first met her future husband in 1949 when he was collaborating with Elia Kazan on the movie ``Viva Zapata!'' and doing research for a novel that eventually became ``East of Eden.'' ``He was recently divorced, and told me, `I'm very disillusioned and very unhappy.' He had two young boys and his wife divorced him. And he said, `I don't want to ever love another woman or ever write another book.' Well, look what happened.'' The couple was married in 1950. They kept homes in New York and in Sag Harbor on Long Island but traveled a lot _ particularly to London and Italy. They made up for the time he was too poor to travel. ``I once asked him, `When F. Scott Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway and all those other writers were going to Paris, why didn't you go?' He said: `I didn't have the price of a ticket. But I'm glad I didn't because I stayed home and wrote about my own people.''' Fans of the film version of ``The Grapes of Wrath'' will find a different emphasis in the play, one that is much truer to the book, Mrs. Steinbeck says. ``The movie was a star vehicle for Henry Fonda, who played Tom Joad. It really ends when Tom leaves,'' she says. ``In the book, the central figure all the way through is Ma Joad. They all leave her for one reason or another. Even Tom. And she says: `We are the people. We must prevail. We must go on.' I feel that's what Frank Galati was going for in the play. ``John didn't write many women's parts. As a matter of fact, critics used to say, `Steinbeck writes better men than women.' He would always look at me and say, `How about Ma Joad?''' During their years together, Steinbeck would write every day in longhand, usually after sharpening three-dozen pencils, his widow recalls. ``That was stalling,'' she says. If he was working on a long book, Steinbeck would keep regular hours. But he would start the morning writing letters. ``John always said writing letters was like a pitcher warming up. He would write letters before he would write his work. Or when we traveled, he wrote travel pieces. Just things that interested him, not things that would live forever. He kept a journal for every book.'' When she first met him, one of the first things they did was to drive to Salinas, Calif., where he was born, to see the little room on the top floor of the house where he first started writing. ``I can't remember a time when I didn't write,'' he told her as he showed her the building. Steinbeck did a lot of research on ``The Grapes of Wrath.'' He wrote a series of pieces called ``The Harvest Gypsies'' for a now-defunct San Francisco newspaper and then realized it was a book, not newspaper articles. ``He loved to think of himself as a journalist,'' Mrs. Steinbeck says. ``I don't think he was accurate enough to be a journalist. He always embroidered a bit. He'd always throw a little bit extra in.'' ``When John won the Nobel Prize, he said, `I don't know whether I deserve it or not, but I certainly am glad I got it,''' she recalls. ``I don't think that John ever got fancy. When he became successful, he didn't start writing a different kind of story. He still wrote about the people he knew. John cared about the people. He talked the same way to great French writers at the Academy Francaise as he did to the fishermen at Sag Harbor. He never talked down to anybody.''

DOC.HEAD: NATO Nations Pare Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: NATO members are responding to Eastern Europe's political revolution by trimming their military budgets and turning away from expensive joint weapons programs. Defense Minister Guy Coeme of Belgium rang NATO's alarm bells recently by saying his country might withdraw its soldiers from West Germany even before East-West agreement on reducing conventional forces. Considering the startling changes in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, he asked, ``How can we justify the status quo on our side?'' If West Germany drops out of the European Fighter Aircraft project because of domestic opposition, which is possible, the program probably would be doomed. Juergen Moellemann, the West German education minister, said the fighter ``will be the safest airplane in the history of the military because it will never fly, and therefore will not crash.'' Relus ter Beek, defense minister of the Netherlands, said, ``A reconsideration of the security situation in Europe is now necessary.'' There is a new feeling among Western allies that they can pare their budgets, drop out of cooperative programs and bring their soldiers home from West Germany. ``In all likelihood, ... spending will wither on the vine as much as governments feel they dare,'' said John Cross, deputy director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. Even the United States has abandoned big increases in spending. Pentagon officials now feel able to talk about shutting down military bases, withdrawing soldiers from West Germany and dropping weapons programs. Other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are eager to do the same, but some caution against moving too quickly. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain says the Soviet Union will have ``vast military capabilities'' even after promised force reductions. Denmark's defense minister, Gen. Joergen Lyng, finds ``developments in Eastern Europe ... so fluid that the situation can change rapidly.'' Governments are under pressure to economize, however, and Somnath Sen of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute estimates military spending by the 16 NATO members will decline 2.7 percent this year from about $450 billion. He said it was off 1.1 percent last year, adjusted for inflation. The United States, which accounts for about two-thirds of the total, probably will reduce spending by 3 percent this year and European expenditures could decline slightly more than 2 percent, Sen said. ``It will be difficult for defense ministers to ask for more'' in the new political climate, Sen predicted. Officials say few members will meet NATO's guideline of a 3 percent growth in spending this year. The target has been in effect since the 1970s, and the alliance's defense ministers probably will abolish it soon. Some countries may keep spending up because of regional problems. Greece and Turkey, for instance, were enemies long before they were NATO allies. Greece has exceeded the United States in the share of its economic output devoted to defense. Last year, it spent 6 percent of its gross national product on the military, the highest in NATO, and greater than the 5.5 percent spent by the Americans, according to alliance estimates. Turkey, one of only two NATO members bordering the Soviet Union, also worries about neighbors Syria, Iraq and Iran. Its military, now undergoing modernization, gets about a one-quarter of the budget. Norway, the other NATO nation with a Soviet frontier, has drafted plans to increase military expenditures by 2.5 percent this year. Analysts say West Germany will be under great pressure to cut defense spending so its powerful economy can help East Germany. Bonn talks of reducing its army from 480,000 to 400,000 in the 1990s and has suspended a plan to increase the conscription term from 15 months to 18. Military hardware is a major target of budget cutters because of negotiations in Vienna, Austria, on reducing conventional forces in Europe, which are expected to produce an agreement this year. ``Countries will for the first time be looking at actually reducing the numbers of equipment they require. ... It's a new environment for force planners,'' said Simon Lunn, deputy secretary-general of the North Atlantic Assembly, made up of legislators from NATO nations. Arms negotiators, for example, want to limit each side to 20,000 main battle tanks, long the dominant weapon in land combat. For the ``thinned-out battlefield'' of the future, governments may place more emphasis on sophisticated mobile weapons, analysts say. NATO members have begun pulling out of costly joint arms programs set up years ago to produce modern weapons that could be shared. ``Today, as defense budgets shrink, we see cooperative programs running into severe difficulties,'' William H. Taft IV, the U.S. ambassador to NATO, said in a recent speech. A senior alliance official, who agreed to discuss the situation only if granted anonymity, said: ``We're in this indecisive period now ... where to rush in to create new programs is probably not wise. ... That's why all these countries are sort of retrenching on the programs.'' An eight-nation plan to develop the warship of the 1990s has collapsed. Britain, France and Italy withdrew last fall, followed in quick succession by West Germany, Spain and the Netherlands, leaving only Canada and the United States. Britain and the United States have turned their backs on plans to build a weapon that fighter planes could fire from a distance, without flying over enemy territory. France and Canada got out earlier. Spain, Italy and West Germany are considering whether to continue, but one official said, on condition of anonymity: ``The investment for research and development would be so significant that it's not likely they will have the strength to carry it themselves.'' The United States dropped out of an eight-nation program to develop special 155mm ammunition to seek out enemy armor. A few years ago, it persuaded West Germany to stay in, officials said. Interest also is waning in a project to develop a family of air-to-air missiles of short and medium range. West Germany said last year it no longer would participate in building the short-range version, leaving Britain, Canada and Norway. Spain, Italy, Britain and West Germany are in the European Fighter Aircraft project, but continued German participation is in question. Another major expense is stationing soldiers in West Germany, the front line of the Western alliance. As part of a conventional arms treaty, the Soviet Union and the United States plan to reduce their troop strength in Central Europe to 195,000 soldiers each, with the United States allowed 30,000 more on NATO's flanks. That means the Soviets would remove 370,000 soldiers and the United States would withdraw 80,000. Reductions in arms should allow other NATO members to call home the soldiers who operate those weapons.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, March 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Behind a Business-As-Usual Facade, Britain Reviews its Defenses
With BC-NATO-Waning Defense, b0672
DOC.TEXT: Officially, it's business as usual in Britain. Behind the scenes, defense is under review. A new nuclear arsenal is being built on schedule, defense spending is steady and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has not abandoned the idea that West Germany should install new short-range nuclear missiles. She remains the most outspokenly hawkish of the NATO leaders, but official say she has quietly initiated a review of defense policy and spending. In January, Mrs. Thatcher set up an informal group of four Cabinet ministers, including herself, to consider the issue. ``There's an acceptance there will be change,'' said a senior government source, who would talk about the matter only if not quoted by name. But there is no sign of swift cuts and no talk of dismantling Britain's independent nuclear arsenal, the source said. Britain reaffirmed in January it will replace its aging submarine-based nuclear missiles with a $10 billion U.S. Trident system, as planned, and military spending will remain at about 4 percent of gross national product through 1992. Mrs. Thatcher is resisting pressure for disarmament following the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. ``We must keep up the level of our defenses, both conventional and nuclear weapons, and not make changes until they are agreed with NATO and at the `Conventional Forces in Europe''' arms reduction talks in Vienna, Austria, she told Parliament in February. She was lukewarm about President Bush's proposal Jan. 31 to reduce U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe to 195,000 soldiers each. Opposition parties accuse her of trying to invent new threats or fretting about the resurgence of old ones, like a united Germany. ``The British government, alone of governments in NATO and the Warsaw Pact, seems actively to resent the challenge presented by the ending of the Cold War,'' said Gerald Kaufman, foreign affairs spokesman for the opposition Labor Party. Most Britons apparently share Mrs. Thatcher's caution about turning tanks into tractors before the changes in Eastern Europe are demonstrably here to stay. A National Opinion Poll in January indicated 63 percent believed Britain should not reduce military spending despite the changes in the Soviet bloc, and 76 percent felt Britain should retain at least some nuclear weapons as long as the Soviets do. Defense analysts foresee a cut of up to one-third in the 155,000-member army, including the phased withdrawal of many of the 66,700 British soldiers in West Germany, the largest foreign contingent after the Americans. ``The dismantling of most, if not all, of the British Army of the Rhine before the end of the decade now looks probable,'' said Henry Stanhope, defense writer for The Times of London. Other likely targets for cutbacks are the four-nation European Fighter Aircraft project and the British-made Challenger 2 tank. Such cuts will cost jobs and could have a psychological effect on a nation that, despite having lost an empire, still sees itself as a middle-rank world power. Even The Daily Telegraph, a conservative paper that supports a strong Britain, recognizes change must come. ``A review of Britain's continental commitment, the cornerstone of defense policy since 1945, has become inevitable,'' it said in an editorial. ``The Germans do not want us any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Hoffman Focuses on Humanitarian Drive as Curtain Closes on Shylock
DOC.TEXT: Now that ``The Merchant of Venice'' has concluded a successful Broadway run, Dustin Hoffman has two priorities _ a rare family vacation and finding a bone marrow donor for a terminally ill student. ``My wife told me a couple of weeks ago I haven't taken a week off in five years. I'm going to take three weeks off, take a rest with my family,'' said the two-time Academy Award-winner. ``Then I'll come back tenanciously and try to solve this.'' ``This'' is a drive to locate a donor for leukemia victim Allison Atlas, a 20-year-old business major at New York University who was told in August she could expect to live six months unless she gets a marrow transplant. Hoffman, 52, felt compelled to help after seeing Atlas, of Bethesda, Md., on television. He donated a six-figure sum and made public appeals for help. In the past, all of his humanitarian efforts have been done in private. ``I became involved to get the public to know they can be donors,'' the actor said in a recent interview. ``We're all inundated with monumental problems of the world, people asking us to give to the disease of the week,'' he said. ``What makes this so special is here is someone who's saying, `If you give me the money, I can find a donor and it can make the difference for me.' ``It picked me. Sometimes you see someone and you sense that she's the one person who would come to my aid if something happened to me,'' Hoffman said. ``It's the person who's the most giving, the most generous, the most courageous.'' ``The Merchant of Venice'' concluded a prosperous 15-week Broadway run on March 10 after getting a two-week extension. The play was the hit of the London theater season during a 16-week showing last summer, with Hoffman making his Shakespearean and British stage debut in the role of Shylock, the vengeful Jew who seeks his pound of flesh in return for an unpaid debt. The role brought different reactions in the two countries. ``New York is a different audience,'' Hoffman said. ``In London, you're playing on a turf where they grew up on Shakespeare the way you grew up on video games. ``They know how `The Merchant of Venice' ends. Here, they don't. They keep watching to see what's going to happen. It's a more vocal audience. They're probably closer to an Elizabethan audience.'' The actor, wearing a double-breasted navy sportscoat and an open collar shirt during a recent interview a few days before the final performance, fidgeted with a gray-flecked beard as he spoke. The whiskers would be shaved ``within 10 minutes of the curtain,'' Hoffman said with a laugh. Hoffman, winner of the 1979 Academy Award for best actor in ``Kramer vs. Kramer,'' repeated the feat last year in ``Rain Man'' for his sensitive portrayal of Raymond Babbitt, an autistic savant institutionalized for social disorders but who was a whiz with mathmetics. He was nominated for best actor four other times. ``Rain Man'' won him personal and financial rewards, but Hoffman also relished the gratitude of those who work with austistic people. ``Sure, you want to entertain people and be rich and famous. But at the same time, you want to alter perceptions or help them,'' he said. ``The most gratifying thing about `Rain Man' was the letters. We got letters from parents of kids and heads of organizations and doctors who gave us awards and plaques for putting autism on the map. It just took a lid off for some of these people,'' he said. In one case, a man who saw the movie called his autistic brother just to see how he was doing. ``Nothing was more gratifying than that,'' Hoffman said. The role of Raymond Babbitt evolved after Hoffman studied several real-life cases of autism, including Joseph Sullivan of Huntingdon, W.Va. ``There's the role that you're given and the role you create. That was one that was created. It wasn't on the page. `Midnight Cowboy' was written. The thing with `Tootsie' was a created role. `The Graduate' was written,'' Hoffman said. ``I enjoy something working when we create it from the ground up. Sometimes a critic comes to you and says, `Ah, it's easy to do that.' It looks easy, but you got to create it. ``It took a year to find a prototype that you would build all your stuff from, then to get it past doctors and get the story in dramatic form without intruding on the illness. How do you get sympathy for someone who doesn't want you around?'' Tom Cruise, who co-starred with Hoffman in ``Rain Man'' but was shut out in the Oscars, is nominated for best actor this year for ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' The movie's box-office appeal could give Cruise a boost when the Oscars are presented March 26. ``It's very hard to predict,'' Hoffman said. ``The odds are probably pretty good in the sense that the more popular the picture the better the odds are that (the Academy members) have seen it. ``Someone like Daniel Day-Lewis who was nominated for `My Left Foot' apparently has a much smaller audience.''
