DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
An AP Newsfeatures Extra
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 6 b&w photos, 1 graphic. ColorFoto subscribers get 2 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: Veterans of what they call The Movement returned to Selma, Ala., last week on a journey that in some respects had the flavor of a religious pilgrimage. For a reporter who covered Bloody Sunday and the Selma-to-Montgomery march 25 years ago, the memories came back with startling clarity.

The city just put up a new historical marker in a park alongside the Edmund Pettus Bridge on the blood-red banks of the Alabama River. That must mean that it won't be long before what happened here 25 years ago will seem as distant and unreal as all those other happenings duly noted in passing on fading historical markers across America, snippets of history largely ignored. This new one records ``Bloody Sunday'' and the ``Selma-to-Montgomery March.'' What happened here was the battle of Selma. No, not the battle of Selma when Yankee troops sacked the town and burned its Confederate arsenal. That was in 1865. This battle of Selma was in 1965 and lasted 10 weeks. What was sacked in 1965 was an arsenal of inequality, a systematic scheme to deny black Americans the right to vote. To the victors, the Voting Rights Act of 1965 ranks with the Emancipation Proclamation on the scale of liberty. Veterans of that battle, graying soldiers of what they still call, reverently, The Movement, returned last week from across the nation on a journey that in some respects had the flavor of a religious pilgrimage. They came to march in procession and to sing old hymns and to embrace old friends and walk on old battlegrounds, some hard to recognize now. And they came to convince a new generation of blacks, who take the ballot for granted, that even after the Selma-to-Montgomery march there remains a distance to travel. ``We are a long way from having our fair share of the American pie economically and socially,'' said John Lewis, a returning soldier from Atlanta. ``What better place to rededicate ourselves to all that is left to do?'' A billy stick fractured Lewis' skull at the Pettus Bridge on Bloody Sunday. Now he is a congressman, a symbol of both the event and its result. What better place indeed? ``Selma did more for the nation than Selma did for itself,'' Lewis said, referring to a current local racial dispute. Selma, then and now, is a city of about 27,000 people almost equally divided racially, about 52 percent black. The issue then was clear-cut, the right to vote. The issue now is less so. But it seems that even after 25 years when disputes get hot in Selma the sides line up according to race, often reluctantly on both sides. The dispute today is over the dismissal of the first black school superintendent in Alabama. The school board that hired him, made up of six whites and five blacks, voted not to renew his three-year contract. The vote was six to five. The lines were drawn and lawmen were called to keep order in the schools and at city hall. Selma 25 years ago became the national symbol of racial intolerance. Even its two fishing ponds, side by side, were racially segregated. Today Selma, of all places, qualifies at first look as a model of racial harmony and integration. Blacks and whites work, live, shop and worship side by side. Yet the city remains as racially polarized as ever. Selma today is like a marigold, lovely to behold but with a strange odor when you get up close. Lewis spoke on March 4 at the Brown Chapel AME Church, The Movement's foremost shrine. It was built by former slaves and sons of slaves and looks much as it did 25 years ago with its twin red towers and worn oak pews, although two chinaberry trees that gave shade outside are gone. Inside, its sweet musty smell of deliverance remains. For those 10 weeks in 1965 that venerable sanctuary throbbed with hymns of hope and courage and The Movement's anthem, ``We Shall Overcome,'' and trembled to the oratory of Martin Luther King Jr., whom many white Selmans back then called derisively ``de Lawd.'' Not long ago Joe Smitherman, who was Selma's mayor in 1965 and remains so today, said from the pulpit of Brown Chapel: ``My hands are as dirty as the others. I ordered the arrest of Dr. King. We were wrong. I did it. I'm sorry.'' Bloody Sunday was March 7, a dour and chilly day. About 600 blacks left Brown Chapel and crossed the Pettus Bridge. They aimed to march to Montgomery, the state capital 54 miles away, to petition Gov. George Wallace in person for the right to vote. Wallace forbade the march. The hymn they sang at Brown Chapel that morning was ``Nobody knows the trouble I've seen.'' And nobody had. Nobody could have forseen the orgy of official violence that turned back the marchers, state troopers with clubs and tear gas and deputies on horseback with bullwhips.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
SELMA, Ala.: with bullwhips.
DOC.TEXT: Americans by the hundreds, black and white, came to Selma in outrage. For two weeks they camped outside Brown Chapel beneath the chinaberry trees and on the dirt road in front, Sylvan Street. A thick rope confined them to that street in Selma. Today, Sylvan Street has been renamed. It is now Martin Luther King Jr. Street. ``It's the longest street sign in town,'' said Smitherman grandly. The street is now paved, and lit, as are all the streets in east Selma now, and there are no more outhouses in the neighborhood, which were commonplace. In front of Brown Chapel, where the chinaberry trees used to be, a bronze bust of King rests on a tall granite monument. So much of the Selma of '65 is gone, largely unmourned. A car dealership has replaced the Silver Moon Cafe. There, on the sidewalk out front, one of those white sympathizers who came to Selma, James Reeb, a minister from Boston, was bludgeoned to death two days after Bloody Sunday. The night he lay dying a throng kept candlelight vigil on Sylvan Street, all night, behind the rope, in the rain. The whites-only Selma Del eatery on Broad Street, the main drag, is gone. In its place stands _ are you ready? _ the Booker T. Washington Insurance Co. Camp Selma is gone, too. It was once an old chain-gang camp long abandoned and then revived in 1965. Sheriff Jim Clark, whose lapel button said ``NEVER,'' arrested blacks by the hundreds when they lined up in front of the courthouse to register to vote. Camp Selma was where he imprisoned them. Camp Selma also accommodated the 3,000 Army regulars, Alabama National Guardsmen and federal marshals sent to protect the ultimate march, the victory march from Selma to Montgomery on March 21-25. The night before the march 4,000 people, the potential marchers themselves, slept wherever they could find a place, some on church pews, some on couches in the housing project across from Brown Chapel, some on the Sylvan Street dirt rolled in blankets in a cold wind under a waning three-quarter moon. Next morning, the first day of spring, they met at Brown Chapel, prayed, sang and gathered at the river, at the Pettus Bridge, and began a journey that seemed somehow biblical after all that had gone before. Even the old highway, the route of the march, is not as it was. It was called then the Jefferson Davis Highway, a two-lane road most of the way to Montgomery. So the marchers' numbers were reduced, by court decree, to 300 when they reached the two-lane stretch in Lowndes County. The rest hoofed it back to Selma or hitched rides with volunteer drivers in hired cars and buses. Today the Jefferson Davis Highway is simply Highway 80, a divided four-lane motorway. The sharecropper shacks have vanished. If the re-enactors of the march sipped no well water they at least were cheered by meadowlarks and mockingbirds, which still abound along the way. When the 1965 march reached the outskirts of Montgomery its numbers again swelled to 4,000, then to 10,000, to 20,000, and on the next afternoon to at least 25,000. They marched past a street now, but not then, named Rosa Parks Avenue, named for the black woman who refused to move to the back of a Montgomery bus. They marched up Dexter Avenue past the church where Martin Luther King Jr. was pastor, the man who agreed reluctantly to take up Mrs. Parks' cause, to eventually become the charismatic head of what became The Movement. And on they marched to the steps of the building where Jefferson Davis took the oath of office as president of the Confederacy, and where, on that day, King exhorted the great congregation of pilgrims in his measured cadences to keep on, keep on. ``How long? Not long, because truth pressed to earth shall rise again.'' That night, the worst happened after the protecting federal army had departed. Ku Klux Klan nightriders shot Viola Liuzzo of Detroit, white, one of the volunteer shuttle drivers, shot her dead in her car in the Big Swamp area of Lowndes County. She was The Movement's 11th martyr. No historical marker commemorates the spot where she died. But somebody, nobody seems to know who, sees to a floral wreath nearby, hanging on a fence. It is there today.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find More Men Caring for Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Edith Stricoff once loved to dance and to travel, but now cannot even brush her teeth on her own. Her husband, Bernard, cleans house, cooks, does laundry, bathes his wife and helps her use a commode in a corner of the living room, where a hospital bed contrasts with colorful Peruvian weavings from a vacation a dozen years ago. Stricoff, 65, said he cares for his 64-year-old wife up to 20 hours a day, on call even through the night, when a groan from downstairs will rouse him to see if she's cold or her arm is stuck under her body. For four hours a day, he has hired help. People sometimes suggest a nursing home. They say Edith Stricoff, former bookkeeper and mother of three, is a burden at her advanced stage of Alzheimer's disease. But Stricoff hums old songs the couple once danced to and sometimes thinks she murmurs his name as he hugs her in the morning. ``You don't throw an injured child out of the house because the child is injured,'' he said. ``Why should I do that to my wife?'' A growing number of men are caring for aging and infirm wives, parents and other relatives, according to a study by Lenard W. Kaye and Jeffrey S. Applegate, professors at the Graduate School of Social Work and Social Research at Bryn Mawr College in suburban Philadelphia. ``Men's roles as caregivers have traditionally been minimized, if not virtually dismissed, by the professional and lay public alike,'' they write in their study. Although women comprise two-thirds to three-fourths of an estimated 7 million caregivers nationwide, a significant number of men ``have been willing to commit a substantial portion of their lives, both in time and effort, to this challenging task,'' the researchers said. More men are doing so largely because women are stretched to the limit by careers, other family demands and the rising number of elderly, the researchers say. Other factors include men's changing attitudes toward family and cuts in governmental aid for elder care, they say. Kaye said in an interview the study was intended to address the special needs of male caregivers. ``In no way are we trying to cancel out the dominant role _ no question it's a dominant role _ played by women,'' he said. ``We just believe that they cannot keep up at this rate. We need to be able to turn and be willing to consider alternative routes to take when we talk about family caregiving.'' The study is based on surveys of 152 leaders of caregiver support groups and 148 male participants in such groups across the nation. The research, supported by a grant from the Andrus Foundation of the American Association of Retired Persons, also included in-depth interviews with 30 male caregivers and nine elderly recipients in the Philadelphia region and surveys of a 26-member national expert panel. Seven of eight men in the study considered themselves primary caregivers, and more than a third were sole care providers. Only 20 percent said they were helped by more than two relatives. Four of five cared for people with Alzheimer's, the progressive brain disorder that causes premature senility. The men often continued to work while providing care and resisted joining support groups, preferring to ``go it alone'' or fearing participation would be an admission of failure. In general, the men felt most competent at such tasks as paying bills, taking people to doctors and helping with telephoning and letter-writing. They felt least competent at helping with grooming, bathing and dressing. The study is limited by its size and by the fact that caregivers surveyed were primarily white, married men over age 60, living with and caring for wives, and relatively secure financially. Minority and low-income men tend less than white, middle-class men to join the support groups from which the sample was drawn, Kaye said. Eloise Rathbone-McCuan, professor of social welfare at the University of Kansas, said she had not seen any evidence of an increasing number of men providing elder care. But she agreed that ``the demographics of women and aging will force men to be confronted with many new roles,'' especially caregiving. Robyn Stone, a research fellow at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, said the study could help draw more attention to caregiving in general, which has often been viewed as a women's issue. ``From a political perspective, since it's still primarily a man's world, there may be more of a serious focus on this problem,'' she said. Kaye and Applegate said their results indicate support groups should reach out more to men, who otherwise may end up enduring too much of the burden and allowing their own health to deteriorate. Advertisements for support groups should include more men and emphasize such practical topics as legal issues, finding home health care, stages of Alzheimer's disease and information on government benefits, they said. ``Men are probably going to hesitate getting involved in a group if you play up too strongly the emotional payoff, the benefits of sharing experiences,'' Kaye said. Stricoff, who prided himself on being able to work things out himself as his wife grew more ill, resisted joining a support group sponsored by the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. ``I said, `Why do I have to go to a group for? Sit there and listen to them. What are they going to tell me? I'm living with the damn thing. I know what it is,''' Stricoff said. But his children and other relatives kept after him. ``And I went, and surprisingly enough, it was fulfilling,'' he said. Now he tries not to miss monthly meetings, because of the tips he picks up on ways to help his wife and the moral support. ``It's not that misery likes company,'' he said. ``That's just not the story. It makes you talk about things that you don't usually talk about.'' Stricoff said he provides most of his wife's care and does most of the household tasks by himself, although the couple's children, who are grown and live in the Philadelphia suburbs and Florida, call regularly and help on weekends. A woman employed by a home health-care firm also comes in four hours a day to give Stricoff a break and allow him to maintain his accounts as a hosiery salesman for a Dallas company. Some friends also have stayed close. The support makes it easier to bear his wife's helplessness. He must stroke her cheeks to get her to chew and cleans her daily with a washcloth from head to toe. But when people ask him why he doesn't complain, he asks what there is to complain about. ``You've got to remember how my wife would have reacted had I been in that situation,'' he said. ``I honestly feel she would probably do as much as she physically can for me, which is what I'm doing for my wife. I do it because of my love for her.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Tax Law Contains Special Features for Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Medicare's catastrophic health-care program is history, but its legacy lingers in this year's tax forms. Congress didn't kill the year-old medical program until after the Internal Revenue Service had sent the 1989 tax returns to the printer, so forms 1040 and 1040A contain instructions for payment of a seniors-only catastrophic surtax that doesn't exist. The catastrophic question is a one-year quirk in the income tax picture that bodes well for senior citizens, but several other continuing provisions in federal law also help to make tax time a little less taxing for the elderly. These provisions, which include a higher standard deduction and more liberal filing requirements for the elderly, mean many people must reacquaint themselves with the tax code when they turn 65, even if they've been doing their own taxes for decades. ``Many older taxpayers are unfamiliar with the special provisions of the Internal Revenue Code which become available to them when they reach age 65,'' the House Aging Committee said in its annual tax guide for older Americans. In addition to benefits that automatically become available at age 65, other changes in the tax-filing routine occur as older Americans mrity benefits, and rules for pension and annuity income. The IRS also offers free tax-preparation help to the elderly through two programs _ Volunteer Income Tax Assistance and Tax Counseling for the Elderly. People can call the taxpayer service number listed in their tax package or in the telephone book to find out where to get assistance. Volunteers in both programs can help people prepare simple tax forms, although the latter is specifically targeted toward the needs of the elderly. Tax Counseling for the Elderly is jointly sponsored by the IRS and the American Association of Retired Persons, which provides 30,000 trained counselors to assist more than 1.5 million older taxpayers a year with federal and state tax forms. The program also serves more than 47,000 shut-ins who cannot visit tax assistance sites. ``We find a lot of people who are intimidated by the form itself,'' said AARP's Patty Hoath. ``We also find people who perhaps have not been in a situation to do the tax form in the past, such as someone who is newly widowed.'' Others need help dealing with tax issues they haven't faced in the past, such as taxation of Social Security benefits or interpretation of pension benefit statements, Ms. Hoath said. The IRS has notified senior citizens that because the catastrophic surtax was repealed, they should ignore Line 54 on Form 1040 and Line 23 on Form 1040A. Anyone who made extra estimated tax payments during 1989 to cover the catastrophic surtax will receive a refund of their overpayments. ``We have tried to get the word out that even though the line appears on the tax form, the provision no longer exists,'' said IRS spokesman Steve Pyrek. ``Some people, no matter what, will include information on that line of the return.'' The repeal of the supplemental Medicare premium affects about 40 percent of the elderly, who would have paid $22.50 for every $150 of federal income tax liability. About 6 percent would have paid the maximum amount of $800 per person. Congress repealed the catastrophic program in November under pressure from higher-income senior citizens, many of whom already had duplicate private coverage and who said the expanded government medical benefits weren't worth the price tag.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: New Day Care Center Supervises Young and Old
DOC.TEXT: As the American population ages amid a mini baby boom, an increasing number of parents must care for grandmother as well as bring up baby _ and juggle full-time jobs. To help families caught in that triple bind, Stride Rite Corp. has opened what company officials say is the nation's only inter-generational day care center. Karen Leibold, director of the center at the company's headquarters, hopes it will become the kind of place where working parents can drop off their children and elderly relatives in the morning and know they will have been fed, entertained, educated and cared for when they pick them up in the evening. The fourth floor of the shoe-manufacturing company has been remodeled to accommodate up to 55 children and 24 older people. The program is open both to the 500 Stride Rite employees in Cambridge and community residents. The weekly fee for elderly care is $140. Child care fees range from $130 to $170 a week. On a recent visit to the center, 4-year-olds were being dressed for a winter walk, toddlers were puzzling over a talking toy and a group of very excited youngsters was getting a cooking lesson. ``We're making play dough,'' one cried out. At the other end of the floor, in a sunny room affectionately dubbed ``the library,'' a grandmother was relaxing on a couch and talking with a staff member. ``It's nice in here,'' she said, glancing around the room that will eventually have additional ottomans and living-room lamps. ``It's comfortable.'' Stride Rite was already a corporate pioneer in providing day care for its employees when a newspaper article on the dilemma of families caught between caring for elderly relatives and children caught the attention of Chairman Arnold Hyatt about three years ago. He immediately wrote a memo to the director of the company's day care program saying the company should create a program for the old as well as the young. A survey of Stride Rite employees found about 25 percent were caring for an elderly relative and an additional 13 percent expected to do so in the future. Leibold said these figures mirrored national trends. She said the study also indicated that a ``daughter track'' existed as well as the ``mommy track.'' Mommy track refers to the course many females take when they juggle jobs and child care. Leibold said National Council on Aging studies found that most care givers for the elderly are women who then may be forced to limit the time devoted to a career. The result of the survey and Hyatt's memo was a $700,000 investment by Stride Rite in designing 8,500 square feet of space into groups of rooms for children and the elderly, with administrative offices and dining facilities in between. Painted in purple, teal and apricot, the center is designed to create a feeling of comfort and cheer, to look like ``grandmother's front porch,'' rather than an institution or even a corporate office, Stride Rite spokeswoman Deborah Singer said. At one end of the floor is an area set aside for the elderly. It includes an arts and crafts area and the ``library'' designed to look ``like someone's living room,'' Leibold said. The other end of the floor has classrooms for ages 2 through 5, all furnished with miniature furniture, splotchy watercolors and a scattering of dolls and wooden blocks. The dining area, shared by both groups, has adult-size tables and chairs and child-size tables and chairs. A long counter, featuring a sink, a hot pad and adjustable chairs, will provide facilities for the adults to cook and the children to learn to cook. ``What we've done is encourage interaction between children and the elderly and ensure the privacy of each group,'' Leibold said. From 7:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. both groups have supervised activities, meals, crafts and exercise programs _ sometimes together. Leibold hopes this will help to ``get rid of stereotypes that old people and young people have about each other.'' The program is designed for elderly who do not need extensive medical attention, but require general supervision for daily activities. Only two are currently at the center, and Leibold said the company is working to inform employees and the community of the elderly program. Stride Rite was one of the first companies to open its own day care center in 1971, and Leibold hopes the inter-generational center will be a model for other such centers. Singer said the facility hopes to provide its elderly with meaningful activities. A computer will be installed, and Singer hopes that one day the seniors could produce a newsletter for the center. The company is working with Wheelock College and the Somerville-Cambridge Elder Services organization to develop elderly programs. ``Families are very stressed today,'' Leibold said. ``Fewer and fewer families are living within close contact with each other.'' The new center will ``help bring the generations together,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Charlie Tucker _ Selling Fuller Brushes at 90
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The figures on his order pad are harder to make out these days, his hearing aids can turn conversations into shouting matches, and he doesn't go anywhere without a cane. But at 90, Charlie Tucker is still doing what he does best, peddling mops and dusters, can openers and furniture polish _ just about anything you might need. And if he doesn't get around quite as good as he used to, he still knows how to move Fuller brushes. ``Your wife might be able to use this,'' he says, opening a box in his dining room and pulling out a mop head that looks kind of like Raggedy Ann as a blonde. ``It's regularly $5, but we've got it on special for just $3.99. Oh, you're not married?'' Tucker hardly misses a beat. ``Well, how about your mom?'' Tucker has been selling household products for Fuller Brush for 59 years, and if you live in this part of the country, he's probably tried to entice you with a free spatula or vegetable brush. ``I just love sales work, I reckon,'' says Tucker, a tidy, compact man whose perfect white hair may be a byproduct of decades of making a good first impression. Mrs. Eugene Collins, 61, of Chattanooga, has known Tucker since she was a teen-ager and figures she's probably bought about every product Fuller has ever made. ``I'm still using them. I love them, and I think Mr. Tucker has been a part of that because he is so knowledgeable and tells you how to do it and how to use them.'' Tucker got his start at age 12, selling dynamite and doing odd jobs at a company store in the Virginia coal fields. After World War I, he hawked newspapers on trains, then worked as a buyer of piece goods and women's ready-to-wear garments. But in 1931, his employer went out of business, and Tucker found himself in the Great Depression with a wife and children but no job. So he answered an ad for Fuller Brush, and went to work in Elizabethton, selling $150 worth of goods his first week. Within a few weeks, that was his daily total, earning him the congratulations of company founder Alfred C. Fuller and a promotion to branch manager in Memphis. He took a similar job in Chattanooga in 1934, managing as many as 35 salesmen until Fuller Brush was sold in the 1960s to Consolidated Foods Inc. of Chicago. The new owners decided to eliminate the district offices, and Tucker decided to return to the sidewalks. ``I was back where I started,'' he said. ``I was too old to go out and hunt a new job, but I figured I could sell Fuller brushes.'' Over the last 20 years, Tucker has been a familiar figure on Chattanooga streets, often using a mop handle to prop open the trunk of his portable warehouse, a 1968 Plymouth Fury. He's found himself thrust into roles of marriage counselor and baby sitter, and he's had a door slammed in his face so hard the glass shattered. ``I've been insulted and everything else, but I put my high feelings in the closet and lock the door, because I would have had them hurt if I'd taken everything seriously,'' he said. But Tucker took his co-workers seriously. Jim Clayton, 72, worked for Fuller Brush for 47 years. One day, he said, he and Tucker were in Dayton, Tenn., and Tucker told him to go to Bryan College, saying the maintenance department probably needed a dozen brooms. ``Well, I walked to the boiler room and the guy said, `Hello,' and I said, `I'm the Fuller Brush man,' and he said, `Bring me a dozen brooms. Now if I'd been Charlie Tucker, I'd have said, `You catch these customers down here and I'll go tend to that (college). No use kidding myself. But that's just the kind of guy Charlie Tucker always was.'' When Tucker went to work in 1931, the company offered about a dozen items. Now, there are 400 products and 13,000 sales representatives, all of whom still work strictly on commission. It's the kind of challenge Tucker likes. ``We're selling one day, and I'm on this porch and he's on the porch next door,'' Clayton said. ``And this lady comes to the door, and she don't want to buy. And he said, `Well, I understand. But when you see your neighbors using our specials, I want to remember you had a chance to turn it down. I'll just step in and show it to you.' And he stepped in and then stepped out in about three minutes with a nice order.'' ``I've never yet found a door that I'd hesitate to knock on, whether it's the governor's or whoever's,'' Tucker said with a grin. ``I'm no high-pressure salesman, but maybe I'll try to create a desire sufficient to overcome your resistance.'' These days, Tucker relies mostly on telephone sales by his wife, Neoma, and on repeat customers who pick up their goods at his home in north Chattanooga. He hasn't driven since last summer, when he underwent complicated heart and kidney surgery, but after nearly 60 years, it's hard to kick the habit. He's feeling better, and his eyes light up at the mention of spring. ``If I get anywhere back to normal, I'll be back knocking on doors.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Want to See if Laughter Really Is the Best Medicine
DOC.TEXT: Researchers will try to determine if laughter really is the best medicine by showing comic films to about 150 nursing home residents in the Carolinas. The study will use films such as those by the Marx brothers and W.C. Fields to see whether humor reduces requests for non-prescription pain medication, said Fran McGuire, head of the project. ``If this kind of thing is true, it would be a tremendous tool for activity directors'' in nursing homes and other group settings, McGuire said. A small-scale film study by the department two years ago found what appeared to be ``dramatic decreases'' in requests for pain medication, he said. That could have been the result of chemical changes in the body relieving pain or the result of reduced stress, which would reduce pain. However, McGuire said that study was so limited that no conclusive findings could be documented. The new study will attempt to broaden the scope and come up with findings that could be used by nursing homes to improve their residents' quality of life, he said. In addition to the quantitative measure of pain medication, the study also will try to measure the residents' happiness through a written test. In addition to classic comic movdistribution of a deceased person's property, according to a report by a senior citizens group. Probate, also called estate administration, is the process by which the debts of someone who has died are paid and the deceased's remaining property is distributed to the rightful owners. The American Association of Retired Persons said its study of 900 probate cases in California, Delaware and Wisconsin found that attorney fees sometimes exceeded 20 percent of the value of the property and some estates took more than a year to settle. Cases in which the deceased person had a will sometimes took just as long to settle as those without a will, it said. ``With redundant reporting and notice requirements, and flexible `deadlines' that are often unenforced or ignored, probate frequently lasts more than a year,'' the report said. It said the three states where cases were studied were indicative of problems across the country, and it estimated probate fees could cost $2 billion or more each year nationally. ``For the estates of the middle class, attorney and personal representative fees can deplete the assets by as much as 10 percent even in uncomplicated cases,'' the report said. AARP recommended that states adopt simple, less costly probate procedures. ``Probate as generally practiced in the United States is an anachronism,'' the report said. ``Probate's procedures and protections, even with recent reforms, are inappropriate for all but the most exceptional cases.'' Horace Deets, AARP's executive director, said probate is largely an older's person's issue. ``Many of these older consumers who want to leave their property with their loved ones have no idea how legal fees can affect their intended gifts,'' Deets said.
AARP offers a free publication on probate procedures. It may be obtained by writing to: A Consumer's Guide to Probate, AARP Fulfillment, 1909 K St. NW, Washington, DC, 20049.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, March 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Don't Delay Making a Will
DOC.TEXT: Paul J. Lochray is an attorney and expert in estate planning for the Denver-based College for Financial Planning.

Estate planning and postmortem planning make most people squirm. Many of us avoid making a will or setting a plan for disposition of assets upon our death for two simple reasons: We are uneasy with the thought that we will die, and we feel that our estates are too small to justify the time and expense involved in preparing a will. Regardless of the size of your estate or your philosophy on death, estate planning and postmortem planning involve everything you have worked for during your life _ and ensure that your wishes will be followed should you become incapacitated or die. There are five important reasons for making a will: You can choose your donees, minimize taxes, appoint a guardian, name an executor and establish a domicile. In the absence of a will, up to half a married person's property usually will be distributed to the surviving spouse, with the remainder passing to the deceased's children. Only if the deceased had adopted the spouse's children from a previous marriage would those children be included in the distribution of property. Even though this distribution of property may not be consistent with your wishes, you have no recourse. By failing to prepare a will, you have abdicated the right to select your beneficiaries, and what and how much each beneficiary is to receive. A properly prepared will can help to alleviate any tax liability that might be levied against your estate. Taxable estates valued at less than $600,000 are exempt from federal estate tax, but ``hidden resources'' _ life insurance policies naming the decedent as the insured, or qualified retirement plan benefits and IRAs can swell the estate's value, oftentimes making it subject to federal estate taxation. Trusts and other techniques available through your will can lessen this tax burden. If you have children, perhaps your greatest concern is who would take care of them if both you and your spouse died. A will can be used to name a guardian. Courts generally will accommodate the wishes of the parents in cases where a guardian is named. Without a will, you have no say in who carries out the administration of your estate. If no will exists, the court will appoint an administrator. And the court could appoint a creditor (They sometimes qualify for this position), which would not necessarily be in the best interests of your estate. By naming an executor, you can ensure that a trustworthy person of your choosing will handle the administration of your estate. Finally, for tax and other reasons, you may want to establish a particular state as your state of domicile, or legal residence. For example, if you have moved frequently, or have homes in more than one state, each state could claim you as a resident and subject the estate to multiple probate proceedings and overlapping claims to state death or inheritance taxes. To minimize that risk, indicate clearly in your will which state you claim as domicile. Experts agree that many people fail to recognize the importance of a will. A person who dies ``intestate,'' without a will, can leave many problems for loved ones and greatly reduce the chances that undocumented intentions will be carried out. The solution for everyone _ no matter the size of the estate _ is to have a will prepared now and alleviate some of the uncertainties and problems that could arise later.

American Express Co. said it would buy all the common stock in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. that it doesn't already own and had ended talks with third parties about possible changes in ownership of the troubled brokerage. The move culminates months of effort by American Express to shore up Shearson's finances and indicates the travel and financial services company has abandoned hopes of reducing its exposure to the volatile securities industry. James D. Robinson III, chairman and chief executive of American Express, said in a statement Sunday, ``These actions affirm American Express's long-term commitment to Shearson Lehman Hutton and its customers, and to working with its management team.''

The government's main economic forecasting gauge held steady in January, offering signs of an aimless economy with little growth but little chance of a recession either. Economist Kevin Logan of the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York said Friday the report on the Index of Leading Economic Indicators means the economy ``is moving sideways. ... There is not a lot of strength but neither is there pervasive weakness.'' The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, and has risen for the previous two months.

The government said sales of new homes fell 7.1 percent in January to their lowest level in nearly a year, despite incentives to builders to offset industry weakness and encourage buying. The Commerce Department said Friday new, single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 589,000 units in January, the worst performance since sales fell to 556,000 homes on an annual basis last March.

Federal regulators are investigating $260 million in employee bonuses paid by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. shortly before collapsing, Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said. Breeden also said Friday he did not believe that $650 million in fines and penalties extracted from Drexel to settle civil and criminal securities fraud charges last year pushed the firm's parent company into bankruptcy court. Breeden told the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee the SEC was looking into whether there was any wrongdoing in the cash and stock bonuses Drexel paid employees in the months leading to the Feb. 13 bankruptcy filing.

Cigna Corp. said it was dropping personal auto insurance coverage because the division generates little business and is only marginally profitable. Cigna's specialty is commercial insurance coverage and is rated one of the nation's largest in that area. Cigna has only 0.8 percent of the national business in personal auto insurance. Its plans were disclosed Friday.

A bipartisan commission recommended a $66 billion plan to provide health care coverage to nearly all Americans but drew criticism from Congress and some of its own members for failing to recommend a way to pay. The U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care voted Friday to send Congress proposals to provide universal health insurance, phased in over five years, and a proposal to ensure long-term health care to Americans.

The government told the nation's airlines to end discrimination against the handicapped, but barred people who are blind, frail, obese, disabled or under 15 from sitting in rows with emergency exits. The Transportation Department order was sharply criticized Friday by the Air Transport Association, which said it would dimish safety. The National Federation of the Blind blasted the exit-row rule as discriminatory.

Regulators seized a large Arizona savings institution, leaving only four thrifts operating independently in the economically troubled state. Pima Savings and Loan Association, Tuscon, was taken over Friday by the Resolution Trust Corp., an agency created last August to sell or close insolvent thrift institutions.

A government advisory council said Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co., Japan's telecommunications giant, should be split into three separate companies within five years. The recommendations Friday by the Telecommunications Council concluded a two-year study that contended NTT's current virtual monopoly on telephone service has hindered free competition in Japan's telecommunications market and hurt efficient management.

Renewed confidence in the economic outlook and in U.S. financial markets propelled stock prices higher Friday for a fifth straight session. The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 24.77 points to finish at 2,660.36, its best closing level since mid-January. The blue-chip indicator climbed 96.17 points in its five-day winning streak. The dollar finished mixed. Bond prices bounced back from a two-day tumble. Coffee, copper and cocoa futures prices rose sharply; precious metals retreated; energy futures advanced; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: American Express To Buy All Outstanding Common Stock in Brokerage
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. said it would buy all the common stock in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. that it doesn't already own and had ended talks with third parties about possible changes in ownership of the troubled brokerage. The move culminates months of effort by American Express to shore up Shearson's finances and indicates the travel and financial services company has abandoned hopes of reducing its exposure to the volatile securities industry. ``These actions affirm American Express's long-term commitment to Shearson Lehman Hutton and its customers, and to working with its management team,'' James D. Robinson III, chairman and chief executive of American Express, said in a statement Sunday. American Express will buy out the minority stake in Shearson through a stock swap valued at $350 million, Shearson spokesman Lawrence Armour said. That brings the total amount American Express has invested in Shearson in recent months to well over $1 billion. Shearson expanded rapidly through acquisitions in the 1980s to become the nation's second-largest brokerage, but its recent struggles to cope with a downturn in the securities business have led to thousands of layoffs and turmoil in its management ranks. American Expreses first moved to strengthen its grip last month by ousting chairman and chief executive Peter A. Cohen, the man who guided the firm's explosive growth, and replacing him with Howard L. Clark Jr., American Express' chief financial officer. As a result of a review led by Clark, ``We are confident that Shearson Lehman Hutton can be returned to levels of profitability that will maintain its position as a premier company in the securities industry,'' Robinson said. In the same statement Clark said, ``This vote of confidence from American Express gives us the support we will need to implement the findings of our strategic review and achieve successful performance levels as a leader in the securities industry.'' Shearson has been searching for capital to avoid a threatened downgrading of its credit rating, which could increase its costs by forcing it to pay higher interest rates on its borrowings. At the same time, American Express had been seeking to reduce its 61 percent stake in Shearson to less than half to remove the firm from its balance sheet and reduce its exposure to Wall Street's sharp profit swings. A sharp drop in Shearson's share price forced it to abandon that plan, though. Last week, American Express said it would increase its ownership by an unspecified amount by injecting $750 million into the brokerage. In December, American Express injected $250 million into Shearson. American Express had held talks recently about a possible merger of Shearson with Primerica Corp.'s Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. brokerage unit, but the company said last week it had terminated discussions. American Express may have decided to buy out minority stockholders now because Clark's appointment has given the company control of Shearson's management, said Perrin Long, who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Services. ``This is the first time American Express has been in the catbird seat since it acquired Shearson back in 1981,'' he said. As part of a tax-free merger of one of its subsidiaries with Shearson, American Express plans to exchange 0.426 of its common shares for each outstanding common share in Shearson. Based on Friday's closing prices of $29.37{ for American Express and $12.50 for Shearson, the swap values the minority stake at $350 million. ``They probably think this is a reasonable time to go in and buy the stock back'' because of the recent drop in Shearson's share price, Long said. American Express also said it was considering adding to its own equity capital through either a public or private offering of stock. No decisions have been made yet about the timing or size of any offering, said Armour, the spokesman. The latest move should help Shearson by removing the uncertainty that has dogged the firm since American Express first said it intended to reduce its stake, Long said. ``I think it would be a healthy thing because once you stop the talk everybody can get down to business,'' he said. Sunday's announcement doesn't affect Nippon Life Insurance Co.'s holding of 13 million shares of convertible voting preferred stock, which gives it a voting stake of about 13 percent in Shearson. Like other Wall Street houses, Shearson has been beset by a downturn in merger activity, securities underwriting and sluggish stock and bond trading since the October 1987 stock market crash. Shearson announced last week it would lay off 2,000 workers to reduce its costs by about $400 million a year, and it left open the prospect of still more job cuts. The brokerage dropped 800 workers late last year. The announced layoffs would reduce Shearson's work force to 33,500 from a peak of 46,000 in January 1988. Shearson reported 1989 earnings of $110 million, up from $96 million a year earlier, but a third of the profits came from the sale of a money management unit. Investment banking revenue, which includes merger advising and securities underwriting, was down 27 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Panel To Hear Arguments On New U.S. Law
DOC.TEXT: An international panel is to decide in April whether an American law banning the import of undersized lobsters violates the Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Canada. The panel, which was scheduled to hear arguments on the dispute today, is to recommend a resolution in mid-May that could range from leaving the law as it is to banning it altogether. The board of three Americans and two Canadians could also call for a compromise. ``Lobster fishing is the backbone of hundreds of coastal communities in Canada. Millions and millions of dollars in lost income are at stake,'' said John Kearney, who represents the Maritime Fishermen's Union in Nova Scotia. Bob Brown, director of the Maine Import-Export Lobster Dealers Association, said the dispute is ``on everybody's lips on both sides of the border.'' At issue is a bill that President Bush signed into law in December, prohibiting the importation or interstate transportation of lobsters that do not meet federal minimum-size standards. Lobsters that are shorter than 3\ inches from the eye socket to where the tail begins are illegal under the new law. By 1992, the minimum legal size will be 3 5-16 inches. But in Canada, lobster fishermen can catch lobsters 1-16th of an inch shorter than those allowed in the United States. Lobstermen, dealers and industry observers throughout New England and the Canadian Maritime provinces say the panel's decision could have a major impact on the industry. ``It could change the way lobsters are marketed,'' and more significantly might change the way the government regulates lobster management, said University of Southern Maine Professor Charles Colgan, a former state economist. Canadian officials argue that the law is purely a trade barrier that violates the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. They say their country has plenty of conservation laws, and the United States has no right to tell them how to manage their resources. American lobstermen have complained to Congress that they could not compete against the smaller, less expensive Canadian lobsters, which were being shipped to American markets. The new law barring the smaller lobsters could mean a potential loss to Canada of $20 million to $30 million in exports each year. American officials maintain that the law will protect the lobster population by allowing more lobsters to live long enough to reproduce. The new law as written will help American dealers protect their domestic markets, but it also could lead to the loss of foreign markets, industry sources say. Maine dealers previously could buy smaller lobsters from Canada and pack them for shipment to out-of-state markets. The new law prohibits that practice, and Maine and New England exporters are making changes to adapt to the law. The board hearing the dispute could call for a compromise that would allow imports only to American export companies or only during certain times of the year, or to place quotas on undersize lobster imports. The panel's decision would not be binding, but both countries are obligated to honor it under provisions of the Free Trade Agreement. It is only the second time since the Free Trade Agreement was enacted on Jan. 1, 1989 that a panel has convened to resolve a trade dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Strikers Rally: One Year Later
With PM-Eastern-Strikers
DOC.TEXT: Exactly one year after 8,000 machinists walked off the job at Eastern Airlines, several hundred union members and supporters rallied at La Guardia Airport to remember the strikers. Vowing solidarity, representatives of dozens of unions stood Sunday in a cold, windy parking lot outside a Continental hangar. ``We're here to show the public that we're still on strike and we'll stay on strike for dignity in the workplace,'' said LeRoy Washington, general chairman of the machinists' union, ``and to tell people not to fly Eastern and Continental.'' The demonstration in New York coincided with others in other cities on Sunday. ``It hasn't been the kind of strike we wanted,'' Washington added, ``but today we celebrate the solidarity of the Eastern strikers. We're not going to give up.'' Eight thousand members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers struck over a new contract on March 4, 1989. Texas Air wanted the union to take a pay cut, change workplace rules and allow some work to be contracted out. ``It's great to have the support of so many unions,'' said Pete Voccola, a union vice president and the strike coordinator at La Guardia, who was still optimistic. ``We hope to either go back to work or put Frank Lorenzo out of business.'' ``The airline is losing $2 million a day at a time when the rest of the industry is doing well,'' he said. ``So there's still a possibility of getting our jobs back. We feel it's salvageable.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo was invited to the rally. Robert Gollnick, state deputy labor commissioner, came in his place. ``The governor's commitment to these people is still strong,'' said Gollnick. ``But this is a federal issue and the federal government should be doing something.'' The atmosphere at the rally was not desperate, but demonstrators expressed frustration and anger towards Lorenzo, president of Texas Air, the parent company of Eastern and Continental Airlines. ``There are no kind words for him,'' said Washington. ``The injustice at Eastern Airlines was created by Lorenzo. Hundreds of hard-working men and women have lost their homes and their standards of living because of this man.'' ``The man is devoid of any principles,'' added Ed Cleary, the New York State president of the AFL-CIO. The union claims Lorenzo deliberately drained Eastern's resources to build a non-union airline. Most people at the rally wore anti-Lorenzo buttons and displayed anti-Lorenzo signs. There were several chants of ``Down With Lorenzo.'' Other speakers called for President Bush to intervene in the year-old dispute and show support for union members in the United States. ``Mr. President, all over Eastern Europe, labor has risen up to lead their countries to freer societies,'' said George Poulin, vice president of the machinists' union for the Northeast U.S. ``You embraced them and promised to assist them, and rightfully so. But there's another eastern conflict _ Eastern Airlines. It's time to embrace the Eastern strikers like you embraced Lech Walesa.''

DOC.HEAD: Fruit of the Loom to Build Two Plants in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Fruit of the Loom Inc. said Monday it would invest $93 million to build two plants in economically depressed Northern Ireland. The Northern Ireland Office said the plants will employ up to 500 people in the province, which has an unemployment rate of 14 percent, the highest in Britain. Fruit of the Loom's investment is the single largest new American investment in Northern Ireland in 10 years, it said. Fruit of the Loom, the largest producer in the United States of men and boys' underwear, said it would build a plant in Londonderry to spin yarn for its leisure wear plants in nearby County Donegal in the Irish Republic. A second plant, to be built later, will manufacture sweatshirts, it said. William Farley, chairman and president of Chicago-based Fruit of the Loom, said in a statement that the new plant ``will make it possible for our garment plants to access quickly supplies of the different yarn needed for particular garments.'' In the past, Fruit of the Loom has had to send yarn from the United States to supply its plants in Donegal, where 1,700 people are employed making T-shirts and sweatshirts for the European market. That could take up to five weeks. Richard Needham, Northern Ireland's economy minister, said the project, backed by the Industrial Development Board, would provide 250 jobs by 1992 with the rest to follow by 1995. Construction of the spinning plant is expected to begin within three months, and production is to begin in mid-1991.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Intervene in Las Vegas Dispute Over `Kismet' Rights
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to alter the fate of a 14-year-old copyright dispute over songs from the play ``Kismet.'' The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that awarded about $1.2 million to the writers and copyright holders of the play from MGM Inc. MGM, under a license from the play's copyright owners, produced a movie version in 1955. About six minutes of music from Kismet was included in a Las Vegas show called ``Hallelujah Hollywood'' that ran at the MGM Grand Hotel from 1974 to 1976. That use of the music sparked a copyright-infringement lawsuit in 1976. U.S. District Judge Robert J. Kelleher initially ordered MGM to pay $22,000 for copyright infringement, but the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the award was ``grossly inadequate.'' The judge subsequently awarded about $343,000, but the appeals court upped it to about $1.2 million. MGM then sought Supreme Court review. The case is MGM vs. Frank Music Corp., 89-1269.

DOC.HEAD: Channel One Debuts Nationally in 400 Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 5 new grafs with information from first show. Picks up 4th graf pvs, Architects of ... Edits to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Channel One, a news show with advertisements aimed at teen-agers, made its national debut in an estimated 14,000 classrooms today with paid pitches for two kinds of snack foods and a razor. The show was airing in about 400 schools across the country, the producers said, even as critics continued to argue that its daily regimen of commercials is out of place in the classroom. The advertisers on the first day of the program were M&Ms candy from M&M Mars, Cheetos snacks from Frito-Lay Inc. and the Sensor razor from Gillette Co. The program, which lasts 12 minutes with two minutes allocated for advertising, also included an anti-drug public service commercial. The show is the most ambitious and controversial project yet from Whittle Communications, a Knoxville, Tenn.-based company headed by Chairman Christopher Whittle that creates magazines and other media used by advertisers to reach narrowly defined audiences. A typical show begins with two young anchors giving the top stories of the day, followed by a chapter in a five-part series each week, a pop quiz and some interesting facts and a closing story. The first week's featured series deals with the fall of the Berlin Wall and how events in Eastern Europe have affected teens there. Architects of the Channel One program say it should produce handsome educational dividends for students and educators as well as potentially lucrative financial rewards for the company producing it. But critics say the commercials represent an unwarranted intrusion on a captive audience of students who are required by law to be in school. Officials in the states of New York and California have prohibited public schools in those states from carrying the program because of the commercials. A state board of education ban on Channel One in North Carolina was overturned Friday by a state court judge, freeing schools there to use the system. Several national education groups are opposing Channel One, and are backing use of a daily commercial-free news show for teens that the cable giant Turner Broadcasting System Inc. began running last August on its Cable News Network. But Whittle said commercials are an essential element of the Channel One system, because revenue from the $150,000 charge for each 30-second ad pays for the $150 million in video equipment loaned to schools that show the program and the $90 million in operational expenses needed to produce it. Whittle said his surveys show few if any students are getting a chance to watch the Turner ad-free news program in school because there are few TV sets available in most schools. Ed Winter, the executive overseeing the Channel One project, said more than 2,700 schools in 34 states have signed three-year contracts to show the program to their students every school day. He said six of every 10 schools approached have agreed to sign. Four hundred of these schools with 300,000 students have been equipped with the dozens of TV sets, a satellite dish and video recorders needed to record the show which is transmitted automatically overnight by satellite. The company is signing schools to the system at the rate of more than 100 a week, and hopes to have 1,000 participating by the end of March and 7,000 to 8,000 schools with 6 million students by next March. The Channel One program was tested last year for seven weeks in six schools, and Whittle said it boosted student awareness of current events and can be a powerful educational tool.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Firm Gets $870 Million In Financing For New Jersey Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: Cogen Technologies Inc. said today it has secured $870 million in financing to build a cogeneration power plant in Linden, N.J., to provide power to Linden-area chemical and refining companies and to Consolidated Edison Co. of New York. The financing, from General Electric Power Funding Corp., is one of the largest packages ever for a cogeneration plant in the United States, Robert C. McNair, president of Houston-based Cogen, said. Cogen and its affiliates will own and operate the plant, which is designed to provide 614 megawatts of electric capacity and up to 1 million pounds per hour of steam. The company said the electricity also could supply up to 860,000 homes. Construction is expected to begin in October with start-up in mid 1992. The plant will be powered by natural gas provided by Public Service and Gas Co. and Elizabethtown Gas, both of New Jersey. Cogen said the plant would be one of the cleanest facilities of its size in the nation, with exhaust emissions levels only a fraction of those produced by coal or oil-fired utility power plants.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Declines by 3
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs dipped by three this week to 894, continuing a first-quarter trend, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The year-to-date count, however, remains well ahead of the 1989 tally, when 761 rigs were working. Traditionally, the rig count declines in the first quarter of the year. Last week, the total fell by 21. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil producing states, Oklahoma showed a 10-rig loss while Texas fell by eight. Kansas fell by four and Wyoming was down by one. North Dakota posted a four-rig gain, while New Mexico and Pennsylvania both were up two and Colorado, Louisiana and Michigan were up one. California and Ohio were unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: A `Deal' That Went Sour: Texas Air Cries Foul Over Examiner's Report
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf to UPDATE with Shapiro declining comment today; picks up 11th graf pvs bg'ng, ``There is ...
DOC.TEXT: It was hardly a typical deal for Frank Lorenzo, head of an airline empire, takeover strategist and consummate dealmaker. This time, the wily chairman of Texas Air Corp. got burned. His adversary wasn't the head of a rival airline, or one of his Texas Air subordinates or even a union leader. It was David I. Shapiro, the court-appointed bankruptcy examiner for Eastern Airlines, a Texas Air subsidiary. Lorenzo and his associates believed they had a deal with Shapiro on Eastern and that the Washington attorney sandbagged them, according to sources close to the negotiations, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The dispute wasn't over prices to be paid for assets, labor concessions or airline routes. It was over words: powerful words in a report by Shapiro that claimed Texas Air had short-changed Eastern when it bought the airline and some of its assets. Shapiro had been directed to supervise an investigation of Eastern and its dealings with Texas Air and sister carrier Continental Airlines as part of Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding, which started last March after pilots, flight attendants and Machinists struck the Miami-based airline. His report, filed last Thursday in federal bankruptcy court, concluded that Texas Air purchased Eastern assets at unfairly low prices and owed the carrier $285 million to $403 million. Texas Air and Eastern publicly called his report ``replete with faulty analyses, hearsay evidence, statements taken out of context and misstatements of fact.'' The companies threatened last Friday to take ``serious and considered actions'' to clear their names. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent wouldn't say what form those actions might take and declined further comment. Shapiro declined comment today when reached at his law firm in Washington, D.C. ``There is sufficient evidence to warrant the bringing of charges that (12) transactions provided Eastern with less than fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value,'' the report said. ``...The court could therefore appropriately authorize litigation of these 12 claims...'' Charges. Litigation. Those were words Lorenzo and his team weren't expecting to see in the report, according to the sources. Houston-based Texas Air had agreed earlier with Shapiro to pay Eastern more than $280 million as a settlement on the condition, sources said, that the report not assign any liability to Texas Air. Texas Air admitted no wrongdoing in the settlement and said it agreed to make the payment to Eastern only to bolster the airline. Although Shapiro's report said there were grounds for litigation, he recommended court approval of the settlement as an alternative. Nevertheless, his premise could tarnish Texas Air's image because it implied wrongdoing on the company's part. Shapiro concluded a deal on the settlement with Texas Air officials at around midnight last Wednesday. He was scheduled to submit his report to the court and speak at a hearing on the subject the next day. On Thursday morning, Texas Air officials received copies of the report at the company's New York office in Rockefeller Center. It wasn't what they were expecting. Some Texas Air officials initially believed Shapiro's associates at his Washington office misunderstood his instructions to them when he called around midnight Wednesday from New York after striking the deal with Texas Air, sources said. The examiner apparently had two versions of his report prepared, the sources said. After reaching agreement with the company, he is believed to have told his colleagues to submit to the court the version that excluded mention of possible litigation against the company. Someone on Shapiro's team goofed, some insiders believed. Shapiro ``had two reports written from the get-go,'' said a source close to the investigation, who described one version as ``heavy-handed'' and the other as ``wimpy''. Under a later theory, Shapiro's team failed in a frantic effort starting late Wednesday to revise the report to reflect the settlement in time for Thursday's hearing. According to that scenario, Shapiro asked U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland for more time but his request was refused. The hearing before Lifland was scheduled for 2 p.m. EST. Its start was delayed, however, as Shapiro met in a stormy session in Lifland's chambers with attorneys for Eastern and Texas Air, Eastern's unions and its major creditors. ``They went ballistic,'' said one of those present, describing the company lawyers' behavior. The company attorneys accused Shapiro of breaching their agreement. After the hearing began and Shapiro addressed the court, he departed from his prepared text at some points in an apparent softening of the language _ saying charges ``could be brought'' against Texas Air, instead of ``can be brought,'' as the report stated. The examiner also added several sentences indicating that the purpose of his report was to determine if there is sufficient evidence to establish claims, rather than to make ``a final finding of fact''. He said measures to be taken to protect Eastern's interests ``could include'' _ instead of the original ``should include'' _ establishment of a monitoring body under the court's supervision. That issue, opposed by Texas Air, had been one of the major sticking points in reaching a settlement, sources said. In his report, Shapiro continued to reject the unions' request that Eastern be run by an outside trustee. Texas Air officials said Lorenzo was unavailable to comment on the settlement. A union attorney said the report vindicated the union's longstanding claims that Texas Air had stripped assets from Eastern. If Texas Air didn't agree with the report, it shouldn't have signed the settlement, he said. ``We challenge Frank Lorenzo to withdraw from the settlement and let the issues be tried in court,'' said Bruce Simon, an attorney for the pilots union.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Drivers Head Back to the Picket Lines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 1 graf to UPDATE with picketing resuming; INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf, `Some strikers ..., to UPDATE with union calling for moment of silence, include background on striker who died; INSERTS 4 grafs after 13th graf, `The response ..., to UPDATE with Vermont bus executive quitting; pick up 14th graf, `The dispute ...
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound drivers walked picket lines today, some still wearing black armbands in memory of a striker crushed by a bus driven by a replacement. Fewer companies than expected applied to take over Greyhound's routes. The union, meanwhile, said the company turned down a request to resume talks, but America's only nationwide bus system said it hasn't formally been asked. The union and Greyhound Lines Inc. also quibbled Sunday over how many union drivers have crossed picket lines since the strike affecting 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers began Friday. Greyhound has been operating with 700 replacement drivers plus, it says, 350 union drivers who crossed picket lines. But the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions said only 95 union-represented drivers were behind the wheel. Some strikers who wouldn't cross the picket lines did stay off them Sunday in memory of a co-worker crushed to death by a bus while picketing in Redding, Calif. James La Sala, the union's international president, called today for five minutes of silence by the pickets on Wednesday to coincide with the beginning of a memorial service for the driver, 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse. Waterhouse was on vacation at the time of his death and had been scheduled to retire in four months after 32 years on the job, according to his widow, Dorie. ``It really wasn't even his strike,'' Mrs. Waterhouse said. ``But he was in there in support of his fellow drivers. He kept saying, ``It's a matter of self pride.'' Police did not charge the replacement driver and said the death appeared to be accidental. Strikers in Jacksonville, Fla., Olympia, Wash., and Minneapolis reported being struck by buses driven by replacement drivers over the weekend, but there were no serious injuries. Shots were fired at a bus in Chicago on Friday; charter drivers in Spokane, Wash., found bus electrical systems vandalized Sunday morning, and a passenger in Philadelphia was charged Sunday with spraying a striker with Mace. Also in Philadelphia, vice president of the Amalgamated Transit Union local, John Bal, was arrested Saturday and charged with criminal mischief for breaking a mirror off a Greyhound bus, police said. Two Greyhound employees were arrested Saturday in Mount Laurel, N.J., on charges of disabling a bus there, police said. The Interstate Commerce Commission said fewer small bus companies than expected had applied to serve Greyhound routes during the strike. An ICC board approved four temporary applications in the East, but none of the companies serves points south of Virginia, said Glenn Eady, ICC regional compliance officer in Philadelphia. ``The response is not what we expected,'' he said Sunday. The president of one small bus company that is owned by Greyhound resigned during the weekend over what he termed ``basic philosophical differences with my superiors.'' John J. Dwyer, 52, who headed Vermont Transit Co. in Burlington, Vt., said he quit Saturday after firing four employees who refused to drive routes normally handled by the striking Greyhound drivers. He declined to say whether he had quit because of the firings. One of the of the fired drivers, Andrew Bahr, said he guessed that Dwyer resigned because he didn't want to fire anyone else. ``I knew he never wanted to do it,'' Bahr said. ``Basically he was a very fair man. Everything you dealt with him on was very fair. He fired us graciously.'' The dispute over whether the union has sought to resume talks centers on a meeting Friday night in Scottsdale, Ariz., between union president Edward M. Strait and P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound executive vice president and chief negotiator. Chairman Fred G. Currey said Saturday the company had received no formal request to resume negotiations. But union spokesman Nick Nichols said, ``I don't know what he defines as formal. What do they need, an engraved invitation?'' Another spokesman, Jeffrey Nelson, reiterated on Sunday the union's belief that it had sought new talks. The two sides were reported to be divided over wages and job security.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Corn Futures Slide; Soybeans Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and corn futures were moderately lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting dimming hopes for new Soviet trade and forecasts for beneficial moisture in most crop-growing areas. Soybean futures were mixed in early trading. Precipitation was forecast for this week in virtually all U.S. and South American agricultural areas. Further selling in the wheat and corn markets stemmed from reports that the Soviet Union had deferred some imports of European grain, possibly due to transportation or credit problems. Whatever the reason, ``if they defer from them, they probably won't buy from us either,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader in Chicago with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Buying in the soybean market appeared to reflect a spillover of bullish sentiment in the adjacent soybean meal and oil pits. In early trading, wheat futures were 1} cents to 5\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.45 a bushel; oat futures were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $1.45 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to \ cent higher with March at $5.69 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .02 cent to .37 cent higher with April at 76.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .48 cent higher with March at 80.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .55 cent higher with April at 50.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .02 cent lower to .05 cent higher with March at 48.80 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Doskocil Cos. And Subsidiaries Plan Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: Doskocil Cos. said today it and its subsidiaries plan to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The Hutchinson, Kan.-based company and its largest subsidiary, Wilson Foods Corp. of Oklahoma City, announced last week they were having financial problems and had defaulted on two large loans. On Friday, the company said about 50 employees agreed to a voluntary layoff to help during the cash flow crunch. In a news release early today, Larry Doskocil, company founder and board chairman, said agreement had been reached with Chemical Bank of New York and other senior lenders to provide $65 million in secured interim financing, subject to bankruptcy court approval. The loans, which replace a $50 million revolving credit agreement, are intended to allow Doskocil and Wilson Foods to continue operating without interruption while finishing the details of a reorganization plan. ``We are not going out of business,'' Doskocil said. ``We do not anticipate closing any plants, although initially there may be some temporary disruptions.'' The Chapter 11 filing will relieve the company of some of the current payments due on its debts and allow more time for the sale of some assets, including the Wilson Brands division of Wilson Foods. That division's sale is taking longer than anticipated, meaning the proceeds from it haven't been available to help pay off the debt taken on from the 1988 acquisition of Wilson, a much-larger competitor. In addition to the Wilson Brands sale delay, Doskocil also attributed the filing to lower operating profits during recent quarters than it had anticipated. Last week Doskocil announced it was in default on a $133 million loan and had been unable to make some other payments to other creditors. Doskocil and its subsidiaries formulate, process and market specialty precooked meat, meat toppings, pepperoni, and other speciality meats.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rules Banking Dispute Now Irrelevant
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today ruled that a dispute between Florida and an Illinois-based bank holding company blocked by Florida from setting up an industrial savings bank has become legally irrelevant. The court unanimously ruled that a 1987 federal law giving states specific authority to block such moves by out-of-state bank holding companies has rendered the dispute moot. The decision is a victory for Florida, but a setback for Continental Bank Corp. The court last June agreed to review the case even though Bush administration lawyers told the justices the 1987 change in federal banking law had made the case moot. Writing for the court today, Justice Antonin Scalia never acknowledged the Bush administration advice that initially went unheeded. Continental Bank in 1981 filed an application with the Florida Department of Banking and Finance to establish and run an industrial savings bank in Mami. The proposed bank would not accept demand deposits or make commercial loans _ making it a so-called ``non-bank bank'' that fell outside the federal law's definition of banks. The application was denied, and Continental Bank subsequently sued in federal court. The suit alleged that Florida's action was unconstitutional. Scalia said 1987 amendments to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 bars bank holding companies from establishing or acquiring a bank in another state ``unless the latter state's statutes specifically authorize it to do so.'' The law ``thus effectively permits states to prevent out-of-state holding companies from owning in-state banks,'' Scalia said. The case is Lewis vs. Continental Bank, 87-1956.

DOC.HEAD: State Doctors Stage Strike
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at state hospitals nationwide went on strike Monday for higher wages, a union spokesman said. The strike came amid continuing labor unrest, including walkouts by 12,000 tax officials protesting alleged loopholes in proposed tax legislation and employees in some departments of the central bank and National Bank of Greece over wages. Doctors in provincial state hospitals started a 48-hour strike Monday. About 70 percent of the doctors in the Athens area staged a four-hour stoppage in sympathy and will repeat it on Tuesday, said Georgios Sepirgiotis, vice president of the Hospital Doctors Union for Athens and Piraeus. The doctors are objecting to a cost-cutting recommendation by the State Audit Council that a ceiling should be set on the number of overtime shifts doctors may work, to be calculated in line with basic pay levels. Sepirgiotis also said hospital doctors had not received a raise since 1983. An intern receives $212 per month, almost half the wage of a 17-year-old factory worker, Sepirgiotis said. There are nearly 9,000 doctors registered in state hospitals, with 4,000 in the Athens area alone.
