DOC.HEAD: From Buckets To Steam Engines, Museum Sparks Interest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation
DOC.TEXT: In the downtown offices of a powerful insurance company, the walls in a second-floor suite are decorated with buckets and iron bed keys. They share a place of honor with antique firefighter helmets and with steam-powered fire engines and hose reels in the lobby of Cigna Corp.'s headquarters. The result is a prestigious corporate museum. These samples of the technology that has kept the company in business celebrate the long, colorful history of firefighting in Philadelphia, where Cigna got its start nearly 200 years ago insuring against fire and shipping losses. Cigna's business traditions are reflected in the museum collection, devoted to the otherwise unrelated histories of maritime shipping and firefighting. Models and paintings of sailing ships the company once insured are displayed around the corner from firemen's tools and ceremonial clothing. Over the years, as more sophisticated equipment gave firefighters better odds against the flames, insurance companies benefited. Now it is Cigna's turn to do the salvaging and preserve firefighting relics. The museum collection contains 9,000 pieces, says curator Melissa Hough. Many of the best items are exhibited in the downtown Philadelphia museum, but as much as 85 percent of the collection is either on loan to museums around the country or spread around Cigna's 60 corporate offices here and abroad, Ms. Hough said. Firefighting traditions in Philadelphia go back to the bucket brigades of the early Colonial times. The nation's first volunteer fire company was founded here in 1736 and the first fire insurance company, Ben Franklin's Contributionship, started 16 years later. In the 19th century, the firehouse was a center of male camaraderie and competition, with rivalries played out fighting fires. One museum painting shows a race between horse-drawn fire engines of rival companies, each trying to be the first to a fire. Another shows several fire companies at an 1850 contest to see whose hoses could squirt water the highest. The competition between volunteer fire companies, Ms. Hough said, eventually became a problem as firemen became ``just plain rowdy.'' They called false alarms to sabotage other companies and cut their rivals' hoses. Ms. Hough said the problem peaked right after the Civil War, and in 1871 the city stepped in and established a professional fire department. Many firefighting buffs visit Cigna's museum. In many Pennsylvania communities, volunteer fire companies remain part of the social fabric as they once were in Philadelphia. Hough said school children come on class trips, and one of their favorite games is to guess the use of some of the odd-looking tools displayed in the museum. They play with wooden rattles, once used by watchmen to rouse neighbors in the event of a fire, and learn that a strange-looking piece of iron is a bed key, actually a critical firefighting tool. Firemen carried bed keys so they could quickly disassemble beds and carry them out of burning homes. Beds were among the most expensive pieces of furniture, and salvaging them was important to homeowners, as well as to their insurance companies. In 1794, the Insurance Company of North America, a predecessor of Cigna, was the first to offer fire insurance on the contents of a building. Cigna, the eighth-largest insurance company in the world, had revenue of $17 billion in 1988, the last year for which complete figures are available. The portion of company business now devoted to fire insurance is difficult to calculate, said Cigna spokesman James Ely, because fire insurance is typically part of a package including theft and liability insurance. About 20 percent of Cigna's revenues are from such commercial packages, he said.
Editors note: The museum, located at 16th and Arch streets in Philadelphia, is open Monday-Friday, 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Admission is free.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Finish Lower

DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished sharply lower Monday on London's stock exchange amid worries of another hike in British interest rates. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 24.3 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,230.5. The Financial Times 30-share index lost 18.6 points to 1,755.6. The Financial Times 500-share index was down 12.86 at 1,211.55. Volume amounted to 316.3 million shares, compared with 542.5 million shares Friday. Dealers said political worries also depressed the market after Welsh Secretary Peter Walker said over the weekend that he would step down from the Thatcher Cabinet, adding to the Conservative Party's mounting woes. ``Until the (March 20) budget, interest rates will remain high and it's not inconceivable that the government may be challenged by the market to raise rates,'' said Adam Bennett, an equity strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton International in London.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Hurt, Helped by Brazil Orange Juice Imports
DOC.TEXT: Every time Florida shivers, Brazil tightens its grip on the U.S. orange juice market. The South American giant again is shipping millions of gallons of juice to the United States at premium prices in the wake of the third major freeze in Florida's citrus groves in six years. The flood from a competitor is a mixed blessing: Florida processors may take most of the imported juice supply to blend with their limited local supply in making frozen concentrated orange juice. ``We will be importing more than 50 percent of our product to meet market demand,'' says Executive Director Dan Gunter of the Florida Department of Citrus. ``Imports will probably exceed the level of 1985,'' which when processors needed supply help due to crop-killing frosts in December 1983 and January 1985. Production in Florida, which until 1982 was the world leader in citrus, is expected to fall sharply due to damage from the Christmastime freeze. The state's share of expected U.S. production of ``single-strength equivalent'' (SSE) juice _ which includes concentrate, chilled and canned juice _ is seen as falling to about 45 percent from 70.6 percent last year. Brazil, meanwhile, is expected to have a record crop this year and export a record 319 million gallons of concentrated juice. Orange processors in California, Texas and Arizona may account for only 6 percent of the total U.S. juice supply this year. As a result, domestic orange-juice imports _ principally from Brazil _ will total about 625 million SSE gallons, according to industry economists, up 72 percent from the 1988-89 import level. At the same time, juice prices have risen sharply. Within the past year, the wholesale price for Brazilian juice has risen from $1.50 a pound to $2.12 a pound this year. And because Brazil is the world's largest producer-exporter, it sets the price _ so consumers will be paying more, no matter where their juice comes from. American grocery store prices are expected to average $4.17 a gallon during the current processing season, an increase of 12.4 percent over the previous year. Particularly ironic to Florida industry leaders is that processors in this state may take 60 percent of all imported juice to blend with the limited local supply in making Florida frozen concentrated orange juice. The state expects to pack about 93 million gallons of frozen concentrate this year and will import about 93 million gallons, compared with packing of 175 million gallons and imports of 52 million gallons in 1989. The state's citrus industry views the imported juice situation in a bittersweet vein: In good times, many bitterly criticize Brazilian imports, although some state processors traditionally buy Brazilian product to blend with what is considered higher-quality Florida orange juice. In bad times, particularly after frigid weather ices the fruit or destroys trees, Florida depends on Brazil to make up the supply difference and maintain a steady market and a good price. ``Florida's problems serve as an impetus for Brazil to plant more trees and produce a bigger crop,'' says Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual, the state's largest grower trade association with 12,000 members. ``This can lead to excess supplies in the future and prices will drop and we'll need to increase demand,'' McKown says. Brazilian imports may help in the short-term, he says, ``But we need to work on a long-term basis. I don't think Brazil is doing enough to expand the markets. We do most of that. After a freeze, they just clear their inventory.'' But Gunter said that because of Brazil's bumper crop and Florida's shortfall, the total amount of orange juice available actually may be about the same as last year. Brazil's record-high price ``is probably based on an expected lower volume for next year,'' Gunter said recently. ``Brazil evidently wants to hold down sales to maintain volume because their crop is expected to be smaller next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Dibrell Agrees to Buy RJR Inrternational's Brazilian Tobacco Business
DOC.TEXT: Dibrell Brothers Inc. and RJR Tobacco International have signed an agreement under which Dibrell would buy Reynolds' Brazilian tobacco business for $50 million in cash, Dibrell announced Monday. The Reynolds subsidiary makes and markets cigarettes and operates a leaf processing and exporting business in Brazil. Dibrell officials also said an agreement in principle had been reached with Philip Morris Marketing SA, a subsidiary of Philip Morris Cos. Inc., under which the Brazilian affiliate of Philip Morris would acquire RJR's Brazilian cigarette business from Dibrell. Also, Dibrell announced an agreement in principle with Universal Leaf Tobacco Co. Inc., a subsidiary of Universal Corp., under which a unit of Universal operating in Brazil would acquire RJR's Brazilian leaf processing business from Dibrell. Under terms of the various agreements, Dibrell will keep RJR Brazil's long-term leaf supply agreements, said Claude B. Owens Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Dibrell.

DOC.HEAD: NEC Plans To Increase Use of Foreign-Made Semiconductors
DOC.TEXT: NEC Corp., Japan's leading computer maker, said Monday it will spend about $40 million to increase the use of foreign-made semiconductors by July 1991 when a U.S.-Japan semiconductor agreement expires. NEC officials said the company decided to raise its share of foreign-made chips to about 24 percent of the total at the request of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Currently, about 20 percent of the chips it uses are imported. The agency was reported to have made the request out of concern that the United States might take retaliatory trade action unless U.S.-made semiconductors account for 20 percent of the Japanese market by the time the bilateral accord expires. NEC is reported to have been buying semiconductors worth about $1.3 billion a year from outside the company, with foreign-made chips accounting for about $267 million of that total. According to industry statistics, foreign-made chips accounted for 12 percent of the Japanese market in the third quarter of last year, far short of the 20 percent share the United States has been seeking.

DOC.HEAD: Volvo: Alliance With Renault Could Take Until Mid-1990's To Influence Profits
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Swedish automaker AB Volvo said Monday that it could take until the mid-1990's for the fruits of its alliance with France's state-owned Renault to show up in the form of higher profits. Pehr G. Gyllenhammar told a reporter that while cost-cutting measures could be implemented almost immediately, significant payoffs from the alliance will take much longer. ``The big money will take four to five years, I think, because it has to do with the components and products that we can develop jointly,'' Gyllenhammar said. ``We will find cost-cutting earlier, but not of any dramatic nature.'' The two automakers announced Feb. 23 an agreement in which they will take stakes in each other and work jointly in the future in such areas as research, product development and purchasing. The accord aims to achieve economies of scale and to extend the reach of both companies, although each will remain legally independent. Executives at both companies say the Volvo and Renault brand names will remain distinct. Renault President Raymond H. Levy accompanying Gyllenhammer at a news conference declined to say when he thought profits would improve as a result of the alliance. Gyllenhammar reiterated that the decision to forge the agreement with Renault didn't represent an effort by either of the partners eventually to take over the other. Asked about rumors that Volvo was in talks with Mitsubishi Motors of Japan and Chrysler Corp. of the U.S. on possible cooperation agreements or joint ventures, Gyllenhammar said: ``There's an ongoing dialogue in our business.'' Under terms of the accord with Renault, each partner can enter joint ventures and partnerships with other companies, provided that the other partner approves, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Tumble On Wet Weather Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices closed moderately lower Monday as wet weather in the Great Plains prompted steady selling on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn and soybean futures were mixed. Rain was expected throughout the U.S. wheat region this week. Winter wheat areas in particular have been receiving ample moisture recently after pronounced dryness in the fall and early winter. Wheat futures also were pressured by technical factors and unconfirmed rumors that the Soviet Union has been seeking to delay some imports of European grain due to transportation or credit problems. Strength in the soybean and corn markets reflected perceptions that farmers must plant more of those commodities than early indications suggest to meet the anticipated demand, said William Biedermann, director of research with Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. Biedermann dismissed talk of quality problems with the South American soybean crop, which is nearing maturity. ``We checked with some commercials on this and they do not think it's anything substantial,'' he said. At the close, wheat futures were 2 cents to 4 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.85 a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.44} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.45{ a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent lower to 4 cents higher with March at $5.70{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Mechanics to Vote on Union Representation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs bgng, Spokesmen for ... with 2 new grafs to UPDATE with comment from Machinists spokesman; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, A recorded ...
DOC.TEXT: Mechanics at Trump Shuttle, the northeast airline service named after the real estate tycoon who bought it last spring, will vote soon on which union should represent them, the airline announced Monday. The 90 mechanics at Trump Shuttle, along with 125 ground service workers, currently are represented by the International Association of Machinists. The company said the National Mediation Board decided last Friday to grant the request of a rival group, the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, for an election for the mechanics to decide their union representation. ``We're entirely neutral; it's up to the employees,'' Trump Shuttle spokeswoman Joan Fudala said. The Machinists union had filed a petition with the mediation board objecting to AMFA's request. Machinists spokesman Jim Conley in Washington said Monday the union was considering contesting the board's decision in federal court, but probably would let it stand. ``We're probably going to go ahead and have the election,'' he said. A recorded phone message at AMFA's office said officials of the group were unavailable. Nearly all the Machinists at Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Boston and Washington, formerly worked for Eastern Airlines. Billionaire developer Donald Trump bought the shuttle service from Miami-based Eastern for $365 million. The AMFA challenge had delayed contract negotiations between Trump Shuttle management and the Machinists union. Late last month, the Trump Shuttle pilots approved a new four-year contract that provides for wage increases averaging 10 percent this year and a total 15 percent over the next three years. The pilots' contract also makes changes in work rules to allow greater scheduling flexibility and calls for the pilots to begin sharing increased costs of medical benefits in 1991. The agreement is scheduled to be signed Thursday in Washington. Contract talks covering the 280 flight attendants at Trump Shuttle are due to start around April 1, according to Ms. Fudala.

DOC.HEAD: Plans to Sell Datastream International, Interactive Data
DOC.TEXT: Dun & Bradstreet Corp., a leading marketer of business information and services, said Monday it plans to sell two subsidiaries that provide historical investment information and related services. The company said it planned to sell Datastream International, a London-based provider of investment information, research and portfolio accounting services throughout Europe and the Far East on international securities. Also put up for sale was Interactive Data, based in Lexington, Mass., a provider of securities-related information, software and systems to the U.S. investment community. ``While these are fine businesses, we believe that it is in the best interest of D&B's shareowners to focus our investments and resources on those key markets in which D&B's participation and leadership positions are strongest,'' said Charles W. Moritz, chairman and chief executive. He identified some of the largest of those markets as those for risk-management information services, marketing information services, directory information services and business-applications software. Datastream and Interactive Data had combined revenue of $155 million in 1989. Datastream was acquired in June 1984 for $102 million; Interactive Data was acquired in March 1988 for $140 million. Moritz said the company expects the investment and redeployment of the proceeds from the sales to offset lost operating income from the two units. ``Actions such as restructuring certain D&B businesses and share repurchase will be considered,'' he said. Nonetheless, the company continues to expect that 1990 earnings per share will be in the range of $2.80, Moritz said. The company earned $3.14 a share in 1989 and $2.67 a share in 1988. The company previously has blamed the impact of lower sales at its U.S. credit services business and the costs of ``repositioning actions'' in that area for the anticipated decline in earnings. The U.S. credit services division was stung by complaints from some customers last year that they had been overcharged. The company said it has taken corrective steps in recent months. Moritz said the divestitures will ``simplify D&B's business mix'' and will not affect its plans for Moody's Investors Service, which provides corporate and public finance debt ratings. The company plans to maintain and strengthen Moody's postition and to invest in its international expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Two Campeau Lenders Agree to Defer Interest Payments
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp., the Canadian parent of U.S. retailers trying to reorganize under bankruptcy court protection, said Monday two of its major lenders have agreed to help the company by deferring $5.2 million in loan interest payments. The property and retail company also said it will work with Olympia & York Developments Ltd. and The Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. during the deferral period on a plan to determine Campeau's fate. Interest due Olympia & York on Feb. 28 under two loans, of $75 million and $150 million, will be deferred until March 7. Campeau said in an announcement released from its Toronto headquarters that it won't be considered in default for failing to pay the interest until March 7. The monthly payments due on the two Olympia & York loans total $1.7 million. A similar agreement was signed with DeBartolo under which DeBartolo agreed to a deferral on interest payments on a $480 million loan until March 7. The payments, which were due March 1, are owed by Federated Stores Inc., the Cincinnati-based holding company of Campeau's U.S. retailing operations, and guaranteed by Campeau. Federated, which operates Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., owes monthly interest on the DeBartolo loan of $3.5 million. Allied and Federated filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act on Jan. 15 in the biggest retail bankruptcy filing ever. They listed total debt of $7.7 billion, amassed when they were taken over in 1986 and 1988 by Campeau. Their department stores are: Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's, Bon Marche, Burdines, Jordan Marsh, Lazarus, Maas Brothers, Rich's-Goldsmith's and Stern's. Campeau spokesman Richard W. Wertheim said the company has the money available to cover the debt payments. But Olympia & York and DeBartolo agreed it was appropriate to defer the payments while Campeau works on a plan on how its business will be run in the future. He said Campeau hopes to announce a longer term deferral soon. ``We're not going to have a business plan by Wednesday,'' he said. Wertheim would not comment on what a business plan might involve, such as asset sales or debt restructuring. The plan concerns Campeau's Canadian operations only, which mainly are real estate development.
Stock prices drifted lower today in a sluggish session on Wall Street. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 6.08 at 2,654.28.

DOC.HEAD: January Construction Contracts Off 3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Contracts for new construction nationwide slid 3 percent in January, extending a slump that is mostly confined to the Northeast and South Atlantic regions, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported Monday. The Dodge Index, which uses 1982 as its 100 base, fell to 155 in January from 160 in December and was well off its most recent peak of 181 reached last September. The yearly pace of total contracting was $244.30 billion in January, down from $251.44 billion in December. In January, contracts for non-residential buildings declined 4 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $83.75 billion from $87.16 billion in December. The value of residential work edged 1 percent lower to $115.97 billion from $117.07 billion. Non-building construction contracts, such as for public works and utility projects, dropped 6 percent to $44.58 billion from $47.21 billion. ``The weakening of construction activity that has set in over the past six months has a decidedly regional tilt to it,'' said George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist of F.W. Dodge. He said virtually all of the decline has been concentrated in two regions: the Northeast and South Atlantic. States included in the Northeast region are the New England states plus, New Jersey, New York and, Pennsylvania. The South Alantic region is made up of Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, North and South Carolina, Virgina, Washington and West Virginia. ``By contrast, the central and western parts of the country are continuing to build at close to last year's rate,'' Christie said.

Stock prices gave ground today, giving up some of last week's gains. Analysts said recent hopes persisted that the economy might avert a recession and start growing at a revived rate as the year passed. But traders also appeared edgy over the interest-rate outlook, especially if business activity should pick up. Rates rose in the credit markets today. Prices of long-term government bonds fell about $10 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.64 percent-8.70 percent range.

DOC.HEAD: American Manufacturers Increasing Foreign Investment, Mainly In Europe
DOC.TEXT: American manufacturers increased foreign investment activity last year mainly in Europe, lured by potential commercial and financial opportunities in Eastern Europe, the Conference Board reported Monday. U.S. manufacturers started 217 new foreign projects in 1989, a 20 percent jump over 1988, and are continuing to invest overseas at a similar rate in the first few weeks of 1990, the business and finance research organization said. Of the new investments last year, the majority _ 53 percent _ were in Western Europe. ``With events in Eastern Europe now suggesting a dramatic expansion in the European market, many American firms are strengthening their presence in Europe to take advantage of future growth opportunities,'' said James Greene, the Conference Board's international investment specialist. The European investments included 72 acquisitions, 24 joint ventures, 14 new plants and six expansions of existing facilities. The United Kingdom attracted 38 American projects, followed by West Germany with 17, Italy with 15, France 14 and the Netherlands 13. Eastern Europe attracted nine investors, the Soviet Union six, Hungary two and Yugoslavia one. But Canada also emerged as a new target for U.S. investors, netting 35 new projects, the board said. ``The Canadian-U.S. free trade agreement may well have ended Canada's status as a satellite market and assured it of a much wider global role,'' Greene said. Twelve investment projects were started in Japan last year, including 10 joint ventures, and three were in China. Manufacturing businesses that went abroad were mainly in chemicals, electronics, food and transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Closing Up to 50 Brokerage Offices
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is closing up to 50 retail brokerage offices nationwide as part of across-the-board cutbacks under parent American Express Co., the investment firm said Monday. Shearson also was said to be trying to sell its troubled Balcor real estate management subsidiary, which has more than $1 billion in real estate loans and direct investments outstanding in a shaky market. The reductions are part of an overhaul being engineered by American Express, which over the last two months gradually has moved to take full control of Shearson, its Wall Street investment subsidiary. American Express announced Sunday that it was buying the remaining publicly held shares of Shearson, reversing its earlier stated intention of reducing its ownership stake to less than 50 percent. Most of the Shearson brokers were informed of the office closings, some of which are to take effect immediately, on Monday and last Friday. The firm would not disclose specific offices to be closed. Shearson, the nation's second largest retail brokerage, has about 10,000 brokers at 600 branches nationwide. Shearson spokeswoman Suzanne Quigley said 45 to 50 offices would be closed or consolidated with other offices by April 1. Layoffs would occur, but Quigley declined to specify an amount. She said there would be no disruption to client accounts at the closed offices. As part of the reduction, sources at the firm said, Shearson would consolidate management of investment products in the hands of fewer executives per region. Shearson last week announced it would lay off 2,000 off its 35,500 employees by the end of the month. Employees said layoffs were occurring daily in a variety of departments. Like other Wall Street firms, Shearson's retail brokerage division has been hit by a downturn in the securities industry since the 1987 stock market crash. Shearson had expanded drastically in the field, including the acquisition of E.F. Hutton & Co. in January 1988 that more than doubled its retail force. Analysts said the retail closings would trim some unneeded personnel and reduce overhead. The sources at Shearson said the firm was cutting back much of its real estate activities, leading with the planned elimination of one department this week and the expected sale of Balcor, which had 145 loans worth about $1.1 billion last Nov. 30. According to federal filings, Balcor had nonperforming assets of $114 million, including nonperforming loans and about $22 million in owned real estate. The subsidiary has just $10 million in reserves to cover its portfolio of loans to real-estate partnerships and client companies. The high level of nonperforming assets and low level of reserves have raised concern because a downturn in the nation's commercial property industry has raised the chances that more loans could be vulnerable. The sources did not identify a potential buyer for Balcor. ``Balcor isn't that important to the revenue or profits of Shearson overall,'' said Perrin Long, who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Services. ``However, it could be a major negative to profits if they have to take reserves against bad loans.'' A Shearson spokesman, Steven Faigen, declined to comment on whether Shearson was seeking a buyer for Balcor. ``There's a strategic review ongoing and its results are still being fashioned,'' he said. More job cuts and large charges against earnings are expected as part of the review. American Express' decision to buy back Shearson shares it does not own was viewed as a another show of support for by the credit card and financial services giant for its subsidiary. Prior to Sunday's announcement American Express already had agreed to pump more than $1 billion into Shearson. But analysts also said the move, which involves exchanging $350 million worth of American Express shares for the 28 million publicly held Shearson shares, did not eliminate the possibility of selling all or part of Shearson. Taking Shearson out of public hands will give American Express more flexibility in tackling the restructuring at the firm, analysts said, because it will occur out of the public eye. The buyback also ended for now talks on merging Shearson with Primerica Corp.'s Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. unit.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Rally
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures rallied Monday with prices of wholesale gasoline and home heating oil posting sharp gains. Traders scrambled to buy contracts for petroleum products on the New York Mercantile Exchange on the assumption that Exxon Corp.'s suspension in operations at a New Jersey refinery could cause temporary tightness in regional supplies. The contract for April delivery of unleaded regular gasoline surged 2.83 cents to 59.30 cents a gallon, expanding on Friday increase of 0.66 cent. Contracts for delivery further in the future also advanced, but more moderately. Among other refined products traded on the New York Merc, home heating oil for April delivery soared 2.12 cents to 57.99 cents a gallon after a jump of 1.24 cents on Friday. Later contracts were up by slightly smaller amounts. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 23 cents to close at $21.58 per 42-gallon barrel following Friday's rise of 18 cents. Later contracts posted slightly larger gains. Andrew Lebow, a broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said strength in products led the energy markets higher. He said Exxon's decision to suspend tanker and barge operations at its Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., will idle the refinery, reducing daily refining capacity in the New York harbor area by 130,000 barrels. Total capacity in the area has been estimated at 465,000 barrels a day, he said. Exxon indefinitely suspended the operations in the wake of two oil spills in waterways surrounding the refinery this year.
