Besides American Express, losers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, down { at 39~; General Motors, down \ at 45}; General Electric, down | at 61}, and Exxon, down { at 46\. On the plus side, International Business Machines rose [ to 105 and Philip Morris was up { at 37]. Mylan Laboratories dropped 1[ to 20~ following a downbeat appraisal of the stock in Barron's magazine. Dataproducts Corp., traded on the American Stock Exchange, fell 1 to 4~. The company said it had received tenders for some 17.76 million shares on its offer to buy back 4 million shares for $10 apiece. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $12.49 billion, or 0.39 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .82 to 184.15. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.76 to 384.49, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.80 at 333.74. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped .87 to 430.15. At the Amex, the market value index closed at 356.64, up .52.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Sales Down
With BC-Auto Sales-Table, f0206
DOC.TEXT: Sales of cars and light trucks made in North America slumped 7.9 percent in late February compared with last year when consumers rushed to showrooms to snatch up expiring incentives, automakers said Monday. For the entire month, sales of domestic and imported automobiles and light trucks were down 4.7 percent, reflecting sagging interest in cash rebates and low interest financing that were the rage in January and February 1989. The incentives in early 1989 turned many spring car buyers into late winter purchasers. ``It's not going too bad,'' said sales Manager Fred Voelkel of Brown and Brown Chevrolet-Geo in Mesa, Ariz. ``We're down a little from last year.'' The nine major automakers making vehicles in North America said they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 42,688 during the Feb. 21-28 period this year, compared with a rate of 46,336 during the same time last year. Sales of new cars fell 6.7 percent and truck sales were down 10 percent. For the first two months of this year, domestic and overseas automakers reported vehicle sales were off 0.8 percent, indicating a strong January sales rate was being watered down by a weaker February rate. Automakers are keeping a careful eye on their new-vehicle inventories in anticipation of what they hope will be a return to a tradition of a spring buying spree in March and April. At the beginning of last year, automakers advertised the incentive programs that expired, for the most part, at the end of February. The specter of those programs ending turned likely spring buyers into late-winter purchasers grabbing a good deal. That disrupted the tradition of a sales bulge in March and April. This year, incentives in effect in January and February didn't generate the same buying excitement, with the notable exception of Chrysler's incentives on minivans in January, which boosted year-to-date sales figures for 1990. ``We are in shape for a good spring,'' said Voelkel. ``That's when we build up our inventories and build up our advertising a little bit.'' He said he expects his current 75-day supply of cars to swell to around 90 days by spring. GM's car and truck sales for late February ran 2.4 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales off 3.8 percent and truck sales up 0.9 percent. For the entire year, GM vehicles sold at a pace 0.2 percent ahead of last year. Ford's car and truck sales fell 19.1 percent in late February, partly because of strong fleet sales a year ago, said Robert Rewey, the company's vice president for North American sales. Car sales by the nation's No. 2 automaker fell 24.5 percent during the period and truck sales were off 10.8 percent. For the first two months of the year, Ford's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 6.6 percent behind last year's rate, with car sales down 8.7 percent and truck sales falling by 3.6 percent. Chrysler said its late-February car sales fell 11.6 percent and truck sales were off 21.3 percent compared with a year ago, combining for a 16 percent decline in vehicle sales. For the year, Chrysler's car and truck sales, which got a big boost from the minivan incentives in January, were up 2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Soar
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures prices soared above $1 a pound Monday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid rising concern about tight availability of high-quality coffee. On other futures markets, copper futures surged; cotton futures were up sharply; energy futures were higher; precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock andmeat futures were mixed. Coffee futures settled 4.64 cents to 5.5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $1.045 a pound, its highest settlement since June 30. Analysts said the rally, which marked the market's fourth consecutive day of unusual strength, was not related to any change in the supply-demand picture but to the same factors that have recently supported the market. Those factors include civil strife in the Ivory Coast, a coffee supply shortfall in Mexico, a lack of availability from Ecuador and poor growing conditions for coffee in Colombia. ``All the reports today were basically news we already had,'' said Celeste Georkakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York. The rally was considered especially significant, though, because coffee futures surpassed $1 a pound, a price at which coffee had not traded since early July, when the International Coffee Organization lifted export quotas and exposed prices to the free market. Coffee futures plunged below 70 cents a pound last year as producers sold out their warehoused stocks but the recent rise indicates the market is moving toward a more balanced supply-and-demand situation. With prices now above $1, chances for a return to export quotas look slim, said Sandra Kaul, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., who said that at these prices, producers are likely to become more willing sellers. ``The concern about nearby availability is likely to moderate up here at higher price levels, which should allow sales to pick up,'' she said. Copper futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange on supply worries exacerbated by the Comex's report that its warehouse stocks of copper fell 175 short tons Friday and by the London Metal Exchange's report of a 4,475 metric ton decline last week in its stocks. Copper futures settled 2.3 cents to 3.6 cents higher with March at $1.23 a pound. Also on the Comex, gold futures settled $1 to $1.20 higher with April at $406.60 a troy ounce; silver futures were 1 cent lower across the board with March at $5.116 a troy ounce. Some cotton futures soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange on strong technical signals. Cotton finished .85 cent to 2.07 cents higher with March, on which the limit has been removed pending the contract's expiration, at 70.15 cents a pound. Heating oil and gasoline futures climbed sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid supply worries linked to the shutdown of Exxon's Bayway, N.J., refinery pending an investigation into last week's spill of oil in the adjacent waterway. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 23 cents to 37 cents higher with April at $21.58 a barrel; heating oil was .91 cent to 2.12 cents higher with April at 57.99 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .75 cent to 2.83 cents higher with April at 59.30 cents a gallon. Wheat futures prices closed moderately lower Monday as wet weather in the Great Plains prompted steady selling on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn and soybean futures were mixed. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 4 cents lower with March at $3.85 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to { cent higher with March at $2.44} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.46 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 3} cents higher with March at $5.70} a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .25 cent higher with April at 76.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .23 cent to .45 cent higher with March at 80.82 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent lower to .08 cent higher with April at 49.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent to 1.32 cents lower with March at 48.02 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Demands for More On-the-Spot Details on Nutrition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf pvs `_McDonald's has... to UPDATE with comment from McDonald's. Picks up 18th graf pvs `_Wendy's has ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Four large fast-food chains are breaking an agreement to offer on-the-spot nutritional information about their menus and to make sure customers know the brochures are available, a consumer group said Monday. ``We are sorry to report ... that, after initial compliance, the voluntary program has broken down,'' the Center for Science in the Public Interest said in letters to the attorneys general of Texas, California and New York. The three state officials won agreement from five chains in July 1986 to provide ingredient and nutrition information at all outlets. The consumer group said that the companies were supposed to post signs alerting diners to the availability of a brochure and that the policies were supposed to apply nationwide. The Washington-based center, a non-profit health advocacy organization with 200,000 members, said only the Jack in the Box chain remains in substantial compliance with the agreement. Based on a survey of outlets in eight states and the District of Columbia, the consumer group said, Burger King, McDonald's, Wendy's and Kentucky Fried Chicken have slipped. Michael Jacobson, the center's executive director, said in a statement that his organization had ``urged the attorneys general to consider prosecuting the companies unless they resume full compliance within 60 days.'' Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for New York attorney general Robert Abrams, said the information program was the result of ``an informal, out-of-court agreement'' and said she did not know if there were grounds to sue. However, she said all three attorneys general have asked officials from the four companies to meet with Texas attorney general Jim Mattox to discuss why they have discontinued the program. ``This is something we'd like to do without having to resort to litigation,'' she said. A spokesman for Kentucky Fried Chicken said brochures are sent to restaurants but they are not required to give them out. ``The deal was that the (1986) agreement was voluntary,'' said Dick Detwiler, the company's director of public affairs. In his letter to the state officials, Jacobson said consumers need to know, for example, that McDonald's and Burger King fry their potatoes in beef fat, that McDonald's Chicken McNuggets contain ground-up chicken skin, that Burger King's Whopper with Cheese contains 711 calories and that milkshakes often contain artificial colorings. The consumer group surveyed restaurants in Virginia, Louisiana, Ohio, Wyoming, New Mexico, Texas, California and New York in addition to Washington, D.C. Jacobson said the center's survey showed that: _Of 14 Burger King outlets surveyed, none had signs and only six had brochures. Customers who requested information were told to write or call corporate headquarters. Spokeswoman Cori Zywotow said Burger King provides all its restaurants with nutritional guides and requires company-owned outlets to distribute them. ``This is the first complaint that we've received,'' she said. ``We certainly will go back and take a look ourselves and, if they are not being given out, remedy the situation.'' _Kentucky Fried Chicken is creating a new brochure and not distributing the old one, which didn't contain ingredient information anyway. Customers ho requested information were told to contact corporate headquarters. Stores were not required to keep brochures on hand and only three of 13 surveyed had any. Detwiler, the company spokesman, said Monday that the new brochure has been sent to outlets, which may or may not distribute them. Asked about ingredient listings and signs, he said, ``I'm not aware that we ever agreed to provide anything other than nutritional information.'' _McDonald's has a policy that all outlets are supposed to have booklets and signs but the policy is being ignored by many of their stores. Only eight of 18 stores surveyed had brochures. Spokeswoman Terri Capatosto said McDonald's never entered into any agreement except a one-year program to distribute nutrition information in New York. But she said that ``we provide complete ingredient information at our restaurants. We send it to our restaurants regularly and it is available at all times from the nutrition information center'' at corporate headquarters. _Wendy's tells customers who want information to write to corporate headquarters. One California Wendy's had a sign noting the availability of product information but had no brochures on hand. None of 14 stores surveyed had any. ``They might have run out of them,'' said Wendy's spokesman Denny Lynch. ``That's easily fixed. We'll just remind our restaurant operators that the ingredient and nutrition brochures are available and ask them to have a supply on hand.''

DOC.HEAD: Armco CEO Boni Stepping Down
DOC.TEXT: Robert E. Boni is stepping down as chief executive officer of Armco Inc. effective at the April 27 shareholders' meeting but will remain as chairman, the company announced Monday. Robert L. Purdum, 54, Armco's president and chief operating officer, will become chief executive officer at the annual meeting. A statement issued by company headquarters in Parsippany, N.J., said Boni, 62, will devote his time to board matters and to strategy and technology planning, working with Purdum. ``This change in organization is part of a succession plan we have had in place for some years,'' Boni said. He said he and Purdum ``have worked together over the past five difficult years, first to survive, then to build the company into a strong, competitive force in the industry. I have found his operating knowledge and experience to be unparalleled and his business instincts acute.'' Purdum is a Purdue University graduate with a degree in civil engineering. He joined Armco's former Metal Products Division in 1962 after serving in the Navy. After several promotions, he was transferred to steel division headquarters in Middletown as general manager-administration in 1976. In February 1978, he became president of the Midwestern Steel Division and two years later was named area vice president with responsibility for four divisions. In 1982, he became CEO of the Steel Group and, on Feb. 1, 1985, was named chief operating officer of Armco Inc. He was elected president of the company Oct. 1, 1986, and is a member of the board. Armco, with Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corp., owns Armco Steel Co., a joint venture which operates steel mills in Middletown and in Ashland, Ky.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chief Attacks Simmons' Qualifications
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp.'s chief executive attacked the motives and management skills of Harold C. Simmons, the Texas financier who leads a group that is seeking control of the aerospace company's board. Daniel M. Tellep, in interviews Sunday, defended his record in the year since he became chairman and chief executive. He cited recent cost-cutting and restructuring at Lockheed, and said Simmons has never taken him up on repeated invitations to discuss the company's future. ``We're completely open to future options,'' Tellep told the Wall Street Journal. ``But he has never put forward his ideas.'' Simmons has gained control of 18.9 percent of Lockheed's stock, and is attempting to overturn ``poison pill'' provisions adopted by the Calabasas-based company that make it prohibitively expensive for an outsider to acquire more than 20 percent of the shares. He has proposed his own directors for the company, which elects a board March 29 at its annual shareholders meeting. Simmons' nominees include Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the former chief of naval operations, and former Sen. John G. Tower, who headed the Senate Armed Services Committee _ names intended to defuse critics who say he has no experience in running a defense contractor. Tellep told the Los Angeles Times that Simmons' only ``concrete plan'' for the company so far ``is a plan for taking over.'' ``Shareholders will have to ask themselves: `What about this uncertainty?''' he said. He was unavailable for interviews Monday, Lockheed spokesman Robert Slayman said. Simmons did not return phone calls. Simmons' slate of 15 candidates for the Lockheed board also includes himself and J. Landis Martin, the president and chief executive of Simmons-controlled N.L. Industries, a Houston-based chemical company that has accumulated the 18.9 percent of Lockheed's shares. Tellep cautioned against any breakup of Lockheed's major operating units. ``If someone started breaking it up ... the parts couldn't help each other,'' he said. ``Any split-up diminishes the value of the whole.'' ``Our board stacks up well compared to Simmons','' he added. Separately Sunday, Lockheed's machinists ended six months of negotiations by voting to accept a 3{-year contract. The contract covers about 128,000 members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers at company plants in Palmdale, Burbank, Sunnyvale, and Marietta, Ga. It provides 4 percent wage scale increases or bonuses retroactive to October and an immediate $2,500 signing bonus for all workers under the contract and currently on payroll. Wages will rise 7 percent over the final two years of the contract, which runs until March 1993. Under the pact, the firm can match employee contributions to a company-sponsored savings plan by using Lockheed stocks. The new Employee Stock Ownership Plan is slated to begin in July. Lockheed management successfully obtained a 6 percent employee contribution for dependent medical care. It also won a two-tier wage scale that would create a lower salary range for newly hired workers in certain jobs. In addition, the contract calls for roughly 20 percent of covered workers to receive quarterly bonuses, rather than an increase in wage scales, during the first year of the pact. That percentage will rise to about 47 percent of all workers by the contract's third year.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Unveils New Computer Line, More Aggressive Strategy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of Cor Vraven is cq in 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. on Monday unveiled a new computer line that the technology company hopes will propel it into the industry's major leagues. But some industry analysts said Motorola could end up alienating companies that buy its computers for resale under their own brand names. Others questioned whether Motorola stands a chance in the highly competitive computer field. ``Motorola is doing so many great things in other parts of the company, you hate to be negative about their computer effort, but I don't think it has too much prospect for success,'' said Richard L. Whittington of Kidder, Peabody & Co. The new computers are designed to operate in a network with machines made by other companies, such as IBM and Apple. They are based on the Unix operating system, which is becoming the industry standard. Motorola said the computers undercut the price of a similar line of IBM machines by 35 percent and more, while offering comparable or better performance. The IBM computers, which were introduced with great fanfare last month, were praised by experts for their low price relative to peformance. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., has made computers for years, but they primarily have been sold to the federal government or to other computer companies that resell them under their own names. The new computers are ``file servers,'' an increasingly popular form of desktop or side-of-desk machine that serves as the central data repository for a network of desktop terminals. Analysts generally are impressed by the new Motorola computers, which they said are competitive with the best in the field. John Rymer, managing editor of the trade publication Unix in the Office, said he believes Motorola's strategy is similar to that of Intel Corp., a computer-chip maker that also makes complete computers it sells to third parties for reselling. He said these chip makers hope to leverage their microprocessor expertise to become major computer manufacturers. Some of the companies that buy Intel chips to make computers have criticized Intel for its strategy, saying it is not fair for their supplier of the most crucial part of a computer to also compete in the end product. However, one major user of Motorola chips welcomes the company's new strategy. Data General Corp. uses Motorola's 88000 chip, the same one used in the new Motorola machines, in its computer workstations. Stan Dolberg, marketing manager for the workstations, said the market for computers based on this chip is relatively small and additional players are needed to help establish it. N.V. Philips, the Dutch electronics company, uses a relabeled Motorola computer as the heart of its computer line outside the United States. Philips spokesman Cor Vraven said he had no comment on Motorola's strategy because it was his understanding Motorola had no immediate plan to sell the computers overseas. However, Motorola spokeswoman Karen Simeone said the company planned to distribute the computers abroad starting in May. Analysts say Motorola needs to improve its marketing and distribution to become a major seller of computers in its own right. To this end, the company has launched a $30 million advertising campaign. Motorola's machines, called the MultiPersonal Computer line, range in price from about $24,000 to $60,000. Each system comes with three desktop screens and a processing unit. Each also is equipped with a local-area network, which is a cable and related software than allows various computers and printers from other companies to be linked. The new machines, which will be available in May, are aimed at the commercial computer market instead of the engineering and scientific customers that often are the target for file servers and for workstations, which are similar to file servers.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Sharply As Central Banks Intervene
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Other late ...,' to RESTORE mark rate.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against most major foreign currencies Monday as central banks joined in an effort to hold down the currency's value. Gold prices climbed. In New York, gold rose $1.10 a troy ounce to $404.10 on the Commodity Exchange, and Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $404.30 a troy ounce, up $1.05 from Friday. The Federal Reserve sold dollars twice in an effort to lower its value, dealers said. The intervention followed dollar-selling by central banks in Europe and Japan, which also depressed the dollar. Thomas J. Palladino, a currency trader with Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said the concerted intervention overseas before the U.S. market opened ``made the market leary to take the dollar higher.'' After the Federal Reserve sold dollars, ``the market did not fight them,'' he said. ``It seemed like they intervened pretty aggressively or the market took them pretty seriously,'' he said. The Fed does not comment on its market interventions. Similar intervention Friday by central banks in Europe and Japan helped moderate a rise in the dollar's value that day. Traders said there was no economic news that affected trading Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 149.95 yen, up 0.20 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, it traded at 149.75 yen, down from 150.28 yen Friday. In New York, the dollar closed at 149.03 yen, down from Friday's 150.15 yen. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6390, down from $1.6515 late Friday. Later, in New York, the pound closed at $1.6445, cheaper than than $1.6485 Friday. The pound, under pressure from disappointing British trade figures and the government's declining position in opinion polls, has retreated steadily from its recent peak of $1.7145 on Feb. 22. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6970 West German marks, down from 1.7150; 1.4970 Swiss francs, down from 1.5085; 5.7330 French francs, down from 5.7910; 1,252 Italian lire, down from 1,264.50; and 1.1891 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19225. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.4985 Swiss francs, down from 1.5130; 5.5715 French francs, down from 5.8065; 1.9155 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9365; 1,255.00 Italian lire, down from 1,268.00; and 1.1904 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1939 Gold traded in London at $403.75 per troy ounce late Monday, down from $403.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the late bid was $403.25 an ounce, down from $402.50 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $403.44 per troy ounce, up 70 cents from Saturday's close. Silver fell 1 cent to $5.116 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. In London earlier, silver was quoted at bid of $5.13 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $5.12.

DOC.HEAD: McCaw Completes $3 Billion of Controlling Interest in LIN
DOC.TEXT: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said Monday it had completed its $3.38 billion acquisition of a controlling interest in LIN Broadcasting Corp., extending its influence in the booming cellular telephone industry. McCaw said the completion of its tender offer for 21.9 million shares of LIN Broadcasting Corporation at $154.11 per share gives it a 51.9 percent interest in LIN. McCaw previously owned about 5 million shares of LIN. In New York, LIN announced it had replaced its chairman and chief executive officer and elected a new board of directors dominated by McCaw, which is headquartered in Kirkland, Wash., a Seattle suburb. ``Our major regional cellular systems in conjunction with LIN's major markets provide the building blocks for creating the independent, seamless national cellular telephone network we have long envisioned,'' Craig O. McCaw, chairman and chief executive officer of McCaw, said in a statement. About 46.3 million LIN shares were tendered. Based on the preliminary count, the proration factor would be approximately 47.3 percent. The proration determines what percentage of shares offered by each stockholder will be accepted for payment at the price McCaw offered. Additional shares will be returned to the owner. McCaw said the final proration on the shares will be announced by March 13, at which time the funds McCaw paid Monday to the depositary, Chemical Bank, will be distributed. The new nine-member LIN board, elected early Monday, includes three independent directors named by the outgoing LIN board and six directors associated with McCaw. The new board set March 20 as the record date for the distribution to LIN shareholders, other than McCaw and its affiliates, of $425 million of McCaw Cellular Class A common stock as a dividend. LIN expects to distribute the stock to stockholders of record, other than McCaw and its affiliates, on or about April 2. The board also elected Craig O. McCaw as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of LIN and Paul H. Stolz as president and chief operating officer. They replaced Donald A. Pels, who was formerly chairman, president and chief executive officer at LIN. McCaw is the largest U.S. cellular telephone company. The LIN acquisition gives it access to cellular franchises held by LIN in the metropolitan areas of New York City, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston. LIN also owns and operates seven network-affiliated television stations and publishes magazines placed in hotel rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Considering Sale of AMBAC Bond Insurance Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp said Monday it was considering the sale of AMBAC Indemnity Corp., one month after federal regulators ordered the bank to put up more reserves to cover liabilities of its bond insurance subsidiary. Citicorp said in a statement the decision was part of a review of businesses aimed at strengthening its capital base. AMBAC Indemnity is wholly owned by Citibank NA, Citicorp's banking arm. Last month, the federal Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates commercial banks, and Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said Citibank would have to consolidate AMBAC Indemnity's earnings on its balance sheet. That would require Citibank to increase AMBAC's capital reserves, which could cause a drain on the bank's earnings. AMBAC Indemnity, which is registered in Wisconsin and headquartered in New York, insures issues of municipal bonds and other tax-exempt securities. It stands for American Municipal Bond Assurance Corp. Citicorp said AMBAC Indemnity had about 33 percent market share at the end of last year and capital of about $700 million. AMBAC Indemnity would not be sold, Citicorp said, ``unless an attractive proposal is made by a high-quality, well-capitalized institution with a long-term perspective on its investment in AMBAC.''

DOC.HEAD: Merc Chairman Melamed to Resign at Year's End
DOC.TEXT: Leo Melamed, a tireless innovator and cheerleader for the futures industry, announced Monday that he would resign from the leadership of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at year's end ``to recapture my life.'' Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee, explained the surprise announcement by saying that after 23 years of policy making and trend setting, he was ready for a quieter life. ``I really want to recapture my life,'' he said at a news conference. ``I want to smell the flowers along the way while I can still smell something.'' Melamed, 57, said he was not retiring for health reasons or for reasons associated with the ongoing federal investigation of fraud at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest futures markets. He said he planned to continue trading futures through his trading company, Dellsher Investment Company Inc., to write and to spend more time with his family. Melamed also said he expects the Merc to launch its Globex electronic trading system, one of his pet projects, by June 30. Implementation has been delayed in part due to trouble in getting approval from the Japanese government for Japanese companies to trade on the system. The charismatic and outspoken Melamed is widely recognized as the father of financial futures, which are risk-management tools for the financial industry. Before Melamed, the futures exchanges were best known for trading agricultural commodities. The development of financial futures, beginning with the Merc's introduction of foreign currency futures in 1972, fueled explosive growth in the industry and brought futures exchanges respectability in the financial world. Melamed was chairman of the Merc from 1969 until 1971, when he stepped aside to become chairman of a newly created affiliate, the International Monetary Market. In 1976, IMM merged with the Merc and Melamed became chairman of the combined institutions. A Polish immigrant, Melamed began working as a runner at the Merc in the early 1950s while working his way through law school. He became an exchange member in 1954 and a member of the exchange's board of governors in 1967. In 1977, the Merc board created the office of special counsel to the board and named Melamed to the position and to the position of chairman of the executive committee. The Merc board has yet to name a successor to Melamed.

DOC.HEAD: Fred Alger Management Settles with SEC
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street money manager Fred Alger has settled an administrative action with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the SEC said. Without admitting or denying the allegations, Fred Alger Management Inc. settled an SEC proceeding charging that FAM filed an allegedly misleading registration statement for The Alger Fund. The SEC claimed the registration statement did not completely disclose the performance of FAM-managed accounts from 1965 through 1986. Specificially, the SEC said that in advertising a 21.2 percent annual compound growth rate over 21 years, FAM did not disclose that one of the accounts with a high rate of return did not have to accept FAM's advice, and in one case rejected it. The settlement announced Monday called for FAM to comply with all SEC regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Accounts Freeze in Rorer Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge in New York has extended a court order freezing the brokerage accounts of two foreign companies accused of insider trading in the stock of Rorer Group Inc., federal officials said Monday. U.S. District Judge Shirley Wohl Kramm ruled last Thursday that she had the jurisdiction to freeze the assets of Unifund SAL, a Lebanese corporation, and Tamanaco Saudi & Gulf Investment Group, a Panamanian concern, officials with the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday. She continued a Jan. 17 court order freezing Unifund's brokerage account, valued at $3.7 million, and Tamanaco's brokerage account, worth $680,000, which allegedly contain the proceeds from their Rorer trading. They are among four foreign companies accused of trading on confidential corporate information that Rorer, a Fort Washington, Pa. pharmaceutical company, was in merger talks with a French company, Rhone-Poulenc SA. The two companies agreed in January to merge their pharmaceutical operations, with Rhone-Poulenc acquiring 68 percent of Rorer's stock in a deal valued at about $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA, No Longer for Sale, Gets Big Distribution Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Warner saying it still has a deal, report of talks on possible MGM purchase by Pathe or its owner; picks up 5th graf pvs, `MGM-UA has ...'
DOC.TEXT: MGM-UA Communications Co., pulled off the auction block in January, has reached a five-year deal to distribute much sought-after films from Pathe Communications Co., the companies said Monday. The deal had been widely expected to go to Warner Bros., but MGM and Pathe officials said a final contract was never signed. Nevertheless, Warner spokesman Rob Friedman insisted his studio already had reached an agreement with Pathe, even though he would not describe it. ``Warner has a deal as far as we're concerned,'' Friedman said. ``We've been working on their movies for a couple of months.'' The releases from the Pathe subsidiary, Alan Ladd Jr.'s Pathe Entertainment, include ``Russia House'' with Sean Connery and Michelle Pfeiffer at Christmas and ``Quigley Down Under'' with Tom Selleck and Laura San Giacomo this fall. MGM-UA said it will boost the number of major films it releases in theaters to at least 15 this year. That is good news for the studio, which virtually shut down movie production of its own for most of two years while controlling shareholder Kirk Kerkorian looked for a buyer. The Hollywood Reporter, an entertainment trade paper, quoted unidentified ``insiders'' as saying that continuing negotiations could lead to Pathe Communications or its head, Giancarlo Parretti, buying MGM-UA. Under one scenario, Warner might pick up distribution rights to the 1,000-picture UA library, MGM-UA's biggest asset, the paper said. Friedman and Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons declined to comment on the report. Parretti, an Italian financier and restaurant owner, was among those who considered buying MGM-UA when it was up for sale, but Parsons said he had no knowledge of any recent talks. MGM-UA has started up its own production again, but for now must depend largely on distributing movies from independent production companies like Pathe. ``It gives them some great product, and they need it right now,'' said Alex Ben Block, editor of the industry newsletter Show Biz News. Pathe will finance the costs of the films and oversee marketing and distribution. MGM gets exclusive distribution rights to home video releases as well as domestic theatrical releases. Other details weren't released. ``This arrangement reaffirms MGM-UA's ability and commitment to supply major motion pictures to all media,'' Jeffrey C. Barbakow, the company's chairman, said in a statement. Australia's Qintex group outbid Rupert Murdoch's Fox studio for MGM-UA last year, but the deal collapsed when Qintex failed to line up financing. Cable TV baron Ted Turner then discussed a buyout _ he already owns most rights to the old MGM film library _ but those merger talks died in January and Kerkorian said he would go back to the business of making movies. Many observers believe Kerkorian's goal remains to sell MGM-UA. Jeffrey Logsdon, a securities analyst with the Crowell Weedon brokerage in Los Angeles, said the company may have aggressively outbid Warner for the Pathe deal to help ``create the illusion they are a full-fledged company, with product in the pipeline.'' ``That's got to always be in the back of one's mind, anyway,'' he said. In addition to ``Russia House'' and ``Quigley Down Under,'' MGM-UA will distribute such Pathe films as ``Fires Within,'' starring Jimmy Smits; ``Not Without My Daughter,'' starring Sally Field and ``Life Stinks,'' written and directed by and starring Mel Brooks. The theatrical release of 15 films this year brings MGM-UA to what once was a standard level for a major studio, although such studios as Disney, Fox and Warner are now trying for about double that number each year as worldwide demand soars for Hollywood entertainment. To help keep the company's distribution network intact, the president of MGM-UA's film group, Richard Berger, spent $9 million this year for rights to ``Desperate Hours,'' a Mickey Rourke film directed by Michael Cimino and produced by Dino De Laurentiis to be released this summer. MGM-UA also has its old faithfuls fired up, with a Thanskgiving release set for ``Rocky V'' with Sylvester Stallone and the next James Bond movie under way and planned for release in summer 1991. The company also has a number of projects under way starring John Candy, Sally Field and Steve Martin.

DOC.HEAD: GM Passes Greenmail Policy
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of General Motors Corp. approved an anti-greenmail policy, prompting a stockholder to withdraw her proposal against such payoffs. The policy approved Monday prohibits the purchase of shares at an above-market price from anyone owning more than 3 percent of the voting power of the corporation's stock. The policy applies only if the stockholder has held his or her shares for less than two years. Shareholder Evelyn Y. Davis of Washington, D.C., proposed a ban on greenmail three years ago after GM paid H. Ross Perot and some associates $750 million for their Class E stock in exchange for his leaving the company. Perot founded Electronic Data Systems and had sold it to GM a few years before. Most shareholder proposals attract only a tiny fraction of votes, but hers garnered 20 percent the first year and nearly 28 percent last year. ``There was a growing stockholder interest in having a formal statement or formal policy in opposition to greenmail,'' GM spokesman William B. Winters said. In a statement, GM said it has consistently opposed the payment of greenmail. ``This adoption of an explicit policy reinforces its belief that the corporation's funds must be employed for the benefit of all stockholders,'' the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Channel One Goes On Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comment from education and children's TV groups, CORRECT that Bush met with Japan's prime minister sted foreign minister; picks up 9th graf pvs, `The program ...' A version also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Students across the country got the news along with a sales pitch for candy, shaving razors and cheese snacks Monday as the advertiser-supported classroom program Channel One went on the air. ``I think it is a good idea,'' said Powell High School student Jim Addington, 17, one of the first to see the Channel One news program, beamed to 400 schools nationwide. ``I don't see why there is so much controversy over the commercials,'' he added, noting he'd seen Channel One's ads for M&Ms, Gillette shavers and Chee-tos before on his television at home. ``I thought the programming was good. I think it will work.'' Christopher Whittle, chairman of the Knoxville-based Whittle Communications that produced the show, agrees. Despite criticism from national education groups and bans by public educators in New York and California, Whittle told a news conference at the high school that 2,900 schools in 34 states have signed up for Channel One. And he predicted a total of 8,000 would be committed by December. ``I predict that within 5 years a system like this will be in 95 percent of all middle and high schools in the United States. In a sense, it will be a new institution in America's schools,'' he said. But Timothy Dyer, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, worried that Channel One, which already has been tested in a number of schools, marked the beginning of ``the commercialization of the classroom.'' Added Peggy Charren, founder of Action for Children's Television in Cambridge, Mass.: ``It's obvious that schools signing on to Whittle's operation are doing it for the free TV sets. I think it is outrageous to barter pieces of the school day in return for a mess of equipment ... and to use that equipment to keep reminding children of how much they need particular products.'' Monday's broadcast by Channel One's five-member team of under-30 anchors and reporters gave a capsule of breaking news _ voting in three Soviet republics, the escape of a 17-year-old Cuban to the United States on a sailboard, the return of the space shuttle Atlantis and President Bush's talks with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The program, produced in New York and sent by satellite to the participating schools, had longer stories on a Japanese high school in Tennessee and an Army recruiting office in Kentucky. Maps preceded several of the stories to show where the action was taking place. Students interviewed approved. ``It gives you a perspective of where it is actually happening,'' said Stacey Surber, 16. ``It gives you a better understanding.'' The program also contained the first of five daily reports on the rise and fall of the Berlin Wall. ``I like the way it combined history with news. It showed what was happening in the `40s,'' said Gabe Thrasher, 16. The 12-minute program was interspersed with two minutes of 30-second commercials. The fourth ad was an anti-drug public service announcement. Al Poe, spokesman for M&M-Mars Inc., said that while the Hackettstown, N.J., candy company believes that subscribing to Channel One is a ``local community matter,'' it deserves corporate support. ``Everyone wins with the Whittle concept _ students, school systems, communities and the sponsors,'' Poe said. ``Our experience has been that situations like this tend to be productive for a long time.'' Whittle said 29 advertisers, whom he wouldn't name, have contracted to run commercials on Channel One at $150,000 per 30-second spot. Ads for tobacco, alcohol, political and religious groups and contraceptives are rejected. ``We have 65 percent of our commercial time sold for the first three years,'' Whittle said. ``It is, from a business standpoint, the most successful television launch ever. ``There is widespread support for this in the corporate community for two reasons _ they think it is good business, but they think it is good education, too. And they see this as a way that they can help schools.'' Whittle said commercials are necessary in order to pay for the $150 million in video equipment loaned to the schools that show the program and the $90 million in annual operational expenses to produce it. Earl Hoffmeister, superintendent of the 50,000-student Knox County school system, said the televisions, video recorders and satellite dishes provided by Whittle for Channel One separate it from other programming geared to teen-agers, such as Turner Broadcasting System Inc.'s ``CNN Newsroom'' that has been carried since August on Cable News Network. ``We think it is a tool that will help many many school systems, as our own school system, in being able to do some things that we either do not have the money for or a teacher is not available,'' Hoffmeister said, adding that the school system planned to use the equipment for other programming. What effect Channel One's commercials will have remains to be seen. Both teachers and students said Monday they tended to ignore them. ``It's almost like when you watch TV (at home),'' Miss Surber said. ``When the commercials come on ... you don't even want to watch, really.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Drivers' Union Seeks To Have Talks Reopened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with judge ordering strikers in Southwest not to interfere with replacements; picks up 4th graf, `Union officials ...'. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The union representing striking Greyhound bus drivers on Monday aske the company to return to the bargaining table to end the 4-day-old walkout against the United States' only nationwide bus system. Meanwhile, a spokesman for Greyhound Lines Inc. acknowledged the company was losing some of the drivers it had hired to replace strikers. The strike has been marred by violence and vandalism since 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked out early Friday. Shots have been fired at buses, and a striking driver was killed Saturday in Redding, Calif., when he was crushed by a bus backing up to get around a picket line. In Los Angeles on Monday, a Superior Court judge ordered striking Greyhound drivers in the southwestern United States not to interfere with the work of newly hired replacement drivers. The temporary restraining order by Judge David Yaffe applies to strikers from Los Angeles to El Paso and also bars picketers from intimidating replacement drivers with ``fear of bodily harm or death.'' Union officials on Monday sent a message to Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey requesting a meeting with him as soon as possible. The message asked Currey to contact Ed Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, or Jim La Sala, international president of the Amalgamated Transit Union. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said the company tried but failed to contact La Sala after receiving the request Monday, and is again awaiting word from the union. There have been no formal negotiations since talks broke off early Friday. Strait met briefly Friday night with P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president and chief negotiator. At that point, Lannie said the union had no new proposals. Union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson would not say Monday if the drivers had a revised offer to make to the company. The two sides entered negotiations last week far apart. The company said it couldn't afford more than the $63 million contract it was offering. The union claimed its offer was lower than management's, but the company valued that offer at more than $200 million. The company has been operating with 700 replacement drivers plus any union members who cross picket lines. Currey said 350 union drivers are at work and the company is providing about 29 percent of its normal service. The union says only 95 members have crossed picket lines. Sources close to the union claimed Monday that some replacement drivers have walked off the job, including 32 in the company's central region, which stretches along the northern third of the country from just west of Pittsburgh to west of Denver. An internal message sent to some Greyhound officials says the company is having to lower its level of service in the region partly due to the loss of newly hired drivers. Gravley said the change was forced because not as many replacements were hired for that area as had been expected, and did not reflect defections. ``There have been a few of them that have left,'' he said, ``and we are not surprised by that. They knew what they were getting into. These people were recruited and they were told honestly and forthrightly ... the nature of the work. ``We told them that there could be times when they might be intimidated.'' There have been several incidents of strikers pounding the sides of buses as they crossed picket lines. In Chicago on Friday, shots were fired at a departing bus. On Sunday, charter bus drivers in Spokane, Wash., found bus electrical systems vandalized, and a passenger in Philadelphia was charged with spraying a striker with Mace. The AFL-CIO on Monday asked its other member unions to help striking driver where possible. ``Because Greyhound bus riders are primarily students, older and lower-income Americans, you should continue to work with our allies in community and minority organizations to carry our message that scab operations will only prolong the dispute,'' AFL-CIO officials said in a letter to local officials.

DOC.HEAD: GM Consolidates Engine Operations
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said it would consolidate its two engine development operations into one organization. The move, which combines engine research and development operations at GM's Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac and Chevrolet-Pontiac-GM of Canada groups, is designed to help streamline the nation's largest automaker. ``This action, which will improve our ability to bring great products more quickly to the marketplace, will greatly benefit our car and truck division customers,'' GM President Robert Stempel said Monday. In 1984, GM underwent a reorganization that combined five engine operations into two. Beginning in 1987, GM embarked on its ``Action Plan'' _ a cost-cutting effort aimed at cutting up to $13 billion in costs by the end of this year. The effective dates of the latest engine consolidation will be determined later. Spokesman Charles Licari said the recommendations were not made with the goal of idling facilities or laying off workers. ``On the other hand we know there are efficiencies to be gained by integrating the CPC and BOC power train operations,'' Licari said. ``Our goals will be to grow the business, bring in contract work and design and manufacture vehicles that help sell vehicles,'' he said. General manager for the new division will be Richard M. Donnelly, product manager of the BOC Powertrain Division.

DOC.HEAD: NBA Sues GTE-Sylvania Over Sweepstakes Tie-in To NBA Championship
DOC.TEXT: The National Basketball Association is crying foul at GTE Corp., accusing the company of trademark infringement by launching a sweepstakes contest with a tie-in to the NBA championship series. In a lawsuit filed last week in U.S. District Court, the NBA is asking for an injunction halting GTE-Sylvania's ``Step Up To The Line'' Sweepstakes as well as unspecified monetary damages for alleged trademark infringement and unfair trade practices. If the court orders the contest cancelled, the suit asks that GTE be required to notify all entrants by mail and to run corrective advertising. The NBA said the contest is substantially similar to a sweepstakes being conducted by Frito-Lay Inc., which paid a ``substantial sum'' for the privilege to link its contest to the NBA Finals. ``The GTE Sweepstakes is ... simply an attempt to take plaintiffs' valuable property rights by improperly associating themselves with the good will and reputation of the NBA,'' the suit said. A spokesman for Stamford-based GTE, said Monday the company could not comment on the suit until its attorneys had a chance to study it. Full-page advertisements for the GTE sweepstakes appeared in inserts in newspapers and magazines nationwide on Feb. 18. According to the suit, the ads were constructed and designed ``to imply and suggest the sponsorship, endorsement or approval of the NBA.'' Ryan Partnership, a Stamford marketing firm, sought permission in November to use the NBA trademarks for a GTE sweepstakes but was denied, the suit said. A woman who answered the telephone at Ryan said there was no one available to comment. The NBA said it sent a letter to GTE and Ryan on Feb. 26 demanding they call a halt to the contest, but that the defendants refused. The GTE-Sylvania sweepstakes ad invites entrants, in the body of the promotion, to ``win a trip to the championship finals and a share of $25,000 in prizes.'' In smaller print, readers are advised that four grand prize winners will receive an expense-paid trip for a family of four to the first two games of the NBA championship finals, and that prize-winners will participate in a free-throw shoot-out with $25,000 in prizes. In addition, the official entry form states, ``Yes, I would like to win a trip to the NBA Championship Finals and a share of $25,000 in prizes.'' The NBA said GTE has not been authorized to conduct any free-throw contest in connection with the championship series, but that the ad falsely suggests otherwise. Entrants in the Frito-Lay contest, on the other hand, are vying for the opportunity to win a trip to the NBA playoffs and the chance to compete in a free-throw shooting contest during half-time of a conference playoff game or during Game 4 of the finals, the NBA said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sharply Lower, Stocks Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Udpates with morning Nikkei, dollar, bond prices
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was sharply lower against the Japanese yen Tuesday and the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded moderately. Trading remained light during the morning as many investors stayed on the sidelines anticipating the Bank of Japan would increase interest rates, possibly during the afternoon. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average recouped 120.52 points, or 0.36 percent, ending the morning session at 33,965.72. On Monday, the index lost 212.36 points. The dollar ended the morning session at 148.77 yen, down 1.18 yen from Monday's close. It had opened at 148.97 yen and weakened during the morning as the Bank of Japan sold dollars actively to support its currency. The yen's rebound sparked a rally in the Japanese government bond market that pushed down interest rates. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 10-year bond fell to 7.075 percent from 7.12 percent late Monday. The dollar continued to weaken in Tokyo after falling against almost all major currencies in overseas markets earlier following internationally coordinated intervention, traders said. Central banks from Japan, Britain, France and West Germany bought their own currencies and sold the dollar in an attempt to weaken the U.S. currency, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Finance Minsiter Ryutaro Hashimoto told reporters Tuesday that the framework of international cooperation remains strong and coordinated action will continue to be taken to ensure stability in foreign exchange markets. He said U.S. concern over the dollar-yen rate was made clear at last weekend's summit meeting between U.S. President Bush and Japanese Prime Minster Toshiki Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif. In rising above 150 yen in recent days, the dollar hit its highest level since last June. The Bank of Japan was seen selling some $1 billion Tuesday morning to bolster the yen, traders said. The central bank does not comment on its market intervention activities. ``Many market players are now trying to reduce their dollar-holding positions now, in case the Bank of Japan raises its discount rate today,'' Kanai said. ``That's mainly because they speculate there might be a raise before central bank Governor Mr. (Yasushi) Mieno leaves for Europe tomorrow, and they think there will be no hike while he's gone until (March) 15,'' he added. Japanese markets have been expecting a discount rate hike to stem inflationary pressures ever since the nation held major parliamentary elections last month. After three hikes last year, the nation's key lending rate stands at 4.25 percent, still the lowest among the group of seven industrial nations. Partly as a result of the Bank of Japan's inaction, growing uncertainties in the market began discouraging stock investment and yen-buying, causing a rapid decline in share prices and leading to a 1,569.10-point plunge Feb. 26, the second-worst fall ever. On the stock exchange, dealers attributed the morning rally to the yen's strength as well as the rise in the government bond prices.
